HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Midtown Tops National Cost Survey; 
$7,000 a Year For Parking

 BODY:
It should not come as much of a surprise to anyone who drives to work in Manhattan, but a recent national survey found that Midtown and downtown are the most expensive places to park a car in the country.
 The survey, by Colliers International, a real estate services company, found that reserved parking in underground or covered structures averaged $590 a month in Midtown and $510 a month downtown. 
Unreserved parking in underground or covered structures was somewhat cheaper, averaging $520 a month in Midtown and $400 a month downtown. 
 The average monthly rate nationally is $157, with the average pulled down by places like Fresno, Calif., and Phoenix, where a month's worth of parking can be had for $35. Boston, San Francisco and Chicago follow New York in expense, with reserved monthly rates of $450, $400 and $375 respectively.
The cost to park a car in a central business district had been increasing faster than the rate of inflation, according to the survey, with the national average parking cost rising 14 percent over last year and by 33 percent over the level in 1996.
"The cost of parking is rising above the rate of inflation because of constrained supply in most major markets," said Ross Moore, Colliers's director of research. "Some cities have waiting lists of three to 15 months for parking spaces."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
A Serious Student Of Cartoons

BYLINE:  By JOHN SWANSBURG 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
A TOUR of J. J. Sedelmaier's animation studio is an introduction to his passions. He keeps his collection of comic books close at hand in his office, near a fleet of toy trains and a library of books on everything from Leonardo da Vinci to Bruce Lee. Antique telephones, including an early touch-tone model that predates the advent of the pound and star keys, have a wall of their own.
 There is no mistaking Mr. Sedelmaier's most fervent passion, however. Artifacts from the history of animation line the studio's hallways. He's even made room for a preview moviola, a piece of equipment that purportedly belonged to Preston Blair, the animator of Disney's "Fantasia." 
 "The possibilities with animation are truly endless," Mr. Sedelmaier said. "You create a world." 
If you own a television, you've probably seen a J. J. Sedelmaier Production. Over the last 10 years, the studio has produced animated commercials for Old Navy, Hewlett-Packard and Volkswagen, among others. 
Its collaboration with the writer Robert Smigel brought viewers of "Saturday Night Live" popular shorts like the X-Presidents, in which the nation's retired commanders in chief take on the forces of evil. In 1992, MTV asked Mr. Sedelmaier to animate a series about two teenagers who eventually became so ubiquitous that it was difficult to avoid them even if you didn't own a television: their names were Beavis and Butt-Head.
"He has a sense of what is entertaining, what is captivating, what will transfix an audience," said Mike Rogers, president and creative director of the Wolf Group New York, an advertising agency. This sense has allowed Mr. Sedelmaier to succeed as a producer of both commercials and long-form animation, Mr. Rogers said: "There are very few people who can do that."
Mr. Sedelmaier, 45, opened the studio after nearly a decade of work in animation. Though he was tentative at first about going on his own, his partner, who runs the business side of the studio, assured him that he had the experience and vision to open up his own shop. That vote of confidence was difficult to ignore: his business partner is Patrice Sedelmaier, his wife. 
Initially, the studio focused on producing commercials. A knack for advertising runs in Mr. Sedelmaier's family: his father, Joe Sedelmaier, directed television commercials and created one of the most famous ads in television history -- the Wendy's "Where's the Beef?" spot. 
A 30-second animated commercial can take from a week to five months to produce, depending on its artistic demands. Such a commercial could cost several hundred thousand dollars, or significantly less, again depending on the nuances of the project. Mrs. Sedelmaier said the studio produces 18 to 20 commercials a year. 
Though Sedelmaier Productions is now in its second decade, the studio has not developed a house style. On the contrary, Mr. Sedelmaier has tried to avoid being pegged. 
Fred Seibert, former president of MTV Networks Online, said: "Most people are known for particular techniques and styles. It's rare when that's not the case. It's not the case with J. J." 
Certain themes do recur in the studio's oeuvre. Its commercial for Volkswagen, in which it adapted Speed Racer cartoons to sell the company's GTI model, is an example of how Mr. Sedelmaier's knowledge of -- and affection for -- the history of animation has influenced the studio's work. In the GTI spot, the studio recreated an existing style -- in this case Speed Racer's Japanimation, rendered to near perfection, including flaws in the original, like poor dubbing -- to sell a contemporary product.
Success producing commercials allowed Sedelmaier Productions to take risks with long-form projects, like animating the first season of Beavis and Butt-Head. Long-form animation has different demands, but many of the same sensibilities evident in the studio's commercials come through in its long-form work.
In "The Ambiguously Gay Duo," one of the Saturday Fun House TV shorts produced with Mr. Smigel for "Saturday Night Live," the studio faithfully rendered elements from superhero cartoons of the 60's. It then added a dash of homoeroticism, to make the shorts not just a parody of classic superhero cartoons, but of contemporary anxieties about sexual identity as well. The result is a crime-fighting duo, Ace and Gary, who confound their enemies as much with their congratulatory pats on the posterior as with their superpowers.
"I had a very specific parody in mind, and I just knew he would nail every detail of it," Mr. Smigel said. "I didn't just want it to look like a superhero cartoon. I wanted it to look like a superhero cartoon from 1964 or 1966. There were all these specific details and I knew that J. J. would care about them. It was such a pleasure working with someone who was really interested in getting it right."
Getting it right has become a good deal easier in the decade since Sedelmaier Productions opened: advances in computer technology have been a tremendous boon to animators.
"The flexibility it affords you is incomparable," Mr. Sedelmaier said. In 1991, a relatively new invention called the fax machine allowed him to open a studio in White Plains, where rents were not as prohibitive as in New York City. Still, even with the help of the fax, the studio had to messenger its work to the city to be shot onto film and to be developed; the work then had to be sent back to White Plains for editing, only to return to the city again to be put on video. 
Today, because of digital technologies, the studio is almost completely self-sufficient. The equivalent of the camera work is now done on a computer named Daniel (after the studio's old cameraman). The finished product can be put on video in-house -- or even e-mailed to a client as a Quicktime movie. 
Being away from the city has its advantages, Mr. Sedelmaier said. Clients inclined to meddle are less likely to do so if it requires a trip from Madison Avenue to Main Street in White Plains.
The studio's 12 employees are currently at work on a commercial for Quilted Northern bathroom tissue and on a new series for Cartoon Network. Mr. Sedelmaier said the studio's willingness to take risks with projects outside the commercial realm has helped it weather the current economic downturn, which has reduced the demand for advertising. "If we had decided to do commercials exclusively, it would have been lethal," he said. 
But Mr. Sedelmaier's desire to seek out new challenges is an artistic, not an economic, impulse, he insists. 
"I feel a strong responsibility to the craft, to push the potential of animation to the limit because there aren't a lot of people doing that," he said. Before he commits the studio to a new endeavor, he must be convinced that animation is right for the project. "I've turned down plenty of work because it had no business using animation," he said. "It's not right for everything."
As for personal recognition, he doesn't seem to mind that many of his best efforts don't come with credits. 
"I wouldn't want someone to look at a commercial and say, 'Oh, that's a J. J. Sedelmaier spot,' " he said. "I want people to look at it and say, 'That works.' "

Middle, the X-Presidents, a cartoon short that can be seen on "Saturday Night Live," Bottom, a shot from a Volkswagen commercial featuring Speed Racer. HEADLINE: The State's New Pastime: Looking For a Job 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA 

 BODY:
THE state's unemployment rate is one of the lowest in the nation, but State Department of Labor statistics released last month show that workers have been losing their jobs at a brisk clip -- 2.4 percent were out of work in May, compared to 1.9 percent in March. Unemployment claims have also jumped, , rising 8 percent from March to May and almost 63 percent from May of last year.
 Suddenly, people in a state known for its good jobs and high incomes are finding themselves out of work. Since last fall, at least two dozen major Connecticut companies have laid off thousands of employees, according to labor department figures. And it's not just the Internet-related companies taking the hits. The automotive, machinery, plastics, retail, and health-care industries have seen significant cutbacks in personnel as well. Just last week, R. R. Donnelly & Sons, a printing company, announced it would close its plant in Old Saybrook, affecting 500 jobs. The labor department said that as of May, 40,100 people were unemployed, compared to 32,900 in March. 
 And while the lost jobs are bad news for the state's economy because out-of-work people don't tend to buy houses, new cars, eat in restaurants and take trips, they do spend money on something else: job-hunting. In the last few months, clothing stores, office supply businesses and career counseling operations are all reporting a surge in business as more and more people come in looking for the tools they need to get a new job.
"Job hunters have helped business because it's no longer one person applying for 10 jobs, it's 10 people applying for one job," said Paul Grenier, manager of Hutton's, a men's clothing store in North Haven. "That means more and more people are coming in and thinking along the lines of, 'I've got to change my appearance and make myself look different than the others."'
Tara Curran, who was laid off in April from her job as a marketing associate at a Norwalk media company, worked hard to package herself for job interviews with a new business wardrobe.
"The first thing I did was buy a black suit, with a long skirt and short skirt, and a couple of shirts to go with it, so I could mix and match," she said. "I bought tons of new stockings and a pair of black summer shoes. I got my hair cut. I did the works."
She also took train trips and cab rides to job interviews, got resumes copied, and faxed two or three pages of job applications at $1 a page to job prospects. Then it was back to the store for more clothes. She said she spent about $350 on her job search.
"I was called back for a third interview with the same person, so I needed another suit," she said about the Manhattan company that eventually hired her. "I wanted her to see me in something different than what I already wore."
Walter Dolde, associate professor of finance at the University of Connecticut's Stamford branch, said there was a "silver-lining aspect" to an economic downturn.
"From the aggregate, or national, point of view, the effects of layoffs are only bad, but there are shifts among sectors in the economy as various events happen," Mr. Dolde said. "There are some segments that do better in slower economic times, like used-car sales. Quality used cars become tighter because fewer people are willing to take the chance and spring for a new car. Usually, people cut back in eating in restaurants. That's bad for restaurants and waiters, but people still have to eat, so processed-food companies, like Campbell and General Foods, do better."
It's what Bob Shullman, president of the Willard & Shullman Group in Greenwich, a company that conducts customer-satisfaction surveys, calls the "yin and yang of the world. Every time you cut one thing, there's an uptick in something else." 
Carol King, 40, of Norwalk, who was laid off in March as associate editor of Internetnews.com, a Darien-based Web site devoted to news about the Internet, said her biggest expense had been for clothes. Ms. King said the way she had dressed for work was no longer acceptable in this post dot-com economy.
"The last two jobs I had were extremely casual," Ms. King said. "Jeans and sneakers were fine. But at an interview I had for a job in New York City, I learned that the company only had casual Fridays,' so I had to buy new clothes -- a blazer, a dress and some skirts and tops. It adds up."
Brian Stockmoe, 34, of Ridgefield said he spent a lot of money to find a new job, although he would not say how much. Mr. Stockmoe had been riding the high-tech wave in Connecticut since the fall of 1999, then "the bubble burst," he said. Mr. Stockmoe was laid off last October from Priceline.com's Webhouse Club, the "name-your-own-price" for gasoline and groceries dot-com in Greenwich, where he developed software and ran the company's Web site. Within a few weeks of his termination, Mr. Stockmoe found an executive position at another high-tech start-up. But, because a downturn in the economy dried up new capital, the company let Mr. Stockmoe go in March.
"You definitely have to make an investment, overall," said Mr. Stockmoe, who has since taken a job at GE Capital in Stamford. "I had to buy a suit because the last one I had bought was in 1992 and most of my environments have been pretty laid back since then."
He also bought three books to stay current on technology trends. But his spending didn't stop there. He also bought a fax machine for his home so he wouldn't have to keep paying $1 a page to fax his resume from local office-supply stores. "And that doesn't count travel expenses to New York City, and parking," he said. "I had to pay $45 just to park for two to three hours for a job interview on the Upper East Side."
Michael Moeser, 37, of Greenwich, who was laid off in April after little more than a year as an associate director at the Gartner Group, a technology research and analysis company in Stamford, has been busy photocopying and faxing his resume at Kinko's in Greenwich. "That's something you take for granted in an office environment," Mr. Moeser said. "Now it's something like $3 to $5 each time I send a resume."
Dave Florio, branch manager of Kinko's on High Ridge Road in Stamford, said the recent layoffs had created an interesting phenomenon at his store.
"More people come in here on a Sunday afternoon after they read the newspaper to fax off a couple of resumes," he said. "I'm seeing more people branching out on their own. I hear things like, 'I'm tired of working for The Man.' My personal business card and letterhead businesses are up considerably from last year. People are going into consulting, or their own start-ups."
In recent months, Ayers Group/Career Partners International, a career-management firm that has a regional office in Norwalk, said it had been busy. Companies hire Ayers to coach laid-off employees in finding new jobs by beefing up their resumes, or teaching them how to ace an interview. 
"In April and May of this year business has tripled over the same months in 2000," said Bill Ayers, president and chief executive.
The pace has also picked up at K2 Resources in Greenwich, an executive recruiting firm, said Kelly Coles, a managing partner. Ms. Coles estimated that the company is receiving about 100 unsolicited resumes a week, about twice the number they were seeing late last year.
"It probably takes on average about 45 minutes to answer and respond to all the new resumes each morning," said Ms. Coles. "We've always had a steady number of incoming phone calls, but now it's full-time."
Mr. Dolde of UConn said the downturn had also increased the enrollment at business schools.
"M.B.A. enrollment between 1997 and 2000 had declined 23 percent because a lot of people said the job market is hot right now so I'll go to work for dot-com and get some stock options," he said. "But M.B.A. admissions are picking up and will continue to pick up for the next year or so."
Peter Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association in Hartford said all this activity helps, but it certainly doesn't come close to making up for the spending that laid-off workers otherwise would have done. "It generates activity in some businesses, but overall, there is more that gets taken out of the economy," he said. "One key factor is consumer spending. Yes, laid-off people are spending on certain specifics, but they won't be buying new TV's and new furniture."
Mr. Grenier of Hutton's, the North Haven clothing store, said the average job hunter spends $475 for a suit, shirt, tie. But he said some people try to make due with less.
"I had one young guy come in looking for a clean, white T-shirt because he was going for a job interview at SNET," Mr. Grenier said. "I said, 'Not dressed like that I hope.' He later said he was going to go home and change."

HEADLINE: For Class of 2001, a Less Frenetic Market 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
IF Yamani Sekhri, who received her M.B.A. from Indiana University in May, had been searching for an apartment in Manhattan a year ago, Michael Shapot would have had one listing, maybe two, to show her on any given day. 
 But this year is different. Ms. Sekhri, who began as an investment banking associate with UBS Warburg in May, phoned Mr. Shapot, an associate broker with Coldwell Banker/Hunt Kennedy for an appointment recently, and three hours later they were off to scout seven places that met her requirements: a studio in the $1,800-a-month range. 
 Last year when the economy was feverish, "new graduates had to jump through hoops to get apartments and doors were slammed in their faces," Mr. Shapot said, as he set out to show Ms. Sekhri apartments in the financial district, Midtown and the Upper East and West Sides. "This year, with a larger pool of properties, doors are opening at prices that are marginally lower. There is basically much more inventory from which to choose, fewer people are looking, prices are more reasonable and the pace of the market is much less frenetic."
Brian G. Edwards, director of leasing with the Halstead Property Company, agreed. "It is not a complete reversal of last summer, but there is a much more comfortable scenario, where new graduates will find that the cards are not all stacked in the landlords' hands," he said. "The class of 2001 can expect to pay slightly less than the class of 2000 and closer to what the class of '99 paid. This year it's not doom and gloom; it's hope and sun."
The outlook is sunny indeed for people like Ms. Sekhri whose starting salaries in fields like investment banking and law are likely to be $85,000 or more and come attached to signing bonuses. But for new bachelor's and master's degree holders entering less financially rarefied fields like teaching and publishing, a Manhattan apartment without roommates may remain unattainable. 
So they are continuing to flock to Queens, Brooklyn and New Jersey, where demand exceeds supply by a stiff margin, keeping rents buoyed up. In some parts of Queens, brokers say, rents are soaring to new heights. In Brooklyn, they estimate, they have increased by 15 to 20 percent since last year. In Hoboken and elsewhere along the New Jersey side of the Hudson River, increasing numbers of young people find it necessary to share their quarters -- and their rent -- with roommates. 
But it remains considerably cheaper to live outside Manhattan. In Queens, for example, it is still possible to find a studio for $900. 
Ms. Sekhri faced no such constraints and found there were several prospects on her tour with Mr. Shapot that met her needs. "I'm not going to spend much time in my apartment and will never cook," she said. "I'm working from 9 a.m. to 2:30 a.m. almost every day, so I just need a place to keep my clothes, shower and sleep a few hours." 
But she didn't take any of the apartments she saw that day, figuring that with the range of choices, she could continue to look. Her starting salary is $85,000, and she received a sign-on bonus of $30,000. 
Two weeks ago she signed a lease to sublet a furnished co-op studio in Tudor City that her mother, Kalpna Deepak, had found through a newspaper ad and last week learned that she had won board approval. "It is a 10-minute walk from my office; it has a health club in the building, a microwave, dishwasher, air-conditioner, stereo and TV," she said. "It's perfect because all I have are my clothes."
The process proved far less painful than she had expected. "You hear so many stories, but if you're willing to spend $1,800 a month, it's not difficult," she said. Actually, she will be spending less: $1,550.
For the most part, landlords are receptive to new graduates, provided that like Ms. Sekhri they meet the requirements: proof of employment, references, good credit records. 
But occasionally, as John Vo and Jackie Pang, members of the class of 2001 at Georgetown University, who will start analysts' jobs at J. P. Morgan, learned recently, they raise the barriers.
"There has been some easing in the process, but at the same time, some landlords fear that people may lose their jobs and are concerned that they won't be able to fulfill lease obligations," said Paul Diem, the agent from Citi Habitats who steered them through the process. 
MR. VO flew up from his home in Miami a week after graduation and was joined by Ms. Pang, who is from Honolulu, in the search several days later. 
Mr. Diem showed them what they considered the perfect apartment: a 1,300-square-foot loft on 29th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues for $3,500 a month, $1,000 more than they had intended to spend. 
"In addition, we needed to come up with about $16,000 to secure the place: the first month's rent, a three-month security deposit and the 12 percent broker's fee," Mr. Vo said. "We liked it so much we decided to put down the money and find a third roommate."
So they sent out a mass e-mail and found David Larson, a new graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, who will also be starting work at J. P. Morgan. He was traveling in Italy, so they had numerous conversations with his mother in Malibu. Mr. Vo turned over some of the negotiations to her because, he said, "she is a real adult; I'm just a kid adult." 
Thinking they had sealed the deal, he went home to Miami and Ms. Pang to Hawaii when the landlady announced she wanted to meet all three roommates in person. Mr. Vo and Mr. Larson's mother both volunteered to meet with her but that did not satisfy her, so they decided to withdraw. 
Now the roommates will move, sight unseen, into a three-bedroom high rise on West Street that Mr. Diem found them. "In a sense, being from all parts of the country, we didn't have that many choices," Mr. Vo said. "We couldn't just show up and spend months looking."
This time they are being charged only one month's rent ($3,075) and a month's security, a good thing, Mr. Vo said, because he has already spent the $10,000 signing bonus he received. His base salary is $55,000 a year.
With new construction coming on the market in Manhattan, with a greater inventory of available apartments and with fewer people competing for them, some owners are reducing rents -- or at least not raising them. The descent began several months before the migration of this year's crop of new graduates to the city. 
"From December to March we saw across-the-board reductions in rents in all sectors ranging from 5 to 10 percent," said Mr. Edwards of Halstead Property, who recently briefed members of the graduating class at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University who were about to relocate here about what to expect.
"Last year one-bedrooms in doorman buildings averaged $2,900 to $3,100. Today they are $2,600 to $2,800. Two-bedrooms, which were $4,200 to $4,400, are now $3,900 to $4,100." 
Mr. Shapot was showing an apartment the other day when "someone slipped the rent bill for the current tenant under the door," he said. "The asking price was exactly the same."
There is also a term that is creeping back into the vocabulary of the rental market that has not been heard for years: "concession," or as it is known today, "incentive." 
At the Foundry, for example, a 222- apartment, two-building complex that opened on 10th Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets in March, those renters who signed leases by July 1 were entitled to two months free rent. Those who take apartments for Aug. 1 occupancy will receive one month free. In addition, some people who rent before Sept. 1 will be rewarded with a $500 gift certificate from Kenneth Cole, the shoe and clothing designer. 
"Landlords are willing to negotiate prices or offer some sort of incentive to the tenant with good credit, a good job and a good pedigree," Mr. Shapot said. 
In some instances, rather than reduce rents, landlords are scaling back the stiff financial requirements they had demanded in the past of young tenants starting their first jobs. "Their heads are no longer on the chopping blocks as they were last summer when landlords required that they bring along Fort Knox and proof of lineage," Mr. Edwards said. 
Andrew Heiberger, president and chief executive of Citi Habitats, a residential brokerage firm, elaborated: "They are being less restrictive. They are allowing roommates to combine their incomes to qualify for the requirement that they earn 40 to 52 times the monthly rent. They are also allowing more than one guarantor and permitting out-of-state guarantors." 
In fact, the subject of a guarantor was not raised by any of the rental agents in the apartments visited by Ms. Sekhri, nor was there the slightest suggestion that she might have any difficulty qualifying. 
However, brokers agreed, landlords are holding fast to the formula that, one way or another, a tenant's annual income be at least 40 times the monthly rent. That means to secure a $2,000-a-month apartment, a tenant must earn at least $80,000 a year. 
Certainly, bargains remain elusive. "Rents are still phenomenal here compared to anywhere else in the country," said Ruth McCoy, executive director of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage firm. "We need to educate people that they are renting in Manhattan for the living experience."
BUT unless they have sources of income outside their paychecks, "living experience" may be no inducement to people in entry level jobs with salaries that are less than breathtaking. James Byrne, for example, an audio-visual coordinator for the Dalton School who earned his master's degree in information and library science from the Pratt Institute in May, found himself shut out of Manhattan by the rents. 
"I have been searching on and off for the past three years," he said. "I grew up in Manhattan, one of 11 children in a four-bedroom apartment in Chelsea, and I feel I deserve to be there."
He has been looking for a two-bedroom apartment and said: "I guess it is not unreasonable to spend $1,400. Anything over that is out of my price range. It looks like I might have to move to Jersey." He is now living in Brooklyn. 
While rents may be moderating a bit in Manhattan, they are not necessarily dropping in the places where young people with more modest paychecks gravitate: Astoria, Long Island City, Forest Hills and Bayside in Queens; Brooklyn Heights, Carroll Gardens, Boerum Hill, Park Slope, Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn; Hoboken, Jersey City, Weehawken in New Jersey. 
"We still don't see things easing up," said Filomena Muncipinto, rental manager for First Choice Real Estate in Fresh Meadows, which has 70 agents deployed throughout Queens. "Rents are still going through the roof and landlords are just as demanding, if not more so." But prices in the surrounding boroughs remain well below those asked in Manhattan. According to Helen Keit, vice president for relocation and new business development for First Choice, studios can be had for $900 to $1,000, one-bedrooms for $1,000 to $1,200 and two-bedrooms for $1,300 to $1,500 in neighborhoods like Forest Hills, Flushing, Rego Park and Bayside.
In Brooklyn, John P. Burke Jr., a developer and president of a brokerage that bears his father's name, said, "Rental prices here are probably 15 to 20 percent higher than last year, and in the last three years they have probably risen 50 percent." He quoted $1,350 for a studio, $3,700 for a two-bedroom. 
Melissa Baily, who graduated from Harvard Law School a few weeks ago and who will start working as an associate at Cravath, Swain & Moore in September, headed directly for Midtown Manhattan when she started looking in April. In fact, she wanted to be within reasonable walking distance of her office at Eighth Avenue and 49th Street. 
"I called a realtor recommended by Cravath and came from Boston for a day," she said. "I said I wanted the cheapest thing I could find from which I could walk to work and that was clean."
She found her apartment, a studio at the Foundry, the new building at 10th Avenue and 54th Street, and took it that day. 
"It was really easy," she said. "They wanted confirmation from my employer regarding my salary and references from my prior landlord. I paid one month's security and one month's rent." 
The leasing agents for the building have been trying to attract young professionals by running advertisements in law and business school newspapers at such elite institutions as Harvard, Yale, Georgetown, the University of Pennsylvania and Dartmouth. 
Ms. Baily, who said she did not know what her salary would be (last year Cravath paid its first year associates $165,000, which included a $40,000 bonus), conceded that "$2,375 does seem high, especially since I was paying less for two bedrooms in Cambridge, but I knew New York would be expensive." 
Mark Buchsbaum had a ruder introduction to the real estate scene when he graduated in May from New York Medical College. He had expected to get staff housing through his internship at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital but was informed at the end of May that there was not enough space. 
Then he began scrambling to find an alternative. "I was trying not to go through a broker, but unfortunately in Manhattan that is impossible," he said. "I signed up for online programs, looked through newspapers, went to open houses listed in The Village Voice and called phone numbers listed there. Either the apartment would already be taken or you would go and find there was no buzzer for the super or if you found the super, he would say it had been taken several weeks ago." 
"I began to look in Brooklyn and Jersey to see if I could find something cheaper," he continued. "You get more space in Park Slope and Greenpoint, but it's still very expensive: $1,600 to $1,800. So I broke down and called a broker, Bonnie Waldman at Feathered Nest, who is a friend of my parents. I told her my upper limit was $2,000, but she showed me more expensive places to be more realistic."
Finally he compromised: taking a studio rather than a one-bedroom apartment for $2,001 in the West Village that he intends to share with his girlfriend, Jennifer Zweig. "It may be small," he said, "but I figured I will be out working so many hours that we won't get on each other's nerves too much."
Tadia Taylor, an unemployed actress, got her bachelor of fine arts degree from New York University Tisch School of the Arts last year, but she is only beginning her search in earnest now. 
"After I graduated, I was working as a server in a restaurant in Manhattan, and the cheapest apartments I could find were $1,300 a month," she said. "So I went to Atlanta to live with my grandmother to save up money."
MS. TAYLOR is planning to audition for television show pilots in the fall and to find an $1,800 two-bedroom apartment in Williamsburg or Fort Greene that she will share with a roommate. 
"Prices in Manhattan are ridiculously high, and they are comparable in Park Slope and Williamsburg," she said, adding: "The process is so difficult. For a student right out of school it is difficult to come up with the security deposit plus the broker's fee of 15 percent of a year's rent. When you sign a lease, you have to put up at least $4,000 or $5,000."
Jeremy Eisemann, who graduated from Colgate University in May, began working on June 1 as a public relations coordinator for three Ziff-Davis magazines, earning a base salary that is under $30,000 a year.
Two weeks after graduation, Mr. Eisemann, who grew up in Houston, began looking for an apartment he could share with four roommates."I felt that living with five people would create an immediate comfort zone of friends," he said. "I didn't want to be lost in a huge city."
But when the five young men went to East Hampton for a weekend meant as a bonding experience, two of them got into a squabble, so Mr. Eisemann decided to scale the group back to three. 
"We went looking every day from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. for two and a half weeks," he said. "We were determined to live in the East Village because we didn't want to have to take taxis from where we were living to where we would be partying. Some of the places we saw were tiny and in horrible condition, and some were in commercial space. One place we saw had 60 ironing boards and 60 sewing machines." 
But they prevailed, and, with the help of a broker, found a two-bedroom apartment on 15th Street off Union Square for $3,700. "Since there are three of us, I am living in the dining room, and my room is the entrance to the kitchen," he said. "But it's an excellent place."
Looking back, he reflected, "This is not a terrible experience if you have money. But once I'm living off my own money, I guess I'll have to move out of Manhattan."

LENGTH: 1417 words

HEADLINE: JERSEY MATTERS; 
Shedding Tiers? Most Eyes Are Dry

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD 

 BODY:
Be honest. Who cares what happens to those piles of prefabricated concrete that squat in the middle of the Meadowlands?
 There's Giants Stadium, where the football team that plays there cares so much about what goes on west of the Hudson that it put the letters "NY" back on their helmets. And then there's the place next door where ice hockey is played and basketball is attempted -- once known as the Brendan Byrne Arena and now named after that famous New Jerseyan, Continental. 
 Huh? Continental Airlines Arena has never exactly been the kind of place that arouses warm and fuzzy feelings like such mythic sports venues as Ebbets Field, the Polo Grounds or Yankee Stadium. 
Such was the case even when the vast block of a building took the name of the former governor -- in those days before New Jersey proved that anything could be put up for sale, even a name.
Yet, despite the jokes about holding victory celebrations for the New Jersey Devils in the parking lot of the sports complex, a lament of sorts has been rising since Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco proposed that the Devils and the New Jersey Nets abandon the swamps for an arena in Newark at a cost of $355 million.
Not so fast. The heads up has come primarily from Bergen County officials, though not because they'll miss the sports fans -- but because they'll have to do without the money those fans deliver. So aside from some elected officials and wide-eyed chamber of commerce types, it is not clear whether New Jerseyans care a bat's ash what happens to the arena or, for that matter, to the entire sports complex, sitting as it does atop a nondescript tract amid a maze of clogged highways.
"It brings a lot of business to merchants here," said one fervent proponent, George Zanakis, manager of the Candledwyck Diner. "It also helps put New Jersey on the map. The New Jersey Devils playing in the Meadowlands. The New Jersey Nets. East Rutherford became known all over the states because the Giants and Jets also play here."
At least the people from Rand McNally are grateful for the complex, otherwise they might not have known where to plug New Jersey in on their maps.
But others, like the borough's police chief, John LaGreca, whose 29-member department patrols the highways around the complex, would not miss the place if it sank into the bog. "It's just an additional burden on the town," said Chief LaGreca.
Gripes aside, when the governor came up with his final vision for extricating the two professional sports teams from the arena and shipping them to Newark, he had goodies in mind to keep Bergen County officials placated. He has even traveled to Bergen County to win support of officials concerned about the economic effect of removing the teams from the Meadowlands, offering ideas on what could replace Continental Airlines Arena. Ideas bandied about include a Disney-style family entertainment center, a mall, a Nascar racing track and, as incongruous as it sounds, a ski slope. Now Mr. DiFrancesco has to similarly appease Speaker Jack Collins, who is looking out for the interests of his fellow South Jerseyans, who are also looking fdor something out of this three carom short.
Chief LaGreca, a Giants fan who tries to avoid the sport complex except for the annual golden oldies show, said he thought it was "nice" to have East Rutherford identified as the home of the Giants, even though people, including the players, referred to the team as New York's. 
"It's New York this and New York that," he said. "I'd like to hand a map out to all the players out there and say, 'Excuse me, you're in the state of New Jersey. Manhattan's about six miles east of you.' "
A Star-Ledger Eagleton Rutgers poll of 800 New Jersey residents in January 1999 showed that 81 percent thought the sports complex had been good for the state's image, though a follow-up poll on a possible move by the Nets to Newark found that 48 percent of those polled could not care less.
"There hasn't been a big outrage over the teams being moved," said Chris Oliver, editor of the South Bergenite, a weekly newspaper in neighboring Rutherford, "except some of the readers complaining about having to go to Newark."
But William Schuber, the Bergen County executive, who attended the first Bruce Springsteen concert at the arena, is still rankled over the fate of the sports complex, which draws six million people a year. Giants Stadium and the Meadowlands Racetrack opened in 1976 and the Brendan Byrne Arena opened in July 1981 with six sold-out Springsteen concerts.
"It's not a Yankee Stadium or an Ebbets Field, but there was a certain pride and convenience that the arena was in our backyard and we identified with that," Mr. Schuber said. "Many of us wonder why it has to come down."
Ed Rice isn't one of them. Although Mr. Rice, an information technology manager from Waldwick, is a sports fan, he goes to only one or two games a year at the complex because of the traffic jams.
"What they do about the Meadowlands, I have no preference at all," Mr. Rice said, "because I usually avoid that area."
A 1998 study by Deloitte & Touche said that the arena generated about $19.5 million in sales and income taxes, according to John Samerjan, spokesman for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. In general, the complex spurred almost 4,400 jobs in Bergen alone, the report said.
But the arena has been operating in the red, in part because of the cost of renegotiated contracts in recent years to keep the Nets and Devils there, Mr. Samerjan said.
East Rutherford, where the complex is situated, gets 21 percent of the amount raised through taxes, said Mayor James Cassella, who helped to negotiate an agreement to that effect. That will mean $3.5 million this year.
"Right now the concern of residents is what kind of financial hardship will there be if they do move," Mayor Cassella said.
Both he and Chief LaGreca, who has conducted parking ticket blitzes and cracked down on scalpers, said that if a mall was built on the site, the effect on an already bad traffic situation would be devastating.
In addition, said Rich Fritzky, president of the Meadowlands Regional Chamber of Commerce, there was a psychological consideration here.
"We don't want the nation or the world to think that people want to get out of the Meadowlands," Mr. Fritzky said. "They should believe it's a place to come.
At Captain's Mobil station on Route 17 in Rutherford, Ahmet Akincioglu, an employee, said he never went to the complex but wanted it to stay healthy. "A lot of people stop and ask directions," Mr. Akincioglu said. "They ask me, 'How can I go to the arena?' And usually they buy something."
One customer at Captain's, Mark Alessio, a computer consultant to Mercedes-Benz who had just dropped off his motorcycle, said he was an avid Jets and Devils fan who went to the complex frequently.
"It's convenient, and I feel safe over there," Mr. Alessio said. But he added, "You go to Newark, you go one block out from where they're thinking of putting up this thing, you've got problems."
Jean Sagarese, a procurement official at Picatinny Arsenal who is a founding member of the Devils fan club, said she was also concerned about safety and preferred the Continental Arena, where she could enjoy tailgate parties in the parking lot.
"It's very easy to get to," said Ms. Sagarese, who lives in Mendham. "I walk in, I know where I'm going, where my friends sit. We visit between periods. We wander around. If they kill the arena, where will I go for concerts? Im not going to Newark."
But Pete Dugan, a pharmaceutical sales and marketing executive from Ramsey who is an avid Devils fan, said the move would benefit everyone.
"The Meadowlands complex has no character," said Mr. Dugan. "Newark is New Jersey's largest city. It has some history to it and has some other things going on around it -- the performing arts center, a minor league baseball club and a vibrancy and energy that cities of any decent size bring. Being out in the Meadowlands, there is no vibrancy or energy other than hanging out in the parking lot."
Sometimes sports fans don't even make it to the parking lot, and that is where Chief LaGreca's difficulties begin. Cars, vans and S.U.V.'s parked by the road near the stadium are especially problematic -- and not just because they impede traffic.
"Let's face it," the chief said. "When people park out on the grass and on the highway, what would be the first thing they do when they come back out of a football game after consuming a lot of beer?"

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Elizabeth Redisch, Hazem Gamal

 BODY:
Elizabeth Sue Redisch and Hazem Saad Gamal were married yesterday at the Wainwright House, an education center in Rye, N.Y. Dr. Khoren Arisian, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony. 
 Mrs. Gamal, 39, is a marketing manager in New York for Aveda, the personal-care products company. She graduated from George Washington University, and received a certificate in Mandarin language studies from Taiwan National University and an international M.B.A. from the Ecole Superieure des Sciences Economiques Commerciales in Paris. She is the daughter of Lois Creditor Redisch of Cliffside Park, N.J., and the late Jerome L. Redisch. Her father was a partner in S. Redisch & Sons, a furniture retailer that was in New York. Her mother, who is retired, was a Democratic political consultant and a freelance writer in New Milford, N.J. 
 Mr. Gamal, 33, is an assistant vice president in the corporate technologies group at OppenheimerFunds, the mutual fund company in New York. He graduated from Johnson & Wales University in Providence, R.I., and received an M.B.A. from the American Graduate School of International Management in Phoenix. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Saad M. Gamal of Cairo. His father is an emeritus professor of linguistics at Cairo University. His mother, Sandra Hodges Gamal, is a librarian at the Cairo American College, a private elementary and secondary school.

HEADLINE: SENIORITY; 
A Special Invitation (to Anyone)

BYLINE:  By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LIKE most of us, Ann Hamman is deluged with mail offering "preapproved" credit cards and various lines of credit from banks and financial services companies, large and small. Gold cards, platinum cards, titanium cards. Credit lines of as much as $100,000.
 Unlike most of us, however, Mrs. Hamman, 93, never sees them. That is because she has been in an assisted-living residence in Homestead, Fla., for more than a year. She suffers from memory problems and needs help with daily activities; she cannot prepare meals or manage a bank account. Her mail goes to her son, Henry Hamman, who lives nearby in Miami. 
 And Mr. Hamman, who has his mother's power of attorney, says he is appalled at the mail solicitations she receives.
"When you market indiscriminately to the elderly and the susceptible, I think it's pretty reprehensible," he said. "This is the financial equivalent of handing a loaded gun to a kid."
He is particularly angry about a check Mrs. Hamman received from Household Bank in Las Vegas, a subsidiary of Household International. The check was for $1,500.02. All Mrs. Hamman had to do was endorse it and, presto, the money would be hers -- along with a legal obligation to repay the loan in monthly installments of $55.72 for 48 months. That means that she would repay $2,674.56, which translates to an annual interest rate of 31.945 percent, more than four times the prime rate. 
"If this check had fallen into her hands, it's entirely conceivable that she might have used it and not really known what she was doing," Mr. Hamman said.
Celeste Murphy, director of investor relations at Household International, which is based in Prospect Heights, Ill., said her company did not specifically single out older people for such solicitations. She agreed that the 31.945 percent rate offered Mrs. Hamman was "stunning."
Mr. Hamman was also puzzled that many of the offers cited his mother's excellent credit history as a reason for offering her up to $100,000 of credit.
"She doesn't have any credit," he said. "She has no assets other than her pension and Social Security and hasn't owned a home since the 1960's. Either there is a credit report mix-up or this is the biggest bunch of hooey I've ever seen."
A spokeswoman in Washington for the American Bankers Association, a lobbying group, said that members "look at creditworthiness" before making credit card offers.
Mrs. Hamman grew up in Oklahoma and during World War II was a lieutenant in the Women's Army Corps, serving in Italy and Algeria. She later worked in Indiana as a consumer education agent and as a food editor at The Evansville Courier. After retiring, she served in the Peace Corps in Belize for two years. 
"She's always been a very independent person, who stood up for folks who couldn't stand up for themselves," Mr. Hamman said. "These credit offers would upset her because of the damage they can do to people who aren't financially sophisticated."
The seemingly personal solicitations can also prove seductive to the psychologically vulnerable. Mrs. Hamman is lucky that she has her son to look out for her in these matters. Many older people who are on their own -- especially if they are homebound, lonely or confused -- can easily fall victim to such practices that, while not illegal, are certainly questionable. 
Travis B. Plunkett, the legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, based in Washington, said "indiscriminate and reckless marketing" had become the rule in the credit card industry, which last year mailed out a record 3.5 billion solicitations. "While members of this industry are asking Congress to make bankruptcy more restrictive, they have actually increased their solicitations and lines of credit," he said, referring to a bill pending in Congress that would make it harder for people to erase their debts. 
"Their business model, the way they profit, is to make risky loans to people who often don't have the financial skills to know whether it's right or not," he added. "They'll give a credit card to anything that moves."
Consider the case involving the late Doug X. Ping. Doug was a Shar-Pei who was struck by a car and killed in 1994, when he was 5. The dog's Brooklyn owner, who had brought him to the United States from China, later put the pet's name on some random consumer survey. Earlier this year, Doug received a solicitation from First USA Bank in Wilmington, Del., for a National Geographic Society platinum MasterCard with a "solid line of credit" of up to $100,000.
A spokesman for First USA Bank, which is a member of the banking association and a unit of Bank One, said, "We make every effort to ensure that the offers we mail out go to credit-eligible adults."
If you're not a dog, you can take some steps to limit the number of mail solicitations you receive.
For a $5 fee, the Web site of the Direct Marketing Association (www.the-dma.org/consumers) allows you to remove your name from its members' mailing lists. The same service is free if you write to Mail Preference Service, Direct Marketing Association, P.O. Box 9008, Farmingdale, N.Y. 11735-9008. There is also an automated toll-free number (888-567-8688) that allows you to remove your name from mailed lists provided by the big credit reporting agencies.
But perhaps the best advice on dealing with credit solicitations comes from James A. Guest, the president of Consumers Union, based in Yonkers. "Just throw the stuff in the trash," he said.

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Isuzu Axiom; 
Joe Isuzu Is Back, and He Has a New Sport Utility to Sell

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
REINVENTING" is a word that pops up frequently on the best-seller lists these days, applied to everything from management to souls. 
 The executives at American Isuzu must be reading a few of those books as the company has been reinventing itself little by little for much of the last decade. In 1994, the United States marketing arm for the Japanese auto manufacturer walked away from the car market to focus exclusively on selling trucks. This year, it refines its focus even further by dropping its last pickup truck, the Hombre, and selling only sport utility vehicles. 
 It has added a new sport utility, the Axiom, this spring, the fifth in its portfolio. To herald the arrival of the Axiom, aimed at attracting new, young buyers, Isuzu has pulled out all the stops.
Joe Isuzu, the lying salesman of the 1980's, is back to star in commercials after a decade-long hiatus. Ad spending is up substantially, when other automakers are slashing ad budgets. Much of the budget is financing Isuzu's largest and splashiest promotional campaign ever for any of its vehicles. It includes a role by the Axiom in the recent family movie "Spy Kids," in which geeky parents, former international spies, are kidnapped and subsequently rescued by their clever children. The promotion also involves tie-ins with McDonald's and Radio Shack.
The marketing plan is appropriate for a design as daring as the Axiom's. Its "knife-edge" styling is based on the ZXS concept vehicle, unveiled at the 1999 Tokyo auto show. With sharp, distinctive lines everywhere, the Axiom fits perfectly into the futuristic, technological world of "Spy Kids." Yet, reviews on today's suburban streets, where the Axiom will travel, were mixed. Some young men called it cool; one young woman called it weird, a word I heard often during my weeklong test drive; older people called it homely.
I wasn't surprised when the young woman said she didn't like it. The Axiom has a masculine, industrial look. There is a bold grille with hefty horizontal slats and beefy spokes on the tires. In contrast, the headlights are squinty and the taillights puny. The back end is boxy, reminding me of the behind of a station wagon. The Axiom is intended to be a reinvention of the sport utility, a crossover that mixes a little car, like the station wagon back end, with a lot of sport utility.
The industrial motif carries over to the interior. The Axiom XS I tested -- the upscale, leather-laden version -- featured a gold exterior with unappealing two-tone browns inside, accented by plastic trim that tried, and failed, to mimic metal. The beige material covering the dash was crackled, apparently to suggest saddle leather, but it, too, was a cheap-looking imitation.
The instrument panel featured red needles attached to knobs that looked like industrial rivets. Bolts and screws in other areas were exposed for a mechanical look.
The center dash came straight out of "Spy Kids." An extremely busy video screen displayed mileage, temperature and radio settings. In bright sunlight, however, the screen was difficult to read.
Little storage areas, 12-volt outlets, cup holders and cargo hooks sprinkled throughout the cabin and spacious cargo bay give the Axiom lots of utility and versatility. However, less thought was given to other items. A six-disc CD changer consumes most of the space in the center console. Only outboard seats have three-point seat belts and head restraints whereas other sport utilities have three-point belts and head rests for all five passengers. Though the Axiom is longer than the Jeep Grand Cherokee, it is also narrower so rear seat room is tight for three adults. Seat backs in the second row split but do not fold completely flat. No third-row seat, an increasingly sought-after feature in sport utilities, or side air bags are available. Anti-lock brakes are standard.
In contrast to most entry-level sport utilities, which use a car platform, the Axiom rides on a steel-ladder-frame chassis, like those used on traditional truck-based sport utilities. According to Isuzu, the more rigid construction makes it better for off-roading. The Axiom is available in rear-wheel drive or four-wheel drive.
I didn't take it off road. Nor will most drivers. Isuzu boasts the ride and handling are similar to that of European sedans. It was unlike any European sedan I have driven. The ride on the pavement was bouncy and noisy, despite the Axiom's being equipped with an independent suspension like those used on automobiles.
The Axiom's engine is borrowed from the Isuzu Rodeo, but it has been tweaked to build the horsepower. Power from the Axiom's 3.5-liter V-6 engine, rated at 230 horsepower, ranks among the highest of V-6-powered sport utilities and is only slightly less than the V-8 engine in Ford's new Explorer. Fuel economy is on par with other V-6 sport utilities at 16 miles per gallon in the city and 20 miles per gallon on the highway.
The engine is paired with a standard automatic transmission with systems designed to prevent hunting for gears while climbing or descending steep grades. But even in flat-as-a-pancake Michigan, the systems engaged too quickly and too abruptly when I drove up and down the slightest inclines. It was so noticeable that I thought the transmission was failing.
The Axiom proved relatively nimble for a sport utility but the steering was far less responsive than I liked. 
The Axiom, which comes as a base model or the XS, is available with four-wheel drive in either version. The Trooper uses the same four-wheel-drive system, which shifts power to the front wheels from the back when it detects a lack of traction.
The Axiom takes on some tough competitors, including two newcomers: the more mainstream, car-based Toyota Highlander and the rugged, less-expensive Jeep Liberty. Prices start at $26,505 with destination charges for the basic two-wheel-drive Axiom and rise to $31,305 for the XS with four-wheel drive. 
Isuzu takes on its competitors boldly. One entertaining television commercial for the Axiom shows Joe Isuzu in a parking lot dismantling a more-expensive Highlander next to the Axiom to find out what the consumer gets for $1,100 more.
The Axiom may be attractive to some beholders who want something different. But what consumers get for a little more in some sport utilities -- and for even less than what the Axiom costs in others -- is something Joe Isuzu won't find in his dismantling job: a level of refinement I found lacking in the Axiom.

INSIDE TRACK: Rough around the edges.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Their Euphemisms Aside, the Analysts Are Usually Right

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT 

 BODY:
HAVE our elected representatives no sense of shame? A Congressional subcommittee began hearings last month into how conflicts of interest compromise Wall Street's objectivity.
 Of course, tainted objectivity is a serious problem, as acknowledged last week when the Securities and Exchange Commission issued an "investor alert" warning investors to be on guard against biased advice. But Congress will be hard-pressed to be a fair judge. In fact, some evidence paints a far different picture from what emerged from opening statements at those hearings. 
Consider Exhibit A in the case against Wall Street's objectivity: analysts' reluctance to recommend that a stock be sold. That, the theory goes, can be traced to the investment banking divisions of analysts' firms, which do not want to alienate companies with whom they have, or hope to have, underwriting relationships.
The circumstantial evidence is indeed compelling. According to Charles Hill, director for research at Thomson Financial/ First Call, just 1 percent of all analyst stock ratings are "sell," whereas nearly half are "buy." The worst rating that most analysts ever give a stock is "hold."
Yet is this any more pernicious than the grade inflation so rampant in society? Virtually no college student now gets a grade below a C, just as few grocers rate eggs smaller than "large." But most of us know that a C is a bad grade and that large eggs are the smallest.
In fact, investors seem to have no difficulty decoding analysts' euphemisms. On Monday, for example, Biogen stock fell 9 percent after Lehman Brothers downgraded it from "buy" to "market performer" and Merrill Lynch downgraded it from "buy" to "hold." Notice that Lehman did not use the word sell, and Merrill Lynch did not say "reduce/ sell," the rating it created in late June.
Of course, the real test for analysts is whether their ratings pay off for investors. If conflicts of interest have seriously tainted their objectivity, their ratings would be worthless. The evidence suggests otherwise.
In fact, according to the most comprehensive study ever of analysts' ratings, their highest-rated stocks have outperformed the market in most years and their lowest-rated stocks have lagged behind. The study, published in the April issue of The Journal of Finance, was written by Professor Brad Barber of the University of California at Davis and three co-authors from Stanford and the University of California at Berkeley.
Using data from First Call and Zacks Investment Research, the professors studied more than a half-million recommendations from 1986 to 2000 by more than 4,000 brokerage-firm analysts. They constructed a consensus recommendation for each stock, then used the consensus recommendations to create five portfolios. Portfolio 1 contained the approximately 20 percent of stocks whose consensus recommendations were the most favorable, while Portfolio 5 contained those that were least favorable.
The results were impressive for the 14 years through 1999. Portfolio 1 outperformed Portfolio 5 in each of those 14 years, and by an average of more than 16 percentage points a year, before transaction costs.
Last year was another story. After earning an A for 14 years in a row, the analysts flunked miserably during 2000, with Portfolio 5 making 37.6 percent and Portfolio 1 losing 42.3 percent. Still, 14 A's and one F isn't a bad report card. 
Of course, this result applies to analysts as a group, not as individuals. But the professors' findings are hard to square with the notion that compromised objectivity is the rule on Wall Street.
Investors can do at least two things to immunize themselves from conflicts of interest. One is to focus on the consensus among all analysts. First Call and Zacks are two sources of such information, though not the only ones. Another option is to demand that your analyst divulge his conflicts of interest and, if he refuses, to ignore him.

Their highest-rated stocks performed well most of the time, and the lowest-rated did not. Graph shows the highest and lowest percentage change from 1985 for the S.& P. 500. (Source: Profs. Brad Barber, University of California at Davis; Reuven Lehavy and Brett Trueman, U.C. Berkeley; Maureen McNichols, Stanford University)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Polaroid Makes a Digital Leap, but Is It Enough?

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
FOR investors in the Polaroid Corporation, prospects appear dim. Shares in the company have dropped more than 55 percent this year. The stock hit $2.45 on Wednesday, its lowest level in at least three decades. It now trades at $2.60 or 90 percent below its price less than four years ago.
 One of the highflying "Nifty 50" stocks of the early 1970's, Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., is struggling with nearly $1 billion in debt, weak earnings and steady erosion of its instant-photography business. While it recently unfurled new digital technologies and deep cost-cutting, there is skepticism about the stock's prospects. "The best thing for shareholders is to go ahead and sell," said Gibboney Huske, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. 
 In recent months, hedge funds have been shorting the stock and benefiting from the drop in price. "People think the company's going to belly up," said Ulysses Yannas, an analyst at Buckman, Buckman & Reid. But Mr. Yannas is optimistic, saying he believes Polaroid's push into digital technologies and efforts to pay down debt will succeed.
Polaroid's core business is traditional, or nondigital, instant cameras, including the I-Zone line, and instant film. While the company makes some digital cameras, it has been hit hard by the digital revolution and one-hour developing services. It acknowledges that its core business is declining, and Salomon Smith Barney estimates the rate of decline at 5 to 10 percent a year.
Staking its future on digital printing, Polaroid introduced two technologies in May -- Opal, for multicolor images, and Onyx, for monochrome. Polaroid is seeking partnerships to sell or license the technologies for photo-developing kiosks, hand-held printers and digital cameras with built-in printers. Onyx is to be commercially available by year-end, and Opal in 2002.
But Polaroid faces rivals with deeper pockets -- companies like Hewlett-Packard and Eastman Kodak. "There's skepticism as to how soon Opal and Onyx can turn things around," said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
The most pressing concern for investors is Polaroid's $549 million in short-term debt, as of May 6. (It also has $424 million in long-term obligations.) The company must refinance a $350 million bank credit line, about 90 percent of which it has tapped, at the end of December or risk default. According to a June 14 commentary by Moody's Investors Service, "refinancing will be challenging," mostly because of Polaroid's weak earnings and current lack of digital partnerships.
Polaroid's sales have declined in the soft economy, and the company had an operating loss of $38 million, or 85 cents a share, in the first quarter. It has said it expects the second quarter, for which it will announce results on July 18, to look much the same.
John Moore, an analyst at Moody's, said that it gives bonds like Polaroid's a Caa3 or speculative rating as a signal that they can end up in default. The company's bank debt, which has a repayment priority above Polaroid's bonds, recently was offered at 90 cents on the dollar.
Concerns about the cash crunch are not lost on Gary T. DiCamillo, Polaroid's chief executive. "Clearly, there's some nervousness in the market," he said. "Right now, our focus is cash flow."
He added, "I believe that Polaroid's long-term success will be fueled by Opal and Onyx and by an overall strategy linking them to the explosive growth of digital imaging."
Polaroid has scrapped its dividend and will reduce its work force this year and next by nearly 3,000 people, or more than 35 percent of its total, to around 5,500. But the layoffs and other belt-tightening measures, announced on June 13 as part of a restructuring, will not achieve their goal of reducing annual costs by $175 million to $200 million until late 2003, according to the company. Polaroid shares initially jumped 13 percent, to $3.99, on the announcement, but fell back later in the day.
"They can explain and explain, but they've got to execute," Mr. Rosenzweig said.
The company intends to sell its sunglasses business, and should sell its drivers' license business as well, said Mr. Yannas of Buckman, Buckman & Reid. Combined, those units could fetch up to $200 million, he said. In May, Polaroid sold property outside Boston for $69 million; it could raise $200 million by selling other real estate, he said, forecasting that the stock could reach $16 by March. "There's enough coming in to help pay down the debt," he said, citing, among other things, the asset sales.
But Phillip A. Titzer, a portfolio manager at Edgar Lomax, an institutional money manager in Springfield, Va., with about 718,000 Polaroid shares, said that even value managers like it were not inspired by the stock's depressed price. "We're not selling -- yet," he said. "But the stock really looks like it's going nowhere."

The company is trying to rebound with devices like its Modem Camera, above. Its core business, however, is instant-print film technology, used in the OneStep. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Training a New Generation of Workers in Alaska 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
LOUIS PEOPLES was a young man when he came to the Alaskan Arctic in 1977 to help build and then run the industrial web that pumps oil from the North Slope and sends it south to market.
 Now Mr. Peoples and many of the men who arrived with him are middle-aged and ready to retire. But, even though production from the North Slope is declining, there are not enough skilled young engineers and roustabouts to replace them. 
 The aging of America's oil work force is more sweeping and urgent in Alaska than in the lower 48 states because so many workers arrived at the same time. Now, they are approaching retirement together.
And the potential effect of the demographic pinch is magnified because the North Slope produces 4.8 percent of the 18 million barrels of oil that the United States consumes each day.
BP, the North Slope's largest operator of oil fields, expects that about 100 of the 700 technicians in its blue-collar work force will retire over the next two years. Industry experts estimate that there are about 1,000 such workers over all in Alaska, and that perhaps 300 of them will retire or quit in the next decade.
To try to avoid the damage that such an exodus could do to production, BP led an industry effort to develop a two-year training program, called the Alaska Process Industries Consortium, at the University of Alaska campuses in Anchorage, Fairbanks and Kenai. Ann Spohnholz, executive director of the program, said she did not know how much the oil companies had invested in the program, but did say that the time that oil company employees worked on the curriculum was worth "millions of dollars."
Students in the program study subjects like chemistry and physics and learn how to run the equipment and systems that pump and transport oil. BP offers scholarships to cover classroom tuition and arranges student internships on the North Slope.
About 200 people are enrolled in the two-year program; 19 percent of them are women. The first 30 technicians are scheduled to graduate from the course in December.
The company is focused on hiring Alaskans because young people eager for high-paying jobs no longer migrate to Alaska from the rest of the country, as they did in the 1970's. And it must train unskilled workers because wholesale layoffs of experienced oil workers in the 1980's and 90's means that there are few veterans available for Alaska now. Mr. Peoples, now 55, has trained two new hires as he prepares to leave. 
Though the Alaskan economy relies heavily on oil -- it accounts for 80 percent of state revenue -- BP officials say they are convinced that many people in the state are not aware of the range of jobs in the industry. To try to educate them, BP has established mentoring programs for young people from colleges down to elementary school.
A FORMER maintenance worker in oil fields, Kelley Griffin, hopes to land a technician job at BP. She spent last fall serving an internship at BP's Endicott field, which sits on a spit of land extending into the Arctic Ocean. Like many trainees with BP's program, Ms. Griffin, 41, worked previously in low-level oil-related jobs.
Ms. Griffin was attracted to the North Slope by the same things that drew Mr. Peoples north from California more than two decades ago: high pay and the challenge of working in an extreme environment. BP pays its technicians $70,000 a year, and even the lowest-paying jobs at other oil companies in the state pay $40,000. In Alaska, oil offers more stability than it does elsewhere in the United States because the fields are already producing, and people are needed to keep them going.
Ms. Griffin said it was unlikely that she would defect to another industry after she graduated from the program, as oil hands in the lower 48 sometimes do. "I like working with stuff that you can take apart and put together again," she said. "Besides, I learned early on that boys get to do all the fun stuff."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kelley Griffin, 41, aiming for a technician job at BP, served an internship at its Endicott field. High pay and challenging work attracted her. (Michael Dinneen for The New York Times)
