HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Selling Big Dreams On the Potomac

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO; Elaine Sciolino is a Washington-based reporter for The New York Times who writes regularly about the arts.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE dimly lighted, demode Eugenia Room on the fourth floor of Sardi's in New York is not the usual site for an announcement by the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. But one morning in June, buttressed by six staff members, there is Michael M. Kaiser, the Kennedy Center's president, introducing three of the directors of six musicals by Stephen Sondheim that will be performed in repertory next year.
 Mr. Kaiser has rented the room, paid for the bagels, decorated the tables with white roses and peonies and affixed the Kennedy Center bronze seal to a podium. If he is put out that only about 30 journalists have shown up, or that one of the four Sondheim directors is off rehearsing, or that a fifth director fell through the night before, he doesn't show it. 
 The Kennedy Center's festival "will be unique in the history of the performing arts," Mr. Kaiser boasts, because it will be creating six new Sondheim productions. "It returns the Kennedy Center to self-production of theater," he says. 
Mr. Kaiser came to the Kennedy Center job five months ago with the sobriquet "turnaround king," earned after he bailed out the Kansas City Ballet, American Ballet Theater, the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation and the Royal Opera House in London. By contrast, the Kennedy Center is financially secure, so his goal, he says, is to make it "a national destination."
People travel to Washington just to visit its monuments and museums, he reasons, so why not just to watch performances at the Kennedy Center? Just under three million tourists pass through the center each year, but they come mainly to see the bronze bust of John F. Kennedy and the red-carpeted, flag-lined hall of states.
The question is whether Mr. Kaiser can take the Kennedy Center -- with its reputation as a glorified booking house -- and raise the money, produce the art and create the buzz to make it a must-go-to place. To do that, he will have to turn himself around, becoming an artistic as well as an executive director. And he has never been an artistic director before.
"Michael's task is to build the uniqueness and quality of performances at the Kennedy Center," says James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank and former chairman of the board of the Kennedy Center. "If you are interested in ballet, for example, you have to be prepared to admit that you see more and better ballet in Washington than anywhere else."
New York is crucial to making the Kennedy Center a destination, and the Sondheim festival is a powerful lure. After the news conference, Mr. Kaiser heads for lunch with a potential donor, not to eat but to pitch. The man confirms his pledge for $500,000. (Anticipating the deal, Mr. Kaiser has already included it in his announcement that morning.) Another New Yorker gave $100,000 for the project even though he had never set foot in the Kennedy Center. More than 250 people, two-thirds of them from New York, have sent in $1,000 for tickets to see all six productions in two weekends. Already half of the $3 million to pay for the Sondheim festival has been raised.
"We are always making things bigger to the press than they are," Mr. Kaiser says. "That's our job. And this is a big one." Later, he says, "There's a P. T. Barnum element to what we do." 
He even seems to have impressed Russia's president, Vladimir Putin. "Now I've met both presidents of Washington," Mr. Kaiser quotes Mr. Putin as saying when they were introduced at a ball in St. Petersburg in June.
Yet some senior figures on the New York performing arts scene seem not particularly interested in promoting Mr. Kaiser. And Jane Alexander, the actress and former chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, says through a representative at the William Morris agency that she "isn't interested" in talking about him.
Mr. Kaiser faces both structural and physical barriers that will be hard to overcome. By common critical consensus, neither the Washington Opera nor the National Symphony Orchestra ranks in the top echelons. (Congress's designation of the opera as the country's "National Opera" last year was greeted with derision in New York.)
The Washington Opera, which even Mr. Kaiser calls "a regional opera," is only a tenant; it rents space from the Kennedy Center, and Mr. Kaiser has no control over what it performs or how it is administered. Placido Domingo, the opera's artistic director since 1996, has a grueling global singing schedule and also serves as artistic director of the Los Angeles Opera.
"The opera company -- I can do nothing about that," Mr. Kaiser says. "It is not my right to say, 'Placido, why aren't you spending another week in Washington?' or 'Do you think that is the right production?' What I can do is bring in other opera." 
Both Mr. Kaiser and Mr. Domingo insist that they have a close relationship. Mr. Kaiser was once on the board of the Washington Opera; Mr. Domingo sang with the Royal Opera when Mr. Kaiser headed the Royal Opera House for two years before joining the Kennedy Center. But Mr. Domingo bristles at the notion of "regional."
"I totally disagree that the Washington Opera is a regional opera," he says in a telephone interview from Seoul, where he is singing with the Metropolitan Opera. "We are growing each year. You can see it in the artists, the productions, the publicity." 
Mr. Kaiser's determination to attend any event that can conceivably build relationships with artists, donors, board members, diplomats and politicians, and his fixation with detail, contrast sharply with Mr. Domingo's episodic involvement. At the Opera Ball in June, the Washington Opera's biggest fund-raising event of the year, Mr. Domingo wasn't there; he was singing with the Met in Japan. Mr. Kaiser, by contrast, dutifully attended one of the Opera Ball dinners. "It is not an obligation for me to be at the Opera Ball," Mr. Domingo says. "It's a social thing, and I am into artistic things."
As for the National Symphony Orchestra, which reports to him, Mr. Kaiser paints it in the most positive light. "There is a lot that is wonderful about the N.S.O.," he says. "And we're working very hard on it, particularly to upgrade the ranks of the guest conductors."
As the nation's official monument to President Kennedy, the center is a distinctly political operation. Congress gives it about $20 million a year for operations and educational programs. The president has a permanent box in the three main performance halls, with chilled champagne and M&M's emblazoned with the presidential seal. (The box is routinely turned over to lesser officials.)
The board of trustees is like no other performing arts board: 30 of its trustees are appointed to six-year terms by the President of the United States, often as consolation prizes to friends who don't get ambassadorships. By law, among the other 17 members are 3 members of the Cabinet, 10 members of Congress, the mayor of the District of Columbia, the director of the National Parks Service and the Librarian of Congress.
Mr. Kaiser's artistic goals may be blurred by his double vision for the Kennedy Center. On the one hand, the Kennedy Center must serve as the pre-eminent performing arts organization for the region, which necessarily means that much of what is performed will be derivative productions like "The Producers," the runaway Broadway hit that Mr. Kaiser hopes to present at the Kennedy Center in 2004. "We have an obligation to showcase a range of art -- ballet, modern dance, jazz, symphonic music, chamber music, film festivals, opera, theater," he says, "because if we don't show it, it probably won't be seen in this region."
On the other hand, Mr. Kaiser wants the Kennedy Center to play a national leadership role by both producing and presenting the most creative performances in America. Bringing in both the Kirov and Bolshoi Ballets next year is part of that vision. So are the Kennedy Center's own productions, including the Sondheim musicals and planned Tchiakovsky, Stravinsky and French festivals. "These are programs designed to capture the imagination of the arts community including the sophisticated arts community in New York and around the world," he says.
So will he be a presenter or a producer? He says he'll be something in between: a curator.
His formula for success is straightforward: create big projects, market them to death, generate excitement, bring in new money. To that end, he is blessed with an in-born, unapologetic approach to fund-raising. "I love fund-raising!" he exclaims. "I'm bizarre that way."
Mr. Kaiser calls potential donors "targets," but insists that he avoids "brute force" to get them to give. Instead, he sells dreams. Not surprising from a man who fell in love with the theater at a performance of "The Music Man" on Broadway when he was 4. His dream formula is based on what he learned from his former psychotherapist who "described therapy as a process of painting a picture," Mr. Kaiser writes in a yet-to-be published book about his life as an arts administrator, "Putting It Together." "Each session would fill in some of the detail, and over time I had developed a rich and clear picture of my life. The metaphor applies to my work in the arts."
Dreaming helped persuade the philanthropist Alberto W. Vilar to give Mr. Kaiser a $50 million house-warming present when he took over in February -- by far the largest gift in the center's history. 
"Whatever adjectives and adverbs you use to describe Michael, they must be off the charts," Mr. Vilar says in a telephone interview from Vienna. "He is such a warm, engaging person, he would look at you and ask: 'What do you want to do? What kind of 'naming' makes sense to you? Let's walk through the house and think together.' He is just so well put together in terms of the things you have to have to reach out to a major giver."
At the Royal Opera House, Mr. Vilar's "naming" gift was $18 million for what became the Vilar Floral Garden. At the Kennedy Center, $40 million of his gift will finance the Vilar Institute of Arts Management, which will train arts managers from around the world. The remaining $10 million will pay for yearly visits by the Kirov Opera and Ballet over the next decade. 
By far Mr. Kaiser's most ambitious long-term project appears only as artist renderings hanging on a wall in his windowless, temporary office: an undertaking with the Department of Transportation to reroute the maze of highways in front of the Kennedy Center and build an 11-acre plaza over them. The Department of Transportation would spend $269 million to build the plaza; Mr. Kaiser would have to raise an additional $200 million to put two buildings on it -- one for administrative offices, the other for a national museum for the performing arts.
Another crucial component of Mr. Kaiser's strategy is working the media. As director of the Ailey foundation, he pushed "The Phil Donahue Show" for 18 months to obtain a full hour for the company and negotiated a contract with the incoming Clinton administration to insure that the Ailey would perform at the Inaugural celebrations in 1993.
At a staff meeting in June (most likely staged, since a reporter is invited in) Mr. Kaiser shows how he is trying to shape publicity about the Kennedy Center. There is discussion of persuading a board member to arrange an editorial about the the center's 30th anniversary this fall with the owner of The Chicago Tribune. There is strategizing about how to get USA Today to do a two-page weekend spread. Finally, Mr. Kaiser wants America Online to put the Kennedy Center on its home page for the anniversary. "That's a big market -- a 13-million mailing list!" he says.
Later in the day, at a meeting (also possibly staged) with Roman Terleckyj, the center's vice president for artistic planning, Mr. Kaiser makes no secret of his displeasure with the quality of some of the productions. "The most popular person was probably the worst performer," he says of the recent fund-raising gala, an annual Ed Sullivan-like variety show and dinner that included a Russian ballerina, a teenage prodigy-violinist and crowd-pleasers like Art Garfunkel singing "Bridge Over Troubled Water." "I want it to be better."
He enumerates his objections to a proposed all-Richard Rodgers gala, saying, "What I don't want is just a C-list of people singing 'Oh, what a Beautiful Morning.' " As for a possible Prague festival, Mr. Kaiser says, "You're going to have to find funding for it because I don't think it's going to sell one ticket." 
Mr. Kaiser's congenial public persona masks a tightly wound perfectionist with an inclination to worry and a determination to have things go his way. He never eats during working lunches and dinners. He frets about whether his tie is too loud. He has turned up two hours early for important appointments. 
At the Royal Opera House, he brought a cup of English Breakfast tea to one visiting conductor before every performance. And he was so scarred by the technical failures at Covent Garden after its $360 million renovation that even now he stays backstage during performances. 
"Michael may have humility and may be gentle and charming, but he is absolutely hard-hitting in what he wants to achieve," says Anthony Russell-Roberts, administrative director of the Royal Ballet. "He's unsentimental about his objective." 
Mr. Kaiser, who is 47, says he has no personal life. He is close to his sister Susan, to whom he donated a kidney 12 years ago. Despite widespread speculation in London that he left to rejoin a partner in the United States, there is no partner, people close to him say. He unwinds by watching sitcoms and sports on television. "I am so pathetic that I even watch golf," he says, "and I don't play golf."
Addicted to work, he is in the office at 6:30 every morning and at performances or events five or six evenings a week. He spent his vacation on Mykonos last summer (his first in five years), writing the first half of his book about his 16 years running arts organizations. He completed it several weeks ago, submitted it to an agent (who is also a Kennedy Center board member), and intends to use it as a marketing tool.
DESPITE Mr. Kaiser's background in management, he is knowledgeable about what goes on the stage. The son of German-born Jews who fled Germany in 1938, Mr. Kaiser grew up in New Rochelle, N.Y., and learned classical music at Saturday rehearsals of the New York Philharmonic, in which his grandmother's third husband was a violinist.
Longing to become an opera singer, Mr. Kaiser sang as a junior cantor at his synagogue and spent his senior year in high school at the Manhattan School of Music. After a brief stint at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (his parents wanted him to get a broad liberal-arts education), he applied to the Manhattan School's college-level program. He was rejected. "I was devastated," he writes in his unpublished book. "I reasoned that if I were not good enough to get into this school, then I simply would not be good enough to have a career as a singer." He studied economics at Brandeis University instead, writing his thesis on the economics of regional opera companies, and later received a master's degree in management from M.I.T. A big regret is that he didn't study conducting. "I think I would have been good," he says.
A job hopper, Mr. Kaiser founded his own consulting firm, Michael M. Kaiser Associates, in Washington in 1981 and ran it from his Georgetown townhouse. A collapse from exhaustion in 1985 contributed to a decision to sell his business and become general manager of the Kansas City Ballet, where his annual salary was less than his weekly income had been.
After serving as the associate director of the Pierpont Morgan Library in New York between 1987 and 1989, Mr. Kaiser became executive director of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation. He rescued it from a $1.5 million deficit and unpaid bills, using sometimes ruthless tactics, including persuading the board (half of whose members donated only $500 a year) to increase the minimum donation to $10,000. 
After another stint in consulting for performing arts organizations, he became executive director of American Ballet Theater, serving from 1995 to 1998. There he grappled with $5 million in debts and back taxes, giving up his salary for a year and making hundreds of thousands of dollars in personal loans and then hundreds of thousands in personal gifts as part of his mission to bail the company out.
He then became executive director of the Royal Opera House, where, as the fourth director in two years, he was greeted by a $30 million deficit, a troubled renovation and hostility from large segments of the British press. The low point, he says, came after technical problems at the new Opera House forced changes of repertory and even cancellations of performances, including one for school children. A teacher assigned her students to write essays on "Why We Hate the Royal Opera House." One began, "Dear Mr. Kaiser, we wish you were dead," he recalls.
Wounded by the criticism and lonely, he spent much of his work day watching the stage from a small window near his office and helping with the scenery and sets. After overseeing the renovation, virtually eliminating the budget deficit and creating an endowment fund, he decided to leave. "He didn't acclimatize," Mr. Vilar says. "His friends weren't there. I wish I had been there five nights a week to have dinner with him." 
But some in the press recognized the viability of his reforms and regretted his departure. And some of his former colleagues find it hard to forgive him for not staying longer. At a garden party for the Royal Ballet at the British ambassador's residence in Washington in June, Dame Antoinette Sibley, the dancer, taps his hand with her finger and says, "You should have stayed another couple of years."
Backstage at the Kennedy Center the next evening for opening night of the Royal Ballet, Mash Corrigan, a stagehand, tells him, "What you did in two years, they've destroyed in six months."
"No, no, that's not true, Mash," Mr. Kaiser protests. But he confesses that he broke a pledge he had made to the board to stay until 2004. 
Mr. Kaiser has a five-year contract at the Kennedy Center, the first contract in his life, earning more than $400,000 a year. He talks about staying until the expansion is finished, which will take a minimum of 10 years. Even if he does a great job, though, he will still be doing it in a city where, on the list of what's important, the performing arts sit far below governing, politicking, lobbying and litigating.
"When people in New York think of Washington, they think of museums and stale government," says Eric D. Schaeffer, artistic director of the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., who will be the artistic director for the Sondheim festival. "The Kennedy Center cannot just offer another touring production of 'Kiss Me Kate.' Michael's trying to change that with programming that's really exciting and challenging."
Tickets for a touring production of "Kiss Me Kate," which opens at the Kennedy Center this month, are now on sale.

How Managing the Arts Can Itself Be an Art
Following are excerpts from "Putting It Together: Reflections of an Arts Manager," a yet-to-be-published book by Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the Kennedy Center:

THE KANSAS CITY BALLET
For marketing purposes, we focused on "Sleeping Beauty." We knew that there would be demand for this classic. But we also knew we had never sold more than 60 percent of our seats for any repertory program and that was simply not enough. Through discussion and negotiation we found the group that should be the best friend of every ballet company: the Girl Scouts of America. We brought thousands of young girls at reduced prices to the Winter Program. In fact, we sold over 90 percent of our seats and the final performance, a Sunday matinee, was completely sold out.

PIERPONT MORGAN LIBRARY
The Morgan functioned not unlike a 19th-century club. There was a palpable distaste for popular culture of any sort and, in a way, for the public. When we mounted a very successful exhibition of the drawings and manuscripts of Beatrix Potter, for example, the curators sniffed that there were too many people, especially children, in the galleries.

ALVIN AILEY
While many people knew the name Ailey, they were not really clear about the merits opf the organization and what it stood for. (This fact became extremely clear to me when we received dozens of letters of condolence on the passing of Alex Hailey, the author of "Roots." Many members of the public thought Alex Hailey and Alvin Ailey were one and the same person.)

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER
One vendor, a small shoe manufacturer, camped out in my office and said he would not leave until I paid him. He told me his wife and children were hungry. It made our debts appear so much more personal and dangerous than I had ever experienced before. I wrote him a personal check for our debt to him. A "friend" from a ballet-clothing supplier wrote me a fax to welcome me to A.B.T., and attached her unpaid invoices. We had run out of toe shoes and no manufacturer would give us more on credit. We had no Xerox paper. We took out every second light bulb to save on electricity. Welcome to the glamorous world of the arts.

THE ROYAL OPERA HOUSE
It was difficult to explain my loneliness to my friends in New York when all they could hear was the meetings with royalty and the dinners with celebrities.

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 4

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Sublets; 
Sublease Space Surges Onto Market in Manhattan

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
SUBLEASE space is flooding onto the market in Manhattan, as dot-com and telecommunications companies go out of business or greatly shrink their operations. According to a survey by Julien J. Studley Inc., a brokerage that specializes in representing tenants, there is more than 10 million square feet of sublease space currently on the market, compared with slightly less than 2 million square feet a year ago.
 And it is not just empty space. Many of the dot-coms and telecommunications companies were richly financed by venture capitalists during their brief existences, and they equipped their offices with state-of-the art telephone systems, computers and furnishings. 
 Unlike conventional office deals where a tenant leases empty space and negotiates with the landlord for a contribution toward building the interior, the furnished space is an attraction to companies that can save their share of construction costs and move in without waiting. 
The current climate of economic uncertainty is making these finished spaces all the more attractive, said Marc R. Shapses, a senior managing director of the Studley firm, who recently brokered a deal for Chanin Capital Partners, a financial services company, to move into 12,000 square feet of space at 330 Madison Avenue.
"In the climate of 2001, people are saying, 'Let's be conservative and not invest a lot of money fixing up space,' " he said. "In the late 1990's, people lost sight of expenses and invested heavily in space."
The space at 330 Madison, which is at 42nd Street, was given up by Cypress Communications Inc., an Atlanta-based provider of broadband communications services in large office buildings. Earlier this year the company announced it was scaling back its marketing efforts so that it would not need additional rounds of financing, which was becoming increasingly difficult to obtain.
Instead of seeking to wire buildings in 28 cities, the company said it would concentrate on only seven metropolitan areas, and New York is not one of them.
The offices, on the 11th floor of the building, are nicely furnished, with executive offices on the outer rim and cubicles for workers in the interior. They also provide an indication of how fast things can change in the technology business. Some of the telephones are connected, but others are still in boxes on the desks and it appears that the space was never occupied.
Sublets like this are difficult to arrange, Mr. Shapses said, because landlords have to give their approval of the arrangement in most cases. And many prospective users of the abandoned space do not want to become the tenant of a fading or failing dot-com or communications company.
SIMILARLY, most high-tech companies are not eager to get into the real estate business and would prefer to leave the space and their lease obligations behind. "What the previous tenant really wants is to get off the hook," Mr. Shapses said.
The landlord in this case, Vornado Realty Trust, was willing to restructure the deal, Mr. Shapses said, and Cypress was written out of the picture and Chanin reached a deal directly with the landlord.
Another complication is the size of the deposit a new tenant must offer the landlord to get sublease space. Many dot-coms were forced to post letters of credit of two to three years rent to get space because of their lack of experience and credit standing.
"Landlords do not want anything less secure, even if the new tenant has better credit," said Michael J. Monahan, an executive managing director with Insignia/ESG. He said the big letter of credit was something of a tradeoff for being able to move into space built at someone else's expense. In such a case, he added, it is important to negotiate terms that reduce the deposit after four or five years of rental payments.
In many cases, landlords are still collecting rent on space available for sublease, and they are reluctant to jeopardize the rents they are able to charge for space they lease directly to tenants by having the sublets offered as bargains. According to a recent report by Grubb & Ellis, the real estate services company, most leases contain clauses barring tenants from offering sublease space at a rental rate lower that the one stated for direct space in the building. 
Although the sublet space may eventually rent for less than direct space, this does not show up in rent statistics, which are based on published asking rents. 
Much of the sublet space is concentrated downtown, said Ruth Colp-Haber, a partner in Wharton Property Advisors, with trophy buildings in Midtown unaffected because their owners routinely refuse to lease space to any company without well-established credit.
The availability of sublease space means that some buildings that are listing only modest amounts of vacant space really have a lot more empty floors. For example, Ms. Colp-Haber said, the building at 33 Whitehall Street has only 3 percent of its space available for direct leasing, but when sublease space is added the building is 42 percent available.
Other downtown buildings with substantial direct and sublease space availabilities, Ms. Colp-Haber said, include 100 Broadway, with 34 percent; 75 Varick Street, with 43 percent; and 233 Broadway, with 22 percent.
In Midtown, buildings with high combined space availabilities, according to Ms. Colp-Haber, include 330 West 34th Street, with 30 percent; 9 West 57th, at 41 percent; and 111 West 40th Street, at 25 percent.
The flood of sublet space, which has increased by about seven million square feet since the end of last year, is affecting the entire market for office space and increasing the negotiating power of tenants, said James Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a brokerage that specializes in representing tenants.
"Sublets have increased to 20 percent of total availability as a result of the stock market, the squeeze on corporate earnings and the bursting of the Internet bubble," he said. He noted that the increased availability of these spaces was putting pressure on landlords to offer concession to attract tenants even in the strongest parts of the city.
"Landlords in the Plaza District are offering $35 a square foot for interior work and six months free rent," he said, referring to the general area between Third and Fifth Avenue in the 50's. "Eight months ago it was one month of free rent and nothing for work."
Mr. Meiskin said the office rental market had been "artificially high" in recent years as dot-coms, communications concerns and other start-up companies scrambled for limited space in Manhattan. He said space in marginal locations, like downtown, SoHo and the far west side of Manhattan, will be unable to sustain recent rent levels as more sublease and direct space comes on the market.
"Space in downtown and 12th Avenue was never worth $50 a foot," he said. "Just a few years ago that space was going for $8 to $12 a foot."
Sometimes moving into prebuilt space can be a mixed blessing, Mr. Monahan observed. He said he brokered a deal under which Fulcrum Global Partners, a financial services company, took over space at 535 Madison Avenue at 54th Street that was once occupied by eColony, an Internet company.
Much of the space is usable as is, but Fulcrum had to go the trouble of demolishing some interior offices to set up a securities trading floor. "Usually when you start to demolish a space, it is best to blow it all out and start over," Mr. Mohahan said.
But he said the configuration of the building and the quality of the existing installation made it more economical for Michael Petrycki, the chief executive of Fulcrum, to retain the perimeter offices as they were.
"Mike decided to put his money into the trading floor and some supplemental air-conditioning and kept the rest of the floor intact, taking advantage of what was there," Mr. Monahan said.
He said the cost of building offices for Internet companies ranged from $125 to $200 a square foot, because of the need for intensive wiring and telecommunications connections. By taking advantage of what was already in place, Fulcrum was able to focus its resources on the trading floor and reduce its overall expenditure. "He probably saved $30 to $50 a square foot," Mr. Monahan said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Commercial Property column on July 1, about the sublease market in Manhattan, reported an outdated figure for space available at 9 West 57th Street. The building's owner, Sheldon H. Solow, said the correct figure is 19.5 percent, including both space directly available and sublet space, not 41 percent.

HEADLINE: Who Died? Me, but Fiddle-de-dee, My Chin Is Up 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the scene in "Gone With the Wind" where Scarlett and Melanie huddle in a horse-drawn buggy at the Atlanta train station, frantically scouring the latest list of Civil War dead? Ashley! Ashley! Would his name be there? 
 Well, fiddle-de-dee, I sure can relate. 
 A few months ago, I felt a Southern swoon coming on as the chief executive of the company where I worked unexpectedly asked employees to join him in a conference room. On the table in front of him was the list of casualties. He handed out the list and, like Melanie, I scoured each name: Not me; not me; not me; not me; not me; not me. Me. 
Since that dramatic scene, I've tried to handle my status as a statistic pragmatically. Me: "Do you really think you're not going to find a job for the rest of your life?" Me: "Of course not!" So, because I have nothing better to do, I've been keeping a journal of the good days and bad days. Welcome to it.
Day 1: Who died? It's like I'm in the receiving line at a funeral home. Co-workers are coming up to me, taking my hands in theirs, and looking deep into my eyes. I'm sure they are sincere in their sympathy. But, come on, I know what they're thinking, "Phew, better her than me!"
Day 8: I arrive 10 minutes late for a company-sponsored workshop with a career counselor. I am stressed. So, I take it as a good sign that the first session is, "How to Manage Stress After Being Laid Off." The counselor brings me up to speed: "We're all talking about the things we'll miss about our jobs." I immediately think: money, self-esteem, and health insurance. She has already written on the board the first three things that came to mind for my colleagues: Starbucks coffee, free soda, and long-distance phone calls. Hello? Did our careers not just nose dive? Or did we all lose a really neat baby-sitting gig?
Day 9: A co-worker loans me her copy of "Who Moved My Cheese?" the best-selling parable about two mice, Sniff and Scurry, and two "littlepeople," Hem and Haw, who react differently when their cheese -- a metaphor for whatever you want in life -- is gone. There is no doubt that I am Sniff, the superior mouse who was ready to find new cheese the minute he found out his old cheese was gone. I ask my husband to read the book so we can discuss it. 
Day 10: I have an argument with my husband at the breakfast table. He said he is Sniff because he saw all this coming and tried to warn me. He then melts my cheddar by saying I am so Hem, who is so taken aback when his cheese is gone that he doesn't do anything and almost dies of starvation. I return the book to my friend and buy "What Color is Your Parachute?" the career-counseling book, which I hide from my husband.
Day 15: The first recruiter to call me in for an interview took one look at my resume and said, "Right off the bat, take out this part about having 25 years' experience." Because? I ask. "They'll think you're set in your ways." Because I am set in my ways, I leave it in.
Days 22, 23, 24: The job offers are pouring in! And, I'd be happy with any one of them -- if I were graduating from college. I'm 46 years old. My salary hasn't been $40,000 since 1989, for pity's sake! Does anyone out there still have a nice, fat payroll? Call me.
Day 25: People say I'm not networking enough, so I send e-mail messages to church friends, relatives in foreign countries, even our veterinarian. In the subject line I put: "Will Write for Food." Here's what I get back: "Better days are ahead!" "These things happen for a reason!" "One door closes and another one opens!" And, my personal favorite: "Chin up!" But nowhere in these inspiring words is a job offer.
Day 32: And so it goes. It's been mostly good days so far, as I keep my chin up and search for open doors. As for the bad days: Well, frankly, my dears, I don't give a damn. After all, tomorrow is another day.

HEADLINE: Round-Trip Retirement: Back to the Island 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Ruth and Albert Ammerman packed their bags and moved to Arizona 15 years ago, they thought they would never see another Long Island winter.
 As a reminder of what they had left behind, the couple framed a photograph of the house of the president of Suffolk County Community College, where they had lived for most of the 22 years that Dr. Ammerman held that title. They hung the picture, snapped in the wake of a 1965 snowstorm, on a wall in their sun-drenched den. 
 Dr. Ammerman, now 86, promised his cars they would never have to endure another shoveling and scraping ordeal, and the couple settled into a new town house in Sun Lakes, a gated complex southeast of Phoenix with five golf courses, six swimming pools and 15,000 residents, most of whom built their lives and careers elsewhere before flocking to sunnier skies. 
But then things changed. As the Ammermans grew older, the sun that had lured them southwestward in the first place became oppressive. The four golf groups that Dr. Ammerman had quickly joined upon arriving began to disintegrate over the years, as his golfing buddies passed away, moved away or simply grew too old to enjoy the game. Before he knew it, only one of the cliques was still intact, and Dr. Ammerman's own skills were diminishing, a development that saddened him.
Most of all, the couple missed their children, three of whom live in New York State, including one son who lives in Port Jefferson. 
So in May, the Ammermans once again packed their possessions -- which by this point included a Navajo rug and a modest collection of Native American pottery -- and moved back to Long Island. In June, they settled into a two-bedroom apartment in Jefferson's Ferry, a new South Setauket development that offers independent living, assisted living and nursing home care but looks more like a five-star hotel, with a winding staircase in the lobby and plush carpeting in the suites. 
On a recent afternoon, the photograph of the snow-draped college president's house leaned against a wall in the Ammermans' new apartment, for future hanging.
"As you get older, I think you want to be back home," said Mrs. Ammerman, 80.
Next door, Martha E. Wright, 82, who lived on Long Island from 1946 until 1989, was still unpacking the boxes full of artwork and sewing supplies that had arrived from Charlottesville, Va., a "delightful place" that she had decided to leave shortly after her second husband died. And in a nearby apartment, also at Jefferson's Ferry, Anita and William Kuhn spent a recent afternoon detailing their exodus from Long Island to North Carolina and back. 
"My mother and dad decided to move to Florida in '71, and they just packed up and moved," said Mr. Kuhn, 76. "They didn't look back." 
Most retirees who head to Florida or Arizona seeking sun, low prices and companions with whom to share hours around a bridge table or on a golf course, do so with the expectation that they will stay there. But for some Long Islanders -- a growing number, some developers believe, although there are no statistics to support the collective hunch -- this is not the case. 
Many retirees are finding the Sun Belt is not necessarily the paradise they had expected. In North Carolina, the gripe is about too many snakes and hurricanes. In Boca Raton, they complain that about uniformity -- too many old people just like them. And some retirees say that the older they get, the more they would rather be playing with grandchildren in the snow than sitting alone on a beach.
Long Island planners and developers say that anecdotal evidence leads them to suspect a trend.
"It was much more of a one-way trip 10 years ago," said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist at the Long Island Association, the regional chamber of commerce. Nowadays, she said, retirees are discovering that Sun Belt retirement communities are not necessarily the paradise they had envisioned. "They miss their families, their children or they miss their friends, or they miss their way of life here," she said. 
"I think there's some dissatisfaction with the public services in some of the Sun Belt communities," Dr. Kamer said. "It's starting to experience some of the problems of urbanization that we experienced earlier."
Peter G. Florey, the vice president of Benjamin Development Company, said that 75 percent of the Garden City company's developments were geared toward the elderly;, 25 years ago, the percentage was 25 percent, he said.
"I definitely think there's been an increase, and I think it's attributable to the availability now," he said. "A lot of the frail elderly who have gone to Florida who now need additional care are also coming back to Long Island because that's where their families are, and that's where they feel the best care is."
Roy A. Fedelem, principal planner for the Long Island Regional Planning Board, estimated that of the 178 Long Island housing developments with age restrictions, usually 55 or over, 60 were built since 1990. Twelve more such developments are under construction, he estimated. 
While the regional planning board does not track assisted living complexes, which vary widely in their offerings, Mr. Fedelem said that they were largely a phenomenon of the last decade. 
Gauging the number of elderly citizens who return to Long Island after initially retiring elsewhere, however, is a tricky task. There are no hard statistics, and it is a phenomenon that even the experts say is difficult to track for a population the size of Long Island's.
Far from being a novel development, "counterstream migration" is a prominent feature of migration in general, said Charles F. Longino, Jr., a gerontologist who in 1984 first documented the phenomenon of retirees moving from Florida to New York, using 1980 census data.
"Counterstream exchanges between states -- that is, migrants moving in two directions between states -- are extremely common among movers in general," said Dr. Longino, who directs the Reynolda Gerontology Program at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C. "Apparently it occurs with older people as well."
In fact, Dr. Longino said, while substantially more people moved from New York to Florida between 1985 and 1990 than between 1975 and 1980, the countermigration had "leveled off" between the same two periods.
But demographers have not had the opportunity to study the 2000 census data on migration patterns, which are expected to be released next year at the earliest. Moreover, Dr. Longino's studies have examined New York state in general but not Long Island in particular. 
"The counterstream migration to Long Island may be increasing while it may be decreasing in other places in the state," the gerontologist suggested. But to the developers' suggestion that the building of retirement villages makes countermigration a more attractive option, Dr. Longino said it was more likely that the developments had enabled observers to more easily spot a phenomenon that existed previously.
"Before, they were just scattered out in neighborhoods," Dr. Longino said. "They just weren't noticed as much."
Angela G. Kubicki, 72, had always taken for granted that she would one day retire to Florida. But after five years in a Boynton Beach ranch-style home with a guest house and a pool, Ms. Kubicki and her boyfriend, Ken Doyle, have decided to relocate to the Hamptons.
If the reverse migration is not a trend, well then, in Ms. Kubicki's eyes, it should be. 
"All that glitters is not gold," she warned, talking on the telephone as she waited for one of her sons and his family to come over for ravioli and meatballs. Since Ms. Kubicki returned from Florida in early June, she has been staying at her other son's Smithtown home.
First, there was the frustratingly constant weather. "I decorated the house for Christmas and decorated with pumpkins for Halloween, but we had no seasons," she lamented. 
Then there were the lizards. "You can walk out and they'll be on your head," she reported. "I'm not exaggerating. They come crawling out of the air-conditioning."
She terribly missed her four children, three of whom live on Long Island. Plus, the Florida lifestyle just became too much -- or not enough. 
"How much can you go to the flea market?" Ms. Kubicki asked. "How much can you go to the beach? How much can you go to the shows? In the end you'll say, 'I can always go to Florida, but there's no place like home.' " 
Changes in tax laws, in particular the rolling back of the federal estate tax, may lure more retired Long Island natives back to their home turf, said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. 
"Those who have fled New York because of the tax issue can easily come back again, and I suspect they'll contribute to the reverse migration," he said.
Whatever it is that ultimately pulls a retiree back to Long Island, the unanticipated consequences of the return are often the most striking. 
For Dr. Ammerman, for example, the return to Suffolk County was a return to notoriety. During a recent hospital visit here, most of the nurses and technicians he encountered were Suffolk County Community College graduates, and they knew his name well. 
That sort of thing did not happen out West, Dr. Ammerman said, adding, "I became Al in Arizona."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After 15 years in Arizona, Albert and Ruth Ammerman have returned to the Island. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Computer Associates: 2 Widely Diverging Views

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
ERIC R. SKELL recalls the two years he worked as a network systems administrator for Computer Associates as a low point in his career.
 This is his account: He joined Computer Associates' Princeton, N.J., office in September 1998 and worked there until January 2001. During much of his time there, the computer industry was at the height of its Y2K preparations, and Mr. Skell was on call around the clock for most of 1999. He regularly worked evenings, weekends and holidays without additional pay. Yet when he asked to use two weeks of vacation time to return to his native Australia to visit his terminally ill sister in November 1999, he was refused. Postponing the trip, Mr. Skell ended up working required overtime during the Thanksgiving holiday. 
 Mr. Skell finally made the trip last July. "I got a phone call from my sister, and she said she'd rather I came now to see her than come to her funeral," Mr. Skell said. "I told the company I couldn't wait. When I got there she weighed maybe 90 pounds." 
His sister died soon afterward, on July 22. "After she died I told my boss, who said he was sorry to hear about it," Mr. Skell said. "That was it. Otherwise, there was no compassion whatsoever, not even a card, from any other manager."
Mr. Skell, 42, said he was fired a few months later because of an unsatisfactory performance rating, which he disputes. He is currently living on unemployment while searching for a new job. 
Asked about Mr. Skell's account, Jeanne Donovan, a spokeswoman for Computers Associates, which is based in Islandia, refused to comment directly. "C.A. always strives to be a caring and responsible employer," she said, "and many well-respected organizations continue to recognize C.A. as a top workplace for employees."
Bitter accounts like Mr. Skell's have circulated on Long Island and beyond for years, mostly in private conversations. When voiced publicly, they have invariably been denied with vehemence by Charles Wang, Computer Associates' founder and chairman; by Sanjay Kumar, Mr. Wang's protege and the company's president and chief executive; and by other company officials.
Now, a high-profile proxy fight waged by a minority shareholder from Texas has put Computer Associates policies, corporate culture and business reputation at the center of a very public campaign aimed at prying control of the world's fourth-largest software company out of the hands of Mr. Wang and the directors who support him. 
"Employees are abused, and this is widely known on Long Island and elsewhere," said Sam Wyly, a founder of Sterling Software in Dallas who sold his company to Computer Associates in April 2000 in a stock transaction. Two weeks ago, he announced plans to challenge Mr. Wang by nominating an independent slate of candidates for Computer Associates directors, to be elected at the shareholders' meeting on Aug. 29.
What Mr. Wyly called the company's "pervasive culture of fear and intimidation" has "abused and alienated" not only its 18,000 employees worldwide, but customers and shareholders as well, he said in statement. "At the same time," the Wyly statement continued, "management's use of accounting gimmicks and its excessive compensation for lackluster performance have strained its credibility with the financial community."
Mr. Wyly said a survey he commissioned from a polling firm in Manhattan showed that 46 percent of Computer Associates' customers would like to end their relationship with the company and that only a third of its customers believe the company is honest. The survey was conducted by Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates, which interviewed 76 men and women selected at random from a list of Fortune 1000 executives. As it turned out, 52 of the executives work for companies that are current Computer Associates customers, 8 were former customers and 16 of the companies have never brought from Computer Associates. The interviews were conducted by telephone June 11 through 15; the margin of sampling error is plus or minus 10 percentage points.
Computer Associates challenged the results of the survey in a statement issued on Tuesday, calling the research "fundamentally flawed and self-serving." 
Mr. Kumar said in the Tuesday statement that "good enough is never good enough" and that the company had made "significant strides in recent years" in focusing on customer needs.
Mr. Wyly has accused the company's directors of neglecting their responsibilities by approving incentive pay for the company's senior executives while investment returns lagged behind the rest of the industry.
Mr. Wyly's accusations have resonated widely. Most of the Island's power brokers have kept their distance from the battle. Calls to two Computer Associates board members with close ties to Mr. Wang, former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Shirley Strum Kenny, the president of the State University at New York at Stony Brook, were unavailing. Mr. D'Amato said through a spokesman last week that he would have no comment, and Dr. Kenny's office said that she was out of town and not available. 
E. Christopher Murray, a partner in the Garden City law firm of Reisman, Peirez & Reisman, said he was forming a coalition to defend Computer Associates from what he described as "strategic damage to the region's economy" if Mr. Wang's directors were ousted. Mr. Murray said last Wednesday that five groups, including the Long Island Association, the Association for a Better Long Island and the Long Island Philharmonic, had joined the coalition.
"Regardless of how you feel about the company or its corporate culture, they are a critical component of Long Island's 21st-century economy," Mr. Murray said.
If Mr. Wyly's candidates are elected to the board, "it would have a profound and negative impact throughout the region equivalent to Grumman's shutting down at the height of the cold war," he added.
Savio Chan, a vice president of Invision, a software and Internet company in Commack, said that Mr. Wang in particular was a motivational leader.
"He is very supportive of Chinese-American entrepreneurs," said Mr. Chan, 37, who recalled that Mr. Wang encouraged him to open his own computer store 12 years ago and even arrived without fanfare one Sunday to see the store for himself. "He inspires many people to take action, to become entrepreneurs and then give back to charity themselves, as he does."
James Citrin, a management consultant who praised Computer Associates in his book, "Lessons From the Top: 50 Most Successful Business Leaders in America" (Doubleday, 2001), described Mr. Wang as a sensitive, likable man concerned with philosophical issues and community service. "There is a real contrast between Charles Wang personally and the organizational culture of Computer Associates," Mr. Citrin said.
Observing that the company's growth has largely come through strategic acquisitions, Mr. Citrin said: "In many cases acquisitions are handled without attention to the emotional and human needs of employees. Often, everybody other than the sales force is let go."
In his book, researched during the late 90's, Mr. Citrin presents Mr. Wang as a visionary leader and exceptional communicator who follows "a moral compass." Now, he said, he saw Mr. Wang in a different light.
"One of the attributes of a great leader and a great company is a complete consistency between what they say and what they do," Mr. Citrin said. "At Computer Associates I see a conflict that can't help but undermine their company."

HEADLINE: An Art Show Worth Honking At 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DALEY 

 BODY:
CARS are parked all over Stamford this summer -- on the front lawns of corporate headquarters, on busy intersections and boulevards, tucked under the trees in the city's parks, or parked smack in the middle of pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk.
 Seventy clever little Fiberglas cars, each one original, sponsored by businesses and organizations based in Stamford and designed by local artists with a sense of humor. These are Stamford's Art-O-Mobiles, on display through Aug. 31. 
 The fleet of auto-art is part of Art in Public Places, exhibitions that are dreamed up, executed and maintained by Stamford Downtown Special Services District, a nonprofit corporation whose mission is to revitalize downtown.
"Art is a great money generator," said the district's executive director, Sandy Goldstein, "and outdoor exhibits bring visitors. They walk around, find things to do, shop, have dinner." 
The exhibit is a fund-raising event organized by the Downtown Special Services District and the City of Stamford. To sponsor a car cost $6,500, $2,000 of which goes to the artist. At the end of the summer, the cars will be auctioned off by Sotheby's and the money given to charities of the sponsors' choosing. The Stamford CowParade last year earned nearly $400,000 for local charities.
"When I was on-site doing some finishing touches, dozens of people stopped to stare and ask questions," said Miggs Burroughs, a commercial artist who created one of the cars. "Families, kids, deliverymen, workers, policemen -- they all stopped. Whether they know it or not, the cars are steering people to an appreciation of art and the process, and the whole community benefits."'
Nina Bentley was one of the artists who created a cow for last year's CowParade, and she created two art-o-mobiles. In fact, it was a group of artists who thought up the idea of using a car. "There were about a dozen of us cow artists," Ms. Bentley said. "We considered chairs, dogs, shoes." 
The group settled on cars, and Gordon Micunis, designer of stage sets, costumes, private homes, hotel lobbies, and restaurants, created the prototype. Area artists were invited to submit designs, which were bound in a book from which potential sponsors could choose. There was the "Road Hog," which looks like a pig, "Hanging Carden" with vines and flowers, "Autobiography," Miggs Burroughs' car wrapped in script that tells the story of Henry Ford's life and "Sundae-Driver" with a cherry on top, created by two juniors at Stamford High School, Vitti and Nicole Bushley.
The idea for one of the cars came not from an artist but from Paul Kauffman, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield of Connecticut, which has been headquartered in downtown Stamford for 25 years. It was his idea to have players for the Yankees "auto"-graph a car. James Scinto is the artist who created Cushman & Wakefield's "Hit and Run."
Another crowd favorite is WWF Entertainment's submission, covered with handprints of wrestling superstars like the Undertaker, Stone Cold Steve Austin and Triple H. The car is displayed in a wrestling ring, and the ropes help protect the car from possible vandalism.
"Oh, we don't refer to it as 'vandalism,' " Ms. Bentley said. "People like to touch outdoor exhibits. They can't help themselves, especially children. It's more like tough love."
Tough love will be repaired and the cars refurbished in time for the public auction at the Rich Forum on Oct. 4. For details, call the Downtown Special Services District at (203) 348-5285.

HEADLINE: No Headline 

BYLINE:  By Barbara Crossette

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 28 

 BODY:
A panel of the world's leading financial and development experts called today for a new round of international trade talks devoted primarily to aiding the poor countries too weak to reap any benefits from the growing global economy.
 The panel -- which included Robert Rubin, the former United States treasury secretary, and Ernesto Zedillo, the former president of Mexico - recommended that a ministerial-level World Trade Organization meeting planned for Qatar in November "should set an objective of making trade as free between industrial and developing countries as it already is among the industrial countries." 
 The matter is urgent, the experts said in a report commissioned by Secretary General Kofi Annan and published today, because many poor countries are suffering from a slump in the prices of the basic commodities they produce, and the rich countries are dragging their feet on promises to help open more markets to them.
Mr. Zedillo, the panel's chairman, said at a news conference here today, said that richer nations should see the intractable poverty of so much of the world as an issue of self-interest. 
"In today's global village," he said, "someone else's poverty very soon becomes one's own problem -- a lack of buyers for one's products, illegal immigration, pollution, contagious disease, insecurity, fanaticism and even terrorism."
Mr. Rubin said in an interview after the report's release that it is in the self interest of the rich not only to ease trade but also to increase foreign aid substantially. "And yet, we won't be able to do that unless the public understands the issues," he said. "People aren't focused on these issues. There isn't public awareness." He blames a lack of both political will and media attention for the situation.
"The issues in the developing countries in an ever more integrated globe are going to force themselves on the industrial countries," Mr. Rubin said. "Sooner or later, these issues are going to intrude in our lives to a degree that we are going to be forced to face them and deal with them in a way that we should be dealing with them right now."
Freer trade, the panel said, is crucial to development. "It is notable," the report said, "that at least since the 1960s, every country that has pulled its people out of poverty has made a significant opening to trade a central feature of<0> its economic strategy." The experts said that recently, the commitment to free trade has been growing faster among developing nations than among the wealthier countries that deal with them.
The panel - whose members also include Jacques Delors, former French finance minister and president of the European Commission; Abdulatif Yousef Al-Hammad, president of the Arab Fund for Economic Development; David Bryer, head of the relief agency Oxfam, and Manmohan Singh, who as finance minister of India a decade ago led his country through fundamental economic liberalization - made a series of recommendations for trade reform.
The experts recommended, for example, that tariffs on agricultural products needed more reduction. The report showed that sugar can be produced in developing countries for a third of the cost of producing it in some European countries. But the European Union keeps cheaper sugar out by imposing a tariff of 213 percent.
In a bold move, the report also recommends taking a new look at liberalizing the movement of workers from poor to richer countries, which would be a source of hard currency for developing countries. Some developing nations are pressing the United Nations to hold an international conference on this issue, leading to agreements easing visa rules for employment.
The panel suggests finding ways to control risks in commodity prices, possibly creating an insurance system for poor farmers. It advocates more debt forgiveness, a process that began in richer countries and international lending institutions in 1996, and accepts that a variety of international taxes - on financial transactions, carbon emissions or seabed mining -- might be considered. A meeting to discuss "global taxation" is proposed. The idea has long been anathema to the United States Congress.
On investment in the developing world, the expert panel was critical of many poor nations for contributing to their own problems by failing to strengthen institutions and laws to make themselves more attractive to foreign investors.
"The main responsibility for securing growth and equity, and hence for achieving rapid poverty reduction and human development," the report said, "lies with the countries' policymakers." The experts warned that tax structures must be effective and not subject to corruption, and that a "diverse, well functioning, competitive financial system" was necessary not only to encourage domestic savings but also to give confidence to investors. Accounting and auditing standards had to be raised, the report said. It also endorsed "a competent and corruption-free public service" and "a vibrant and independent press."
Other panel members are Mary Chinery-Hesse, former deputy director general of the International Labor Organization; Rebeca rebeca Grynspan, former vice president of Costa Rica; Alexander Y. Livshits, chairman of the board of the Rossiysky Kredit Bank in Russia; Abdul Magid Osman, a banker who was finance minister of Mozambique, and Masayoshi Son, founder of the Softbank Corporation.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Microsoft Wins A Chance To Focus

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
FOR once, conventional wisdom may have it right. 
 A lot of people assumed that the government's antitrust case against Microsoft would not stand up on appeal, and that a court-ordered breakup of the company would be reversed. 
 A unanimous decision by a federal appeals court last week gave some support to those assumptions.
Still, Microsoft is not out of the legal thicket. And it remains to be seen just how much the decision will help the stock. 
In late February, when the court heard Microsoft's appeal, the stock had already risen by more than 30 percent since the start of the year. In the last three months, it has gained an additional 30 percent. 
Michael E. Stanek, head of West Coast software research at Lehman Brothers, took some time on Thursday to talk about the case and the company. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. What is your take on the Microsoft ruling?

A. The solicitor general, a Bush appointee, is not likely to take this to the Supreme Court.
The appeals court put some pretty tight guidelines on the judge that might take up the case if it goes back to the lower court. The government is going to have to prove there was harm to the consumer, which they never did in the case they argued before Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson.
I think the odds of this being settled and finished by the end of the year are about 70 percent. But we are dealing with so many complexities when the states are factored into the equation that you just don't know. 

Q. Some have argued that uncertainties about the case have put a damper on the entire technology sector. Do you agree?

A. No, I don't. My view is that this was very much a politically driven case. The Clinton administration got generous contributions from venture capitalists and a lot of people in Silicon Valley who cried crocodile tears to see Microsoft get broken up. Clinton helped out his friends, and it slowed Microsoft down for a couple of years.

Q. The appeals court bounced the issue of bundling Microsoft products to its operating system back to the lower court. The company may try much the same strategy for a variety of products on the Internet. The current case is about the past. Should it apply to what is happening now?

A. I think Microsoft will be very careful. If they aren't, they will get in trouble again with someone powerful, like America Online, who has a lot of friends in Washington.

Q. You had a "strong buy" recommendation before the ruling came down. Why?

A. I have been focusing on the upgrade cycle with Windows and Office XP.
In the past, from the day the product ships, every product upgrade cycle at Microsoft has always led to an increase in the stock of between 15 percent and 40 percent. Now, I am not going to say Microsoft stock is going to go up by 40 percent, but if the market and economy pick up, it clearly is an earnings-acceleration story. 
Now that you have removed most of the litigation risk, the company can focus on business fundamentals exclusively. 

Q. But right now the stock is trading at more than 40 times earnings. Isn't it really expensive at these levels?

A. It is probably about fairly valued. I wouldn't look for further multiple expansion, but for earnings to increase.

Q. What are realistic revenue and earnings growth expectations for a company this size?

A. Ten percent to 12 percent revenue growth and 12 percent to 15 percent earnings growth is about what they can do.

Q. The company is banking $1 billion a month and has more than $30 billion in cash. What do you expect that it will do with the money?

A. I think they are going to be acquisitive. I would expect them to look at the Internet space, the applications and storage space and probably the consulting and service space.
I don't think Mr. Gates will use the money to shrink the share base or to issue dividends. 

Q. Is it likely that any acquisitions, particularly large ones, won't happen until after the antitrust case is finally resolved?

A. It would have been imprudent for Microsoft not to have been mentally accruing for settlement payments of something around $1 billion.

Q. Who loses as a result of this decision and its likely outcome?

A. A defanged Microsoft would have been helpful to a lot of people. But in the short term I don't think there is any de facto loser. Oracle and Sun Microsystems will find it really difficult over the next five to seven years.

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
A Day at the Races Offers a Checkup As Another Pit Stop

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
I had my body in line for a free checkup at Pfizer's traveling men's health inspection station last Memorial Day weekend when I started talking to Phil Koon, a 41-year-old tool-and-die maker. This was the day before the Coca Cola 600 in Concord, N.C. Like a lot of Nascar fans, Koon hadn't seen a doctor for preventive maintenance in years. Other men waiting with us said their companies tested their blood annually, but mostly for drug use. 
 Still, Koon had a quibble. He said he would prefer if the Winston Cup car that Pfizer sponsored -- Mark Martin's No. 6 Ford -- bore only the drug company's name and not its $1.3 billion men's drug. Koon is not comfortable giving Viagra hats and T-shirts to the children of friends back home in Erie, Pa. His was a minority opinion; the crowd outside Martin's souvenir trailer that day was far thicker than the one outside the men's health pit stop. 
 Next weekend, when the second half of the Nascar season begins with a new broadcast team and a return to Daytona, the Pfizer Tune-Up for Life mobile unit will be waiting outside the track near a parking lot, an oasis of health in a sport that runs on noxious fumes, beer, paranoia and controlled aggression. At least 60 percent of Nascar fans are men, according to industry statistics, and my own unscientific eyeballing would have at least 60 percent of those men smoking, drinking and defiantly, often shirtlessly, overweight. 
"It's the right population to reach with a health message," said Geoff Cook, a Pfizer spokesman, delicately. "And since we've had a 31 percent jump in the number of people screened since last year, our first year, I think we've made a connection."
This is Pfizer's second year as a Nascar sponsor and medical screening presence, its first year sponsoring Martin, a fanatically fit 42-year-old who shows up routinely to get his finger stuck. Inside the 50-foot, cheery screening trailer, lab techs check blood pressure and take blood for cholesterol and glucose tests. Men are also given a five-question "sexual health inventory" questionnaire that concentrates on erectile function. While waiting in a tent outside the trailer for blood-test results, men can read brochures on various Pfizer pharmaceuticals, including Viagra and Zoloft, an antidepressant that is also marketed as a treatment for panic disorders. 
The dozen men and a few wives and girlfriends I spoke with were all Nascar fans who showed up because Pfizer has been advertising the promotion and because it was conveniently located between the parking lot and the speedway entrance. They were overly casual ("It's free, right?") although the women tended to wink a lot. Nobody wanted to talk about Viagra or Zoloft; in this meaty world, everyone was suddenly cholesterol conscious. 
But then, Nascar is a river town on the banks of denial. Heading into the second half, no one wants to think about NBC losing the ratings Fox built, about the eventual end of the posthumous Dale Earnhardt boom (think Elvis, Princess Di), the economy's effect on sponsorship and the ongoing, nongoing safety issue. 
Hey, I'm not worrying. My glucose, cholesterol and blood pressure stats were fine. But Phil Koon's cholesterol was not as good as he had thought; actually he hadn't been thinking about it. The numbers got him a free chat with Dr. Mark Lenderman, one of the local primary care physicians that Pfizer hires for the day. Drugs like Viagra and Zoloft make the family doctor the go-to guy for pharmaceutical companies; they are the prescribers. The doctors also advise anyone who scores dysfunctionally on the erectile inventory to see a family doctor. Dr. Lenderman gave Koon a mini-lecture on how he could lower and control his cholesterol through exercise and nutrition. 
Koon, who gets to three or four Nascar races a year, had been camping for the past 10 days in a nearby field with 100 other Pennsylvanians. He seemed grateful for the wake-up call. According to John Theriot, the on-site manager of the Pfizer facility, one of nine clients sees a doctor, usually because of high cholesterol. Several times, ambulances have been called. 
Dr. Lenderman said that the Nascar fans reflected his own blue-collar practice. 
"This is the working insured," he said. "They work hard, 40 to 60 hours a week in a sedentary job. Many of them relax by eating and watching TV. In general, they are a lot less preoccupied with healthy living than urban folks." 
Dr. Lenderman, who grew up near the Nascar track in Martinsville, Va., has been in Asheville, N.C., for the past 10 years. A lean, fit 37-year-old, he is philosophical about his role in changing lifetime habits. 
"I just saw a woman whose blood sugar was out of control," he said. "She told me she can't afford her diabetes pills. I thought about how expensive Nascar tickets are. I don't know the answer to the question. When you're extending your life by giving up habits, are you always increasing the quality of your life?"
I wondered what I was missing, so I walked over to the Winston booth and tried to sign up for free cigarettes. But I was rejected. Along with proof of age, you had to prove you were already a smoker by showing an open pack. I hadn't opened a pack in 30 years. So I slunk off to the press box where the Marlboros and Camels are free, no questions asked.

The Series So Far
This is the 14th article in a series following auto racing. Previous articles were about Nascar's appeal to a crossover audience, death on the track, religion under the checkered flag, midget racing, life in the pits and the costs of sponsorship.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Land of Monopolies

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
AFTER Thursday's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which threw out out District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's order to break up Microsoft, the big question seemed to be: Who won? It's an interesting question, given that the court agreed with Judge Jackson that Microsoft was, after all, a predatory monopoly.
 But whatever the answer in this case, there is a growing realization among economists and technology experts that Microsoft may be only the most visible symptom of a problem afflicting the Internet economy. 
 What troubles some observers of the world of Internet-enabled software and services -- which marches to slogans like "get big fast" and "winner take all" -- is that a number of factors may make it a breeding ground for monopolies.
Not all of those factors are new. There are decidedly old fashioned economies of scale that make it cheaper to manufacture things in bulk. In the world of selling intellectual property like software, the trend is even more pronounced, because it costs a great deal of money to develop the product and almost nothing to put it on disks and sell it again and again. This makes it harder for newcomers to enter the market, because they must spend so much time and money up front just developing a product, before they can try to sell it. 
Inertia also helps, since consumers and businesses alike hate the frustration and delay that learning how to use new systems entails. This "lock-in effect" helps preserve market dominance, said Hal R. Varian, economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley, because it creates a different kind of barrier to entry for newcomers -- not the cost to the company of entering the market, but the cost to consumers of making a switch.
But what is really driving the Internet economy, Mr. Varian says, is a relatively new phenomenon known as "network effect" -- the notion that a technology based on connectedness grows increasingly compelling and valuable as more and more people use it. 
The power of the network effect can be seen in technologies like America Online's Instant Messenger. Once teens realized that they could gab after school online, it became a must-have, Mr. Varian said -- and its use exploded, rapidly bringing AOL a near-lock on a market of more than 100 million people that Microsoft is struggling to break into.
Put all of these together and you get an environment in which the benefits of getting big pay off again and again, and consumers themselves reward the urge to grow. The result is a number of markets thoroughly dominated by the biggest player. 
"As software becomes a bigger part of our lives and it becomes a bigger part of the economy, this is going to become a bigger problem," said Michael Froomkin, a professor at the University of Miami School of Law. 
Nor is this effect limited to software. The dynamics of the new market have helped Intel grab 80 percent of the PC microprocessor market -- a share that will grow even larger after last week's announcement that Compaq Corp. would stop offering customers its own Alpha processors by 2004. Oracle Corp., which dominates the database market, is the second largest software company -- only Microsoft is larger. And ask just about any teenager about America Online's hunk of the market for Instant Messenger software.
In a world that tends toward bigness, what's a policy maker to do? Judge Jackson concluded that consumers were being hurt by Microsoft not because the company raised prices too much, but because it suppressed the creativity and competitiveness that a truly open market allows.
Lawrence I. Lessig, a professor of law at Stanford university and author of "Code and Other Laws of Cyberspace," said that whether the company chooses to fight on or settle, its true intentions will be revealed in the architecture of its future products.
"Are they building code that will level the playing field, or are they building code that will tilt the playing field in their direction?" he asks. 
"Microsoft, more than anybody else, recognizes that architecture matters," said Mr. Lessig.
It has been suggested that the so-called open source technologies -- software like the computer operating system Linux -- might offer real competition to the commercial software giants. These software platforms are designed by volunteers, given away for free. But Linux, like many of these software labors of love, isn't a really consumer product that can be easily installed and run by mere mortals. Although people who run Web sites have flocked to the free, open software, consumers have not.
Some commentators suggest that technology moves too quickly for government to effectively regulate, and that fast moving technology markets should simply be left to regulate themselves. They point to the fact that the technology market is so volatile that today's monopolist is tomorrow's loser -- lessons learned by the makers of such products as Lotus 1-2-3 and Wordstar, which once dominated their worlds.
A RECENT paper by the economists David S. Evans and Richard Schmalensee suggested that classic antitrust law might not be the best tool to deal with these emerging issues. The two economists, who have written papers and legal filings supporting Microsoft's position in its antitrust case, said that government should act to keep companies from abusing their monopoly power to undercut competitors, but that "the application of antitrust principles should take account of the important ways new-economy industries differ from traditional ones."
In particular, they wrote, if a dominant company can prove that there is healthy competition despite its commanding share of a market that has winner-take-all characteristics, that fact "should be a defense to claims of predation."
Mr. Schmalensee, the dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, declined to comment because he anticipates being called as a witness if the Microsoft case goes to a new phase.
Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, while admitting that "judicial time doesn't move anywhere near as fast as Internet time," says that the fact that antitrust regulation in the new economy is hard doesn't mean that it should be abandoned. 
Governments fight terrorism even though that task becomes more difficult with each passing day, he said, and although he hesitated at a potential comparison between antitrust and terrorism, he said,"we may not be able to stop it, but we'd be stupid if we didn't try." 
"We do need to watch the winners more closely," he said. That naturally means paying attention to the most powerful players, because "monopolies are in the position to wield their power unfairly."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Gates on Thursday, after learning of the appellate court's Microsoft decision. (Larry Davis for The New York Times)
