HEADLINE: MEDIA GIANTS: OVERVIEW: THE CORPORATE STRATEGY; 
Where the Message Is the Medium

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif. 

 BODY:
Under the headquarters roof held up by the Seven Dwarfs, Michael D. Eisner is nervous.
 Mr. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, is nervous not because "Pearl Harbor" has fallen short of expectations. He is nervous not because ABC is still working off its "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" hangover. He is nervous not because the new Disney's California Adventure theme park seems half-empty. 
 After all, at a company built on films, television programs and vacation attractions, such routine disappointments come with the job. Rather, Mr. Eisner is anxious because he is feeling pressure to change Disney's architecture. While Sneezy, Sleepy, Dopey & Company are the company's literal and figurative pillars, Mr. Eiser feels pressure to add cables, antennas and satellites. 
"I'm a little nervous," he said in an interview here. "I am nervous of the monumental pressure of The L.A. Times and The New York Times and Variety and all that stuff. 'How come Disney is not buying Telemundo?' 'How come Disney is not buying NBC?' 'How come Disney isn't fighting Rupert to get DirecTV?' 'How come Disney doesn't own 12 million cable homes?' 'Why doesn't Disney buy AT&T Broadband and get in the pipe business?' 
"I'm nervous that we'll all -- including me -- lose sight," he says. "I have to tie myself to the vision and I have to say to myself, 'What is Disney?' "
Mr. Eisner clings to the vision because it is getting a bit lonely in his corner of the media world. And he knows it. For years, media moguls and gadflies alike have argued about whether greater power accrues to the owners of content (like films and television programs) or distribution (like cable and satellite systems). Now, many big media companies are concluding that it is more powerful to own both. AOL Time Warner is largely the result of America Online's desire for Time Warner's cable systems. The News Corporation is vying for the DirecTV satellite system. Even Viacom, where Sumner M. Redstone enjoys proclaiming that "content is king," has built a new television network, UPN, to complement its acquisition of CBS.
And then there is Disney, the company that the producer and animator Walt Disney founded in 1923 and that first offered stock to the public in 1940. Such is its tradition that Mr. Eisner, chairman since 1984, paints even the acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC six years ago as an investment in content rather than distribution. Where others saw a television network, Mr. Eiser saw ESPN's sports properties and ABC's television library. If the other conglomerates are about the media, Mr. Eisner wants Disney to be about the messages.
"What makes the company different is that everybody right now, the other big companies, are run by very gifted businessmen who are out vociferously championing the control of the conduit to the public in one way or another," Mr. Eisner said. "But for us, the main product is intellectual product, or content. And all those words are so antiseptic that it's hard to talk about it and much harder to write about it. But if you sit in a theater and you see 'Dinosaur' or 'Atlantis' or a Garry Marshall movie or you watch a television show in a group or you go to a theme park and you see people react, then you start to understand content. And it is our single driver."
That may be so, but it appears that a fair number of Disney executives who are not named Michael D. Eisner are spending a lot of time thinking about how to bypass, co-opt or otherwise handle the distribution channels (particularly cable television operators) that Disney relies upon to deliver content to consumers. And those executives are coming up with some innovative and provocative plans, like using the broadcast television airwaves to deliver movies for video-on-demand services.
The outside pressure that Mr. Eisner feels is mounting at this particular moment for a reason. Because reporters and Wall Street analysts are fickle and shortsighted sorts, it is unlikely that Mr. Eisner would be feeling heat to diversify were Disney's core content units enjoying a run of incredible success. But they aren't.
At first glance, there seems to be no single overarching reason why most of the company's content businesses are falling short of blockbuster success just now.
For the company's media networks operation, the biggest problem may simply be living up to its own record. During the company's fiscal year that ended last September, the networks posted stellar results for essentially two reasons: a sizzling advertising market and the ABC hit show "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." Now, the advertising market has fallen off the stove and "Millionaire," while still among the top-rated prime-time programs, is no longer the phenomenon it was. ABC also failed to generate a strong lineup of new hits last fall -- although ESPN became even stronger, largely because of its expanded National Football League schedule. 
After networks, Disney's biggest unit is its theme parks and resorts operation. As the company has added new parks and cruise ships, revenue at the unit has grown steadily.
But attendance has fallen off this year at the company's United States parks, perhaps because of the overall slowing of the economy and the rise in gasoline prices. Moreover, the company's new park in Anaheim, Disney's California Adventure, has not yet hit its stride. During a recent visit, the park's signature roller coaster was closed, construction was underway outside a key attraction and, most important, the crowds were less than overwhelming. There are strengths, including a popular attraction based on "A Bug's Life."
Meanwhile, there have been disappointing results from the company's studio operation, which is dominated by the movie business. Revenue and operating income at the unit have fallen each of the last three fiscal years. Part of the decline is a result of the company's scaling back of its home-video release schedule. Another part, however, is a result of box-office turkeys; Mr. Eisner cites "The Insider" and "Kundun" among the duds. And while this summer's much-hyped "Pearl Harbor" will be profitable, it will not be a world-beater of "Titanic" scale. 
Two weeks ago, Disney announced that the studio's chairman, Peter Schneider, was stepping down. Mr. Schneider's mere departure was more than enough material for the Hollywood gossip factory. But the most interesting aspect of the move is the fact that the company has no intention of replacing him. Instead, three key executives who reported to Mr. Schneider will now report directly to Mr. Eisner.
And there, perhaps, is the overarching issue in the company's performance. Mr. Eisner may be trying to mend what he sees as the common, fraying thread at Disney: his own lack of day-to-day involvement in the content operations. (Jeffrey Katzenberg, the former Disney executive who left in a dispute with Mr. Eisner in 1994, might have a different opinion.)
Mr. Eisner is hardly known as the supreme delegator; the word "micromanager" has even been thrown his way. But that may be because he genuinely sees himself as an entertainment producer who happens to be running a big company, rather than as an executive whose company happens to be in the media business.
And now, Mr. Eisner is ready to get back in the game again, after spending a few years on what he considers the sidelines.
"I'm going to be increasingly involved in the studio," he said the day before Mr. Schneider's departure was announced. "I'm going to increasingly try to get myself back into the main creative thrust of the company, where I was."
For his freedom to do that, Mr. Eisner thanks Robert A. Iger, the former ABC executive who is now Disney's president. Mr. Eisner is counting on Mr. Iger to make the trains run on time while Mr. Eisner himself concentrates on the movies, shows and theme parks that are still his passion.
"It's much easier now for me because I have Bob Iger -- because I don't have to do everything," Mr. Eisner said. Talking about Mr. Iger brings to his mind Frank Wells, Mr. Eisner's longtime deputy, who was killed in a helicopter crash in 1994.
"When Frank Wells was here, I was 90 percent in creative and 10 percent in making big decisions and Frank was the opposite," Mr. Eisner says, almost wistfully. "And when Frank died I ran it by myself for a while, which was fine. Then I made a mistake and that really put me back. And then I ran it for a little while longer alone and then Bob came in."
The mistake Mr. Eisner refers to is his hiring in 1995 of Michael S. Ovitz, the former talent agent, as his No. 2. That arrangement deteriorated over the course of 16 months before Mr. Ovitz resigned. 
Perhaps as rancorous was the fight a year ago between Disney and Time Warner Cable. As the companies wrangled over how much Time Warner would pay to carry Disney's cable channels, Time Warner cut off ABC for some 3.5 million of its cable subscribers for 39 hours.
It turned out to be a colossal public relations blunder by Time Warner. "I almost became religious," Mr. Eisner recalls. "It was like a gift."
At one level, the episode confirmed for Disney the value of its content. As Mr. Iger recalls: "What was learned was that a cable operator or a pipe owner could not stand in the way of consumers' getting the programming or the content that they demanded. A middleman cannot, forever, block access to that content, and we're confident of that."
But as confident as Disney may be, the Time Warner fracas may have also highlighted a fundamental vulnerability: In the end, other companies control the manner in which much of Disney's content is actually delivered. Without much distribution, Disney would have to get smarter.
Enter Peter E. Murphy.
As Disney's chief strategy officer, Mr. Murphy is trying to figure out how Disney can extract more money from its content and also build stronger, more direct relationships with customers. Standing in his way are gatekeepers like cable systems and video rental shops.
For instance, Mr. Murphy estimates that Americans spend about $2 billion a year renting Disney home videos. Disney gets only 30 to 35 percent of that, he says, and he wants more.
So Mr. Murphy is working on a plan to use television broadcast spectrum to transmit movies overnight to hard-drive devices, much like Tivo recorders, that sit atop televisions. The boxes might store 100 movies at a time, from Disney and other studios.
With such a service, which Mr. Murphy calls datacasting and wants to start next year, the video-rental gatekeeper would be cut out of the business model. More important, so would the local cable system.
Mr. Murphy is quick to say that cable companies will continue to be important for distributing traditional channels like ESPN and the Disney Channel, but he says: "We see movies as the Trojan horse. Once you have a relationship with the customer and you have a big hard drive in their house, there's all sorts of different data you can put on there. It can be music, it can be TV, it can be text."
Lots of obstacles stand in the way of such a plan, not least the myriad technical difficulties. And consumers may balk at bringing yet another gadget into their homes.
All of a sudden, though, it looks like there actually are some people at Disney who are thinking hard about distribution issues.
Mr. Eisner -- knowing his strengths, perhaps -- chooses not to be one of them.
Asked about the datacasting initiative, he says: "Peter Murphy spends a good deal of time on that. I spend not any time on that. I would rather spend my time making sure that if you get that working we have stuff that goes over those pipes.
"I say, 'Hey guys, let's go put on a show,' " he said. "I mean, that's what's fun: Hey, let's go do 'Beauty and the Beast' for Broadway. But we're running a day-to-day business with 100,000-plus employees and that's a big responsibility in itself.
"You ask what is the soul of the company and what is our direction? I'm trying to be the bridge from what Walt Disney made and created," he added, "to whoever will be the next person after me that maintains that same philosophy of 'Let's put on a show.' Let's be silly. We're a silly company. Let's never not be a silly company."

The Media Giants
This article is the second of a series to be published on Mondays in Business Day over the coming months, examining the business strategies of the major media conglomerates, including AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann, Disney, News Corporation, Sony, Viacom and Vivendi. HEADLINE: A Grand Plan Meets Skepticism in Mexico's South 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Mexico, June 28 

 BODY:
Miguel Lopez, a peasant farmer, stood on an empty railroad track, glancing up from his muddy boots. He looked a tad skeptical about President Vicente Fox's vision of factories sprouting from this rich farmland, filling freight trains roaring down this rickety line.
 "We don't have electricity or drinking water," said Mr. Lopez, who makes $2 a day working the fields of eastern Oaxaca. "If the president can't give us that -- and no president has -- what's the point?" 
 A century ago, the dictator Porfiro Diaz dreamed that a great railroad would run through here, carrying majestic cargo ships from the Gulf of Mexico to the Pacific, turning the south of Mexico into a world trade route and making the nation an economic powerhouse. But it took a generation to lay this narrow, now disused track. By that time the United States was building the Panama Canal. 
Not since Diaz's dream has a leader had a vision like President Fox's plan to develop southern Mexico, then and now the poorest and most politically isolated part of the country. And no other project so typifies Mr. Fox and his ambitions in the year since he was elected last July 2, uprooting the old regime that had ruled Mexico since 1929.
Its aims are enormous, its details undone and its future uncertain, like much of what Mr. Fox has promised in the seven months since taking office.
Mr. Fox wants to spend billions on development -- and rebuild this lonely railroad line into a humming cross-continental cargo route -- to lift up southern Mexico and link it to Central America and the United States in a giant 21st-century free-trade network.
"We want to begin by constructing great corridors of highways and rail lines, of gas pipes and electrical grids, ports and airports," Mr. Fox said this month. Dams will generate power, tourism projects will draw visitors, goods will flow from the south, and money will flow in, he says.
Making Diaz's dream railroad a reality, his plan states, will turn the south "into a trade route to Europe for businesses located on the Pacific Coast and to the East for businesses located on the Gulf of Mexico" -- exactly what Mexico envisioned back in the 1880's but never accomplished.
"It is a grand vision -- and a good one," said David B. Atkinson, the Interamerican Development Bank's representative in Mexico. "The next step is to translate it into action."
Like President Lyndon B. Johnson's "war on poverty" in the 1960's, Mr. Fox's plan seeks to end what he calls "the disgracefully unacceptable situations of poverty and isolation" in Mexico's poorest states, and to close the development gap between Mexico's north and south."
Mexico's south, similar to the American south in the century after the Civil War, remains worse off than the rest of the nation by any economic and social measure. It has one-quarter of Mexico's land, but only one-seventh of its wealth and three-quarters of its Indians, who live concentrated in little villages, lacking jobs, roads, schools, water, electricity and political power.
And while his vision is grand, Mr. Fox's mandate is thin. He won office with 43 percent of the vote, presides over a fragile political coalition and a slowing economy and lacks consent in Congress.
His plan, so far, is primarily about business -- energy, transport, and factories to assemble consumer goods. Its budget contains millions, not the necessary billions. And so far only one part directly addresses people like Mr. Lopez, the millions of subsistence farmers in the south. It proposes to "make rural farms into profitable business," though exactly how is not spelled out.
The plan provokes deep skepticism from those who claim to speak for the poor, in particular the popular spokesmen for Mexico's Indians, the man who calls himself Subcommander Marcos, whose Zapatista rebel movement rose from the dirt-poor hills of the southern state of Chiapas.
"Instead of using riches to support poor peasants and small business owners," he said, "Fox has a plan to use the money to support those who want to fill the land with gas stations, malls and plastic playlands," turning Indian villages into "amusement parks where the peasants and the indigenous would be clowns," entertaining tourists for a handful of pesos.
Officials of the Interamerican Development Bank, which has provisionally pledged $2 billion for the plan, say that grand development projects cannot work unless the people they are meant to help are closely consulted from the start.
So the money will not flow soon. First there must be many talks in many towns with peasants and local politicians, a process that the plan's coordinator, Florencio Salazar, called "difficult but indispensable."
Representatives from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the United Nations Development Program, the United States Agency for International Development and other institutions met to discuss the plan for the first time this week at the Interamerican Development Bank's headquarters in Washington. Mr. Fox has asked the development bank to write the plan as well as finance it.
Mr. Atkinson, the bank's representative in Mexico, says the plan must first give an "effective voice" to "those most in need -- the poor, the indigenous communities," letting them help choose the ways in which the money is spent.
Exactly so, said Pablo Salazar, the governor of Chiapas, the first ever from outside the old ruling party. "This is a rich state with poor people, the poorest in the nation," he said. "And we are fighting, demanding that the government reduce this abyss."
The plan, he said, is not "the state's salvation, nor the demon by which transnational businesses will come to plunder our wealth." But it will not work, he said, unless the government "takes the proposals to the communities."
Today four-fifths of the 12,500 miles of road in Chiapas are unpaved. And Governor Salazar wants, literally and figuratively, "a dignified path that connects Chiapas with the country's capital."
Easier said than done. The last serious capital investment in southern Mexico came near the end of the 19th century, in the days of the dictator Diaz. Back then, under a banana-republic system approaching slavery, Indian peasants hauled precious woods, coffee, fruit, sugar cane, tobacco and chicle out of the land.
The 21st-century plan would have the peasants making consumer goods in assembly factories, as they do in Mexico's north, or harvesting food and wood in biotech plantations, for perhaps $10 a day.
In theory, "they would be integrated into the mainstream of the economy," said Luis Rubio, a prominent political scientist in Mexico City, and that "would make them like average Mexicans striving to earn a living."
But Armando Bartra, the director of the Instituto Maya, which studies rural and agricultural issues, said the plan to date represented a new version of the old colonial ways.
"The south needs large public works" to create jobs, he said. "But there is no sign that the plan will improve the lives of those living in indigenous communities," he said, or that Mr. Fox and his aides "have talked to people living in those communities."
During a tour of three southern states, down the Isthmus of Tehuantepec railroad line in Veracruz and Oaxaca, then east to Chiapas, it seemed that people's support for the program depended on their wealth.
People in business liked the plan enormously. "A brilliant idea," said Victor Manuel Cancino, a coffee exporter in Chiapas -- especially if it includes loans or credits for enterprises like his.
People with a little money thought it was nice, if perhaps a bit dreamy. Antonio Dominguez, 44, riding the rails on horseback, hauling his homemade cheese to market near the Oaxaca-Veracruz border, put it plainly. "God knows, people need work and money," he said. His partner, Pedro Contreras, 50, said, "We work like dogs to make 80 pesos a day," about $9, "and that's what you need just to survive." 
People with next to nothing, like Mr. Lopez, the peasant farmer, were dubious at best. "We are poor people, we have always been poor, and I think we always will be, no matter what the president promises," he said, trudging across the tracks to the fields near Santa Ana, in eastern Oaxaca.
Down the line, in Lagunas, stood a version of Mr. Fox's dream made concrete -- actually, made by concrete. Lagunas is a company town of 4,000 people living next to the great gray cement factory run by Cruz Azul, a Mexican firm that has been here for 80 years.
The neat little houses have lawns. The landscaped park has benches. Street lights line extremely well-paved roads. Lagunas looks a little more like southern California than southern Mexico.
On a railroad siding, Felix Guttierez, 45, was inspecting the freight cars that haul the cement down the hills. "This is a good idea the president has," he said. "But we need deeds, not words."
Mexico has gold in its hills and oil under its seas, he said, but millions of people are looking for work.
"The land is rich," he said, "but the people are poor."

HEADLINE: Product to Protect Women From H.I.V. Is Elusive 

BYLINE:  By SHARON LERNER 

 BODY:
Twelve years ago, when Salimata Niang first began talking about the risk of AIDS in her native Senegal, women asked her for something she did not have: a product they could use without their husbands' knowledge to protect themselves from infection with the AIDS virus.
 Last week, at the United Nations conference on the disease, Ms. Niang, a program officer at the Society for Women and AIDS in Africa, said she still had nothing to offer. There is no such thing as a vaginal microbicide -- no cream, gel, foam or sponge that can protect against AIDS or other sexually transmitted diseases. 
 At the United Nations meeting, Dr. Peter Piot, executive director of the organization's AIDS program, which coordinates the international response to the epidemic, said that he had first recommended microbicide development more than 10 years ago and that the main challenge had always been attracting the pharmaceutical industry. Companies have not been eager to develop microbicides, because they are unlikely to be big moneymakers.
To be useful in the poor countries where new AIDS infections are concentrated, a microbicide would have to be inexpensive. Even in the United States, a recent survey by the Alan Guttmacher Institute showed that women's interest in a microbicide would decline as its price increased.
Scientific questions have also plagued the microbicide development. In the last decade, researchers have puzzled over which host cell a compound should target to interrupt H.I.V. transmission and how cells of the genital tract respond to the virus differently from other cells. Hopes for the most promising microbicide candidate were dashed last year when a spermicide, Nonoxynol-9, appeared to increase H.I.V. transmission in human trials rather than reducing it.
Some experts have expressed reservations about microbicides. While some envision them as an important alternative for women who would not use condoms, others fear that they might cut down on condom use.
Despite setbacks, scientists and people concerned about women's health issues are more optimistic than ever about prospects for a microbicide. Sixty potential products are now in development, including a gel called the invisible condom, another gel that interrupts the replication of viruses and a chemical derived from plants that have been genetically engineered to produce human antibodies active against sexually transmitted infections.
Four of these chemical candidates are heading toward the last phase of human trials in the next two years. Pro-2000, a gel made by Interneuron, a company based in Massachusetts, disrupts both H.I.V. and herpes infection by binding with the viruses. Pro-2000, which also shows promise as a contraceptive, is scheduled to begin its last round of trials in January. Another compound, Buffer Gel, kills pathogens by changing the acidity in the vagina. And Ushercell, a big sugar molecule being promoted by a nonprofit organization called Conrad, is thought to work against H.I.V. and the bacteria that cause chlamydia and gonorrhea by blocking their entry into cells. Carraguard, which contains a seaweed-derived compound used to thicken ice cream, seems to prevent viral infection by coating the vaginal walls. Carraguard is being developed by the Population Council in New York and is expected to allow conception while fighting H.I.V.
The need for microbicides is rooted in the doubly difficult position in which women find themselves: not only are they more susceptible to sexually transmitted diseases than men, but they are less able to insist that their partners use condoms.
"If men don't want to use them, they don't get used," said Dr. Julie Pulerwitz, a scientist at the Program for Appropriate Technology in Health, an international nonprofit group that studies contraception and AIDS prevention. Dr. Pulerwitz, who is studying condom use in Bolivia, Vietnam and South Africa, said that men often disregarded their partners' requests to wear condoms or reacted violently. 
The female condom has made little headway. Women cannot use it without a partner's knowing, and both men and women complain that it is awkward and noisy. 
A successful microbicide would cost an estimated $50 million to develop, according to the Alliance for Microbicide Development, a group representing scientists and biotechnology companies. Pharmaceutical companies can expect a return of about 5 percent on a drug sold in a developing country, as opposed to an 18 to 20 percent return from drugs sold in developed countries, according to Dr. Stephen Schondelmeyer, a professor of pharmaceutical economics at the University of Minnesota. 
Without the backing of big companies, efforts to nudge microbicides toward the marketplace have fallen to government researchers and women's health advocates. The Global Campaign for Microbicides recently began a search for donors that it is calling "Looking for Mrs. McCormick," a reference to Frances McCormick, who personally financed research on the birth control pill in the 1940's, when it was controversial. The Rockefeller Foundation has a microbicide initiative, and the Gates Foundation recently set aside $25 million to help bring the right compound to market.
Some of that money has gone to small biotech firms like Biosys, a Philadelphia company that is developing a cream called Savvy. The cream has shown potential as both a contraceptive and a barrier to H.I.V., syphilis, chlamydia and gonorrhea and is undergoing safety trials. The company's president, Anne-Marie Corner, said she was cautiously optimistic; if all goes well, Savvy could begin its final phase of clinical testing next summer and appear on drugstore shelves as soon as three years from now. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Venerable Institution In a Season Of Turmoil 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS OVERBYE 

 BODY:
In November 1988, Andrei Sakharov, the Russian physicist, political dissident and Nobel Peace Prize winner, came to the United States after he was released from years of house arrest. One of his first stops was an Italianate building on East 63rd Street that is home to the New York Academy of Sciences. There, at an emotional reception in the academy's travertine marble halls, Sakharov thanked the academy for leading the fight for his freedom. It was a proud moment in the history of the academy, which, since its founding in 1817, has claimed Thomas Jefferson, Charles Darwin and Albert Einstein as members.
 Today many people are wondering about the future of the academy, an association of scientists, engineers and doctors that has 28,000 members worldwide and is known for its scholarly publications and ground-breaking conferences on subjects like AIDS and women in science, as well as for human rights campaigns for foreign scientists. 
 The academy, New York's oldest scientific institution, has lost almost a third of its members in the last seven years. In April, it announced that it was putting its headquarters on the market for $30 million. And on May 31, provoking a chorus of protest from scientists and journalists, the academy's board voted to stop publishing The Sciences, an elegant magazine that has won seven National Magazine Awards for its combination of literary science writing and fine art. 
Some see these events as the visible manifestation of a worrisome trend toward centralization and the pursuit of the corporate dollar in an institution that has traditionally operated more like a federation of little scientific societies. To the academy's president, Dr. Rodney W. Nichols, they are growing pains. 
The academy is changing, he says, and not everybody is happy about it. Partly, it is a debate about who will control the agenda of the academy -- the volunteer members who run the academic sections into which it is divided or the staff and board of governors -- and whether the university or the corporation is the right model for a 21st-century nonprofit scientific academy.
"This is a 19th-century organization, and it's organized in a 19th-century way," Dr. Nichols said in an interview. Two years ago he led the way in getting the academy to approve a new mission statement -- something he says it never had before -- that emphasizes the use and understanding of science and technology for the betterment of society.
He intends to replace the academy's sections, which are centered on traditional disciplines like chemistry and mathematics, with interdisciplinary forums, and to establish centers for science education, studies of technology and society, and the promotion of human rights.
To finance all that activity, he said, he has begun to raise money for an endowment, something he said his predecessors had neglected to do. 
In some quarters, however, these moves seem ominous.
"Nicholas is going the way of corporate America invading the public and private institutions of learning," said Dr. Constance Sutton, a professor at New York University and chairwoman of the academy's anthropology section.
Dr. Nichols's critics say closing the magazine was a mistake. They cite surveys showing that The Sciences has consistently been rated as one of the prime benefits of academy membership.
"This is not the way to reverse a membership decline," said Dr. Charles Ramond, a psychologist and advertising expert who is a former member of the academy's board and was chairman of its committee on The Sciences. 
But everyone agrees that change is needed. 
The academy was founded as the Lyceum for Natural History; its members were instrumental in founding the American Museum of Natural History in 1868 and N.Y.U. The academy found its niche not in research but in disseminating findings through meetings and publications. The Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, which first appeared in 1823, ranks among the top 2 percent of publications according to the frequency with which it is cited by other scientific papers.
The academy got into the human rights business in 1978, running seminars in Moscow apartments for "refuseniks," Jewish Soviet scientists who had been fired for wanting to emigrate to Israel, and publishing the proceedings in the Annals.
"That was where we made our mark in human rights," said the academy's human rights director, Svetlana Stone. The academy's efforts have spread to China, Iran, Indonesia, Cuba, Egypt and Myanmar, among other countries.
In New York City the academy has been a "very important kind of centripetal force for the city's intellectuals in keeping in touch, networking, keeping up with what's happening," Dr. Sutton said. Anyone who pays the dues -- $95 for Americans and $115 for others -- can join, said Katherine Goldring, director of marketing and membership. Only about 18 percent of members live in the New York metropolitan area; 45 percent live abroad.
Dr. Nichols, a physicist who was formerly a vice president of Rockefeller University, became executive director of the academy in 1995. He changed his official title soon thereafter to president and chief executive, a move that has symbolic importance to the academically oriented old guard. And he expanded the board of governors by adding leaders from business and government and two former presidential science advisers, Dr. D. Allan Bromley and Dr. John Gibbons. Dr. Nichols has embarked on a series of initiatives into the areas of science and society, often in conjunction with outside institutions. In 1995 he talked the Federal Reserve Bank of New York into co-sponsoring a conference on technology and the economy of the tristate area. In recent years the academy has also undertaken, among other efforts, major projects to improve science teaching in the schools and, at the request of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to study pollution in New York Harbor.
These expanding interests have put a crimp on the academy both physically and fiscally. The academy's headquarters is impressive but too small; up to 70 people at a time are crammed into 32 rooms, and it lacks an auditorium large enough to hold more than 100 people, causing the academy to hold its larger meetings at other institutions. 
The plan is essentially to give it up for a larger but less expensive space in Manhattan that could be outfitted with modern offices and an auditorium. But the new building must have "gravitas," Dr. Nichols said. "We're not going to move into one floor of the World Trade Center," he said.
Dr. Nichols described two properties, including a former three-story warehouse that was already wired for high-speed Internet access, that he had his eye on and that could be bought and renovated for about $15 million.
That would leave $5 million or $10 million to serve as the seed for an endowment.
The academy operates on a tight budget of about $10 million a year, he said, mostly financed by members' dues. That was augmented last year by about $2.5 million in restricted and unrestricted grants and donations. But to be secure, he said, each of the new projected centers, as well as the offices on human rights and women in science, need their own endowments of a few million dollars -- like the named chairs in a university department.
"We don't have any of that," Dr. Nichols said. "It's all on our own bootstraps." He said he would probably announce a capital campaign in the next year.
Dr. Nichols's critics worry that he would rather run a research organization than one oriented toward membership, but he denies it.
"I'm not a Beltway bandit," he proclaimed, adding that he was determined to participate in projects with government and industry when they fit with the academy's mission and to rely more and more on the academy's senior staff members in figuring out how best to fulfill that mission.
The sudden closing of The Sciences has brought the debate over the academy's future into sharp focus. By all accounts, the magazine, which goes to all members as well as to a few thousand outside subscribers, has always been highly praised and short of cash. Richard Liebman-Smith, who edited the magazine in the early 1980's, said: "There has always been a feeling that it was an expensive thing to do. The history of trying to get rid of The Sciences doesn't begin with Rodney Nichols."
He said one of the magazine's signature features, the use of fine art instead of scientific diagrams for illustrations, was originally conceived as an economy measure because the publication could not afford graphics. Another economy move was the use of young writers, many of whom went on to better-known publications like The New York Times.
"It wanted to be almost literary," recalled Paul LiBassi, who edited The Sciences from 1982 to 1989. Dr. Stephen Jay Gould, the Harvard paleontologist and best-selling author, called The Sciences "the best integration of art and science that we have."
Mr. LiBassi and Mr. Liebman-Smith said they had hoped to excite their readers about ideas and the benefits of research, rather than simply covering academy activities. As a result, the magazine kept the academy at arm's length -- a fact that led to growing irritation between Dr. Nichols and Peter Brown, the most recent editor, according to a former staff member at the magazine. Mr. Brown declined to speak publicly about the situation.
The board, Dr. Nichols said, had considered closing The Sciences before, considering it outside the main mission of the academy. It had tried to license it to an outside publisher in the late 1980's but failed to attract a respectable offer. Subsequent attempts to lift the magazine out of its financial hole -- estimated by Dr. Nichols at $700,000 to $900,000 a year -- by selling advertising also failed.
"By the late 90's, what also became clear was that the magazine was not really the voice of the academy," Dr. Nichols said. "You could read the magazine for years and never know that we have programs in the city schools, not know that we have an active human rights committee, not know that we held meetings."
Dr. Nichols submitted his conclusion to the board on May 31 in the form of a budget that had no provision for the magazine. He said The Sciences would be replaced by a newsletter and an expanded Web site.
"This is not Harvard -- we don't have an endowment," said Jacqueline Leo, an executive at Meredith Publishing, who is chairwoman of the academy's committee on The Sciences. "But if this is the reason people come to the academy. . . ." 
In the days after the announcement, many academy members expressed shock. "Of all the things you do, why give up the most visible, most reputable thing you do?" asked Barry Kreiswirth, a microbiologist at N.Y.U.'s Public Health Research Institute.
The curator of the academy's art gallery, Lynn Gamwell, resigned. "The magazine's mission was integral to the gallery," she wrote in an e-mail message to Dr. Nichols, "and by shutting down The Sciences you created a void at the core of the gallery."
"Some people think I'm an assassin," Dr. Nichols acknowledged. "I don't feel good about the whole situation. I feel good about the decision. I don't feel good in human terms." 
Dr. Nancy Toomey, chairwoman of the women in science section of the academy and associate dean of engineering and applied sciences at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, said she was not completely comfortable with the changes under way. "Should the academy decide to do away with the old sections' structure," she wrote in an e-mail message to The New York Times, "I hope it finds a way to continue to support face-to-face meeting of members that do so much to foster networking and mentoring, in addition to the exchange of information."
But she added, "As someone once said, the only thing more frightening than change is not changing."

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about changes at the New York Academy of Sciences misstated the background of its president and chief executive, Rodney W. Nichols; he does not have a doctorate and he became the group's leader in 1992, not 1995. The article also misstated the source of the academy's income; it gets most of its income from a combination of members' dues and sales of publications, not from dues alone.

HEADLINE: Critic of China Flees to U.S., Fearing Arrest In Crackdown 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, July 2 

 BODY:
A maverick Chinese economist who is an outspoken critic of China's endemic corruption has fled to the United States, fearing that she was about to be arrested in a crackdown on dissidents and scholars with ties to the West.
 The economist, He Qinglian, 44, was already planning on leaving China on June 26 for a year's sabbatical at the University of Chicago. 
 But, speaking by telephone today from a conference at American University in Washington, she said she left China instead on June 14, after security agents broke into her apartment in Shenzhen and seized documents, including invitations to academic conferences in the United States, Japan, Taiwan and Sweden.
Just two months earlier, she added, security agents had seized her cell phone and other personal effects. And for the last year, ever since she was dismissed as a writer for The Shenzhen Legal Daily, she said, the police had regularly shadowed her, and her telephone had been tapped. 
Fearful of being arrested, Ms. He left her apartment on June 14 without any luggage, and adhered to her usual routine -- except that instead of going to work, she went to the bank, then to Baiyun Airport in Guangzhou for a flight to Beijing. She then flew to Singapore, and landed in the United States on June 16.
"I was very worried that I would not be able to safely leave the country because they knew that I was going to the United States in two weeks," Ms. He said. "I have decided to leave China for now."
In recent months China has arrested scores of dissidents, closed newspapers and fired outspoken editors in an accelerating effort to tighten control on public discourse. And it has charged several visiting scholars with spying, including a naturalized American who had been teaching in Hong Kong and a United States resident who had been working at American University in Washington.
No one knows why, though theories abound. 
Recently issued regulations allow the government to close publications that mention a broad range of subjects, including speculation on China's coming leadership transition. 
Jiang Zemin, who is president, general secretary of the Communist Party and chairman of the Central Military Commission, is expected to step down as leader of the party next year and to retire from the presidency in 2003. Li Peng, the chairman of the National People's Congress, and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji are also expected to step down in 2003. Who fills those posts will be decided next year, at the party's 16th Congress. 
The crackdown may also be motivated by a growing fear of espionage by disaffected Chinese nationals for the United States or Taiwan.
Ms. He, educated as an economist in Shanghai, made her name in 1998 with "China's Pitfalls," a pessimistic evaluation of the economic and political system as irretrievably corrupt. Nine companies refused to publish the book until after it had been published in Hong Kong and had won the praise of Liu Ji, an academic who is a close adviser to Mr. Jiang. 
Its subsequent mainland edition sold a 170,000 copies, and an estimated one million more were sold in pirated editions. 
Her attacks have been unrelenting, eroding the government's patience.
In March 2000, she published a long analysis of the growing inequalities in Chinese society in Reading Room, a magazine based in Changsha. The essay formed the core of another book, "We Are All Still Gazing at the Stars." 
The book included criticism of Mr. Jiang's three priorities for the party, the cornerstone of what he hopes will be his intellectual legacy. He says the party should represent "the advanced forces of production, advanced culture and the interests of the grass roots." But Ms. He's book said that theory was really just an attempt to consolidate the power of the ruling elite.
The book was banned, and Reading Room's editor in chief and several other senior editors were removed from their jobs.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing and Consumer Data Signal a Recovery 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2 

 BODY:
An index of manufacturing rose to a seven-month high in June, and consumer spending increased more than expected in May, industry and government reports showed today. The data were seen as a sign that the economy could be starting to recover.
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's index increased to 44.7 last month from 42.1 in May. Last month's reading, the highest since November, was lifted by gains in orders and production. Still, a reading below 50 signals a decline, and the index has been in the 40's since last August. 
 "I feel like we've hit bottom, and we're coming back," said Michael Kluiber, senior vice president for global automotive business at Rockwell Automation, the largest supplier of factory automation equipment for the American auto industry. "We're still not out of the woods. But every month has been better than the month before."
Spending by consumers rose 0.5 percent in May, the same level as in April and more than the 0.4 percent forecast by analysts, the Commerce Department reported. Demand for durable goods like appliances and cars jumped 1.2 percent. The report also showed that incomes grew 0.2 percent in May, the same level as a month earlier. The personal savings rate dropped to minus 1.3 percent in May from minus 1 percent in April.
Consumers are borrowing or dipping into their savings to make purchases, "an indication that people have a lot of confidence in the future of the economy," said Joel Naroff, chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa. "They are maintaining their spending in light of a pretty clear slowdown in income, especially in wages and salaries."
Manufacturing wages declined for a second month and pay in other industries slowed in May, the report said.
A separate Commerce Department report showed construction spending rose 0.3 percent in May, to $881.6 billion at an annual rate, after a 0.4 percent increase in April. Spending on housing and public works led the increase.
Central bankers, economists and some company officials say they expect a recovery to have begun by the end of the year. The economy will probably grow 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter after expected growth of 0.5 percent in the second three months of the year, according to a survey of analysts. The economy grew 1.2 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter.
The increase will probably come from the six interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve as well as a tax-lowering plan enacted by Congress that includes cash rebates. The government will start mailing rebate checks on July 23.
"Consumers are doing their part to keep the economy out of recession," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Banc of America Capital Management in St. Louis. "The economy appears to be shaking off its slump of the past several months."

HEADLINE: Fast Investments, Missing Returns; 
U.S. Charges Internet Operation Was a Huge Scam

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY 

 BODY:
By last September, life was getting rough for Donald A. English.
 An unemployed single father, Mr. English was almost out of cash. His family was threatened with eviction. Collection agencies were at the door. His credit cards were mostly tapped out. 
 With the walls closing in, Mr. English, 53, decided to grab for a distinctly modern solution to his crumbling finances: He started his own dot-com. 
But this was no ordinary Internet company. Instead, government investigators said, it was the centerpiece of a huge scam. With it, they said, this down-and-outer from Midwest City, Okla., established one of history's fastest frauds, conning tens of thousands of small investors out of as much as $50 million in a matter of weeks, until the scheme collapsed early this year in scandal.
The rapid-fire rise and fall of Mr. English and his enterprise, EE-Biz Ventures, is more than just a tale of potential fraud on Internet time. It has also exposed, investigators said, a strange corner of the cyberspace investing world, one permeated with financial fantasies spun by assorted hucksters and believed by legions of the gullible.
It is a place of fictitious currencies and make-believe investments, where 100 percent returns over a few days are not only promised but expected. Investigators have stumbled across imaginary banks hawking nonexistent "digital" certificates of deposit, illusory trillion-dollar government obligations and bogus business deals to "lease" millions of dollars in cash. 
The fantasy world is so detailed that, in one instance, the government was struggling to cash a $9 million check posted in the English case, only to find that the bank on which the check was drawn did not exist. And then there are the bizarre individuals connected to the case, like the purported financier who claims to be in radio contact with a 9-foot-6 extraterrestrial circling the earth in a spaceship.
"When you look at what went on here, you have to willingly suspend any sense of reality," said J. Chris Condren, an Oklahoma lawyer appointed by a federal court as a receiver for EE-Biz. "It's like Rumpelstiltskin. You have to believe in fairy tales to buy into this."
Regardless of the oddities, government officials said, the harm done by Mr. English is all too real. 
"While a lot of this may seem silly and absurd, we have real victims and real losses here," said Spencer Barasch, associate administrator for the Securities and Exchange Commission's Fort Worth office, which is handling the case. "And a lot of these victims are elderly and vulnerable."
These days, Mr. English sits in a federal prison here, charged with contempt for ignoring a court order that he disclose the location of almost $9 million that is missing. As for the victims, many still have not accepted that they were cheated and send e-mails regularly to the S.E.C. and other officials, demanding the release of the man who promised to lead them to financial prosperity.
William B. Federman, a lawyer for Mr. English, declined to comment on the specifics of the accusations against his client.
From the beginning, there was nothing particularly clever about EE-Biz, according to an S.E.C. complaint filed here. It was, the agency said, a simple Ponzi scheme, in which early investors are paid bogus profits with money from new investors. Eventually, as new cash stops coming in, the music stops and the scheme collapses, leaving the latest investors with huge losses even as early investors like Mr. English can walk away with fortunes.
In the case of EE-Biz, court records show, investors who signed up opened an account with a legitimate company that functioned like a bank, using an Internet currency known as e-gold. Then, they transferred dollars in e-gold -- a transaction known as a spend, involving as little as $20 or as much as several thousand -- to an e-gold account, controlled by someone else. The early investors received double their money back, with no explanation of how it was done. As word spread of the payouts, investors flocked to the site to participate. 
Mr. English himself had been a victim of a number of similar schemes and decided to open up his own, according to transcripts of chat room conversations. Those transcripts indicate that Mr. English himself may not have completely understood the bogus nature of the plan.
"The way it is set up is really kool, and we will make plenty and pay everyone, too," Mr. English wrote in the chat room. But then, for several minutes he struggled to understand how the plan could take in $300, only to pay out $600 days later.
"Where does the additional $300 come from so everyone gets paid?" Mr. English asked repeatedly. To solve that problem, Mr. English ultimately suggested that he would invest money in other Ponzi schemes.
According to records of EE-Biz investors, the company was formed last Oct. 21 by Mr. English and five others. Mr. English took the title of chief financial officer. The others -- who were mostly unemployed, with little experience in the business world -- were each named president.
Yet Mr. English "was the only one who knew how the money was being made," George Anderton, one founder, wrote in a memo to the S.E.C. "He refused to tell us but assured us that he had done massive work with his legal team to ensure that everything was legal, moral and had the blessings of all of the applicable regulatory agencies."
Actually, Mr. English had no such approvals -- and later, when he consulted a lawyer, he was told that his idea could not be carried out legally in Oklahoma, according to a confidential EE-Biz document.
The false assurances of compliance were part of an attempt to make EE-Biz stand out from other Internet Ponzi schemes, investigators said. But Mr. English went further, recruiting promoters for the site who were compensated for chatting up EE-Biz in cyberspace.
EE-Biz was also dressed up in the garb of a quasi-charitable organization to attract religious investors. Mr. English held the company out as a humanitarian group helping families with their finances. 
The promotion lured investors from around the world. According to information later seized by inspectors for the Postal Service, EE-Biz victimized people from all 50 states and the District of Columbia, as well as from Canada, Australia, New Zealand and other countries.
"Their lives are lived in the virtual world rather than the real world," Mr. Condren, the EE-Biz receiver, said of the investors, many of whom he has contacted. "They live all day long on the Internet. They stay up all night on the Internet."
To manage the Web site, Mr. English hired an Internet specialist named Kevin Thiesse. Before taking the job, Mr. Thiesse and a colleague spoke with Mr. English "and asked him whether EE-Biz Ventures was a 'Ponzi' scheme," Mr. Thiesse wrote in a subsequent e-mail to investors. Mr. English "assured us that EE-Biz Ventures was not a Ponzi scheme and that he was legitimately investing the funds offshore."
Money for EE-Biz poured in so fast that Mr. English's money problems were quickly solved. Banking records show that he opened multiple accounts, with tens of thousands of dollars running through them. 
With the flow of cash came a taste for spending. Weeks after being unable to pay his rent, Mr. English paid $23,000 for a silver Ford Mustang. Days later, he returned to the dealership with $25,000 for a pickup truck. Receipts show that he also spent tens of thousands of dollars for new computer equipment, videocassette recorders and other big-ticket items. The good life, it seemed, had come to the English home.
Soon, problems cropped up. Demand for EE-Biz was so strong that the computer systems crashed, stopping not only the payouts but also the influx of new money. Then in December, investors -- many needed cash for the holidays -- slowed their contributions. Payouts stopped completely, and complaints began.
"I need at the least a full refund of the $3,000 spend if you do not intend to pay anyone back," one investor wrote. "Remember, I have cancer and am unable to work for the next six months."
A couple in their 70's wrote Mr. English, explaining how they had been heavily in debt when they heard of EE-Biz and had taken out a loan to participate. "Had EE-Biz rolled just one more time, we would have been well on our way to recovery," the couple wrote. "We sure would be most grateful to you and EE-Biz for any help we may receive at this low tide in our lives."
As the pleas for help came in, Mr. English thrashed about for new money. Before Christmas, he sent an e-mail to investors, asking for financial support. Then, he sent another e-mail, saying that if everyone did not put in more money, their initial investments would be lost. That shocked the specialists running the EE-Biz Web site.
"The letter was nothing less than a letter of extortion," Mr. Thiesse wrote in a subsequent communication to investors. "It was requiring investors to make further spends in hope of obtaining their money."
Distressed, Mr. Thiesse and a colleague made some calls and became convinced that EE-Biz was a scam. They shut down the site. 
But with a list of as many as 56,000 gullible investors, EE-Biz attracted other get-rich-quick schemers. According to court depositions, Mr. English and several other EE-Biz founders met at a Florida hotel with a man promising to engineer a giant currency trade. For the deal, the group was told that they needed to raise more than $1 million, which would be used to "lease" $100 million from a shadowy Hong Kong entrepreneur. 
The proposal was ridiculous on its face -- why would anyone put his own money at risk so that others could take huge profits? But the EE-Biz investors sensed nothing wrong, and forwarded several hundred thousand dollars. The money has since disappeared. 
Investors contacted the government, and the S.E.C. quickly filed a complaint against Mr. English and EE-Biz, demanding that he return the money. Mr. English was also put on notice that he was a target of a criminal investigation.
Mr. English broached the idea of a plea deal, under which he would return $9 million that the government concluded had disappeared. The money, he said, would be provided by a benefactor named Garry Stroud, a resident of Canada who claimed to be the principal in a Swiss bank, Euro Credit and Exchange. The government agreed, after receiving sworn affidavits from both men that the money would not come out of the proceeds from EE-Biz.
In March, a $9 million check arrived from Mr. Stroud. But officials soon learned it was all a ruse: Euro Credit was not a real bank.
In a letter to the S.E.C., Mr. Stroud accused the government of failing to cash the check properly. The check, he wrote, should have been sent by courier to his bank's offices in Geneva, which would then cash it. But investigators checked out the story, and found that the offices were nothing more than rental space and that Mr. Stroud had given instructions that checks sent to the address were to be forwarded to him in Canada.
"He wrote a check that would only be cashed when it was sent back to him," said Harold R. Loftin Jr., an S.E.C. lawyer in the EE-Biz case. "The whole thing was ridiculous."
The more they examined Mr. Stroud, the more uncomfortable investigators became. The primary financial asset he listed was a half interest in a purported Peruvian debt, which he said was now an obligation of the American government for more than $1 trillion. The half interest was granted to him by the woman who said she was in contact with a space alien.
Why would Mr. Stroud, who did not return phone calls, go through the charade? Largely, officials say, to get a crack at the EE-Biz investors. 
According to a recently filed S.E.C. suit, Mr. Stroud has a history of defrauding investors. Already, he has informed EE-Biz investors that he deposited money they lost in accounts at Euro Credit. And while the investors can see the money in their name at the Euro Credit Web site, they cannot take any out. To do that, they have to send more money to Mr. Stroud, who says he will then provide a bank card that will allow withdrawals from any A.T.M. On top of that, he is offering the investors an opportunity to participate in another program to double their money.
And how have they responded? Many investors have already sent Mr. Stroud their money -- throwing another $300,000 away, by the S.E.C.'s estimate. Now they are anxiously awaiting the delivery of working debit cards that investigators believe will never come.

HEADLINE: Little 'Quiet' in Israel: 3 Arabs Die, Palestinians Retaliate 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 2 

 BODY:
The tenuous truce that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell tried to reinforce here last week was strained to the breaking point today when Palestinians killed an Israeli motorist and detonated car bombs in retaliation for Israel's killing of three West Bank militants late Sunday.
 In an effort to keep the violence from worsening, American intelligence agents held a late-night meeting with Palestinian and Israeli security officials in Tel Aviv. But diplomats were deeply pessimistic about the prospects for the full week of "quiet" that Israel has demanded before it will relax economic and travel restrictions on Palestinians and resume political talks. 
 "The events of the past two days show how fragile the cease-fire is," Terje Larsen, the chief United Nations representative in the region, said today. "All indications now are that it will not hold." 
The car bombs, which exploded early this morning in a blue-collar neighborhood east of Tel Aviv, caused no serious injuries. But an Israeli driver was shot dead this afternoon on a border-zone road near a Palestinian town, Tulkarm, prompting cries for retaliation from the Israeli right.
Nearby on the West Bank, in Jenin, thousands of angry Palestinians marched in a funeral procession, bearing aloft the bodies of three young men killed late Sunday night by missiles fired on their car from Israeli helicopters. An Israeli military spokesman said the fusillade thwarted a terror attack. 
The bodies were wrapped in the flags of the radical Islamic Jihad movement, and mourners chanted slogans vowing revenge. 
Hours later, outside Nablus, Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian who they said was holding a suspicious object. Palestinians said the man was a taxi driver tossing a bag of garbage into a rubbish heap.
In the evening, Palestinian snipers wounded a Jewish settler driving in the West Bank, and the Israeli Army reported isolated shootings at its posts in Bethlehem, Ramallah and southern Gaza.
"We think the Palestinians have not done enough to fight terror and to end the violence," Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said in Washington. "We also want to make clear that we remain opposed to Israel's policy of targeted killings."
At the United Nations, Secretary General Kofi Annan called on both the Israelis and Palestinians to exercise maximum restraint, adding that neither side could achieve security without progress on political issues.
Mr. Larsen met in Gaza this morning with the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, whom he described later as "furious" about the previous night's helicopter strike by the Israelis.
"This was a flagrant violation of the cease-fire," Mr. Arafat told reporters as he left the meeting. "It is an ugly crime against our citizens."
Still, Mr. Arafat vowed to continue to try to enforce the cease-fire, Mr. Larsen said.
But several Palestinian militant groups declared after Israel's attack that the truce Mr. Arafat had asked them to honor was no longer in force. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestinian, a small leftist faction, claimed responsibility for the car bombs this morning, which they said were retaliation for the helicopter assault and the killing of two other Palestinian activists earlier Sunday. 
The Islamic Jihad declared that "every Zionist in every inch of Palestine and the depth of Zionist settlements will be a target for our human bombs, our car bombs and our bullets."
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, defending the helicopter strike as "active self-defense," shrugged off the threats, saying: "The Palestinians announced they will end the cease-fire. I don't know what cease-fire they are talking about. I don't know of one quiet day so far."
Israeli politicians from across the spectrum endorsed the helicopter strike, accepting the army's assertion that the three men had loaded the car with explosives and were planning to bomb an Israeli target. An army spokesman said today that the army knew when and where the men had planned to strike, but could not give details without compromising intelligence information. 
"This is not fire directed against innocent people," said the transportation minister, Efraim Sneh, a Labor party leader and former general. "This is an operational action against those who are planning terror attacks."
Palestinians challenged the suggestion by some Israeli officials that the helicopters were dispatched at short notice to frustrate an imminent attack. The oldest of the three men killed, Mohammad Ahmed Besharat, 28, identified in Israel as a Hamas leader but said in Jenin to belong to Islamic Jihad, had been the target of a failed Israeli assassination attempt one month earlier, Palestinians said. Mr. Besharat was said by Israeli officials to have been involved in terror bombings in two Israeli cities, Hadera and Netanya.
Also killed in the car was Samech Nur Ziab, 22, an officer in the Palestinian Coast Guard who Israeli officials said was an explosives expert, and Walid Sudki Besharat.
Some Palestinian officials contended that the raid was a premeditated Israeli attempt to keep a truce from taking hold in order to avoid subsequent political negotiations. 
"I am not a Shin Bet man, nor a member of the Palestinian security apparatus," Ziyad Abu Zayyad, a Palestinian cabinet minister, said on Israeli Army radio. "I am a political man. But I can also read what's happening on the ground, and what's happening on the ground testifies that there's an Israeli strategic decision to try to evade the cease-fire."
Speaking anonymously, Israeli military officers told Israeli reporters today that the attack was carried out in accordance with a cabinet directive issued before Mr. Sharon departed for the United States last week. That directive was also said to have authorized the killing of a Fatah leader in Nablus, Osama Jabara, who died June 24 in an explosion in a public telephone booth that he regularly used. Israeli officials said Mr. Jabara had prepared bombs for use against civilian Israeli targets. 
According to Palestinian human rights organizers, 25 Palestinians have been killed in 16 Israeli assassinations since November, including six bystanders. Most targets were political militants known to oppose peace agreements with Israel, or members of Palestinian security forces that Israel contends had taken part in armed attacks during the last nine months.
Israeli human rights groups have protested what they say is an undeclared government policy of "extrajudicial executions" of suspected terrorists. European diplomats said today that the European Union planned to condemn the helicopter assault.
The Israeli government has never acknowledged that it carries out pre-emptive assassinations of Palestinians it considers security threats. But after many of the earlier incidents, government radio and television news programs cited unidentified officials defending what they called the "liquidations." Such was the case today, as army officers offered biographical details about the slain men, saying they had been identified as security threats long before and had been killed deliberately.
"They are not interested in having people talk, in a cooling-off period, in dialogue," said Mr. Sneh, the transportation minister. "That contradicts their world view."

HEADLINE: OPEC Planners Are Guessing Because of Iraq 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
When the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Vienna today to take up its delicate task -- keeping oil prices high without crippling the global economy -- it will likely be hamstrung in its planning by one of its own, Iraq.
 Iraq pulled its exports off the world market last month to protest a British-American plan to revise radically the sanctions by the United Nations that have been in place since the war in the Persian Gulf. Though that plan is off the table for now, it remains unclear if Iraq will resume exports -- and, therefore, what sort of market OPEC will operate in. 
 Most analysts expect the cartel to hold production levels steady, at 24.2 million barrels a day, out of satisfaction with a supply-demand equilibrium that has kept prices in the $25-a-barrel range. 
OPEC members have pointed out that with supplies ample -- despite the halt in Iraqi exports -- crude oil prices have retreated since peaking above $30 in mid-May. Yesterday, oil for August delivery fell 1.1 percent, to $25.95 in New York.
So far, the cartel has been reluctant to officially increase production quotas, for fear that Iraq could soon turn on the pumps and flood world markets with petroleum, driving prices down further.
The danger, analysts say, is if OPEC is guessing wrong about its most inscrutable member. If Iraq stays out of the market through the peak driving season in the United States -- the world's biggest oil consumer -- prices could rise enough to rattle the already-fragile world economy, experts warn.
"It's as if OPEC by not doing anything is cutting production at a high-demand time," said Amy Myers Jaffe, senior energy adviser at the James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy at Rice University. "This could tighten markets considerably. That is going to affect the price of oil and send it up."
Iraq's fury was provoked by an British-American effort to revise the so-called oil-for-food program, established under United Nations sanctions to let Iraq sell oil to meet its citizens' basic needs. The plan would have expanded civilian trade while tightening controls on the smuggling of oil and prohibited weapons.
Rather than invite an expected Russian veto of that proposal, the United States and Britain decided to seek a five-month extension of the current program, which expires at midnight today.
Iraq, before its recent exit from the world market, exported a little more than two million barrels a day. Anywhere from 500,000 to one million barrels of that total made its way to the United States on a given day, or 5 percent to 11 percent of this country's daily imports. 
Over the last month, other OPEC members have informally replaced some of the missing Iraqi oil by exporting about 700,000 barrels a day above their quotas, industry experts said. That means, however, that markets are still shy more than one million barrels a day.
Analysts said that it is still too early to assess the impact of Iraq's export cutoff. "It takes 30 to 40 days for the drop in Iraqi exports to show up in U.S. inventory figures," said Adam E. Sieminski, senior oil analyst with Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "In another week or two, people will be going the other way with prices, because they will see the loss of the Iraqi barrels."
For now, OPEC appears comfortable with that possibility, said Raad Alkadiri, an expert on Iraq and oil at the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm. 
"This approach creates a risk later in the year that supplies will be tight," Mr. Alkadiri said, referring to OPEC's likely decision to keep production steady. "But OPEC is willing to take the risk that prices might go too high rather than do something and have prices fall too low."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
I.B.M. Will Cut Jobs In Its Services Group

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 

 BODY:
I.B.M., in an effort to hone the size and shape of its services group, announced layoffs today that could affect as much as 1 percent of the fast-growing division's jobs in America.
 I.B.M. declined to give a figure, but roughly 750 positions could be cut if 1 percent of positions were shed in the United States, which has roughly half the 150,000 employees in Global Services, I.B.M.'s consulting arm. 
 The layoffs were being made by local managers trying to respond to changing client demand and did not reflect a business slowdown, I.B.M. said.
"This is not a voluntary program," said Jan Butler, a spokeswoman for Global Services. "I think today is the day that some people are being notified, but it is something we do."
The cuts come as investors are looking for clues to the state of the economy, but, "This is not a signal of anything," Ms. Butler said. "I wouldn't say it is a matter of business slowing down."
Global Services, I.B.M.'s consulting and outsourcing arm, brought in more than one-third of the corporation's sales in its last fiscal year and has helped it weather the economic downturn better than many other technology firms.
