HEADLINE: A Local Institution Makes His Rounds 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA R. OLSEN 

 BODY:
They are everywhere, it seems, those brown United Parcel Service trucks and white FedEx vans that rumble down the street to deliver books, legal documents, computers, swimsuits, gifts, CD's and the like to America's homes and businesses.
 With the boom in Internet shopping, the increase in home-based businesses and until recently, a strong economy, the number of small-package delivery drivers in the United States has climbed to more than one million, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 To some people, they are anonymous faces, men and women clad in look-alike uniforms who ask customers to sign a hand-held computer and then are gone. But in small towns especially, they are Joe or Charlie or Sue, local fixtures who ask how the children are doing in school or shoot the breeze about a favorite sports team. They are part of the daily rhythm of things -- a reassuring human presence in an increasingly wired world. 
Those relationships -- as well as the chance to make a living outdoors and out from under the thumb of a boss -- are what make driving a delivery truck a rewarding career for workers like Warren Plum.
Mr. Plum has driven the same route for nearly 35 years in Spring Lake, N.J., a seaside town of 3,500, an hour's drive south of Manhattan. His status as local institution was on full display as he made his rounds one recent Friday.
At 8:15 a.m., Mr. Plum, 58, checked his truck's tires, horn and directional signals at the U.P.S. distribution site in nearby Tinton Falls. He then filed into an office with about 15 colleagues for a management pep talk. Richard Bowers, the supervisor, reviewed safe-driving pointers and wound up by saying that "it's going to be a hot one."
He was in his truck at 8:40. He turned onto Route 18 south for the 12-mile trek to Spring Lake. "I started out delivering to people with young children, and now the children have grown up and had children," he said. He could have retired years ago, he added, but he stuck it out for the benefits. With all the climbing in and out of the truck carrying packages, his job is like a gym on wheels. Then there is the scenery: the ocean surf, the lake with its carpets of lily pads, the manicured lawns.
In this job, speed matters, and Mr. Plum averages 25 stops an hour, completing some deliveries in under a minute. If a package does not require a signature, he might knock, yell "U.P.S." through a screen door and leave it on the porch.
But speed is not everything. When Mr. Plum pulled up to a house on Route 71, James Fetyko came outside to take two big boxes containing fire-alarm equipment from him. The two men chatted awhile before Mr. Plum climbed back into his truck. "See you Monday," he said.
"I never ask, but he always helps," Mr. Plum said. "He's a big Mets fan, and we usually talk about the previous night's ball game."
On the way to the next stop, Mr. Plum passed Joseph Amato in the parking lot of his business, JMA Auto Service, also on Route 71. The two men waved and Mr. Plum slowed down and shouted to him through the passenger-side window, "I'll be back later."
At 10:15, he walked into Joseph's Delicatessen on Warren Avenue for a cup of coffee and a buttered bran muffin. As one of the restaurant's most faithful customers, he has his own chair imprinted with the slogan, "Warren -- The Main Man." His photo graces the "wall of fame" behind the counter, along with Mickey Mantle, Joe DiMaggio, and Craig Biggio, the Houston Astro infielder and Spring Lake resident.
He sat in his personalized chair at a table with two other regulars, maintenance workers for St. Catherine's Church a few blocks away, and fell into a conversation with one of them, Richard Burgess. Mr. Burgess moonlights as a member of the pit crew at Wall Stadium, the local stock-car racing track. Mr. Plum has been going to the races almost every Saturday night for the last 10 years, so the two men like to compare notes. 
Joseph Valentino, the deli's owner, came over to greet Mr. Plum. He told a visitor that the town would not be the same when Mr. Plum retired. Mr. Valentino's father, who also works at the deli, nodded in agreement. "It's going to take three people to replace Warren," the elder Mr. Valentino said.
At 10:30, it was back to work and a drive over to Win-Tron Electronics. As Mr. Plum scanned the boxes and sent them down a roller, Christopher Bobbe, the Win-Tron worker who retrieves them, joked that he needed to borrow his truck. The shipping manager Mark Fala eyed Mr. Plum's brown shorts and teased him about his legs.
On the way to a delivery at Alan's Butcher Block, Mr. Plum walked by four retired men sitting on a town bench. "Hey, Warren, what's happening?" one called out. One of his companions said: "What's new? Were you on vacation?" "Yes," Mr. Plum said, keeping up his quick pace.
At the butcher shop, the owner Alan Lacey asked Mr. Plum if his ears had been ringing. Mr. Lacey and some friends were just talking about him at the Spring Meadow Golf Course down the road in Wall Township, he explained. "They wanted to know if you were still working, and I told them yes," he said.
At 1 p.m., Mr. Plum returned to Joseph's Deli for a pork barbecue sandwich. This time, he rubbed elbows with the town's police chief, Robert Dawson Jr., 34. When he was a child, Mr. Dawson would throw snowballs at him, Mr. Plum recalled. "Now, he enforces the law."
At around 5, having delivered a total of 230 packages, Mr. Plum returned to Tinton Falls to turn in his truck. He then drove his 1993 Toyota truck to his home in Point Pleasant, 18 miles away.
Point Pleasant might be where he lived, but Spring Lake had a hold on him, too, he said. "Come to think of it," he said, "I'm in Spring Lake more than I'm home."

HEADLINE: A Success for BP in Moscow: Fill It Up, Boris? 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 3 

 BODY:
Almost four years after sinking half a billion dollars into a Russian oil company, BP still has had more frustrations than profits. But it has met with quiet success in one of the least likely places -- Moscow's retail gasoline market.
 Russia's huge oil deposits lured BP to this market in 1997. In that year, BP invested $484 million in Sidanko, a Russian oil company, expecting to use its extraction expertise to transform Russia's oil industry. But the investment became mired in a bitter dispute among local business groups, a fight that last week extended to a separate project in a big Siberian gas field. 
 Even as BP fought that high-profile battle for Sidanko, a lesser-known -- and initially unwanted -- investment in gasoline stations was beginning to gush cash.
BP went into the gas station business here by accident. It inherited plans for a handful of gas stations from Mobil of the United States, after the two companies merged their European operations in 1996. BP, now one of the biggest foreign investors in Russia, at the time had chosen to focus its retail efforts on Poland, a country with clearer rules than those in Russia.
But after opening the small chain in Moscow and its suburbs with help from the ST Group, a powerful local partner with close ties to the Moscow city government, the business began to look like it was worth keeping.
The company now owns 30 stations, each of which now sells an average of 3.4 million gallons a year -- four times the average in Europe and three times the average in the United States.
Jeff Franks, general director of Petrol Complex, a joint venture of BP and the ST Group, said that from the time he arrived in 1998, "we didn't have enough cash registers to take in all the cash."
Those casino-size revenues, however, did not produce profits until March, in part because a ruble devaluation in 1998 caused the price of imported equipment and supplies to soar. BP now tries to buy as much as it can in Russia, with cheap rubles.
Cost is only part of the reason for BP's success. The company has also benefited by offering Russian drivers what is a rare commodity here -- good service. BP's minimarts, complete with selections of wine and espresso bars, contrast starkly with Russian gas stations, which rarely carry food and usually require customers to pay for gas by stuffing cash through a tinted window and to ask questions into a microphone.
President Vladimir V. Putin, who passes two stations on his way to work every day, has praised them publicly. BP has even had to contend with imitation brands, the ultimate compliment.
Mr. Franks said the gas stations have added to BP's reputation, which should help its investments in Sidanko and the Siberian gas field. They also give the company an enviable head start as Russians become wealthier, increasing the demand for cars -- and gasoline.
BP's experience in the retail market here illustrates how Russia's business climate has changed the last five years. While BP's powerful partner set it above small crime groups that sought to control the market in the early 1990's, the company still had to contend with more than 500 independent retailers. Since then, the strongest companies have prevailed, leaving about 25 retailers. (This same consolidation process took about 20 years in Britain, Mr. Franks said.)
Many problems remain, notably red tape. At one gas station construction site, for example, two different state inspections have given conflicting sets of orders.
"When I first got here, I thought we had bad translators," Mr. Franks said. "Now I know the laws are just written in gray. The same rule looks different in the hands of each new official."
But things are changing. The government has taken some steps in an economic reform program, notably slashing tax rates, which could help BP, whose diligence as a taxpayer puts it at a disadvantage in a country where few of its competitors pay in full.
"Russia isn't different from anyone else, it's just a few years back in history -- it's a 10-year-old country," Mr. Franks said. "When it moves, it moves fast. From the absurd to reasonable in two years -- that's classic Russia."

HEADLINE: Accord Is Set on Timor Gap Energy Revenue 

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, July 3 

 BODY:
Australia and East Timor have agreed on how to split potentially lucrative energy revenue, a deal that is expected to channel millions of dollars to the struggling East Timorese economy, as development of rich gas and oil deposits beneath the Timor Sea begins.
 The proposed 30-year agreement will give East Timor 90 percent of the revenue from petroleum development in the Timor Gap, a portion of the seabed between Australia and East Timor that has been in dispute for decades. 
 The previous agreement, which Australia reached in 1989 with Indonesia, lapsed 10 years later after East Timor voted for independence. Negotiations on a new pact started last year. Until a deal was set and the legal and tax rules were clear, progress on major petroleum projects was stalled. 
East Timor is expected to receive substantially more than $3.6 billion in revenue from existing and planned developments in the area the next 24 years, according to a statement today from the Australian government.
Previously, East Timor received just half of the proceeds from development in the Timor Gap, an area of about 30,000 square miles. Oil is the nation's only significant economic hope besides coffee, and perhaps eventually, tourism.
The money from petroleum development will swell significantly in coming years as billions of dollars of investments come on line. One major development now under way is a $1.6 billion project to develop liquid reserves in the Bayu-Undan field. Phillips Petroleum of the United States estimates that there are 400 million barrels of liquid reserves there. Woodside Petroleum of Australia also has interests in the Timor Gap. And there are methanol and liquefied natural gas projects planned there, too. Liquefied natural gas could be exported to growing markets in Asia and the United States West Coast in three to five years.
Time was running short for the new treaty to be completed. East Timor will hold national elections the end of next month. And the agreement that was announced today will be incorporated into a new treaty when East Timor becomes independent, which is expected early next year.
Jose Ramos-Horta, Mari Alkatiri and Peter Galbraith, members of the transitional East Timor cabinet, finished the agreement last week in Canberra.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Rose in May Led by Demand for Vehicles 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3 

 BODY:
Orders placed with factories rose in May for the third time in the last four months, led by increased demand for autos and semiconductors, the government said today. Inventories fell for a fourth consecutive month, suggesting manufacturers may have to bolster production after an eight-month decline.
 Factory orders increased 2.5 percent in May after a 3.4 percent drop in April, the Commerce Department said. Orders excluding transportation rose 2.3 percent, the biggest gain in one year. 
 The report comes a day after a private industry index measuring manufacturing rose last month to the highest level since November and adds evidence factories may be recovering from their slump.
"Stockpiles are moving off the shelves and, if demand starts to increase, manufacturers will boost production, which leads to higher economic growth," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist at Argus Research in New York.
Nonmilitary capital goods orders excluding aircraft, a barometer of business investment in new equipment, rose 0.3 percent in May, the first increase since January.
Inventories at factories fell 0.3 percent after falling 0.2 percent in April, and shipments rose 2.6 percent. That brought the inventory-to-shipments ratio to 1.37 months from 1.41 in April. The ratio is the lowest since May 2000.
"Inventories have been pulled down so low that it doesn't take much of an increase in demand to get orders to pick up," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union in Charlotte, N.C. "It's a very favorable development." 
Orders for all durable goods, big-ticket items intended to last three or more years, rose 3 percent in May after falling 5.7 percent in April.
Orders for transportation equipment rose 3.5 percent in May after falling 9.4 percent in April. Orders for automotive equipment rose 3.5 percent in May.
Orders for nondurable goods like clothing and paper goods rose 1.9 percent in May after falling 0.6 percent in April.
Orders for computers and electronic products rose 2.3 percent in May after declining 13.7 percent in April. Semiconductor orders surged 32.5 percent after falling 40.3 percent a month earlier.
While demand for semiconductors will probably decline 14 percent to 17 percent this year from last, a reduction in inventories may lead to increased orders toward the end of the year, George Scalise, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, said last week. "The underlying demand for the computer products, communications products, is still there."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Warnings on Profits and Holiday Lull Keep Shares Flat

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street stalled yesterday, held back by a new round of earnings warnings and decreased trading activity ahead of the Fourth of July holiday.
 The Dow Jones industrial average declined 22.61 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 10,571.11, after an abbreviated session that ended at 1 p.m. United States markets will be closed today for the holiday and re-open tomorrow. 
 Broader stock indicators were nearly unchanged. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 7.92 points, or 0.4 percent, to 2,140.80, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.26 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 1,234.45. 
"We've had a little bit of earnings news, but basically this is a pretty quiet market because of the holiday," said James Meyer, director of research at Janney Montgomery Scott. "It'll probably be more productive today on the golf course, than on the trading floor."
DuPont fell 92 cents, to $47.20, after sharply curtailing its earnings estimate for the second quarter, blaming a global economic slowdown and a strong dollar.
Earnings worries also hurt technology stocks. Axsys Technologies fell 17 cents, to $10.74, after reducing its second-quarter outlook and cutting 9 percent of its work force because of soft demand for products.
In the software sector, BroadVision dropped 89 cents, to $4.04, after lowering its second-quarter revenue forecast and expanding loss estimates.
The warnings are the latest in what has been an unrelenting string of bad news ahead of second-quarter earnings reports, which start this month.
Although Wall Street had been expecting the second quarter to be weak, many investors have been caught off guard by the level of weakness and most companies' inability to predict when the environment will improve.
That murkiness has thwarted the market's efforts to rally. Since investors have no confidence in when results will improve, they have had little incentive to fully commit their money to the market and do a lot of buying.
Even a new Commerce Department report yesterday showing United States factory orders rebounding in May to their best performance in nearly a year -- chiefly on stronger demand for cars and semiconductors -- failed to inspire investors.
"The whole key here is earnings, and when earnings will start to turn," said Robert Harrington, co-head of listed block trading at UBS Warburg. "It's just not visible quite yet when that will happen, but people are hopeful it will.
"The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates six times this year. People are just waiting to see when things will turnaround," he added.
Also yesterday, European regulators, as expected, blocked General Electric's $45 billion purchase of Honeywell International, citing competitive concerns. G.E. slipped 69 cents, to $49.51, while Honeywell rose 99 cents, to $35.10, on a report the board was going to replace Michael R. Bonsignore, the chief executive and chairman. 
In the bond market, Treasury prices fell yesterday in a shortened trading session. Bond markets, which closed at 2 p.m., will be closed today and will reopen tomorrow.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 13/32 , to a price of 9 76/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.38 percent from 5.32 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 15/32 , to 95 4/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.72 percent from 5.68 percent yesterday.

HEADLINE: Honeywell Regroups as Chief Resigns 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Hours after the European Commission rejected the $45 billion acquisition by General Electric of Honeywell International, Michael R. Bonsignore, the chairman and chief executive of Honeywell, tendered his resignation.
 The company, which is based in Morristown, N.J., also said it would take a pretax revamping charge of $575 million to $625 million in the second quarter and forecasted full-year revenue and earnings that were lower than consensus Wall Street estimates. 
 The announcements came last evening, at the close of an extended meeting of Honeywell's board.
Lawrence A. Bossidy, who was chairman and chief executive of Allied Signal when it bought Honeywell in 1999 and served for a brief period as chairman of Honeywell after the merger, was named to succeed Mr. Bonsignore, 60, who had been with Honeywell for more than 31 years. 
In recent weeks, as the prospects that Honeywell and General Electric would merge faded, analysts said Mr. Bonsignore's future role at an independent Honeywell was increasingly suspect. They said the appointment of Mr. Bossidy was a positive move.
"Mr. Bossidy's return is a plus for the stock," said Harriet C. Baldwin, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "He is very focused on operating numbers. With him in charge the likelihood improves that Honeywell will improve profit margins over the next year."
" He has very good credibility with investors," she added. "And it will be important for Honeywell to communicate with investors." 
In a telephone conference call with reporters, Mr. Bossidy, 66, said he was first approached about returning to Honeywell three weeks ago, following a board meeting. "There was a discussion about a change of command," Mr. Bossidy said. "I know the company better than anybody else, and I was an ideal candidate."
Mr. Bossidy, who has signed a one-year contract, said his tenure at Honeywell "might be less, it might be more."
"I am not here to start a new career," he added, "but to restore stability." 
The intention, Mr. Bossidy insisted, is not to prepare Honeywell for an immediate sale. "We want to stay independent now, and get the company back on its feet," he said. 
But in the next breath, he described his mandate from Honeywell's board to "fix the company or sell it." 
Mr. Bossidy said a decision on whether to take legal action against General Electric for not moving forcefully enough to get the merger approved would be made "sooner rather than later." 
The threat of a lawsuit could pressure G.E. to make some payment to Honeywell to compensate for the collapse of the deal, even though under the merger agreement G.E. is not required to pay a termination fee. 
Analysts said at this point the merits of a lawsuit look dubious and could be a needless distraction for Honeywell. It also remains to be seen if Mr. Bossidy, who spent much of his career at G.E., would want to sue his former employer. 
During his conversation last night, Mr. Bossidy said he had spoken with John F. Welch Jr., the G.E. chairman, earlier to arrange a golf date.
Shares of Honeywell closed at $35.10, up 99 cents yesterday. Over the last 52 weeks, the stock has traded as high as $55.69 and as low as $33.
Analysts agreed the company needed a bit of time to regain its footing.
"In essence, Honeywell has not been run as an independent company for the better part of a year," said Eli Lustgarten, an analyst at H. C. Wainwright & Company. "Because of that, there are a lot of basic business decisions that have been postponed. I would assume they will begin to get the business back in shape before they go back on the block." 
Last night, Honeywell said that its second-quarter charge related primarily to customer settlements, asset impairments, merger-related expenses and legal and environmental costs. It expects second-quarter revenue to be $6 billion, and earnings to be 53 cents to 55 cents a share. For the full year, the company is forecasting revenue of $24 billion to $24.5 billion and earnings of $2.15 to $2.30 a share.
Wall Street analysts, who have not had any guidance from Honeywell since General Electric made its offer last fall, had been projecting earnings of $2.50 to $2.55 a share. 
Despite the lower numbers, Mr. Bossidy suggested Honeywell could bounce back from its problems, which are only partly rooted in a weak economic environment.
"We have been hurt by the distraction," involved in attempting to merge with G.E., he said. "There is a lot we can improve despite the economic environment. I want to reinitiate our Six Sigma activities, and do more on e-commerce." (Six Sigma is a cost-cutting procedure that was started by G.E. during Mr. Bossidy's tenure there.) 
Matt Collins, an analyst with Edward Jones in St. Louis, said Mr. Bossidy's return to Honeywell made it more likely that for a while at least the company would remain independent. "That is a good sign they want to fix things," he said. "With Bossidy back in control there is a higher likelihood they could survive alone for some period of time." 
It appears Mr. Bossidy will shed some of Honeywell's businesses. Last summer, before G.E. pre-empted United Technologies and began its $45 billion bid for the company, Honeywell identified its automotive brake business as a candidate for sale. 
"It is obvious that we have the best aerospace business in the world," Mr. Bossidy said. "That continues to be at the centerpiece of what we are going to try and develop and grow further." 
However desirable, selling businesses in the midst of an economic slowdown will be a challenge, analysts said. And some said that once they were gone Honeywell itself would again be a takeover candidate. 
"It is likely Larry Bossidy is being brought in to clean up the company a bit, shore up morale and shine it up for sale. I think the odds on the company remaining independent seem pretty low," said Michael Holton, an analyst at T. Rowe Price.
In addition to United Technologies, Mr. Holton said Tyco International and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing have been mentioned as possible bidders for Honeywell.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
True or False Or a Bit of Both

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
A COMMON indictment of public schools is that they no longer offer upward mobility to most immigrants. It is said that in the first half of the 20th century, children learned English, went to college and joined the middle class but that many of today's immigrants are more likely to drop out, take dead-end jobs or end up in prison.
 Many true accounts reinforce these beliefs. But less noticed are equally valid anecdotes pointing to an opposite claim. 
 Policy by anecdote is flawed because too often we notice only what confirms our preconceptions. California's recent experience with Mexican immigrants provides ample material for stories about school failure. But on a day to celebrate the American promise, we might also turn to anecdotes of another kind.
Recent college graduations in California featured many immigrants from impoverished families whose first language was Spanish, who came through much-maligned bilingual education programs, learned English and now head for graduate schools or professions.
At California State University at Fresno, for example, about 700 of 4,000 graduates this spring were Latino, typically the first in their families to attend college. Top-ranked were Pedro Nava and Maria Rocio Magana, Mexican-born children of farm and cannery workers.
Mr. Nava did not settle in the United States until the third grade. Before that, he lived in migrant labor camps during harvests and in Mexico the rest of the year. His California schooling was in Spanish until the fifth grade, when he was moved to English instruction. Now, with a college degree, he has enrolled in management and teacher training courses.
Ms. Magana did not place into English classes until the 11th grade. Now fluent in both academic and conversational English, she will soon begin a Ph.D. program in anthropology at the University of Chicago.
Their achievements are not unique. Both credit success to their mothers' emphasis on education. Both mothers enrolled in English and high school equivalency courses at the local community college.
Across California, these two-year institutions play an especially important role for immigrants.
Lourdes Andrade just finished her junior year at Brown, having transferred there after getting associate of arts degrees in history and liberal arts at Oxnard Community College, 40 miles northwest of Los Angeles. She arrived here at age 4 and all through elementary school worked with her mother making beds and cleaning bathrooms in hotels. She, too, attributes her success to her mother's strong academic pressure and also to mentoring she received in a federally financed program to give extra academic support to migrant children.
The program's director, Lorenzo Moraza, also grew up speaking only Spanish. Now a school principal, Mr. Moraza estimates that about 30 percent of the immigrant children he has worked with acquired public school records that led them to college. Those who receive bachelor's degrees are many fewer, but Mr. Moraza says he thinks most drop out of college for economic reasons, not academic ones.
At the Fresno campus, nearly two-thirds of the immigrants and children of immigrants who enter as freshmen eventually graduate. The university operates special support services to help them do so.
You cannot spend time in California without noticing an extensive middle class of Latino teachers, doctors, lawyers and small-business people. Many are recent immigrants. Some attended Catholic schools but most are products of the public system. Many had bilingual education in the 1970's, 80's and 90's. California has now banned such instruction, assuming it failed.
Anecdotes are plentiful to support a claim that schools fail immigrant children or an equally persuasive claim that schools serve them well. Getting better statistics should help. Government numbers do not distinguish between students who are immigrants (or whose parents immigrated) from Hispanics with American roots for several generations.
To help interpret California's experience, the best federal data tell only that in 1996, there were 100,000 college students nationwide who were American citizens born in Mexico. This is less than 1 percent of all college students. But uncounted are even larger numbers of those born here to recent migrants.
Even a balanced collection of anecdotes that include successes as well as failures cannot determine whether California schools are less effective than we should expect, and whether wholesale change is needed to move more immigrants to the middle class. But the answer is certainly more complex than the stereotypes of systematic failure that pervade most accounts.

Study of Car Loans Shows Racial Disparity in Costs
A study of more than 300,000 car loans arranged through Nissan dealers from March 1993 to last September -- thought to be the largest pool of car loan data ever analyzed for racial patterns -- shows that black customers in 33 states consistently paid more than white customers, regardless of credit history.
 Among the largest states, the study showed that, on average, blacks paid $245 more in Connecticut, $339 more in New Jersey and $405 more in New York. Page A1. 

Airlines Provide Online Bargains
The bargains available on the Internet are becoming scarce everywhere but the airline industry, which is pushing customers to buy online and rewarding them to do so. A1.

Orders placed with factories rose 2.5 percent in May for the third time in the last four months, led by increased demand for autos and semiconductors, the government said. HEADLINE: New Jersey Appeals Court Bars Firing of Transsexual 

BYLINE:  By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A New Jersey appeals court said yesterday that transsexuals were protected by state laws against discrimination, as it ruled in the case of a doctor who was fired after he began dressing as a woman in preparation for a sex change.
 A three-judge panel of the state's Appellate Division ruled that the doctor, who is now a woman, could sue her former employer, a South Jersey clinic, for wrongful termination under the state's bias laws. 
 "It is incomprehensible to us that our Legislature would ban discrimination against heterosexual men and women, against homosexual men and women, and others, but would condone discrimination against men or women who seek to change their anatomical sex," the judges wrote in a lengthy decision.
Civil rights advocates called the decision significant because it broadened the definition of the characteristics or conditions protected by laws that bar discrimination based on sex. 
Matt Coles, director of the lesbian and gay rights project for the American Civil Liberties Union, said many courts around the country had addressed, piecemeal, issues of gender identity, like whether a male employee can be fired for wearing a dress.
"This court looked at the whole thing and said that gender identity of every sort is protected against discrimination," said Mr. Coles, whose group has offered to join in the lawsuit. "It said in effect that everything from being a little too masculine if you are a woman, or being a little too feminine if you are a man, to someone's actually physically changing their gender, is protected against discrimination."
The court reversed a decision by a Superior Court judge in Camden that had dismissed a lawsuit by Dr. Carla Enriquez, born Carlos Enriquez, against West Jersey Health Systems, which ran the West Jersey Center for Behavior, Learning and Attention. That center, whose location was not disclosed in court papers, fired Dr. Enriquez as its medical director in October 1997 after learning of the doctor's plans to undergo surgery to become a woman.
The Superior Court judge, E. Stevenson Fluharty, found that transexualism was not a recognized mental or physical disability, and noted that Dr. Enriquez did not consider herself gay and did not face discrimination as a gay person. Therefore, the judge said, she was not entitled to protection under state bias laws, which say it is unlawful for an employer to dismiss someone based on the person's sex or "affectional or sexual orientation."
The appellate court disagreed; it ruled that Dr. Enriquez's condition, known as gender dysphoria, was a handicap covered by the state law, and ordered the case back to Superior Court.
Calls to Dr. Enriquez's lawyer were not returned. A spokeswoman for Virtua Health, a nonprofit health system that now owns West Jersey Health Systems, would not comment on the ruling. Virtua was created two years ago when West Jersey merged with Memorial Hospital of Burlington County. 
According to court papers, Dr. Enriquez was in the private practice of general and developmental pediatrics from 1974 to 1995. As Carlos Enriquez, he was hired in November 1995 as medical director for the West Jersey clinic. Less than a year later, he began preparations for a sex change, including shaving his beard and growing breasts.
Dr. Enriquez contends that in early 1997, executives of West Jersey, including John Cossa, the vice president, expressed their discomfort with the changes and that Mr. Cossa said, "Stop all this and go back to your previous appearance." That October, Mr. Cossa gave Dr. Enriquez a letter of dismissal. 
The doctor, who had a sex change operation in 1998, is also suing for breach of contract and interference with economic opportunity.

HEADLINE: Guitars Gently Weep as Nashville Pays Tribute to Chet Atkins 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, July 3 

 BODY:
Chet Atkins was as lean and spare and intense as Nashville is boisterous, a reticent musical craftsman who shaped and defined a city of showmen. At his funeral today, a worshipful country music industry tried to define its debt to him, finally giving up on superlatives and expressing itself as he did in the gentle picking of a Gretsch electric guitar.
 As his friends Marty Stuart and Vince Gill played some of Mr. Atkins's hits, much of country music's royalty sat motionless on the hard wooden pews of the Ryman Auditorium, the old gospel tabernacle where Mr. Atkins played so often with the Grand Ole Opry. There was a strong sense among them that Mr. Atkins, who died of cancer on Saturday at 77, was the best musician of their music's founding generation, and took with him something elemental that is now lost in the marketplace. 
 "We will never see the like of his talent in one man," said a barely composed Eddy Arnold, the country singer whose hits in the 1950's and 60's were produced by Mr. Atkins. "When you talked about who was the greatest guitar player, Chet's name was never mentioned, because you just took him and put him up there, and then you argued about the rest of them." 
But even beyond his six-string virtuosity, Mr. Atkins presided over the city for decades as its most prominent recording executive, a principal creator of the smooth and palatable "Nashville Sound" that took the music from its bluegrass origins to worldwide commercial success and erected a pillar of the state's economy. If the strings and controlled arrangements he and other producers added to the music stole some of its spontaneity and edge over the years, Mr. Atkins always said he did what was necessary to keep from being drowned out by rock 'n' roll.
Some results of his rescue efforts were evident in the long caravan of limousines that pulled up to the side door of the Ryman this morning and discharged celebrities that he first signed to recording contracts, or produced, or coached through ramshackle lives to stardom.
"He changed my life," said Charley Pride, the industry's only black superstar, discovered by Mr. Atkins. "Everything that ever happened to me started with him."
Dolly Parton, whom he signed to RCA, was not there, but Ray Stevens was, and Steve Wariner and T. G. Sheppard. 
But it was the older stars, Mr. Atkins's own fragile generation, who showed up in the greatest numbers, struggling through infirmities to pay their tributes. Kitty Wells and her husband, Johnny Wright, walked slowly into the hall, Mr. Wright using a cane. Jumpin' Bill Carlisle, 92, whose Knoxville radio show gave Mr. Atkins early exposure in the 1940's, arrived in a wheelchair, a difficult sight for those who remembered him bounding across the stage of the Ryman during two of the three decades it housed the Opry. Waylon Jennings, country music's legendary rowdy, squirmed into his wheelchair from the back of the day's longest stretch limousine.
"He was a genius," said Mr. Jennings, whom Mr. Atkins signed and produced. "We used to argue and we'd get madder than hell. Then we'd go inside and make some great records."
Mr. Atkins's orange Gretsch guitar sat on the front of the stage in a spotlight during the service, next to one of his signature white hats. His friend Paul Yandell played a similar guitar on "Mr. Sandman," an instrumental hit for Mr. Atkins in 1955, and Connie Smith sang the gospel hymn "Farther Along," backed by an instrumental group that included Mr. Stuart on mandolin.
Later, perhaps in a tribute to Mr. Atkins's sweetened production style, Mr. Stuart and several other musicians played the old Skeeter Davis song "The End of the World," accompanied by a string quartet.
Garrison Keillor, who became a friend of Mr. Atkins's after many years of sharing the stage on Mr. Keillor's public radio show, "A Prairie Home Companion," gave a eulogy laced with quotations from their personal correspondence, revealing a joking side to the guitarist not always on display in the studio.
"I had a screamer in the audience," Mr. Atkins wrote Mr. Keillor a few years ago. "I saw her later and she wasn't all that bad, about 35. A fellow could run some weight off her and maybe fall in love."
Mr. Keillor told some of the Atkins stories that have entered into local lore: How Mr. Atkins grew up poor and asthmatic in eastern Tennessee, replacing a broken string on his Sears Silvertone guitar with a wire from the screen door; how he developed his trademark picking style listening to Merle Travis on a crystal radio set; how he enchanted listeners at his first Opry performance in 1946 with an acoustic version of "Maggie," prompting Minnie Pearl to kiss him and say: "You're a wonderful musician. You're just what we've been needing around here."
Mr. Keillor reminded his audience of about 1,800 that Mr. Atkins knew and played with Elvis Presley, Hank Williams and Patsy Cline, and said Dolly Parton recently kept him laughing for hours as she flirted outrageously with him on his deathbed.
And he called Mr. Atkins the "guitar player of the 20th century," perhaps the greatest influence on other guitar players any musician has had.
"You might be shy and homely and puny and from the sticks and feel looked down upon," Mr. Keillor said, "but if you could play the guitar like that, you would be aristocracy and you would never have to point it out. Anybody with sense would know, and the others don't matter that much anyway."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 4 about the funeral of Chet Atkins, the Nashville musician and producer, misidentified the manufacturer of one of his guitars, which was onstage during the service. It was made by the Gibson Guitar Company, not by the Gretsch Company.

HEADLINE: COMMODITIES; 
OPEC Ministers Agree to Maintain Output at Current Level

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: VIENNA, July 3 

 BODY:
OPEC producers agreed to keep oil output limits unchanged today as expectations rose for an imminent resumption of crude exports from Iraq.
 The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries left output for 10 members at 24.2 million barrels a day, keeping in place the supply restrictions it set earlier this year. 
 OPEC is struggling to defend prices at its $25-a-barrel target because of the likely resumption of substantial Iraqi supplies and an economic downturn that is eating into world oil demand. 
"We took account of the situation in the market, which is well supplied," said Chakib Khelil, the president of OPEC. "Stocks are at a very good level relative to last year." 
Ali al-Naimi, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, said the cartel was prepared to rein in supply again if the return of Iraqi oil pushed prices too low.
"If Iraqi oil returns, we may have to take steps to cut back," Mr. Naimi said. "Demand is reflecting the slowdown in economic growth. It is not picking up in the East or the West."
In New York, crude oil for August delivery rose 29 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $26.24 a barrel. In London, Brent crude oil for August was down 29 cents, or 1.2 percent, to $25.35 a barrel.
Iraq is expected to lift a self-imposed block on oil sales after the United States and Britain, facing the threat of a Russian veto, abandoned efforts to overhaul United Nations trade sanctions on Iraq. Instead, the existing oil-for-food program was renewed for five months.
That would appear to meet Iraq's conditions for a resumption of its exports of two million barrels a day. Iraq stopped exports in early June in protest of the proposed change in sanctions.
But the extension by the United Nations included a reference to the June 1 British-American resolution on sanctions along with several other Iraq-related resolutions passed by the council "as they relate to the improvement of the humanitarian program for Iraq."
Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations declined to say whether Baghdad would accept the extension and resume its oil exports. But he said the reference to the June 1 resolution "is unacceptable in principle."
Previously expecting to compensate for Iraq, OPEC found it had no option but to maintain production unchanged to keep prices in its range of $22 to $28 a barrel.
OPEC ministers are hoping that the return of Iraqi deliveries will not cause any further decline in oil prices.
"Now we believe the market has considered Iraq's return and in the third quarter we are very close to balance between supply and demand," said Bijan Zanganeh, the oil minister of Iran.
Many oil analysts think there is more likelihood of oil prices climbing than falling. "Even if Iraq comes back, there are still bullish pressures on the market because of seasonal factors which could create upward pressure on prices," said Raad Alkadiri of the Petroleum Finance Corporation in Washington.

HEADLINE: Review of Nissan Car Loans Finds That Blacks Pay More 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
A statistical study of more than 300,000 car loans arranged through Nissan dealers from March 1993 to last September -- believed by experts to be the largest pool of car loan data ever analyzed for racial patterns -- shows that black customers in 33 states consistently paid more than white customers, regardless of their credit histories.
 The gap between black and white borrowers was largest in Maryland and Wisconsin, where the average finance charge paid by blacks was about $800 higher than whites paid. 
 Among the largest states, the study also showed that on average blacks paid $245 more in Connecticut, $339 more in New Jersey and $405 more in New York. In Texas, the black-white gap was put at $364; in Florida, it was $533.
"Unfortunately, since we have not been able to examine this new material, we cannot comment yet on these new studies," said Dierdre Dickerson, a spokeswoman for the Nissan Motor loan unit, Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation. 
"But NMAC has never tolerated unfair treatment of any of its customers, let alone racial discrimination," Ms. Dickerson said.
Nissan, like other auto lenders, lets car dealers make the final decision about how much customers pay for loans. But class-action lawsuits filed in Nashville against the Nissan loan unit and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, as well as similar suits against other auto lenders, argue that the lenders are responsible if dealers set rates in a racially disparate way.
None of the companies are accused of racial bias -- indeed, both sides agree that the giant lenders do not even know the race of the customers whose cars they finance.
Rather, the plaintiffs argue that the lenders' credit policies, for whatever reason, are having a statistically disparate impact on blacks. If they can prove that, the legal burden shifts to the lenders, who must then show a valid business need for the policies, which cannot be met in a less harmful way.
Indeed, one expert who examined the new data for the plaintiffs in the Nissan case suggests that some, though not all, of the racial disparity in loan charges may be an unintended result of limits NMAC puts on certain kinds of loans -- loans that go disproportionately to white borrowers. Other contributing factors, he said, may be simple racial bias among dealers or an assumption among dealers that blacks will be less likely than whites to balk at higher credit prices.
The plaintiffs for whom these new studies were done are challenging the industrywide practice of letting car dealers rather than lenders make the final decision about the interest rate customers will be charged on car loans arranged through their dealer. Similar fair-lending cases have been filed since October by black consumers against the financing arms of Ford, DaimlerChrysler and Toyota.
Lenders like NMAC allow dealers to add several percentage points, known as the dealer markup, to whatever interest rate Nissan has established for customers based on their income and credit history. That becomes the rate quoted to the customer, who has no way of learning of the disparity. The lender then splits the money generated by those extra percentage points with the dealer.
Dealer markup is a big-ticket issue for the industry, and the new Nissan data show why. One of the studies, done for the plaintiffs by a Vanderbilt professor, Mark A. Cohen, estimated that Nissan's share of the dealer markup paid by black consumers alone since 1990 was more than $210 million. Based on fee-splitting formulas in place during much of that time, the dealers' aggregate share would have been roughly three times that amount.
The Nashville cases were originally based on a smaller pool of loans in Tennessee. Based on the new data on Nissan -- the only lender that has provided such information so far in the cases -- lawyers for the black consumers are now seeking a preliminary injunction that would prevent Nissan from continuing to participate in dealer-markup arrangements nationwide.
NMAC has argued that any action should be postponed until a decision is reached in its appeal of an order certifying the class action.
Auto finance companies say that the dealer-markup system, besides generating revenue, allows lenders to compete for fresh business from car dealers, who can steer a customer's loan application to any of a number of financing outlets. Dealers say their share of the markup compensates them for providing customers with one-stop shopping and access to a broader spectrum of lenders than the consumer could command alone.
And the lenders themselves have argued in court that they are not responsible if the markup system is being applied in a racially discriminatory way by some car dealers.
That argument has been challenged by the Justice Department, which last fall filed a brief for the plaintiffs arguing that federal fair-lending laws hold lenders responsible for the actions of the dealers to whom they grant discretion. 
The Nashville lawsuits were filed almost three years ago, but were first disclosed publicly last October by The New York Times and ABC's "20/20," which had jointly petitioned the Federal District Court there to lift the court orders sealing the files in both cases. 
A spokeswoman declined to comment on the case pending in Los Angeles against Toyota. Dan Jarvis, a spokesman for Ford Motor Credit, which has been sued in Manhattan, said Ford had "zero tolerance for any form of discrimination." Chrysler Financial did not respond to questions about the case pending against it in New Jersey.
As the most mature of the pending lawsuits, the NMAC case remains the bellwether in the battle over the dealer markup system. And the new studies pose a roster of fresh questions about the practice.
The first study, by Professor Cohen, showed that blacks were more than twice as likely as whites to be charged a dealer markup in the first place. In the national Nissan data, 72.8 percent of blacks were charged a markup, compared to 46.7 percent of white customers.
And among all customers who were charged a markup, blacks consistently paid more than whites, according to Professor Cohen. Black borrowers who paid a dealer markup were charged, on average, $1,351, compared to $989 for the whites whose loans were marked up.
Moreover, the Cohen study showed that dealers were far less likely to give blacks, even those with top-quality credit, the advantage of the lender's preferential interest rates. Of the customers in NMAC's first credit tier, for example, 32.4 percent of whites were offered special interest rates, while only 15.3 percent of blacks were.
Professor Cohen tested for a number of variables that the lenders' statistical experts had offered as possible explanations for the observed racial disparities in Tennessee. None, he said, were sufficient to explain away all the differences in markup charges.
Professor Cohen cites, as an example, the case of two Louisiana women who purchased Nissan Sentras last year. Both women were in NMAC's first credit tier and were thus qualified to borrow at 8.25 percent. The first, who was white, borrowed $15,093 over five years at the preferential rate of 3.9 percent, with monthly payments of $277.73. The second, who is black, borrowed only $14,787 over five years, but she was charged a dealer markup of one percentage point, for a total interest rate of 9.25 percent. Her monthly payment was $309.94.
Nissan also permits dealers to move approved customers from a higher credit classification to a lower one, which has the effect of raising the customer's interest rate. Professor Cohen found that 4 percent of the black customers had been moved into a lower credit tier, while only 2.3 percent of white customers were.
NMAC established a limit on how much dealer markup can be imposed for each credit tier -- and policies like that may be inadvertently contributing to the racial disparity that shows up in the loan data, according to Ian Ayres, a lawyer and economist who is a professor at Yale Law School.
Professor Ayres, who has conducted several widely cited studies on car retailing over the past decade, examined the new Nissan data for the plaintiffs in the NMAC case.
He noted that NMAC limited the amount of markup allowed on loans in the highest credit tier. Because whites are more likely than blacks to be placed in that tier, that limitation has the side effect of reducing the markup paid by whites. Similarly, NMAC allows greater markup on loans of longer duration. Because blacks tend to borrow for a slightly longer term than whites, this too can contribute to the higher markups they pay.
Finally, NMAC often imposed lower markup caps on loans for new cars, which whites are more likely to buy than blacks.
But Professor Ayres noted that there was no business justification for allowing dealers, who have no money at risk in the transaction, to impose a higher markup based on factors such as the credit tier, the loan term or the age of the car.
"None of these selective markup caps are justified by the dealerships' costs of arranging and or processing loan applications," Professor Ayres noted in his study.

HEADLINE: Rescuers' Mission Remains Steadfast; 
Time's Erosions Do Not Deter Coast Guard's Vigilance on L.I. Sound

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: EATONS NECK, N.Y., June 30 

 BODY:
Everything about this place flows from a single, immutable fact: when the wailing siren of the search-and-rescue alarm rings, young men and women run down the hill from the station house to the boats. There they scramble for a few minutes with ropes and vests and clattering metal hatches, and then without ceremony they launch themselves in a small vessel onto the water to face what may come. Their breathing, in these rarefied moments, comes in truncated puffs of exhilaration. Muscle and energy are unbound.
 It has been that way here for a long time. When the Hudson River School painter John Frederick Kensett stood on this beach nearly 130 years ago to capture a stark scene of sand and sea and sky called "Eatons Neck, Long Island," the place already had a volunteer ocean-rescue team. The culture of derring-do on the water had been established. 
 Since then the beach and the cliff around the 202-year-old Eatons Neck lighthouse have eroded. Leisurely pleasure boating emerged as the Long Island Sound's main use, replacing the freight and packet steamers of days past. The United States Coast Guard, which evolved out of the old United States Life Saving Service of the 1800's, took over "The Neck," as the locals called it. High-tech navigating and radio equipment eclipsed the need for the old glass-windowed lookout post on the station-house cupola. 
But the golden braid of values and rhythms that historians say defined the culture of rescue work back then -- the swaggering invincibility of youth and the danger of the sea, the boredom of shore duty and the excitement of the call to action -- still very much shapes the human landscape of Eatons Neck today. 
"I sometimes think, just look at this, look at what we're doing," said Bryan Mastrangelo, a boatswain's (pronounced BOE-son) mate third class, as he and a crew roared onto the water one recent morning after a race to the dock. 
Mr. Mastrangelo, who grew up on Long Island in the Nassau County village of Malverne, is the officer in charge when one of the station's two 41-foot utility boats leaves the station. Whether they face rough seas, rescue attempts or law enforcement actions that require the crew to unsheathe the sidearms that they carry as military personnel, he makes the call as the government's representative on the spot. He is 20 years old, even younger than the average age here of 23.
And the age curve, at least for the short term, is still heading down. A strong economy in recent years has hampered the Coast Guard's ability to retain recruits. And many of the older officers who joined in a big wave in the late 1970's and early 1980's, at a time when the economy across much of the nation was weak, are retiring. The station's No. 2 commander, Executive Petty Officer Rodney D. Randall, who is 42, will transfer in August to a new posting at the Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn. His replacement is 27.
"The younger people, they think you're some old guy just like their parents," Chief Randall said. "It's a balance between trying to keep them going on a straight path and the right path and them thinking that you're trying to take over their lives."
One of the priorities of the station leadership, though, he said, is to make sure one of the few "old guys," in their 30's or 40's, is around at any given time.
"We like to maintain adult supervision," he said.

Potential for Danger on Every Call
The search-and-rescue bell roared to life at 4 a.m. on this particular Saturday, wailing through the ceiling speakers of the communal station house where the duty crew sleeps.
The details were sketchy: something about a rowboat, a man with chest pains, a location somewhere in Stony Brook Harbor.
Andrew Konopacki, 19, a seaman from South River, N.J., ran down the hill, still putting on his shirt in the dark. 
"This is bad," he muttered. "This is very bad."
In the cabin, the four crewmen on this assignment were mostly silent as their boat plowed onto the calm, dark waters, making 25 knots. There had been barely four hours since their return from the last call, just after midnight.
Now, in the pre-dawn gloom, the red instrument lights reflected on their faces and up under their blue Coast Guard caps, casting shadows that -- at least for a few minutes -- made them look gaunt. Their day had begun.
The first pillar of Coast Guard philosophy is that every mission, however seemingly routine, is potentially fraught with danger. People die every year in these waters, and if a seaman serves long enough, he or she will see it firsthand. A stone plaque reminds the crews every time they step out of the station house of the three Eatons Neck seamen who perished while attempting a rescue in 1946 off the coast of Connecticut. 
The second pillar is that every mission is a training mission. That is why Chief Randall avoids going out with his crews, as much as he would sometimes like to, he said.
"If you've got somebody there who you think has the answers, it's easier to ask the question than to think it out," he said. "They ask me: 'What do you think? What do you think?' "
As their commander, he said, it is his job to build self-directed men and women who can think on their feet, and the only way to do that is by authorizing them to make decisions on the spot, right or wrong.
"They need to do it on mornings like this when it's nice and calm and beautiful," he said later that day, after the 4 a.m. case, "because there are times when that alarm goes off and we've got eight-footers out front. They'll need to have the confidence to fall back on." 
For an enlisted seaman, there is also a third and an often unstated pillar of truth about serving in what is known as a "small-boat station," like Eatons Neck, where the main effort involves lightning-fast rescues. It is rooted in an odd ambivalence about the work that firefighters also know: bad news is good. It's what keeps you engaged.
"I know it doesn't sound right, but it gets exciting when people are in trouble," said Josh Doubenmier, 24, a machinery technician third class from Las Vegas.
On this morning, there was to be no resolution of the case -- no rescue, no rowboat, no trouble. By the time the Coast Guard crew reached the approach of Stony Brook Harbor, a dispatcher from the local fire department radioed to say that the department's own small launch had found the two men, and that one was being treated on the beach. So the crew turned back and rode into a dawn that looked strikingly like the one Kensett painted in 1872 -- ethereal and endless, full of grays that faded to blue and rose and finally to white.

From the Surfmen to the Coasties
Kensett reached the height of his powers in capturing the dazzling, hazy luminosity of places like Long Island Sound in the last few years of his life in the 1870's, art experts say. But the period he painted here was also the time when the national Life Saving Service was at the height of its growth.
The Surfmen, as the rescue workers came to be known, were apparently a fairly wild bunch, often mistaken for pirates when they would row furiously toward a damaged or disabled vessel. And, in fact, the line between rescue and plunder was a bit vague: in the earliest days of the station here, farmers around Eatons Neck were induced to volunteer for the hazardous work by an agreement to share the proceeds of what could be salvaged. 
Many descendants of the Surfmen -- the Coast Guard was formed in 1915 when the Life Saving Service was merged with an arm of the United States Treasury's customs enforcement operation -- have a deeply studied cool about what they do. People like Mark DeBonis, who are open enthusiasts for the Coast Guard and its mission, get teased mercilessly. But he said he doesn't care.
Mr. DeBonis, a 30-year-old boatswain's mate second class, left the Coast Guard after one four-year hitch, earned a college degree and worked in computer graphics for Spin magazine, among other places. But after five years out, he came back. He has a Coast Guard tattoo on his shoulder and books about Coast Guard history by his bed. 
"This is one of the few things where you can actually make a difference in someone's life," he said.
The private-sector world that he experienced outside, mostly working in Manhattan, did not have the rewards he wanted.
"I just got sick of it," he said. "I figured as long as I was going to be stressed out, I might as well risk my life so it will at least be worth it."
Mr. Mastrangelo also walks the line between detachment and idealism. He wants to be a police officer someday, like his father, Rocco, who served for 25 years in the Nassau County Police Department, working for many years in the hazardous-substances unit. Rocco Mastrangelo died at age 41, when Bryan was 10, of a lung disease that the family believes was linked to his work. 
"He'd be proud of me now," Bryan said, standing on the back porch of the station. "Got to think of that."
Maya Leonard said her main emotion was homesickness. Ms. Leonard, 20, is a new recruit who has been here only for a few months, and she said she was still trying to adjust. She grew up in California, her family members live near Atlanta now, and she has never been away from them, or her twin sister, Malia, for so long. She had thought that calling them a lot on the phone would help, but it doesn't.
"It's hard," she said, sitting on the station-house porch between her shifts on the radio system.
She unwrapped a package from her brother, a music lover who regularly sends along a stack of compact discs. "It's harder than I thought it would be," she said.
Joe Harrington, 22, a machinery technician from a small town near Lake Tahoe, Calif., said he sometimes felt bad that people mocked the enthusiasts like Mr. DeBonis.
But there have been times, Mr. Harrington said, when a real old-fashioned Coastie -- as such unwavering loyalists are known -- is exactly the kind of leader you want for your team.
"It means that when I'm out there, I can trust him with my life," he said.

In Art's Footsteps
The paintings of the Hudson River School are portraits of the Northeast, captured at a time when 19th-century America was re-examining its ideas about nature. The landscapes helped spur tourism and environmentalism.
This is the fifth of 10 summer articles in which The New York Times returns to the places illuminated by Hudson River School artists. The sixth article, about Lake George, N.Y., will examine the creation of wilderness tourism that Hudson River painters helped promote. When Martin Johnson Heade painted his sparsely populated scene of Lake George in 1862, the lake was already a bustling resort. Today it is a destination, especially in many immigrant communities, that defines the American vacation experience.
 The articles and additional materials are available on the Web:

www.nytimes.com/nyregion

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
ROADWAY EXPRESS EARNINGS FELL 59% IN 2ND QUARTER

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The freight hauler Roadway Express said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings fell 59 percent because of smaller amounts of freight as a result of the economic slowdown. The company said earnings in the third quarter would also be below the level of last year's quarter. Roadway, based in Akron, Ohio, reported second-quarter earnings of $4 million, or 22 cents a share. In the quarter a year ago, earnings were $9.8 million, or 52 cents a share. The average estimate by Thomson Financial/First Call was 18 cents a share. Second-quarter freight levels fell 13.3 percent from a year earlier. The company said it expected third-quarter levels to be 10 percent below those of a year ago.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Legislature Advances Special Taxing Plan for Arenas 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 3 

 BODY:
A bill authorizing a sports and entertainment tax district to help pay for a $355 million sports arena here has been introduced in the Assembly, a development that some lawmakers said moved the project one step closer to reality.
 The measure, quietly introduced late last week, is identical to the one the Senate passed Thursday in the waning hours of the regular legislative session. 
 As the session was moving toward closing and bills were being hurriedly passed and budget compromises reached, it was thought that negotiations had not progressed sufficiently for an arena bill to emerge in the Assembly. Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco favors the Newark arena, and Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, who is said by his assistants to be seeking a similar economic development project for South Jersey, apparently resolved their disagreements, though, enabling the measure to be introduced without fanfare. 
"I don't know the exact status of negotiations between the governor and the speaker, but this bill is positioned to be accelerated through the process," said Assemblyman Richard Bagger, the measure's sponsor and chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee. 
Tom Wilson, a spokesman for Mr. DiFrancesco, echoed that view, saying: "We are not stalled nor deadlocked, and the speaker is not opposed to the measure. He just wants some balance."
Similarly, Lewis Eisenberg, Mr. DiFrancesco's chief negotiator on the arena project, said the introduction of the bill was a positive development. 
Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., who sponsored the measure in the Senate, predicted that there would be a special session to vote on the bill and amendments by early August.
In the last four months, the arena proposal has moved from being a political long shot with no financing to a piece of legislation that quieted some of the opposition from Bergen County, which stands to lose Continental Arena in the Meadowlands as the home of the New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils. That hurdle was overcome after Mr. DiFrancesco proposed creating a family sports and entertainment village as a replacement for the arena.
The legislation now introduced in the Assembly and the version approved by the Senate last week would authorize the creation of a special sports and entertainment taxing district in the area of the proposed 18,500-seat Newark arena. It would also create a similar district in the area of the proposed Meadowlands sports development to help private developers finance the projects.
Under the plan, Mr. Kyrillos said, the state sales tax would be standardized at 6 percent in both districts, and half of it and a new hotel tax would be used to pay off privately issued bonds. 
With the financing in place and Bergen County fears addressed, Mr. Collins's quiet insistence on some similar type of aid for the southern part of the state appears to be the final hurdle.
Mr. Collins represents parts of Salem, Gloucester and Cumberland Counties, and, according to some officials close to the negotiations, has suggested a similar taxing district in his area for an unspecified project. Officials said his suggestions included a rowing center for crew races on the Cooper River near Camden, a zoo in the southern part of the state, and an athletic complex on the campus of Rowan College in Glassboro.

HEADLINE: Web Sales of Airline Tickets Are Making Hefty Advances 

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The bargains available to shoppers on the Internet are becoming scarce in all but one place: the sky.
 More than almost any other industry, airlines are still pushing their customers to buy online and are willing to reward them for doing so. Last week, for example, Delta started a fare sale, matched by other airlines including American and America West, that offered an extra 20 percent discount for using its Web site. Other airlines and online travel agency sites have lured passengers with discounts, last-minute specials and bonus miles. 
 This year, travelers will spend $14 billion buying tickets on the Internet, amounting to 14 percent of their total airline spending, according to PhoCusWright, a consulting firm in Sherman, Conn. That share is up from 9 percent last year, despite some occasional problems with online bookings. 
No other major consumer industry has had such a significant shift, and it is not slowing. Southwest Airlines already makes 30 percent of its sales online, and the other major airlines aspire to reach that level the next few years.
In other industries, established companies are pulling people and money away from their Internet operations, as their fear of being "Amazoned" by start-ups has subsided. The Nasdaq market's crash has dashed the companies' dreams of minting gold by taking their online units public. Consumers, in turn, are seeing fewer, less elaborate sites, with higher prices.
But in these tough times, the Internet is one of the few bright spots for the airlines, which face rising costs from new labor contracts just as business travel has started to plunge.
"We spend $1.7 billion a year on distribution costs," like travel agent commissions and fees for reservation systems, said Vincent Caminiti, senior vice president for electronic business at Delta Air Lines. "The single best way to mitigate those costs is to drive people from offline to online." 
Delta, he said, sold 13 percent of its tickets online last year and as a result saved $45 million in commissions and fees. By 2003, it hopes to sell 30 percent of its tickets online and, as efficiencies increase, save $150 million.
In addition to reaping special discounts, travelers are embracing the Internet because the airline Web sites and online travel agents like Expedia and Travelocity are proving to be an effective way to compare myriad fares and schedules and hunt for bargains.
And there are entirely new ways to buy, like through Priceline.com, which sells tickets cheaply to those willing to endure heavy restrictions and uncertainty about which airline they will be flying and exactly when. The airlines can use such sites as their outlet malls, where they can mark down unsold seats safe from the view of other customers.
The savings can be substantial. A recent check of advance purchase, round-trip fares between Boston and Los Angeles showed that the lowest published fare on a major airline was $403. But nonstop fares were available on the airlines' own sites for $309 to $325. Priceline said it would sell the same route, with restrictions and possible connecting flights, for $199.
Even investors are doing better with online travel companies than with most other Internet stocks. Expedia and Travelocity, the two largest online travel agencies, are among the few dot-coms that are healthy, growing and even profitable. Accordingly, their shares have actually risen this year, with Travelocity nearly tripling to $44.11, and Expedia more than tripling to $35.40.
The airlines have been so eager to exploit the Internet that they have pumped an estimated $145 million into Orbitz, a new online travel agency that opened last month to great fanfare and widespread service glitches. Orbitz has already raised protests from both consumer groups and rivals who say it will be a platform for collusion and price fixing, an accusation that Orbitz rejects.
The biggest losers in all this are likely to be local travel agencies, which have already been squeezed by cutbacks in airline commissions. "Being a travel agent these days is more a hobby than a profit-making business," said Jeffrey G. Katz, the chief executive of Orbitz and former chief executive of Swissair.
Some travel agents counter that they still can thrive by imposing fees to book tickets and specializing in more complex itineraries. 
"The only business we've lost to the Internet is business we didn't want anyway, people who want to go check every departure to save $5 on an airline ticket," said Arden Lisnek, a partner in Fisher Travel in Southfield, Mich. "The people who deal with us want personalized service and expertise." 
Just as one-third of bank customers still prefer human tellers to automated teller machines, airlines are convinced that a significant number of travelers will still use travel agents, although fewer than in the past. But the number who want to go online is greater than in nearly any other industry. 
The stock brokerage industry is perhaps another, but the growth of online trading has slowed and major brokerage firms, like Merrill Lynch, have seen little benefit from such trading.
In computers, direct sellers like Dell Computer have lowered costs by shifting sales online, but manufacturers, like Compaq Computer, that sell through retailers have found the Internet to be of little benefit.
As Scott Praven, president of United Networks, the Internet subsidiary of United Airlines, sums it up, "The Internet was invented for travel." 
Indeed, the elaborate computer reservation systems like Sabre and Worldspan built to serve travel agents meant that most airline information was already in digital form, ready to adapt to the Internet. "We were doing e-commerce before the word was invented," said Craig S. Kreeger, a vice president for sales at America Online. "We took the infrastructure we had for travel agencies and gave it to consumers."
The airlines have financial incentives to keep putting nifty new features on their Web sites. Every time someone goes to their sites to see if a flight is on time or to redeem a frequent-flier award, an airline can avoid answering a phone call at the cost of several dollars. 
And even people who are afraid to type in their credit cards and buy tickets online are using the Internet to research fares before calling, saving the airlines money.
"People know what they want," Mr. Caminiti said. "They call us and say, 'I saw it on the Internet; now book it for me.' " At Delta, he said, 20 percent of phone calls now result in a sale, up from 16 percent last year.
For many of the same reasons, the Internet is a growing channel for other parts of the travel industry. This year, PhoCusWright estimates that 6 percent of hotel bookings, 15 percent of car rentals and 3 percent of cruises and vacation packages will be sold online. 
Roughly half of travel industry bookings are made on the Web sites run by the airlines and other travel suppliers. And half are at the travel agency sites. But PhoCusWright estimates that the big travel agency sites are growing faster as consumers see value in comparison shopping.
One of the main reasons for the airlines' controversial investment in Orbitz is to counter the growing power of Travelocity and Expedia, which have 60 percent of the online travel agency market. 
"For the airlines, the only thing worse than 30,000 travel agencies is two travel agencies," said Philip Wolf, the chief executive of PhoCusWright. "Travelocity and Expedia could emerge with such market share they could force the airlines to discount more than they want to." Indeed, both of those companies have started to cut special deals with airlines beyond their published fares.
Orbitz hopes to beat its competition by offering travelers access to discount fares that until now have been available only at the airlines' own sites. The other online travel agencies, backed by some consumer groups, argue that this is unfair competition. Orbitz contends that it deserves to offer the lower fares because it has developed technology to, ultimately, sell tickets without using any of the computer reservation systems, which charge the airlines $12 to $15 a ticket.
But first, Orbitz will have to tame the technology it has. When it began last month, the site sometimes lost track of customers' reservations, telephone calls went unanswered and some e-mail confirmations of tickets went out well after the planes took off. Orbitz says it has fixed many of these glitches already.
Priceline, too, has had a spotty reputation for service, and disastrous attempts to expand into businesses other than travel. But it has found a big niche for itself in a short period. Last year, it sold $1.2 billion worth of airline tickets and hotel rooms, making it the nation's 11th largest travel agency. 
Priceline's inconveniences and rigid rules, with tickets not refundable or even changeable, are designed to scare off most business travelers and more demanding leisure travelers. But there are still ready buyers for seats that would otherwise go empty. Roughly 2 percent of the airline tickets in the country are now sold by Priceline and other sites that offer "opaque" tickets, in which buyers can choose only the dates, but usually not times, airlines or connections.
Among airlines like American, which was not an early participant, sites like Priceline have won a growing allegiance. "I think we're attracting people who would not otherwise travel," Mr. Kreeger said.
A number of sites say that the economic slowdown and resulting falloff in business travel is actually accelerating the shift to sales online. "When there are empty airplane seats and empty hotel beds, the suppliers go to partners who can deliver customers," said Richard Barton, chief executive of Expedia. "We've benefited from that."

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the growth of online travel reservations misstated the company affiliation for an executive who noted that the elaborate computer systems built to serve travel agents eased the way for airlines to adapt to the Internet. Craig S. Kreeger is a vice president for sales at American Airlines, not America Online.
