HEADLINE: Auto Sales Increased in June, Despite Decreases at Ford and G.M. 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
Auto sales last month rose 0.3 percent from June last year, the first monthly increase over 2000's record pace. The increase surpassed the expectations of analysts, who continued to be surprised by the strength of auto sales despite the sluggish economy. Foreign automakers, however, are still reaping most of the rewards. 
 Ford Motor and General Motors both reported lower overall sales compared with June of last year, while the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler reported a 1 percent sales increase over June 2000 after months of declines. 
 In contrast, Toyota, Honda and BMW reported big increases in sales in the United States. Part of the reason is that companies like Toyota and Honda are now aggressively competing for business in the market for sport utility vehicles, once the exclusive domain of domestic automakers.
Auto sales are a closely watched economic indicator because they provide a barometer early in the month for consumer demand and because they account for a significant portion of the country's production.
The auto industry posted record sales of 17.8 million vehicles in the United States last year, but a year with sales of more than 16 million is generally considered strong. For June, the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales was 17 million vehicles, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a data service in Southfield, Mich.
"The question is why we continue to see this pace against the backdrop of the dour news coming out about the direction of the economy," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director of global market and industry analysis. 
"Over the last few months, a number of clear pluses have developed for the industry," he added, "the falloff in energy prices, the aggressiveness of the Fed trying to stimulate demand through interest rate cuts, and certainly the tax relief that is forthcoming in the third quarter."
The industry, however, is also offering an increasing number of incentives, and many analysts say they believe that while rebates and discounts may keep the pace of sales healthy, they will cut into profits. It will also be difficult for Ford and G.M. to stop using incentives, analysts said, because they are already losing market share to their foreign competitors. 
Ford's total sales fell 6.6 percent compared with June a year ago, despite strong sales of its Explorer sport utility vehicle. Despite the dispute between Ford and Bridgestone/ Firestone over responsibility for the vehicles' rollover problems, Ford sold 42,833 Explorers, more than in any previous month. 
One reason is that Ford began offering its own employees and suppliers a $1,000 discount on Explorers. 
"You'd be surprised what that can do to the numbers," said Rod Lache, an analyst at Deutsche Bank. "They needed some good news."
"It's costing so much to keep those numbers going that the profitability is not going to fall to the bottom line," he added. 
At Ford, sales of light trucks, which include S.U.V.'s, minivans and pickups, were essentially flat, while car sales fell 15.5 percent from the previous June. G.M. reported an overall sales drop of 3.2 percent from June 2000. Car sales fell 13.5 percent from last June, while sales of light trucks rose 8.6 percent. 
In contrast, Toyota had a 19.8 percent increase in sales in the United States, driven partly by strong sales of its S.U.V's and pickup trucks. At BMW, sales increased 32 percent from June of a year ago, and sales increased 7 percent at Honda.
"Sales over all have been pretty good," said Phillip Hartz, a spokesman for the UnitedAuto Group, a company that owns more than 100 dealerships in 19 states, selling brands from most of the major automakers. 
"Obviously, the significant level of Fed activity has made a huge difference," he added. "Also, manufacturers have held the line on pricing, either with rebates or no new increases," he said. "Cars are affordable."
The nation's gross domestic product, the market value of all goods and services produced, grew by 1.2 percent in the first quarter, according to a recent Commerce Department estimate. That is well short of the 4.8 percent G.D.P. growth in the first quarter last year. That growth slowed to 1 percent in the second quarter, according to a survey of analysts' estimates conducted by the Blue Chip Economic Indicators newsletter.
Even so, auto sales have been strong. General Motors said it would stick to its plan to produce more than 1.2 million vehicles in the third quarter, down about 6.4 percent from the third quarter last year, and Ford maintained its plan to produce 930,000 vehicles. 
"I was expecting a much deeper downturn when we hit February and March," said Larry Fette, who owns a Ford and Kia dealership in Clifton, N.J. 
"I didn't expect the storm to be huge, but I didn't expect things to be this good either."
It helps that Mr. Fette's customers normally buy about four times as many trucks as they buy cars. The Explorer and the Escape, both S.U.V.'s, are among his most popular sellers. 
"Everybody's got an S.U.V.," said Mr. Fette. "I don't know what would happen if people stopped buying S.U.V.'s."

HEADLINE: Europe Ends Bid by G.E. For Honeywell 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS with PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 3 

 BODY:
As Europe's chief antitrust regulator bristled at what he called "political interference" from the United States, the European Commission today formally blocked General Electric's proposed $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International.
 The decision was already a foregone conclusion after negotiations broke off on Friday between G.E. and European officials. But the decision was a milestone, not only because European officials blocked a deal between two American companies but because United States antitrust regulators had made the opposite ruling. 
 As corporate executives consider the implications of General Electric's defeat, many analysts assert that it would be a mistake to infer that European and American antitrust enforcement practices are headed in opposite directions. Both sides, they say, remain anchored to similar goals of enhancing competition and keeping markets open. Some say there is a difference in emphasis, with European regulators concentrating first on whether a merger will hurt business competition, while those in the United States focus initially on whether it will hurt consumers. But others say the distinction is diminishing. 
A growing number of experts worry that Mario Monti, the European commissioner in charge of competition, has introduced a new dimension of unpredictability and uncertainty by invoking novel theories that have rarely been used elsewhere. 
In the G.E. case, Mr. Monti raised the specter of "portfolio effects" -- the danger that G.E. could use Honeywell's strength in avionics equipment to expand its reach in aircraft engines. In particular, regulators worried that GE Capital Aviation Services, the largest aircraft-leasing company, would buy only Honeywell aerospace products, just as it chiefly buys G.E. jet engines.
Two years ago, Mr. Monti invoked the threat of "collective dominance" to block a merger between two British travel agencies, asserting that a handful of companies would control the industry and thwart competition. More recently, he rejected the proposed merger between WorldCom and Sprint on the grounds that the combined company could dictate prices in Europe for Internet access.
The United States Justice Department also sued to block the WorldCom-Sprint deal. But its case was based primarily on the companies' huge share of the American long-distance telephone market, as well as a significant presence in the Internet access business.
WorldCom and one of the British travel agencies have appealed Mr. Monti's verdicts, although no decision has been reached. And G.E. repeated its complaint today that Mr. Monti's objections were unlike any it had encountered anywhere else.
"The commission took a fundamentally different approach to competitive issues than its counterparts in the U.S., Canada and nearly a dozen other jurisdictions," the company said in a statement.
Peter Alexiadis, a competition lawyer in Brussels at Squire Sanders & Dempsey, said Mr. Monti's approach was ripe for testing. "If G.E. appeals, this will bring to three the number of cases characterized by controversial theories," Mr. Alexiadis said today.
Mr. Monti brushed aside criticisms today. "This was by no means a U.S. versus E.U. case," he said. "Yes, two American companies wanted to merge. But their nationality was irrelevant."
Alluding to recent comments by President Bush, who expressed dismay that the deal might be blocked, Mr. Monti said he was "distinctly unimpressed by political pressure."
Yet for all the drama of Mr. Monti's stand against G.E. and its chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., antitrust experts say the case may prove to be the exception rather than the rule in trans-Atlantic mergers.
"I think this is a fairly unique transaction based on a fairly unique theory," said Mark Powell, an antitrust lawyer in Brussels at White & Case. "I do not think we are going to see a pattern of transactions that are blocked in one jurisdiction and approved in another."
European and American antitrust lawyers say the European approaches are, if anything, increasingly similar to those in the United States. The European Commission has repeatedly attacked the long-cherished European idea of "national champions" -- big companies in key areas like banking or telecommunications -- and has hammered away at subsidies and special preferences that kept such companies strong.
Both Mr. Monti and his predecessor, Karel van Miert, have labored mightily to invoke rigorous economic analysis along many of the same lines used in the United States.
"Fundamentally, there isn't a real difference in viewpoint," said Wernhard Moschel, a longtime adviser to the German government on antitrust issues and a professor of law at the University of Tubingen. "In Europe, the decisive question is whether a merger will create or strengthen a position of market dominance. In the U.S., the question is whether a merger will substantially reduce competition. In practice, there is not that much difference," he said.
As negotiations over the General Electric case reached an impasse, some experts asserted that European officials were more focused on concerns raised by competitors than on the effect on consumers.
European officials have conceded that the merger with Honeywell might have initially led to lower prices for aircraft parts. But listening to adamant opposition raised by rivals like United Technologies and Rolls-Royce, Mr. Monti concluded that G.E.'s dominance would squeeze out competitors and ultimately lead to higher prices.
That theory was not persuasive to the United States Justice Department's antitrust division, which approved the deal in March.
"The European Union's process offers a lot more credence to competitors," said Edward Kee, a management consultant in Washington for the PA Consulting Group, which is based in London. "In the U.S., they listen to competitors but don't give them as much weight."
But other antitrust experts are skeptical about such distinctions. "It might have been true at one time, and indeed there is case law to prove it," said Chris Norall, a lawyer in Brussels at Morrison & Foerster. "But I think it is a lot harder to say that today."
It does seem clear that Mr. Monti has not been motivated by a desire to protect European companies from American rivals. United Technologies, an American company, waged one of the heaviest lobbying campaigns against the G.E. deal.
And just a few months ago, Mr. Monti approved the huge and potentially much more sensitive merger between Time Warner and America Online, and settled for extremely modest concessions.
European companies have felt much more of the brunt of Mr. Monti's verdicts. He has railed at European power companies, demanding major divestitures before approving the merger of two major German utilities into what is now E.on.
Bertelsmann, the huge German media conglomerate, recently abandoned efforts to acquire EMI, the British music producer, because of concerns raised by Mr. Monti. And before that, Mr. Monti derailed a proposed merger between the Swedish truck makers Volvo and Scania.
But some critics say Mr. Monti, a former professor of economics, can be baffling. In his investigation into America Online, Mr. Monti's staff originally raised concerns that the merger with Time Warner might allow it to monopolize broadband networks in Europe.
But while Time Warner did have vast broadband networks in the United States, neither it nor America Online had significant networks in Europe. Mr. Monti later dropped that concern and focused primarily on the issue of distributing music over the Internet.
In the G.E. case, Mr. Monti raised initial objections about "bundling," the possibility that G.E. would use Honeywell's avionics business to strengthen its dominance in engines for large aircraft.
But as the process evolved, Mr. Monti's focus shifted to GE Capital Aviation Services, or Gecas.
In Strausbourg today, Mr. Monti made no mention of bundling in outlining his reasons for rejecting the G.E. case. But he also denied that he had changed course midway through the process.
"The role of bundling is fairly limited in our assessment of the case," he acknowledged. "But it is wrong to say that the commission moved from being concerned about bundling to focusing on the vertical effects of Gecas."
Regardless of how Mr. Monti reached his decision, antitrust experts say, he was not about to be budged once he had made up his own mind. That may have led to a crucial miscalculation by G.E. and Mr. Welch, who angered Mr. Monti two weeks ago by announcing that a deal could probably not be reached.
Mr. Monti appears to have viewed the move as lobbying through the media, and G.E. did return to the negotiating table last week with new but equally unacceptable proposals for a compromise. Mr. Monti became even more incensed when President Bush spoke out and the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, said a rejection of the deal would be "off the wall."
"The thing you have to remember about Monti is that he always tries to stay completely independent," said Josef Tobien, a lawyer specializing in takeover law at the Frankfurt office of Weil, Gotschal & Manges. "He does not want to be part of any political strategies."
Mr. Monti tried to extend an olive branch to American antitrust officials.
"It is one of my key political priorities to enhance international cooperation in antitrust, and that means first the bilateral cooperation with the U.S.," he said. 
In response to the European decision, Charles A. James, United States assistant attorney general for antitrust, issued a statement in Washington calling for a more closely aligned stance on antitrust issues.
"Clear and longstanding U.S. antitrust policy holds that the antitrust laws protect competition, not competitors," the statement said. "Today's E.U. decision reflects a significant point of divergence."
"This matter points to the continuing need for consultation to move toward greater policy convergence," it concluded.
Mr. Monti also made a nod to Mr. Welch. "The charismatic Mr. Welch isn't just an American icon. He is a world icon," he said. "I have not been insensitive to his charisma, but my job is to be sensitive to consumers."

HEADLINE: Parts of Free Trade Pact Are Made Public 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
The draft text of parts of the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas agreement was made public yesterday, giving the first official view of negotiations to create a trade area stretching from the Arctic circle to the tip of South America. 
 Although it is coming nearly two months later than expected, the release of nine chapters of the agreement fulfills a promise made by the leaders of the 34 democratic nations of the Western Hemisphere who gathered at the Summit of the Americas in April. 
 At the meeting, the leaders told thousands of protesters that the draft was being translated into the four official languages of the hemisphere -- English, French, Portuguese and Spanish -- and would be available as soon as the translations were completed, probably within a few days. 
Although a hemispherewide trade area could not be set up until 2005 at the earliest, many unions, environmental groups and public interest advocates throughout the hemisphere have expressed concern over the scale of the agreement and the effect its transnational regulations would have on national sovereignty. 
In particular, the groups have complained about the possible inclusion of a mechanism to resolve investor disputes in which arbitration panels would settle conflicts in secret sessions and without public participation. 
The draft of the agreement posted yesterday on the official Free Trade Area of the Americas Web site (www.ftaa-alca.org) included that contested dispute resolution mechanism in its chapter on investments. 
The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, said publishing the draft text well in advance of the completion of the negotiations would make creating the trade area more transparent, and he said he hoped it would also increase support for the initiative. 
In a statement, Mr. Zoellick called release of the documents an "effort to make international trade and its economic and social benefits more understandable to the public."
But Lori Wallach, director of Public Citizen's Global Trade Watch, complained that the documents did not include important information like indicating the positions of each country on the provisions of the agreement. 
"What they released is a scrubbed and sanitized version of the text," Ms. Wallach said.

HEADLINE: As Changeable as the Weather 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3 

 BODY:
Anyone interested in clearly understanding Japan's position on the Kyoto Protocol on global warming would search in vain through Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's statements over the last several days, during his first official overseas trip.
 Mr. Koizumi's extraordinary popularity at home was built in part from his straight-shooter style -- which differs significantly from that of recent predecessors, who were more often given to endless hedging. But from Washington to London to Paris, sometimes on the same day and within the same city, his position on what is probably the most ambitious international environmental agreement seemed to shift by the hour or the audience. 
 Whether deliberate or accidental, Mr. Koizumi's ambiguity appears to stem from a variety of causes. 
To begin with, this is his first experience on the world stage.
Moreover the protocol -- whose name comes from Japan's ancient capital, where its terms were hammered out nearly four years ago after a decade of arduous talks -- represents a rare opportunity for Japan to take the pivotal position on an issue of major international importance. But because Japan has had little experience wielding such influence, it finds itself stuck between firmly formed and opposing schools of thought: those of the European Union and the United States.
Japan's self-image as a world power has become increasingly tied to environmental issues, which are loosely linked in the minds of the public with the country's postwar vocation as a kinder, gentler power, constitutionally at peace and devoted to assisting the development of poorer nations. 
With important parliamentary elections scheduled for July 29, many opposition candidates, and even some members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, have turned support for the Kyoto Protocol and other environmental issues into campaign themes. Many newspaper editorials have also supported ratification of the protocol.
At the same time, Japan is as firmly attached to the United States -- economically, diplomatically and in security terms -- as perhaps any country. Going against its ally on a major issue like carbon emissions does not come naturally for Tokyo.
As a new, stirringly reformist prime minister, Mr. Koizumi has yet another important consideration: the need for support from Washington for his sweeping but risky economic restructuring. Mr. Bush gave Mr. Koizumi's plans a strong endorsement, which could prove useful for warding off critics at home.
Those strong crosswinds have brought an extraordinary sequence of shifts and nuance and near contradictions from the Japanese leader about the agreement, which establishes a timetable for strictly limiting the carbon emissions of industrial nations.
After the talks last weekend between Mr. Koizumi and President Bush at Camp David, Md., the Bush administration, which has rejected the protocol as "fatally flawed," all but claimed that it was indeed dead. 
In support of that view, administration officials cited Mr. Koizumi's supposed pledge not to ratify the protocol without Washington -- a decision that would leave the accord short of the minimum number of countries needed for it to take effect.
"When Japanese politicians go to the United States, they are just engulfed by the American atmosphere, and when they go to places like Camp David they forget their original positions and are often overwhelmed by the agenda of the American side" said Kaoru Okano, a political scientist and former leader of Meiji University. "When we saw Koizumi playing baseball with Mr. Bush, we knew he was totally immersed in the American environment."
But while still in Washington, Mr. Koizumi spoke of respecting the "spirit" of the protocol. And by the time he reached London, where support for the protocol is strong (as it is throughout Europe), Mr. Koizumi's language had become more affirmative still. Speaking to reporters there on Monday, he said he would "continue to talk to the Americans so that the Kyoto Protocol becomes an effective document."
Even that, however, was not the final word. Mr. Koizumi appeared to take another step backward on Monday, contradicting his own government's chief spokesman, when he denied that he had discussed possible revisions to the protocol with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain that might make it acceptable to the United States. 
The distance Mr. Koizumi has traveled in his various statements is all the greater when one considers that just last month, speaking before Parliament, he described Mr. Bush's opposition to the protocol as deplorable. During a photo session in Washington on Saturday, though, Mr. Koizumi praised Mr. Bush as someone who is "enthusiastic about environmental issues."
Perhaps reflecting that confusion, officials at Japan's environmental agency did not return telephone calls today seeking an explanation.
Mr. Koizumi may be trying to avoid making a firm decision now, which will disappoint many at home and abroad. But for now his decision-making process seems to be subordinating strictly environmental considerations to the one issue upon which the prime minister has staked his political fortunes: economic reform.
"Koizumi's priority has been economic and structural reform," said Yuuri Onodera, an official with Friends of the Earth Japan. "The environment remains a relatively low priority in his blueprint. This is the first global environmental issue he has tackled, and he has not decided what approach to take.
"But the most important reason for his present position is that he needs the Bush administration's wholehearted support for his economic reforms."

HEADLINE: Mets and Yankees Asking State For $300 Million in Transit Work 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Yankees and the Mets are seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in highway and transit improvements from the state as part of their efforts to build new stadiums in the Bronx and Queens.
 Officials from both teams have been negotiating with the Pataki administration in recent weeks for a total of about $300 million in improvements for subway stations and highway ramps. 
 Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been saying for months that after more than four years he is finally close to a deal to keep the Yankees in the Bronx and to build new homes for the city's baseball clubs, the teams began talks with the state only last month.
Gov. George E. Pataki, who shares the mayor's enthusiasm for the projects, has long insisted that he is opposed to using taxpayer money to build stadiums for privately owned teams, but he has said he would be willing to help with transportation improvements. 
There has been speculation that a deal to build the stadiums would be announced either today, coinciding with George M. Steinbrenner's birthday, or during the break for baseball's All-Star game, which is Tuesday. According to people who have been briefed on the talks with the state, though, a resolution could take longer than that.
Mets officials, who disclosed plans for a domed 45,000-seat stadium three years ago, are asking for what one state official estimated was about $100 million in roadwork and renovations to the existing Shea Stadium subway station on the No. 7 line. The new stadium would be built in the parking lot next to the present stadium, the team's home for 37 years.
The Yankees have talked to state officials recently about plans to build a new stadium in a public park just north of the existing stadium in the Bronx. The state official estimated that the team's request for a Metro-North train station, parking garages and various highway improvements would cost about $200 million.
"The only talks that have taken place with the state are about infrastructure needs for Yankee Stadium and the new Shea," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "We're not in the business of building stadiums with taxpayer money. If infrastructure improvements would help the stadiums and the general public, that's what we'll do."
According to a city official and a team official, the Giuliani administration is proposing to split the cost of the stadiums with the teams. Under the plan, the city would contribute $400 million in cash toward each stadium and issue tax-exempt bonds. The teams, however, would be responsible for making the annual payments on the bonds -- the equivalent of $400 million -- with revenue from ticket sales, naming rights, advertising and parking.
The Giuliani administration has met continually with the teams on plans for two new stadiums, which would cost about $800 million each, according to executives on both sides of the bargaining table. The state's estimated $300 million in related transportation projects would put the total price tag at nearly $2 billion.
But for all the fanfare, Mayor Giuliani's periodic pronouncements have puzzled state officials, local politicians and urban policy analysts. As the end of Mr. Giuliani's second term approaches, critics say there is little that he can do to make the proposal a reality. 
The projects would arouse a lengthy discussion and almost certainly require a variety of approvals by both the Pataki administration and the City Council, since the plans involve issuing bonds, leasing park land and spending more than $1.5 billion. 
The Pataki administration, which has been at odds with the mayor on economic development issues, resisted Mr. Giuliani's call earlier this year for the state to pay for a third of the cost of building the stadiums. It was only after the city realized that the state would not help with the stadiums themselves that the teams opened negotiations with the state on access.
At least one mayoral candidate, Mark Green, has said he would not put public money into the stadiums, raising the question of whether the next mayor would be bound by Mr. Giuliani's deals.
Although the mayor's plan may amount to wishful thinking, Robert Berne, a vice president of New York University and an expert in municipal finance, said that Mr. Giuliani could chisel his name into the public imagination if he's successful. He would like to be known as the mayor who kept the Yankees in the Bronx, who completed two minor league baseball stadiums and created a plan for two new stadiums for two of the most valuable teams in baseball. 
"Giuliani wants to go on record as the one who provided a mechanism for two new stadiums and leave it to others to try and stop it," Mr. Berne said. "Stopping the project would require an explicit veto, which puts a bigger political burden on the new mayor. And the stadiums would always be seen as Giuliani's idea."
The baseball clubs and the Giuliani administration are betting that they have defused much of the opposition to stadium deals by abandoning plans by the mayor and Mr. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, to move the team from its home in the Bronx to the West Side of Manhattan.
Publicly, the Yankees organization continues to say that it is exploring its options, staying in the Bronx or moving to Manhattan or New Jersey.
"The Yankees retain their three options," said Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for the team and a part owner. "No decision has been made. The Yankees are negotiating in good faith. I will not discuss any of the details currently unfolding."
Those options may no longer exist. Jerry I. Speyer, a developer and another part owner of the Yankees, told a private group of developers in December that the team had given up on the proposal to move to the West Side. Lewis Eisenberg, chief negotiator with professional teams for Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco of New Jersey, said, "I have had no discussions concerning the New York Yankees baseball team."
According to executives involved in the discussions, the Yankees are looking at plans to build a new ballpark next to the existing stadium, in Macombs Dam Park. Under that plan, the city would seek to offset criticism by building a new park nearby. 
The Yankees want the state to build a new Metro-North station, spruce up the local subway stations and build new highway ramps and lanes for the Major Deegan Expressway and Harlem River Drive so fans can arrive and leave faster. 
Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, announced his plans for a new stadium next door to Shea in 1998, and he has been waiting for the Yankees proposal to jell ever since. The Mets proposal calls for a stadium with a retractable roof, 78 luxury suites and high-price club seats. According to a state official, the team wants the state to renovate the nearby subway stations and to reconfigure the highway ramps.
So far state officials have resisted agreeing to build multilevel parking garages for either team unless they are convinced that the garages will be used by more than baseball fans.

HEADLINE: Play Money? Not to These News Investors 

BYLINE:  By SARA ROBINSON 

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
JUST as a day trader combs business publications for tidbits that could affect a share price, Jerome Charretier, a 24-year-old French business student, anxiously listens to the news stations in his car, hoping to make it home in time to adjust his portfolio.
 Only Mr. Charretier's holdings don't have any real-world value. Rather, they are virtual futures contracts on the outcomes of events -- like whether Prime Minister Lionel Jospin will run for president in 2002. Or whether the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, will shake hands by Sept. 22. 
 "It's stressful sometimes," said Mr. Charretier, who trades these futures sometimes for hours in one day. "If I hear something very important that will modify the price of a share I own, I can't play in my car so I'm very impatient to go home." 
Mr. Charretier is a participant in NewsFutures, a Web site that poses questions about future events -- whether sporting, financial or political -- and enables the ongoing trading of "shares" on the outcomes. The site also provides chat rooms and forums, much like Yahoo Finance message boards, where players can discuss each day's events and their impact on share prices. For now, the site (www.newsfutures.com) exists only in French, but the company plans to introduce an English version this summer. 
French law doesn't permit online gambling, so the market in events is merely a game with virtual winnings and losses. Each new user gets a starting balance of 2,000 doubloons, the game's fictive money, supplemented by 500 more each day, up to a cap of 10,000. 
Each contract in favor of an outcome of an event is worth 100 doubloons when that outcome occurs and zero otherwise. Since the contracts can be traded and the perceived likelihood of the event is changing over time, the actual price of a contract rises and falls, just as financial securities and derivatives do. Winnings propel participants in the site's player rankings and can later be used to purchase gifts at the site's online store.
Among the most popular bets are those connected to live events, like a basketball game or an episode of reality television. "It's fun to watch the real-time movement in the price," said Emile Servan-Schreiber, president of NewsFutures. "This is what interactive TV should be."
Mr. Charretier agrees. "It is this interactivity, like a real stock market, that obsesses you and forces you to play again and again," he said. "You think that if you leave your screen, something could happen."
The company, incorporated in the United States, was founded by Mr. Servan-Schreiber and Maurice Balick, an American. Mr. Servan-Schreiber's grandfather, also named Emile, founded Les Echos, the first business news service in France. His father, Jean-Jacques, is a prominent politician and journalist who was a founder of the weekly L'Express.
Mr. Servan-Schreiber said he hoped that the site would continue his family's tradition of generating interest in the news by providing a new way to interact with events as they unfold. "What we are doing is inventing a new type of newspaper, focused not on today's news but on tomorrow's news," he said.
NewsFutures is not the only site to enable people to gamble, in a sense, on future events. Iowa Electronic Markets (www.biz.uiowa.edu/iem), a real-money futures market run by the University of Iowa business school as a teaching tool, focuses on economic and political events. The Hollywood Stock Exchange (www.hsx.com) allows users to bet virtual cash on fictive movie and celebrity stocks.
The concept is a powerful one. Studies show that markets have better predictive power than polls. When stakes are high, those with the most information will have an incentive to make large bets on an outcome while those with less information will tend to drop out, or so the theory goes. Even play-money markets have predictive power, according to a study released this year by scholars at the NEC Research Institute, Pennsylvania State University and the Technical University of Denmark.
Even without the lure of real money, the NewsFutures site, started up last fall and marketed by word of mouth, has attracted 15,000 registered users, some 5,000 of whom play regularly, sometimes for hours at a time.
In France such enthusiasm can be expensive since dial-up users must pay by the minute for their Internet access, though the site itself is free. The company's revenue comes from partnerships with French publications that integrate their coverage with the relevant portion of the NewsFutures site and provide subscriptions and other gifts for the online store.
The site received its initial boost during the presidential race between Al Gore and George W. Bush, when thousands flocked to the site to place bets on the outcome. Except for a brief swing toward Vice President Gore during the legal battle over the vote recount in Florida, the price remained fairly steady at 80 doubloons in favor of Mr. Bush, Mr. Servan-Schreiber said.
Sports events are highly popular, as are daily bets on whether France's CAC 40 financial index or the Nasdaq will end the day up or down.
Denis Lazat, who runs SwissQuote France, a financial Web site, says he uses NewsFutures to bet on politics or to test his theories about the markets without the risk. "If I'm wrong, it doesn't matter; I'm just glad it wasn't real money," he said, just "pure entertainment."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Overseas Shares Fall on Concerns About Technology

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower overseas yesterday, pulled down mainly by the technology and telecommunications sectors. The markets in New York were closed for the Fourth of July holiday.
 In Japan, the Nikkei stock average declined 1.5 percent, weighed down by selling in technology shares, including Sony, Matsushita Electric Industrial, Hitachi and NEC. 
 Traders said investors were concerned that slumping stock prices and corporate earnings in the United States would hurt Japanese technology companies, whose profits hinge on overseas markets.
The Semiconductor Industry Association had reported earlier in the week that sales of semiconductors in May sank to $12.71 billion -- a 7 percent fall on the month and a 30 percent fall on the year.
According to Bank of America, electronics and electrical goods amount to 62 percent of total exports in Malaysia, 60 percent in the Philippines, 54 percent in Singapore, 39 percent in Taiwan, 36 percent in Korea and 28 percent in Thailand. 
In currency trading, the dollar ended marginally stronger against the euro and the yen. The market focus was mainly on the dollar and yen after remarks in Tokyo from Japan's administrative vice finance minister, Haruhiko Kuroda. 
Mr. Kuroda's comment that authorities would be happier with a weaker yen if fundamentals dictated sent the dollar surging up for a time above 125.00 yen. The dollar finished a shade above Tuesday's close of 124.40 yen, closing at 124.45 yen.
European stock markets closed lower, also pulled down by technology and telecommunications stocks. Telecommmunications shares in particular stumbled after the British equipment supplier Marconi suspended its shares. 
Marconi took the step while a board meeting discussed the outlook for the company. Marconi later announced it expected profits to drop 15 percent this year and that it was cutting as many as 8,000 jobs. 
Investors in Europe also were disappointed by dim prospects for lower interest rates. The head of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, indicated the bank was unlikely to cut rates when it meets today.
Other international markets gained ground yesterday. In Hong Kong, shares closed slightly higher, supported by a sharp rise by Pacific Century CyberWorks after the telecommunications firm announced plans to lay off 340 employees. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.17 percent.

HEADLINE: Producers And Actors Reach Accord 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 4 

 BODY:
About 10:30 p.m. here on Tuesday, after reaching a tentative agreement on a contract that ends months of trepidation about an actors' strike, the chief bargainer for the producers turned to the man who represented actors for a moment of reflection.
 They had come to terms on a three-year deal that gives actors more money, although not as much as they wanted, and helps producers hold the line on spending. 
 "Once we got the planets lined up it worked pretty well," J. Nicholas Counter, chief negotiator for the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said to Brian Walton, who bargained for the actors' unions.
The package includes increases in the industry's standard minimum wage: 3 percent for each of the next two years before rising to 3.5 percent in final year of the contract. 
"These were very difficult negotiations because of the complexities of the business today," said Mr. Counter as he announced the tentative agreement by the alliance and the actors' unions, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
Finding that alignment had been elusive in the three days since the contract expired on Saturday at midnight. Negotiators faced the task of meeting the unions' goal of putting more money into actors pockets as producers faced dwindling profits and a fragmented marketplace.
To reach the agreement, negotiators traded ideas like they were pieces of a puzzle that at last fit together. The agreement finally puts to rest months of anxiety about a major labor showdown that could have crippled Hollywood.
The deal now goes to the boards of the two unions for approval before being mailed out to some 135,000 members for ratification. It was unanimously approved by the actors' bargaining teams and is expected to be accepted.
Actors will also receive more money when their work is sold to cable. The issue of these residuals -- payments when work is resold -- had vexed negotiators right up to the end. Producers did not want to increase the 6 percent allotment paid to actors and instead proposed that they increase what actors received by covering the amount deducted from that payment for the health and pension fund.
Actors accepted the proposal, which would result in an increase of about 13 percent in income from residuals, but the producers wanted something in return. They won it as the actors ultimately agreed to a lesser raise in the minimum wages, which are currently $617 a day.
Producers also agreed to an increase in contributions to the guild health plan; a substantial increase in salaries for guest stars and stunt coordinators; and new provisions for work on the Internet.
From the outset, the guild had put so-called middle-class actors at the heart of discussions, seeking ways to increase salaries of the members whose work relies on nonregular roles on television series and smaller parts in movies. Although stars may be able to command $20 million for a movie, these actors bring in only $30,000 to $70,000 a year.
In recent years, these actors said their paydays had decreased as producers paid more for big name stars. In addition, they said, they have made less money from residuals as more programs go to cable.
These actors will benefit specifically from an increase in the minimum for guest appearances on television and an additional $5,000 payment for actors in movies with limited roles.
Shelby Scott, president of the TV and radio association, said, "We began these negotiations focused on improving wages and working conditions for the backbone of our unions -- our middle-income members -- and I believe we've made solid gains for that group."
In many areas, the contract tracked along the same lines of an agreement struck two months ago by the Writers Guild of America and the alliance, and in some areas was identical. Specifically, producers agreed that by the third year of the contract Fox television network will pay the same residuals as ABC, NBC and CBS.
Actors also won new provision for Internet work that were similar to the writers'. However, they did not win increases in video and DVD sales.
After commercial actors struck for nearly six months last year, fears were heightened as the writers' guild and television and film actors contracts expired this year. Those fears eased in May when the Writers Guild of America accepted a three-year contract that included $41 million in pay increases.
With the agreement Tuesday, Hollywood breathed another sigh of relief. Although Mr. Counter said neither side was 100 percent pleased, "on the whole it keeps the town working and it keeps the economies of Los Angeles and New York, where a lot of production takes place, booming."
According to an independent study, a one-month walkout by actors would cost Los Angeles 21,700 jobs and $1.3 billion to the economy. If the strike went on for three months, those figures would increase to 54,000 jobs and $3.2 billion. In addition, the report noted that there would be significant effect on suppliers to the industry.
Some segments of the entertainment industry were already reporting slowdowns in work.
Attention now turns to starting production, and Mr. Counter said, "I don't see a delay in the fall season."
After it was over, a weary but satisfied Bill Daniels, president of the Screen Actors Guild, said, "If I look a little slap happy, I guess that's because I am."
He said he had been predicting since October that a deal was possible. "I was right," he said. "There was a deal to be made."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian Walton, chief negotiator for the Screen Actors Guild, left, and J. Nicholas Counter, chief negotiator for the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, celebrated the tentative three-year deal on Tuesday. (Associated Press)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Tycoon Ends Online Venture In Hong Kong

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 4 

 BODY:
For Richard Li, the brash tycoon once celebrated as an Asian Internet visionary, it has come to this: He announced today that his telephone company, Pacific Century Cyberworks, had all but shelved its most ambitious venture in cyberspace -- and the company's shares soared nearly 8 percent.
 Cyberworks, which is based in Hong Kong, said it would fold Network of the World, a satellite-delivered entertainment and information network, into its existing Internet service in Hong Kong. The move will result in 340 layoffs, or 40 percent of its Internet work force, and cut the company's spending by nearly $100 million a year. 
 "The fact is, Internet advertising is practically nonexistent," Mr. Li said in a telephone interview. "We have the financial resources to push this, but we would consider it fiscally irresponsible." 
Mr. Li, the 34-year-old son of Hong Kong's most powerful businessman, Li Ka-shing, said the Internet venture also had less and less to do with the company's core business, telecommunications. Cyberworks acquired Hong Kong's local phone company last year for $38 billion -- a deal that turned Mr. Li into a celebrity but left his fledgling company staggering under more than $5 billion of debt.
"Our first priority is to pay down the debt," Mr. Li said. "There's really no point in creating something with little synergy."
Investors rewarded his shrunken vision by driving up his company's stock 7.78 percent, to 31 cents a share. 
That gave Cyberworks, which has lost more than 80 percent of its value since the merger, the rare distinction of being the top performer on Hong Kong's otherwise ho-hum stock market.
"Some shareholders might wish he had killed off the project faster because it is bleeding red ink," said David Webb, the editor of Webb-site .com, an Internet service that tracks Hong Kong companies.
Some sort of retrenchment by Mr. Li had been expected since March, when the company reported an $886 million loss in its first full-year results. Most of that stemmed from a huge write-down of its Internet investments and costs associated with its acquisition of the telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT.
At the time, Mr. Li pledged to reduce spending on Network of the World, or NOW, to $200 million a year from $1.5 billion over five years. Today, he said he would cut it further, to $100 million over two years.
Michael Johnson, an American television producer who was the executive creative director of NOW, said that he would probably resign. "What this company needs is not what I do," he said in an interview.
Cyberworks built a slick studio in London, and was planning three more in Hong Kong, Tokyo and Bombay, to produce interactive television programming for NOW. The programming was to have been piped to subscribers in Asia, Europe and the Middle East through satellite and high-speed cable television connections.
Despite the company's grand claims to create a "revolutionary new medium for the new generation of consumers in the digital age," NOW never caught on with viewers. Its programming seemed less pioneering than peculiar, and critics said that NOW actually stood for "no one watching."
Mr. Li said Cyberworks would keep bare-bones operations in London and Hong Kong, but would produce programs only in partnership with other companies. He said it would limit the service to Hong Kong, where 230,000 customers buy either the company's broadband or its interactive-television services.
"If we prove that this is a good model in Hong Kong, that it generates good cash flow, then we will take it elsewhere," Mr. Li said. "But we're not going to rush out and conquer the world."
Such words do not come easily to Mr. Li. After creating the Star TV satellite network and selling it to Rupert Murdoch for a huge profit and then engineering the largest corporate takeover in Asia, Mr. Li seemed born to conquer.
Instead, Pacific Century Cyberworks has become Asia's most spectacular Internet flame-out. Yet because Mr. Li was able to use his once highly valued stock to buy a phone company, the long-term survival of Cyberworks is not in doubt -- as it is for so many other Internet start-ups. 
Mr. Li said today that he had not lost his belief that the Internet was transforming the economy. But he acknowledged that success was no longer measured by vision but by financial prudence. He noted that he had delayed today's announcement a day to brief officials at Standard & Poors and Moody's Investors Service, the rating agencies that will soon rate Cyberworks' debt.
"I also sleep better with strong cash flow," Mr. Li said.
Rebuilding the finances of Cyberworks means that Mr. Li may eventually have to relinquish the top job. He said the company was searching for a telecommunications executive to become its chief executive. Mr. Li said he wanted a senior-level person with significant experience in Asia.
"This company is like a car," Mr. Li said. "A chief executive can only run it when it is fully constructed and in good working order. Right now, I'm making sure the wheels are on and that the pedals work."

HEADLINE: Protecting the Gulf of Mexico 

 BODY:
Balancing energy and environmental interests in the Gulf of Mexico has long been a challenge to Washington and state governments along the Gulf Coast. After initially planning to open a vast new area to oil and gas drilling, the Bush administration has wisely scaled back its expectations. But even its more modest proposal for drilling in eastern gulf waters should be blocked for now by Congress. 
 Under a compromise announced earlier this week, Interior Secretary Gale Norton said the administration would seek to let oil companies drill on about 1.5 million acres in the eastern gulf, a quarter of the area that the Clinton administration first proposed opening for drilling in 1997 and that the Bush administration also favored developing. The plan would bar all exploration within 100 miles of the Florida coast. The administration believes that would still preserve the most promising sections of the original site for drilling. 
 The revised plan clearly reflects mounting White House concerns that Mr. Bush is losing public support even among moderate Republicans by so closely aligning himself with energy interests. In this case, drilling companies have been eager to tap an estimated three to seven trillion cubic feet of natural gas, whose price has been rising in part because it is the preferred fuel for most new power plants, along with what may be 400 million barrels of oil. But environmentalists in league with the president's brother Jeb Bush, the Florida governor, and Florida's Congressional delegation have opposed any drilling that might threaten the state's beaches and its multibillion-dollar tourist industry.
Jeb Bush pronounced himself satisfied with the plan. He faces a difficult re-election bid next year, and the administration's original plan could have cost him dearly among voters concerned about the preservation of the Florida Gulf Coast and the economic activity that is dependent on it. 
Drilling elsewhere in the gulf has long been an accepted component of the nation's energy strategy, even by environmentalists. Oil and gas rigs in the western and central gulf currently supply about 30 percent of the country's natural gas and 20 percent of its oil. Industry executives say the wells in the western and central gulf are beginning to run out. 
But Congress should withhold its support for drilling this far east until the administration has demonstrated that the area's oil and gas are truly needed. With prices rising, drilling is already accelerating on land in the West and Southwest that has long been open for both oil and gas exploration. It is worth establishing whether these new supplies are sufficient before drilling in sensitive areas. The ecological good health of the gulf and the economic and recreational value of Florida's beaches and those of other Gulf Coast states are worth too much to jeopardize without proof that there are no alternatives.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Living wages are practical and don't let theory get in the way.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." He also is a fellow at the Shorenstein Center at Harvard. E-mail:challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
IN an era of increasingly free markets, it is a little surprising that the "living wage" movement has caught on in America.
 Starting in Baltimore in 1995, it has spread to approximately 60 metropolitan areas, rich and poor, across the country. Living-wage agreements require any company doing business with a city, county or school board to pay all its workers on the project a high minimum wage, often as high as $10.50 an hour. This comes to about $21,000 a year for full-time work. The federal minimum wage is $5.15, or less than $11,000 a year. 
 But the living-wage movement, even as it spreads, will at most raise the pay of 75,000 or so workers. Only those companies with government contracts must comply, and they pay most of their workers more than the living wage already.
Partly because the impact is limited, economic objections to these programs have not truly taken hold. Conventional economic theory argues that any artificial increase in wages will tend to reduce jobs. Cities may also hire more qualified workers at the higher wage and dismiss the very low-wage workers whom the programs are designed to help in what is called the displacement effect. Because these programs are limited in scope, however, so are the purported adverse effects.
But the living-wage movement is now spreading beyond its original mission. Advocates for living wages are fighting battles for state and city minimum wages. They also participate in calculating so-called self-sufficiency wage standards of localities. Can these programs do more harm than good? If they go too far, of course they can. But given the low level of wages for so many in America, we are a long way from any such concerns.
In the face of general support for unfettered markets among economists and policy makers, the living wage movement seems to be potent because it is emanating from the grass roots. The original organizers of the living wage movement in Baltimore, for example, were church-sponsored poverty groups. The successful student sit-in at Harvard in the spring is likely to give further impetus to student movements around the country that were already under way.
And these groups are now spreading their wings. The Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, or Acorn, a national organization of 150,000 low- and moderate-income workers, has been at the center of many living wage movements. Now Acorn is leading an intense political battle for a citywide minimum wage for all public and private workers in New Orleans. It would be the first city minimum wage in America, other than the longstanding one in Washington. Acorn was also involved in the adoption of a $6.75 statewide minimum wage in Massachusetts.
Such battles have also been joined by the self-sufficiency wage advocates. These groups, like the Women's Education and Industrial Union in Boston, are operating in 14 states. They calculate the cost of housing, food, health care, transportation to work and child care -- no recreation is included. They typically find that the self-sufficiency standards are 50 to 100 percent higher than the living wage.
As these movements become more influential, the opposition is bound to be more intense. Indeed, the basic lessons of economic theory cannot be dismissed. If wages move too high, they will reduce economic growth and hurt low-wage workers.
But knee-jerk assertions about such wage-raising programs are oversimplified. First, while there may be some job loss when wages are legislatively raised, the number of jobs will depend more on the state of the economy than on somewhat higher labor costs for business. The recent increase in the federal minimum wage, for example, has not made a blip in the unemployment rate because the economy has been strong. If the economy weakens, businesses are likely to let workers go because sales are down, not because wages are a dollar too high.
Second, the displacement effect is exaggerated. This criticism has received the most attention, including during the Harvard sit-in. If you are going to pay $10.50 an hour, why not hire a more qualified worker to replace the $8 worker? But it turns out that such higher-wage workers are not all that more qualified.
Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of Massachusetts, analyzed the educational backgrounds of the nation's cleaning and building services workers and retail cashiers. These workers represent a large share of the nation's low-wage employees. Mr. Pollin, who has been closely involved with living-wage movements around the country, found that there were only 15 percent more high school graduates in the higher-wage group than in the lower.
"There will probably be some displacement," says Mr. Pollin. "But it will be small and usually worth the gains for all the other workers."
Michael Reich and Peter Hall, economists at the University of California at Berkeley, provide corroborating evidence for this finding. They analyzed job displacement that resulted from the increase in the minimum wage in California from $4.25 an hour in 1996 to $5.75 in 1998. It was marginal.
Finally, raising wages may well improve the nation's productivity. A higher wage will reduce the high job turnover in these low-wage industries. Restaurants and hotels, which are major employers of low-income workers, lose 75 percent or more of their employees each year. Having to hire and retrain new workers is costly, so reduced turnover might well compensate for the higher wage.
American companies cannot pay any wage that community groups deem desirable. But the self-sufficiency advocates are not demanding that their high standards be met by the private sector. As Mary Lassen of the Women's Education and Industrial Union says, they want to help workers get the educational background required to qualify for better jobs. They also want more government support of child care.
The movement for decent wages in America has been a moral imperative for its advocates. But within reason, it can also be economically beneficial. It would too bad if economists used their considerable persuasive power to undermine this movement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the spring, students at Harvard staged a sit-in to demand "living wages" for the university's lowest-paid workers. A protester, Ashwini Sukthankar, in window, spoke with passersby. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Loans, Interest Rates and a Religious Principle 

BYLINE:  By SHIRA J. BOSS 

 BODY:
The Koran explicitly forbids "riba," an Arabic word that Muslim jurists have defined as usury; it was banned to protect poorer classes from exploitative money lenders.
 But many observant Muslims and experts in Shariah, or Islamic law, do not agree whether that prohibition bans any interest at all or only excessive interest. 
 "Shariah scholars have ruled both ways," said Timur Kuran, a professor of economics and the King Faisal professor of Islamic Thought and Culture at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. "It's been a persistent controversy." 
Because of that ambiguity, observant Muslims until fairly recently either financed their businesses and purchases in cash or agreed to pay and receive interest. Those who paid riba could invoke a necessity clause in the Koran; many who accepted it on savings would donate the interest earned to charity.
"It wasn't until the 1970's that this issue was even discussed, that there could be an Islamic, or interest-free, banking system," said Mahmoud A. El-Gamal, a professor of Islamic economics, finance and management at Rice University in Houston. Many Muslims were simply paying and collecting interest -- "and not worrying about it," he added.
A growing number of Muslims, however, are seeking an alternative that adheres to the stricter interpretation of Islamic law.
"In the United States, there is a larger degree of conservatism among American Muslims, so there is more demand for Islamic banking," said Khaled Abou el Fadl, who teaches Islamic law at U.C.L.A. 
One goal in Islamic finance is to have both partners -- the bank and the buyer -- share equally in the risk of a transaction. Because Islamic banks invest with their customers rather than lend to them, the risk of losing principal is greater and there is no fixed rate of return. In some cases, such transactions amount to nothing more exotic than the sort of lease that is familiar to many Western car buyers: the finance company buys a car and lets the customer drive it in exchange for monthly payments over a fixed period. When the term is up, the customer can buy the used car at the market price or enter another lease.
For homes, however, different approaches are used. To conform to Shariah, homebuyers and finance companies effectively become partners, either through lease-purchase agreements that resemble conventional financing or through self-help groups that pool money from Muslim investors to help one another buy houses.
Under lease-purchase programs, for example, a home buyer and the finance company pool their money to buy a house. The home owner agrees to make monthly payments that are split between repaying the company its capital and paying a fair-market rent on the property. The rent is split between the buyer and the financial institution according to how much each has invested in the house.
If, for example, the finance company put up 70 percent of the purchase price, it would receive 70 percent of the rent -- that is the return on its investment. As the homebuyer repaid part of the capital each month, however, the institution's ownership stake in the house -- and, therefore, its percentage of the rent -- would decrease. Eventually, the homeowner would repay all the capital and the rent payments would cease.
At American Finance House-Lariba, an Islamic finance company in Pasadena, Calif., the lease-purchase program is similar in structure to a traditional mortgage so that a portion of each payment would qualify as tax deductible under the section of the tax code that covers interest payments. That allows Lariba to qualify for financing from Freddie Mac, the government-chartered private company that helps to finance home purchases. 
Lariba is the first Islamic institution to receive Freddie Mac financing. It receives about 15 requests for loan applications every day, three times as many as last year, said M. Maguid Abdelaaty, the company's president.
"We're required to calculate the implied rate of return," he said, adding that the financing structure his company uses eases customers' mind about paying interest, "but the documentation, the note and the mortgage forms are the same" as for loans.

HEADLINE: Colorado Struggles to Define Rules for Recreational Water Use 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GOLDEN, Colo., June 30 

 BODY:
With the snow melted and tumbling down the Rocky Mountains in rivers and creeks here, the kayaks, rafts and canoes have come out just in time for growing legal battles over who controls Colorado's waterways and how they should be used.
 In one controversy, towns along rivers that are popular with tourists have asked state water courts, which allocate water rights, to guarantee enough flow for boaters. But state officials, and towns upstream, have objected, saying such rulings would impede development and even limit the water available for homes, industries and farms. 
 The City of Golden recently won a ruling in water court that entitled it to use 1,000 cubic feet -- more than 600,000 gallons -- of Clear Creek every second from May to July to keep kayakers bobbing in the municipal Clear Creek Whitewater Park, a nationally known course. 
In a parched land where ranchers, farmers, industrialists and developers have fought pitched battles over precious water, the ruling was one of the first to acknowledge the increasing importance of recreational water use and its economic impact. 
"Recreation is king in terms of the economic base for this state," said Glenn Porzak, a lawyer who represented Golden. "It's the primary industry, the primary lifestyle reason that people live in this state or come to visit this state."
But the Colorado Water Conservation Board, which oversees water use throughout the state and has not dealt with recreational water issues, has said that the flow the judge permitted is available only nine days a year and that the allocation is too great. 
"In a semiarid state, you've got to have adequate water," said Dan McAuliffe, deputy director of the conservation board, which could appeal the ruling to the State Supreme Court. "We're seeing limitations in the future with more growth or if there is a prolonged drought."
This spring the state enacted a law requiring the board to review all but the most minor requests for recreational water use and submit its finding to the water court judge hearing the case.
Water sports are an industry in Colorado. River rafting alone generated $122 million in business last year, up from $89 million in 1995, according to the Colorado River Outfitters Association.
While the main tourism draw in Golden is the Coors brewery -- also known for its water use -- the water park brings in an estimated $2 million to $3 million a year. 
"The more water, the more attractive it is," the Golden city manager, Mike Bestor, said. 
But old mining towns upstream also depend on the water from Clear Creek for everything from household uses to running the Georgetown Loop steam train in the summer. 
"What it comes down to is, Is recreational purpose more important than consumptive use?" said Paul E. McKenna, the administrator of Georgetown, upstream. 
In another legal battle over water, the issue is not quantity but location. 
A rancher in Gunnison, Colo., is suing a rafting company whose boating tours cross his property.
At issue is the right to float. In Wyoming, New Mexico and other Western states, the law gives the public a clear right to use rivers and streams recreationally as long as they enter them from public land.
The law in Colorado is not clear on this point. A law enacted in 1977, a decision by the Colorado Supreme Court in 1979 and a 1983 opinion from the state attorney general have in part contradicted each other. As a result, each side has interpreted the law in its own way, with custom holding that boaters can float or paddle through private property as long as they do not touch the riverbed or banks. 
"Every river in the state flows through private property at some point," said John Nichols of Cannibal Outdoors in Lake City, Colo., the company that is being sued for trespassing by the rancher, Yosi Lutwak.
"This could essentially cripple the entire river industry in the state if we don't win," Mr. Nichols said.
He added that the cost of litigation could put him out of business. 
John Hill, a lawyer for Mr. Lutwak, said the issue was property rights, not water rights.
"There is a popular misconception that there is a right to do this," Mr. Hill said. "My client wants to protect his resource from overuse."
In other rivers the steps to curb floating have been more extreme. Landowners who run a fishing business along the South Platte River recently lowered a gate along the river to prevent boaters from passing. Kayakers were arrested and ticketed for trespassing. 
In a more peaceful protest, Mr. Nichols staged a "float-in" last month along the Lake Fork of the Gunnison River.
"This could open a Pandora's box of litigation throughout the state if landowners have the right to close rivers," Mr. Nichols said. 
Robert C. Ward, director of the Colorado Water Resources Research Institute in Fort Collins, said water rights were continuously developing.
"How do you define a human use when the water doesn't leave the stream?" Mr. Ward asked. "Historically, water rights are a constant evolution, and recreation is just now beginning to find its way into our water law."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about battles over Colorado's waterways included a miscalculation of how much water a court recently permitted the city of Golden to divert for recreational use in its Clear Creek Whitewater Park. It is 1,000 cubic feet of water per second, which is about 7,480 gallons, not more than 600,000 gallons.

HEADLINE: Marconi Announces New Plan to Cut 4,000 Jobs Worldwide 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 4 

 BODY:
The British telecommunications equipment maker Marconi said today that it expected to cut 4,000 more jobs worldwide. The new cuts are in addition to 4,000 jobs lost since April. 
 It said sales for the current financial year were likely to fall 15 percent, while operating profits could be cut in half. The loss excludes Marconi's American-based unit, Marconi Medical Systems, which the Dutch company Royal Philips Electronics said it would buy for $1.1 billion in cash. 
 Marconi said companies were delaying purchases because of the global economic slowdown.
The company, which employs about 50,000 people in 19 countries, said the new job losses were part of a cost-cutting plan, and that 1,000 of the jobs would be cut in management.
Marconi said that after the new round of cuts, and the farming out of part of its business, its staff will have been cut a total of 10,000.
Sales have slowed in the United States, where Marconi does about 40 percent of its business. Weaker economic conditions have weakened demand there, too.
In April, Marconi outlined plans to cut 3,000 jobs. Today, the company said 4,000 people had "left or agreed to leave" since those plans were announced.
