HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron 

 BODY:
It's a Wrap; It's a Laugh
The sportscaster WARNER WOLF got to say his signature phrase, "Let's go to the videotape," on a movie set. But only after the director RON HOWARD had yelled "cut" for the last time.
It happened last month when Mr. Wolf was hired as a background actor for a scene in "A Beautiful Mind," the film about JOHN FORBES NASH JR., the mathematician whose career was derailed in the 1950's by paranoid schizophrenia. 
 "Ron Howard put me in a great spot," Mr. Wolf said. "This comes at the end of the movie, where RUSSELL CROWE accepts his Pulitzer Prize." 
 Wait. Wasn't the prize that Mr. Nash won a Nobel, not a Pulitzer?
"His Nobel Peace Prize," Mr. Wolf said. "Exactly."
Well, not exactly. The Nobel that Mr. Nash won, in 1994, was in economics. But back to Mr. Wolf and the movie. 
"Ron Howard's right-hand man, he comes up to me and says, 'When Ron Howard says it's the final take and it's a wrap, the crew wants you to say, "Let's go to the videotape," ' " Mr. Wolf recalled. "I said, 'I'm not going to do that. This is serious business.' "
Mr. Wolf relented when the assistant assured him that Mr. Howard would find it funny. All Mr. Wolf had to do was wait for his cue.
"Finally," Mr. Wolf said, "about 3 o'clock in the morning, he said, 'It's a wrap.' So I said, 'Let's go to the videotape.' Everybody started laughing. I was surprised at the reaction. And Ron Howard did laugh."

Back to the Restoration
JANET L. HANCHEY, who has refurbished gilded ceilings at Radio City Music Hall and entire rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is returning to an 18th-century mural she had all but finished refurbishing when it was damaged by fire. The mural is in Fraunces Tavern, the landmark in Lower Manhattan that was preparing to open next month after extensive renovations. But the fire on Friday left Ms. Hanchey frustrated and back on the job.
"We just spent two months restoring this mural, the view from 1717 of New York harbor," she said. "Now there's so much blistering and cracks, and there's soot. We're going to have to erase every square inch with an eraser. It's going to be more time-consuming to do this than it was to restore the whole thing the first time."
The 16-by-5-foot mural is in a room of the tavern, a replica built in the early 1900's of the building on that site where George Washington bade farewell to his troops with a toast at the end of the American Revolution in 1783. The cause of the fire has not been determined.
"Luckily I didn't put the final three coats of varnish on it," Ms. Hanchey said, referring to the mural. "I think that would have ignited the whole thing. Now it's all baked on with a black coat."

Talking Shop, Talking Nudity
DICK CLARK was talking about cholesterol (his) and television shows (ditto).
Being Dick Clark, after his doctor prescribed cholesterol-lowering medication, he signed on as the spokesman for a cholesterol-lowering campaign that begins next week. And in the fall, he will become a co-host of a syndicated talk show that is being marketed as a male counterpoint to "The View," the ABC talk show with five co-hosts, all women.
"We'll be four guys talking about things women can identify with," Mr. Clark said. "They've got a catch phrase, 'The world of women seen through the eyes of men.' Some guy in a cubicle sat for hours figuring that out. The essence is women don't get to see four men sitting around talking."
The women on "The View" are already talking. As Mr. Clark tells it, one morning last month, the topic was which men women would pay to see nude. JOY BEHAR said there were only two: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI and Mr. Clark.
"I sent her a note: 'I'm sorry you're late. I get thousands of requests every week, but we could trade. If you took off all your clothes, I'm sure that under those zippy 'View' garments, you're something to see. P.S. See you at the Daytime Emmys.' They liked it so much they read it on the air and said, 'See you in your Speedo.' "

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION; 
The Other Utopia Jefferson Founded

BYLINE:  By PAULA DEITZ; Paula Deitz is the editor of The Hudson Review.

 BODY:
While everyone else lolled on the beach or barbecued in the backyard, 75 people from 34 countries celebrated Independence Day this week in Charlottesville, Va., by taking the oath of citizenship on the west lawn of Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson. This year, the annual ceremony was held on the 225th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence, drafted by Jefferson, and also recalled his own death exactly 50 years later on July 4, 1826.
 Though Jefferson laid the groundwork for a new nation, nowhere are his goals and values felt more in the present than in his hometown of Charlottesville, not only at Monticello but also at the University of Virginia, the great educational and design achievement of the last nine years of his life. While the neo-Classical domed image of Monticello has gained symbolic familiarity on the reverse of the nickel, the bits and pieces of the university -- the much spoken-of serpentine brick walls, colonnades and rotunda -- are like a great architectural jigsaw puzzle that is difficult to fit together mentally without seeing it. 
 What finally motivated me to spend a weekend discovering Charlottesville, however, was a conversation I had in France during a visit to the Desert de Retz, the fantasy garden created by Francois Racine de Monville in the 1770's at the edge of the royal forest of Marly. Jean-Marc Heftler, a present co-owner of this visionary ensemble of follies that resemble antique ruins, described how Jefferson's designs for the oval rooms of the university's rotunda were inspired by seeing the Desert's Column House.
Jefferson had succeeded Benjamin Franklin as minister to France, serving from 1785 to 1789, and profited from his years abroad by absorbing the entire range of European architectural history, making notations and drawings as he went along. After his visit to the Desert, he remarked, "How grand the idea excited by the remains of such a column."
To arrive late on a summer evening in Charlottesville -- named in colonial times for the wife of George III -- and see the original university complex (called the Lawn) for the first time by moonlight and lamplight, flickering behind luminescent magnolia blossoms, is to observe one of the most magical settings in America.
Volumes have been written about the architectural influences for specific details of decoration, but the ensemble essentially represents the Jeffersonian vision for a sophisticated American learning environment that would make leaders out of young men from a hitherto agrarian society and attract European academics. (In his view, the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., was already too provincial and in decline.)
Rather than relax after he left the presidency in 1809, Jefferson geared up for what he perceived to be his crowning achievement by appropriating a sloping cornfield for a secular university that would condense thousands of years of European culture into its architecture. What did not originate from his own drawings and notes came from such studies as Andrea Palladio's "Four Books of Architecture," as well as from architect-friends like William Thornton and Benjamin Henry Latrobe, who provided sketches, specifically for the individual brick pavilions with white architectural trim.
The general plan was this. The library, a domed rotunda based on the Pantheon in Rome, was the centerpiece of the complex at the north end. Perpendicular to the rotunda, and facing each other, were two rows of five two-story pavilions or lodges, as Jefferson called them, reminiscent of the pavilions that once stood on either side of the Chateau of Marly.
With a lively mixture of pedimented facades and columns representing every classical order (the Ionic order of Pavilion II, from the Temple of Fortuna Virilis; the Corinthian order of Pavilion VIII, from the Baths of Diocletian), each pavilion housed on the second floor a professor of a different department -- law, medicine, natural history, moral philosophy, ancient languages, etc. -- who taught on the ground floor.
Linking the pavilions were the one-story dormitories for the students. In front of these were the long, covered passageways or colonnades, as rhythmical as those at the Palais Royal in Paris and a protection for students as they made their rounds of classes in inclement weather.

The Verdant Village
"The whole of these arranged around an open square of grass and trees would make it what it should be in fact, an academical village," wrote Jefferson, using the term that has evoked this special community for 175 years. The 200-foot-wide by 700-foot-long swath of lawn is a lush carpet of blue grass that descends in levels, giving greater height and importance to the rotunda in the distance. In fact, the pavilions are spaced farther apart as they descend the Lawn, giving the illusion of being evenly spaced, an illusion that reverses itself when seen from below.
"It is a daunting task to keep the Lawn green when it is the center of life," said Mary Hughes, the university's landscape architect. And herein lies the success of Jefferson's plan: even as a modern university has grown up around it, and a major library has left the rotunda and its restored oval rooms to ceremonial functions, with very few adjustments the "academical village" is occupied today exactly as Jefferson intended.
The privies may be gone, but students still go outside in their bathrobes to use the modern bathrooms behind their dormitories or to collect firewood in winter for their individual fireplaces. The bachelor professors of yore long ago gave way to romance and families, who now occupy entire pavilions, though two pavilions were recently restored to hold classes again on the ground floor.
But now for the first-timer's surprise. Behind the familiar colonnaded pavilions is a hidden network of gardens, originally both pleasure and kitchen gardens, divided by the graceful but economic serpentine walls. (The curves allow the walls to be built only one brick wide, like agricultural or forcing walls in England.) And beyond the gardens is a further range of buildings, including the original hotels or eating halls, now mostly offices, and more arcaded student housing. (Edgar Allan Poe's room from 1825 to 1826 is the only one preserved, though it lacks the rocking chair customarily allotted to every student.)

Pockets of Botany
Because Jefferson viewed the pavilions as private villas, he assumed that each professor would create his own garden. It is known from correspondence about cuttings and seeds that the botany professor and the philosophy professor did. The daughter of the latter married the former and brought her gardening skills farther down the Lawn with her.
Under the professors' private jurisdiction, a crop of utilitarian outbuildings gradually intruded on the individual gardens, and several still in evidence add character to the major landscape restoration undertaken by the Garden Club of Virginia from 1948 to 1965.
Under the aegis of Alden Hopkins, the resident landscape architect of Colonial Williamsburg at that time, and after his death his assistant, Donald H. Parker, these gardens in the Colonial Revival style survive today with a refreshing singularity of configurations and plant materials, many of them rare for the region because of the microclimates created by the serpentine walls.
Along the intermittent walkways between gardens, the day lilies that grow within the curves of the walls project an endearing simplicity. The garden club's terms required that the individual gardens remain open to the public at all times, so they are no longer the private domain of faculty members.
As the university has expanded, other architects have added their marks, and it is clear that each understood how Jefferson integrated architecture with landscape.
Early on, after a major fire, McKim, Mead & White altered the streetside facade of the rotunda and added three buildings at the bottom of the Lawn (although these obscure the view over the mountains that Jefferson treasured). A colonnade by Michael Graves along the facade of Bryan Hall, the English department building, exaggerates the girth of the columns; Hereford Residential College by Tod Williams Billie Tsien & Associates accentuates the role of a series of lawns and subgardens as dividers between walls of brick buildings.
Robert A. M. Stern's Darden Graduate School of Business Administration recreates the idea of the individual pavilions without varying each design. And in the Gooch-Dillard houses that Edward Larrabee Barnes designed, he captured Jeffersonian simplicity with the long perspective of a squared-off, outdoor brick passageway. Even one end of the new football stadium is wrapped with a classical colonnade.

Never Quite Satisfied
Jefferson would have appreciated the variations and eccentricities of his fellow practitioners, as a visit to Monticello makes clear. On a tour, William L. Beiswanger, the director of restoration, was quick to point out Jefferson's constant interior alterations to Monticello, which he began constructing in 1769 at the age of 26. Many changes were made in one wing of the house to suit his own privacy. These interior reconfigurations are reflected on the exterior by a great exuberance of complicated molding designs.
Back in the offices, Mr. Beiswanger displayed copies of Jefferson's drawings, now housed at the Massachusetts Historical Society. They were made shortly after his visit to the Desert de Retz and record the configuration of the famous oval rooms from the circular column house, with his careful notations in French.
Jefferson lost no detail of his travels as he tried to transform the new American society through architecture into a cultural power that would hold its own and even sometimes surpass the Old World.

In the View Of a Visionary

Charlottesville is about 350 miles from New York City. (The area code for the region is in the process of changing from 804 to 434.)

Attractions

UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA, at the intersection of I-64 and Route 29, Charlottesville, (434) 924-0311. During the summer, tours are given daily of the Lawn and gardens at 5 and 6 p.m. and of the rotunda at 10 and 11:30 a.m. and 2, 3 and 4 p.m. The tours of the Lawn and gardens meet on the front steps of the rotunda; tours of the rotunda meet inside. Free.

MONTICELLO, on Route 53, near the intersection of Route 20 South and I-64 (about two miles southeast of Charlottesville), (434) 984-9822. Through Oct. 31, guided tours are offered daily from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.; from November to February, from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Admission: $11; $6, children 6 to 11; under 6, free. www.monticello.org.

Where to Stay

BOAR'S HEAD INN, Route 250 West, Charlottesville, (434) 296-2181 or (800) 476-1988. A country resort in a restored 1834 gristmill. Double rooms: $185 a night; $215 to $225 a night for a room with a lake view; $360 to $500 a night for a suite. Packages are available.

OMNI CHARLOTTESVILLE HOTEL, 235 West Main Street, Charlottesville, (434) 971-5500 or (800) 843-6664. Situated on the historic downtown mall, with pool and workout equipment. Double rooms: $149 to $169 a night.

Getting There

BY PLANE: U.S. Airways has daily direct flights from La Guardia Airport to Charlottesville/Albemarle Airport. A direct flight is about 1 hour 45 minutes. A round-trip direct flight costs $140.50 to $435.

BY TRAIN: Amtrak runs trains from Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan to Charlottesville Station. A direct train ride takes about seven hours. A round-trip ride in coach costs $156 to $206; sleeping accommodations are available for an additional charge.

HEADLINE: Let Us Remember the Dear, Departed Plymouth 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
WITH little fanfare, the final Plymouth rolled off a Chrysler assembly line last week.
 The car, a silver Neon LX with a 2.0-liter engine and a five-speed manual transmission, was built on June 28, in Belvidere, Ill., finishing the division's 74-year run. The $18,210 Neon went to Darrell Davis, the Chrysler vice president for parts and service operations, who added the car to his collection of vintage automobiles. 
 It was fitting that the final Plymouth was an economy car because Walter P. Chrysler created the brand in 1928 in a bid to attract entry-level customers. It took Plymouth just six years to sell a million vehicles. Chrysler used Plymouth as a repository for affordable, sometimes peppy models designed to attract young buyers. Its high-water mark came in 1973, when sales peaked at nearly 750,000, thanks to spunky models like the Road Runner.
But Plymouth had trouble in the 1980's, fighting off competition from American and Japanese rivals. Chrysler executives decided to give Plymouth one last boost of products in the mid-1990's to see if the brand could survive.
First came the Neon, in 1994. The next year brought the Plymouth Breeze. The Plymouth Prowler, an eye-catching roadster with exposed front suspension, arrived in 1996.
Nothing really helped. DaimlerChrysler, the parent company, announced in November 1999 that Plymouth would depart at the close of the 2001 model year. Chrysler has transferred Plymouth's lineup: the Prowler and the Voyager minivan became Chryslers; Dodge sells the Neon. The Breeze was dropped last year.
Eliminating Plymouth made financial sense, but Chrysler has had trouble hanging on to Plymouth customers, who tend to be younger and less educated, and earn less per year than the average car buyer, said Art Spinella, an analyst with CNW Marketing Research in Bandon, Ore. "People who were buying Plymouth Neons don't buy Dodge Neons," he said. "They buy Hyundais and Kias and Daewoos." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The last Plymouth was made on June 28. (Dave Bock)

HEADLINE: European Central Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 5 

 BODY:
Despite continued signs of a significant economic slowdown in Europe, the European Central Bank declined again today to lower interest rates and made it clear that it would not relax its grip on monetary policy any time soon.
 Today's decision was not a surprise because it was foreshadowed on Tuesday in unusually specific comments by the central bank's president, Wim Duisenberg. 
 But as recently as last week, many economists were predicting a rate reduction either today or by the end of the month. Based on today's comments as well as on the coming summer break, any rate cut before the very end of August now appears extremely unlikely. 
The Bank of England also decided today to leave its interest rates unchanged as well. That decision was widely expected.
In sharp contrast to the Federal Reserve, which announced its sixth rate cut of the year last week, Mr. Duisenberg hammered home the point that his top priority is wringing out inflation rather than propping up growth. 
"Our monetary stance seems appropriate in the current stance and should bring inflation back in line with price stability in the medium term," he said at a news conference here today. "This remains appropriate for some time to come. I can't be clearer than that."
Last month, consumer prices across the 12 nations that share the euro jumped at an annual rate of 3.4 percent, the biggest increase since the euro was adopted in January 1999 and far above the targets set by the central bank. 
But European business has become markedly gloomier the last several months, and manufacturing industries are already teetering on the edge of a recession as exports to the United States and Asia weaken. Here in Germany, which accounts for a third of the euro zone's economic output, economists say the growth may have stopped entirely in the second quarter and will probably remain nearly dormant until later in the year.
The European Union's most recent survey of business confidence showed that industry sentiment across the Continent had slumped to its lowest level since July 1999, when companies were still reeling from the Asian and Russian financial crises. In Germany, business executives have become increasingly pessimistic for nearly a year now. Commerzbank, in a analysis this week, went so far as to warn that Germany was perilously close to a recession.
European inflation has been caused by a variety of problems, most of which are outside the central bank's control. Countries are still absorbing increases in world oil prices. Food prices have jumped at an unusually rapid pace, in part because of bad weather this spring as well as the massive slaughter of livestock in order to fight an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease.
On top of that, the weakness of the euro has pushed up the cost of products imported from outside the euro area. The dollar rose today to its highest level against the euro since October. In late New York trading, the euro was trading at 83.55 United States cents, down from 84.78 cents on Tuesday, before the Fourth of July holiday.
Because most of the recent price increases have stemmed from what appear to be one-time shocks, central bankers continue to believe that the inflation rate will drop back to their target of 2 percent by some time next year. 
But Mr. Duisenberg warned that the path ahead would be "a bumpy one" and repeated his concern about "secondary effects" of the previous price increases. He is particularly concerned about demands for big wage increases from European unions.
Because the central bank's governors do not meet for four weeks in August, that probably means they will not reduce rates until at least Aug. 30. And they may not do so then, either.
Jose Luis Alzola, an economist with Schroeder Salomon Smith Barney in London, said the central bank would not cut rates simply because growth in the monetary supply had abated. "The hopes for a rate cut lie elsewhere, and that will be in confirmation that the worst of the inflation is over," he said.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Treading Water" shows the euro has fallen back to the same level as last November. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Services)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
A marketing blitz is aimed at promoting a 'living brand' from Britain for the U.S.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
EVER hear of Anne McKevitt? Chances are, no, unless you are a devotee of doyennes of domesticity. But you are soon likely to be bombarded with an ambitious marketing blitz on her behalf in an attempt to promote her into being the latest "living brand." 
 In Britain, Ms. McKevitt is a popular television host and author whose programs and books about home decorating and interior design have led to lines of merchandise sold under her name in categories ranging from paint and bedding to tiles and wallpaper. The McKevitt Web site (www.anne-mckevitt.co.uk) describes her goal as "good quality, fashionable product at an affordable price for inside and outside the home." 
 Now, two companies with experience in producing and selling products through direct-response media like television home-shopping shows and infomercials, catalogs and the Internet are teaming up to bring the McKevitt brand of advice to the United States. Their intent is to spend tens of millions of dollars on developing an American presence for Ms. McKevitt, to stimulate demand for her products in this country that could potentially reach $110 million to $125 million in sales over two years.
The campaign to introduce American consumers to Ms. McKevitt -- whose aesthetic objective could be described as Ikea affordability meeting Terence Conran style -- will be waged by HSN Direct International in St. Petersburg, Fla., which is majority owned by a British media company, Telewest Communications, and the Frederiksen Entertainment division of the Frederiksen Group in Falls Church, Va., a company specializing in developing products and programs centered on marketable celebrities.
The effort, which is planned to get under way in September on television and the World Wide Web, is indicative of the growing trend of grooming personable pitchmen and women as living brands, whose mere presence can help peddle products because they symbolize what they sell. Such selling is part of the frenetic efforts by marketers to overcome the American economic slowdown, as they try making an end run around traditional retail and advertising channels where sales are softest.
The best-known living brand is of course Martha Stewart, whose Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has mushroomed into an empire of publishing, merchandising and e-commerce with a market capitalization of almost $1 billion. Other examples include the exercise and fitness devotees Denise Austin and Billy Blanks; Joan Rivers, for the costume jewelry she has sold on the QVC home-shopping channel; Susan Lucci, the soap opera actress, who has sold hair-care products, dolls and fragrances and is now selling costume jewelry on the Home Shopping Network; and the designer Diane Von Furstenberg, who has sold her apparel on QVC.
Whether Ms. McKevitt can accomplish the daunting task of translating her appeal on one side of the Atlantic to the other will be "up to her" and her corporate partners, said Allen Adamson, managing director at Landor Associates in New York, a corporate identity and brand consulting company owned by the WPP Group.
The danger, he added, would be if the McKevitt brand was presented too broadly, covering too many product categories, because "anytime a brand is so stretched, it becomes easier for competitors to nip off a piece here and there."
Still, there may be "room for another spokesperson" in the home-design market, Mr. Adamson said, because it is "a fragmented and fashion-driven segment, where people are looking for advice."
If Ms. McKevitt "is fresh and different," he added, she may catch on, particularly because of her heritage, in that "we don't look to England for technology, but we do feel the English have a sense of style."
Ms. McKevitt, who is Scottish, may be familiar to some Americans from two of her books already published in this country by Bay Books, "Style on a Shoestring" (1998) and "House Sensation: Spirited and Stylish Home Decorating" (1999). And some of her British television programs, which have appeared on networks like BBC2, have run on the HGTV cable network here.
Even so, "I've always felt America is a market with very big differences," Ms. McKevitt, said in a telephone interview. "For example, crafts are not such a huge thing in the U.K., but a large part of the U.S. market."
"I wanted to make sure I understood the U.S. market -- what the life styles are, how people dress, what people eat -- and if there was a place for me," she added. "What I offer is approachability, projects that are quick and easy for people to achieve, affordability: 'It's O.K. to make mistakes. You don't have to be perfect.' "
But by being perceived as informal or not stuffy, Ms. McKevitt, a former hair stylist, said, she is aware she must "not seem to be doing things that are slightly on the tacky side, selling people things in a way that's inappropriate."
Mary DiMaggio, president at Frederiksen Entertainment, said she was attracted to Ms. McKevitt by "the easy access and the no-rules philosophy," which she described as fitting well "with the need for consumers in the U.S. to be their own designers and decorators."
Already, the domain name www.annemckevittideas.com has been registered for American use, named after the company that sells her branded products in Britain.
"We have a long-sighted marketing plan," said Nancy Sutton Scott, product development manager at HSN Direct.
"We pride ourselves in our ability to identify people who identify with people, and that's Anne McKevitt," she added.
People, people who identify with people -- are they the luckiest marketers in the world?
Besides, turnabout may only be fair play. As Ms. McKevitt aims at the United States, on the way to further expansion, she said, to Asia, Australia and South America, Ms. Stewart has expanded from America to Brazil, Canada and Japan, on the way to Latin America and possibly Europe.

HEADLINE: How to Train -- and Retain -- Teachers 

BYLINE:  By Vartan Gregorian; Vartan Gregorian, former president of Brown University and former president of the New York Public Library, is president of Carnegie Corporation of New York.

 BODY:
For some time now, the nation has been warned that our schools will need up to 2.5 million new teachers over the next decade. Indeed, school officials from New York, Atlanta, Houston, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and other cities are actively seeking teachers from India, the West Indies, South Africa, Europe and anywhere else where good teachers can be found.
 But America has no shortage of idealistic and competent people who want to teach. Far from it: the nation's 1,300 schools of education have more than enough teachers in training to meet the need. So why should this be an issue at all? Because 30 percent of all our teachers and up to 50 percent of teachers in urban schools leave their jobs within five years. Out of every 600 students entering four-year teaching programs, only 180 complete them, only 72 become teachers and only about 40 are still teaching several years later. 
 The problem is not only recruiting teachers; it's retaining them -- and that problem points to some very real shortages.
To begin with, there is a shortage of public and official support for the profession of teaching and for professional teachers. Many of us would readily testify to the pivotal role teachers have played in our lives. In public opinion surveys and scholarly studies, we continually say that good teaching is key to school reform. And yet the teachers to whom we entrust our children and our future are not given professional respect, recognition and compensation.
The public rightly demands quality teaching and accountability but has been unwilling to acknowledge that quality comes with a price. The misconception that anyone can teach exists throughout the education system. Hence, many states routinely issue "emergency" teaching licenses to unprepared applicants -- a practice that would not be tolerated in any other profession. 
The true crisis in the teaching profession cannot be solved with simple answers, like raids on other nations' teachers. It demands a comprehensive response.
We lack a critical mass of very good schools of education. Many colleges and universities have marginalized their schools of education, treating them as revenue generators. Survival for many of these schools has often meant increasing enrollments and reducing educational quality. 
The governing boards and faculties of universities, both public and private, have an obligation to insist that universities annually provide more information about the quality of their schools of education, including data about the quality of their faculties, entering students and graduates and about the graduates' professional placement. More disclosure would help prospective students find higher-quality programs before going into debt for tuition at mediocre ones. This would create competition among schools for good students and would put political pressure on substandard schools to either improve or close down.
There is a shortage of meaningful professional advocacy on behalf of teachers. Teachers' unions devote most of their energies to improving working conditions and pay for their members. But by and large they have failed to secure the professional prerogatives of teachers -- namely, autonomy, flexibility and freedom to innovate.
To uphold the standards of teaching as a profession, unions need to push for more rigorous intellectual content in teacher education and professional development programs. Unions might even explore the cost and practicality of giving teachers sabbatical semesters for professional development after a decade of teaching.
Unions must also press for reforms in the existing teacher certification system. The patchwork quilt of weak teacher certification requirements needs to be replaced with a national certification program. Not only would this increase teachers' mobility from state to state, but it could provide research-based standards for what all teachers need to know and be able to do. One approach is to create a national commission to develop standards and national exams for teachers. Such a commission should also be able to develop a model system for measuring teachers' skills and performance. Accountability is essential, and only when teachers themselves push to eliminate mediocrity in their ranks will the standing of the profession itself improve in the public's eyes.
We must find better ways to help people entering the profession. Instead of giving them the toughest assignments, as is often done in our seniority-based system, we should give them a choice of schools, along with mentors and a reduced teaching schedule to ease the adjustment in the first year. Unions and management must also confront market realities: there is considerable competition for teachers in certain academic specialties, like math, and teachers in these fields have to be paid more.
But most important, we must change the perception that teaching is a dead-end job. We must provide young men and women, who are often burdened by college debts, with compensation on a professional level -- as it is, teaching in most states pays less than any other occupation requiring a bachelor's or master's degree. It is a measure of the profession's weakness that the only way most teachers can earn a good salary and grow professionally is by becoming administrators.
We are told that ours is the era of the "knowledge economy," that our nation needs well-educated "knowledge workers" and that our schools need to be transformed. But we can't achieve these goals without a stronger, more professionalized teaching corps, and we as a nation have not begun to make the longer-term investments that would bring that about.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Decline on Bleak Corporate Earnings Forecasts

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks slumped yesterday as investors faced a new batch of bleak corporate earnings forecasts including the announcement from Britain's Marconi that profits would be sharply lower this year.
 The announcement late on Wednesday from Marconi, a leading telecommunications equipment maker, reverberated across the technology sector yesterday. But investors returning from the Fourth of July holiday received even more bad news from Federated Department Stores and other companies. 
 The Nasdaq composite index lost 60.69 points, or 2.8 percent, to 2,080.11. Nearly two stocks fell for each one that gained. 
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 91.25 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,479.86, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 15.21 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,219.24.
"It basically stems from the Marconi announcement, which started a new sell-off in tech stocks across the board," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments. "The news was pretty bad." 
But the selling was a "bit exaggerated," Mr. Cardillo noted, adding that trading volumes were low with many people on vacation and with others awaiting the release today of the unemployment report for June. 
Wall Street could find some encouragement when the actual earnings reporting season kicks in the next few weeks, money managers said. That is because investors are betting much of the bad news will be out after the dismal preannouncement season, when companies acknowledged profit shortfalls.
But for the time being, corporate confessions are in full swing. Companies in the S.& P. 500 are now expected to report a drop of 17.3 percent in earnings, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. That is more than twice the shortfall seen in the first quarter, when profits slumped 6.1 percent, Thomson said.
The American depository receipts of Marconi lost $3.68, or 52.3 percent, to $3.35. It was the Nasdaq's third-most-active stock. The company attributed its falling sales to the global slowdown in the telecommunications industry, and Marconi's woes spread to other issues, including Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, which fell $1.85, to $20.35, and Lucent Technologies, which dropped 39 cents, to $6.30.
Retail shares slumped after Federated, the parent of Macy's and Bloomingdale's department stores, cut its second-quarter and full-year profit outlook. Shares fell $2.37, to $38.01. The rival May Department Stores lost $1.34, to $32.11. The S.& P. retail index fell 1.62 percent.
United States shares of the Dutch semiconductor equipment maker ASML Holding slid after the company said it could lose as much as $88 million in the first half and withdrew expectations of a recovery later in the year. It fell $1.42, to $20.80.
A bright spot was the energy sector as stocks rose across the board, partly in line with firmer crude oil prices after new data showed United States petroleum stockpiles fell sharply last week. The S.& P. oil and gas index rose 1.71 percent on gains by the likes of Apache, which gained $1.51, to $51.01. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Bonds fell yesterday as an improving outlook for service businesses suggested the Federal Reserve might stop lowering interest rates.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note fell 9/32 , to 96 29/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.42 percent from 5.38 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond fell 16/32 , to 94 20/32 . Its yield rose to 5.76 percent from 5.72 percent.
Treasuries declined after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of nonmanufacturing business rose to 52.1 last month, the highest since December, from 46.6 in May. Readings above 50 signal economic expansion.
"The Fed is obviously near the end of its rate cuts," and "we'd be hard-pressed" to buy more Treasury securities, said Gary Pollack, who helps manage $10 billion at the Bankers Trust private banking division of Deutsche Bank.

HEADLINE: In Florida, Fraud Doesn't Matter. Will Congress Object? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
LET'S consider two people who are bankrupt.
 The first, a father of a struggling family, lost his job and tried to meet his obligations. Each month, he paid the minimum on the credit card bills but ran up other charges as the family tried to make ends meet. 
 The second man was well-off before filing for bankruptcy. Facing a multimillion-dollar judgment, he moved his assets in a way that a court concluded might be a fraudulent effort to duck the judgment. 
Which one should be forced to pay his debts? 
Under current law, neither. But that may soon change.
The law now allows the first debtor to have his debts wiped out after he files for bankruptcy. The credit card company would not be able to recover the money that the man borrowed as he struggled to keep going unless it could prove that the man intended to commit fraud when he ran up those charges. Such proof is virtually impossible.
The second case was confronted by the Florida Supreme Court last month. Elmer C. Hill, a Tennessee coal broker, filed for bankruptcy in 1992 after a court ordered him to pay $15 million to a company that said Mr. Hill had defrauded it. Three days before the judgment became enforceable, Mr. Hill paid $650,000 in cash to buy a waterfront home in Destin, Fla., and $75,000 to furnish it. Under Florida law, people cannot lose their homes in bankruptcy, but it was not clear to a federal appeals court whether that applied if the house was bought with the clear intent to defraud creditors. So it asked the state supreme court to decide the issue.
The state supreme court cleared that up. "A homestead acquired by a debtor with the specific intent to hinder, delay or defraud creditors" is just like any other home, the court ruled.
Both the House and the Senate have passed bills to penalize those who owe money to credit card companies when they go broke. If a debtor charged more than $250 in the 90 days before he filed for bankruptcy -- or $750 in the Senate bill -- those charges may not be discharged if they were for "luxury goods and services."
There is no real definition of "luxury goods and services," other than to say that the term excludes things "reasonably necessary for the support" of a person. Credit card companies no doubt will try to define that to exclude almost everything. "Sure it was for groceries. But did you really need to buy steak instead of bologna?" Cash advances are assumed to be for luxury goods, but payments of credit card bills during the 90 days are not considered. Both the House and Senate bills include other provisions to force bankrupts to pay more of their credit card debts.
But the bills differ in the other area. The Senate bill would overrule Florida law and allow a bankrupt to keep just $125,000 in equity in a home. The House bill contains a provision that might hurt those who moved to Florida just before filing for bankruptcy, but not those who moved two years earlier. (Mr. Hill moved 18 months before filing, and might have been able to wait longer.)
With the economy weak, layoffs and bankruptcies are on the rise. Passage of either bill will increase the pain for those who go broke and perhaps slow the recovery. But the credit card companies are likely to get a bill through.
So Congress will crack down on struggling families that do not plan bankruptcies well. The question is whether it will close the loophole that allows some people to live in luxury while stiffing their creditors. That will depend on whether the Senate caves during final negotiations.

HEADLINE: In Rome, O'Neill Plans To Laud U.S. Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that he would carry a message of optimism about the United States economy to a meeting with his counterparts from the other big industrial nations on Saturday in Rome, where the main topic will be the faltering world economy.
 The United States, Mr. O'Neill said at a news conference, has done its part to spur an economic rebound by reducing interest rates and cutting taxes. He suggested that the Bush administration would like to see Europe and Japan do more to live up to their roles as "locomotives" for world growth. 
 Mr. O'Neill did not address one of the most pressing issues for many companies in the United States, the strength of the dollar against the euro and the Japanese yen. The strong dollar makes American exports more expensive in foreign markets and cuts into profits earned in foreign currencies, but also damps inflation by holding down the price of imported goods.
The finance ministers from the seven major industrial democracies are expected to discuss a variety of other issues, including some in which there are sharp differences between the United States and Europe.
Mr. O'Neill chided the European Union for its rejection on antitrust grounds of General Electric's proposed merger with Honeywell International.
Mr. O'Neill, who earlier this week described the decision by European antitrust regulators as "off the wall," used gentler and more general language today. He said he supported the general theory of antitrust most often applied in the United States -- that deals should be judged on whether they help or harm customers -- and by implication rejected the European view that antitrust judgments should hinge on what business combinations would mean to competitors.
"It does seem to me the driving principle should be what's in the best interest of ordinary people around the world in terms of raising their standard of living," Mr. O'Neill said. "If companies can combine and produce more value for regular human beings, it seems to me that's a conclusive test."
The meeting will come at a time when economic relations between Europe and the United States are strained on several fronts. The two sides are battling over a ruling by the World Trade Organization against the United States regarding provisions in the American tax code that give a break to exporters. And some European nations are unhappy with the Bush administration's decision to seek trade sanctions against some foreign steel producers.
The United States and Europe also have differences over how to crack down on tax havens and international tax avoidance.
Among the other topics on the agenda are money laundering and how to make the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank more effective in heading off financial crises and stimulating more economic growth in poor countries.
But Mr. O'Neill said the world economy would be a key focus of the talks, which are being held in part to lay the groundwork for a meeting of the leaders of the G-7 countries in Genoa, Italy, in two weeks. The G-7 countries are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States.
Mr. O'Neill said the United States was in the middle of a correction set off by "a rate of expansion and acceleration in consumer spending in the early part of the last year" that could not be sustained. Economists have put more of the responsibility on overinvestment by companies in computers, telecommunications equipment and other capital goods.
But he said the potential for a return to strong growth "was still there." And he added that he thought the growth rate of productivity -- the basic measure of business efficiency and long-term economic potential -- could ultimately go as high as 3.5 percent a year, or even 4 percent a year. Mr. O'Neill's productivity estimates were equal to or above the most optimistic assessments by private economists.
Mr. O'Neill said he was heartened by signs that automobile sales were running at a healthy pace and that the housing market had remained relatively strong. With consumers starting to receive a tax cut this summer in the form of rebate checks and lower withholding rates, the economy should get a "bounce, and that bounce will carry forward into next year," he said.
Asked about the adequacy of policy actions taken by Japan and Europe to strengthen their economies, Mr. O'Neill did not give a direct answer, but said, "They need to play a locomotive role as well."

HEADLINE: In Another Bronx, Everybody Knew His Name and His Party 

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO

 BODY:
Under a punishing noontime sun, made tolerable only by a gentle breeze blowing from the river, Herman Badillo came out of his car yesterday, took off his navy suit jacket, rolled up the sleeves of his blue shirt and began walking, alone, the streets of the South Bronx.
 A campaign volunteer with a bullhorn walked a few steps ahead, proclaiming, in English and Spanish, that Mr. Badillo was "the man." 
 "Here is the man of the people, the one who will get us out of poverty," shouted Leon Suarez, his well-trained master of ceremonies' voice amplified through the bullhorn. "Badillo. El hombre. El Puertorriqueno! The next mayor of New York City!" 
Mr. Badillo smiled, waved, shook hands, patted heads and smiled some more through his first tour of the Bronx since announcing last month that, once again, he wanted to be mayor of New York City. 
He joined a race already crowded with four Democrats and one other Republican, Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire political novice who has captured the media's spotlight precisely because he is an untested, self-financed candidate in a sea of familiar faces.
Like the other mayoral candidates, Mr. Badillo has to find a way to set himself apart from the crowd and to claim some of the attention now focused on Mr. Bloomberg, whose every move and word, from his social schedule to his taste in television shows, is recorded by an eager press.
And so, Mr. Badillo is walking the streets -- even venturing into heavily Democratic territory -- distributing fliers, shaking hundreds of hands, participating in debates, calling news conferences and struggling to raise the $250,000 he needs to qualify for city funds by July 16. He acknowledged yesterday that he probably would not be able to raise that much until the next qualifying deadline, in early August.
On Wednesday, he campaigned in downtown Brooklyn. Yesterday, he toured an overwhelmingly Hispanic section of the Bronx, despite pollsters' repeated predictions that most Latinos in the city will back the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, a Democrat, for mayor. 
"So what?" Mr. Badillo, 71, said. "Before the Bronx was Freddy's, it was mine."
It was a different Bronx back then, Mr. Badillo said. There were fewer Hispanics in the early 1960's when he was running for Bronx borough president, and they were all from Puerto Rico. Yesterday, most of the hands that reached out to shake Mr. Badillo's belonged to Hispanics from all over Latin America.
The candidate they were greeting, though, was also a different man from the one who first asked them to trust him almost 40 years ago.
Mr. Badillo is no longer the towering national figure who made urban renewal his trademark, or the big liberal voice who, as a congressman from New York, fought for bilingual education and won. 
He is also not a Democrat anymore, having switched parties eight years ago because, he said, the party was no longer in line with his political philosophy. Mr. Badillo opposes open admissions to senior colleges and social promotion in the city's schools.
"The interesting thing is that Badillo is saying now the same things he has been saying for a long time," said Angelo Falcon, senior policy executive with the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund and a close follower of city elections. "But no one was paying attention back then because he was a Democrat. Now that he is a Republican, people are shocked by what he says and call him conservative." 
Part of Mr. Badillo's challenge in this race is to reach out to Republicans without alienating potential voters -- those in the Bronx who remember his name from past campaigns, for example -- by reminding them that he is no longer a Democrat.
It was not difficult to strike that balance yesterday because most people who shook his hand did not ask questions; some did not even look him in the eye, unsure of who he was or why he would want to greet them. 
Those who approached him with enthusiasm appeared to do so because they have already made up their minds to vote for him. Some said Mr. Badillo reminded them of another era. Others welcomed him because they recognized the name, or because they knew he was born in Puerto Rico.
"Viva Borinquen!" shouted Juan Rodriguez from inside a bodega when he saw Mr. Badillo approach. 
"I know he'll do the right thing for the city," said Mr. Rodriguez, 30. Asked why, he simply replied: "Because he is Puerto Rican."
But Ana Araujo, 62, does not know what to make of Mr. Badillo. She shook his hand warmly and reminded him that, years ago, her husband had worked as a volunteer in one of his campaigns. She said that members of her Pentecostal church are supporting Mr. Ferrer but that her family, for old time's sake, is sticking by Mr. Badillo.
"I'm a Democrat," she said. "Of course I'll vote for him."
When told that Mr. Badillo is a Republican, Mrs. Araujo, a retired seamstress, was surprised.
"Oh, he is?" she said, holding her head. Will she still vote for him, if he wins the primary?
"Well, you see, that's the question now. That's the question of the year."

HEADLINE: U.N. May Delay Climate Treaty's Target Date 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN

 BODY:
The chairman of a United Nations conference negotiating a climate treaty said on Thursday that he was willing to delay the target date that countries would have to start cutting emissions of heat-trapping gases. His offer of such a compromise was widely seen as a bid to gain Japan's support for the treaty, known as the Kyoto Protocol.
 The proposal came during a speech to the Dutch Parliament by the chairman, Jan Pronk, who heads the negotiations and is the Dutch environmental minister. 
 He outlined a way to soften the treaty's rules that might make it easier for a country like Japan, facing a recession, to participate.
The current language of the treaty would require 38 industrialized countries to reduce their annual emissions, averaged between 2008 and 2012, to more than 5 percent below where they stood in 1990. 
"I can imagine that it would be possible to postpone the date of 2008 by two years, to 2010," Mr. Pronk said, according to The Associated Press and European wire services.
Until now, European officials have uniformly resisted any change in the timetable or targets of the proposal.
Nonetheless, many experts on the treaty predicted that Mr. Pronk's move was too little, too late -- with the only chance of American support evaporating after European negotiators rejected proposals from the Clinton administration last November.
The treaty was negotiated in Kyoto in 1997 and signed by the Clinton administration and 167 other governments, but countries remain deeply divided over its fine print and no large industrialized country has ratified it.
The treaty has been rejected by President Bush as "fatally flawed" because it excuses developing nations from obligatory emissions cuts and could, according to the Bush administration, harm the economy.
But it could still take effect if countries responsible for more than half of the industrialized world's 1990 emissions of warming gases support it. 
The European Union has said it would push to ratify the treaty without the United States. But without the support of Japan, a large source of emissions, it would be nearly impossible to reach the threshold for enactment.

HEADLINE: Argentina in Quandary as Protest by Jobless Gets Nasty 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: GENERAL MOSCONI, Argentina, June 29 

 BODY:
The 200 unemployed workers occupying the central plaza of this squalid oil town may look harmless in their makeshift tents sipping an herbal beverage through metal straws to while away the hours.
 But after an exchange of gunfire with the federal border police two weeks ago that left two bystanders dead and more than 40 protesters and police officers wounded, they have been described in the nation's newspapers as a threat to Argentina's political and social stability. 
 The government's intelligence agencies say that the protesters represent the core of a potential guerrilla insurgency and that they are at least loosely connected to Colombia's rebels or international narcotics traffickers seeking to stir up trouble in this part of northwest Argentina.
President Fernando de la Rua's cabinet is divided over whether to negotiate with them or repress them, leading to an embarrassing public feud between two ministers that has reinforced the impression that the government is adrift in its handling of a three-year-old recession and rising unemployment. 
In this town of 20,000 people, where 40 percent of the adults are unemployed, the protesters hardly appear more than a huddle of poverty, akin to the impoverished masses who occupied the Hoovervilles of the American Depression. They ridicule talk of their links to outside agitators as mere excuses to repress them.
Demanding jobs, they spend their days crouched around fires where they cook stews and heat their mate, the herbal beverage. They carry slingshots, which they normally use to hunt birds, and say they will use them against the police if they come to disperse them.
"We're not moving until Governor Romero meets with us, but he says we are nothing but delinquents," said Rosa Elena Torrez, 42, referring to Juan Carlos Romero, the governor of Salta Province, as she prepared soup in the plaza. "But he is the delinquent who killed two of our sons."
She showed the shell casing of a bullet and said border policemen fired shots at several hundred protesters on June 17 to force them to remove their blockade of a federal highway, which had been paralyzing the local economy for three weeks.
In the so-called "Battle of Mosconi," two innocent bystanders were killed by gunfire, 14 protesters were wounded and 39 were arrested. Hooded marksmen began the firing, and there are conflicting reports whether they were policemen, protesters or outsiders who mingled with the picketers.
But what has shaken the government most is that 27 policemen were also wounded, not by slingshots but by bullets, indicating that at least some protesters had guns.
After the confrontation -- one of the nation's most violent in years -- more than 300 heavily armed border policemen took up positions around General Mosconi, checking the papers and vehicles of all who enter and leave the town as if it were enemy territory. The protesters dropped their highway blockade and moved to the central plaza, where they demanded the release of three of their leaders who were arrested in the confrontation.
Taking a cue from the General Mosconi protesters, other unemployed workers have sporadically blocked roads around Buenos Aires. Another labor group rallied in front of the presidential palace on June 21 in a protest that grew violent when hooded men with gasoline bombs set the entrance of a nearby bank on fire. Tobacco growers around the city of Salta are now threatening to block roads to demand government subsidies.
"This is a problem the national government better resolve immediately because it is getting out of hand," said Governor Carlos Ruckauf of Buenos Aires Province. Interior Minister Ramon Mestre said the protesters were beginning to resort to "urban guerrilla tactics."
With the national employment rate now hovering above 16 percent and several provincial governments near bankruptcy, officials say they fear a rash of roadblocks by the unemployed will only slow the weakened economy. Several local protest groups with Trotskyist ideologies have sent delegates to General Mosconi to offer support and learn tactics.
The unrest in General Mosconi is rooted in the selloff of YPF, the huge state oil company, between 1991 and 1993. Hundreds of local oil and gas workers were laid off with modest severance packages and little if any retraining or loans for the difficult transition to new employment.
Several smaller oil and gas companies took over the YPF operations in this company town, which takes its name from the founder of the company, but they employed only a fraction of the workers. Meanwhile, the closing of YPF's large headquarters here and the exodus of a large number of executives reduced the demand for carpenters, gardeners and other workers.
Unemployed workers began to block local roads in 1997, and their protests have become increasingly violent. Last November, a mob burned down the town hall. More ominously, another mob attacked a police station in nearby Tartagal and stole weapons, including several assault rifles. "If the provincial government or national government don't begin a plan to convert this region into a cattle or agricultural zone soon," said Juan Nieva, 49, a former YPF employee who is now occupying the plaza, "these social explosions will continue and more people will die in the streets."
Such statements and the provincial government's refusal to negotiate has put Mr. de la Rua's government in the awkward position of either rewarding the protesters with concessions or allowing an unstable situation to fester.
When Social Development Minister Juan Pablo Cafiero visited General Mosconi, Labor Minister Patricia Bullrich publicly criticized him for "politically positioning himself at the cost of the government." She left the impression that Mr. Cafiero had come to General Mosconi without President de la Rua's approval.
But Mr. de la Rua sided with Mr. Cafiero, and a middle-ranking official has been sent here to devise a plan to give forestry and other public works jobs to the unemployed.
Aides to Mr. de la Rua say they will not interfere in local judicial decisions in order to free the three protest leaders, suggesting that if they were too lenient with the General Mosconi protesters it would only spur more violent protests.

Owner of Macy's Lowers Profit Forecast for Quarter
Federated Department Stores, the owner of the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, lowered its profit forecast, citing slow sales and steep markdowns.
 Federated projected earnings of 40 to 50 cents a share, or $78 million to $97 million, for the quarter ending Aug. 4, compared with an earlier forecast of 70 to 75 cents a share, or $136 million to $146 million. Page C6. 

Optimistic O'Neill Heads for Rome
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said that he would carry a message of optimism about the United States economy to a meeting with his counterparts from other big industrial nations tomorrow in Rome, where the main topic will be the faltering world economy. C6.

Editor Appointed at Financial Times
Richard Lambert announced that he would step down as editor of The Financial Times in September after 10 years in the job. He will be succeeded by Andrew Gowers, left, the head of The Financial Times Deutschland, the paper's German-language edition, which he established in 1999 as the founding editor. During his tenure, Mr. Lambert established a United States version of the paper and oversaw a large increase in circulation. C4.

Freelance writers, who won a Supreme Court ruling that said three large publishers had violated copyright law by using freelance material in electronic databases without the authors' explicit permission, are headed back to court. They contend that The New York Times Company is trying to bully freelancers into giving up the rights to their work for nothing. C4.

Nonmanufacturing Index Increases
An index of business other than manufacturing expanded in June for the first time in three months, but initial jobless claims rose. C6.

Freeze on Fund Group Roils India
India's stock market has been roiled by a move to ban selling and buying in the flagship fund of the country's largest mutual fund group. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Angel Investors Fill Void Left By Risk Capital; 
Impressing Private Financiers Becomes Crucial to Start-Ups

BYLINE:  By BONNIE AZAB POWELL

DATELINE: LOS ALTOS, Calif. 

 BODY:
Even in a gathering of some 70 people, spotting the money seekers was easy. They were the younger men huddled off to the sides, clutching glasses of mineral water and trying not to look anxious.
 All around them, mostly gray-haired or balding Silicon Valley veterans in semiformal attire traded jokes and gossip over cocktails. It was early evening, but the mid-June sun still slanted through the picture window of the Los Altos Golf and Country Club's private dining hall, where the Band of Angels was convening again. 
 Begun in 1995, the band is an informal club of about 150 "angel" investors, or private financiers, who meet for dinner once a month to network with one another and to listen to representatives from three companies looking for seed capital. Before being invited, each start-up must find an angel from the group to serve as its sponsor (and the investors do not make themselves easy to find by listing the members' names anywhere). 
Those seeking money must then pass the due diligence -- or vetting -- process and survive the final cut administered by Hans Severiens and Ian Sobieski, the band's managing directors. All for the chance to zoom through their PowerPoint presentation in the 20 minutes before the timer next to the podium flashes red.
But running the gantlet can definitely be worthwhile. If a company's presentation is well received, interested investors usually attend a follow-up luncheon a week later, where they may well write a $50,000 to $100,000 personal check in exchange for a small stake in the company.
In early 2000, it was still possible for a start-up to skip the angel stage and go directly to venture capitalists, taking home perhaps $5 million with few questions asked. In the heady days before the tech boom collapsed, the venture capitalists had billion-dollar funds raised from limited partners like universities and could easily afford to risk a pittance on early-stage concepts. No longer.
Venture capital financing fell from $26.1 billion in the first quarter of 2000 to just $10.2 billion for the first quarter of this year, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers/Venture One. What cash there was went mostly to struggling mid-stage companies already in the venture capitalists' portfolios; seed-stage financing plummeted to $32.9 million, down 75 percent from a year earlier.
Not only are venture capitalists shying away from start-ups just getting off the ground, they are also creating a bottleneck down the line for those angels still willing to take a chance. "The companies in the tough spot now are ones that have angel backing but no venture capital," said Steve Jurvetson, managing director of Draper Fisher Jurvetson, an early-stage venture capital fund. "When they need more money, it's difficult to get v.c.'s attention."
Last year the Band of Angels invested roughly $25 million in 23 companies, making the group one of the most active of the many angel networks in the United States. The Center for Venture Research at the University of New Hampshire puts the number of active angels in America at around 400,000. To be accredited, angel investors are required by the Securities and Exchange Commission to have assets of at least $1 million.
Angel investing has become one of the most popular activities for many wealthy people. But it is not a hobby for the impatient or the cautious: angels will not see their money again unless the company successfully goes public or is acquired. Given the youth of these companies, that can take a while even in an environment less hostile than the current one. Since its founding six years ago, fewer than 10 of the group's more than 100 investments have gone public, while about 15 have been acquired.
The group is also, in effect, a social club for Silicon Valley's elite. The Band is distinguished from other angel networks by the credentials of its members, many of them veterans of Intel, Sun Microsystems and other icons of technology development. That can make them an intimidating audience to a lot of struggling entrepreneurs -- even more so now that the stock market's deflation has sewn up the purse strings of most other money sources.
"Times being what they are, we have to be realistic," said David Bandych, chief operating officer of the start-up Notiva, No. 2 in the evening lineup. Mr. Bandych and Tom Furphy, Notiva's chief executive, both left the East Coast supermarket chain Wegmans in early 2000 to found their software company, based in Rochester.
"I think it's a good thing we didn't get funding last year," Mr. Bandych added, not entirely convincingly. "We've had to get customers and prove ourselves first instead."
Sharply at 7:30 p.m., Mr. Severiens urged everyone to be seated. "If we don't get started now we'll all be here way past our bedtimes," he chastised the group, with the trace of a Dutch accent that remains even after half a century in the United States. Mr. Severiens' breadth of experience -- a nuclear physicist who worked for Perkin-Elmer and the Atomic Energy Commission before becoming an investment banker at Morgan Stanley and other white shoe firms -- is par for the course among members of this group.
He calls himself and Mr. Sobieski the Band's chefs, setting a smorgasbord of wine, food and good companies to nibble on.
But first comes the warm-up act from Fred Hoar, a co-founder of the group and a public relations maestro whose decades-long career has touched landmark technology companies from Fairchild Camera, whose later exiles founded Intel, to Apple Computer before it went public. Mr. Hoar began with a cheery "Greetings, Angels and Angelettes, Welcome to You Bet Your Assets, our monthly walk on the wild side of Wall Street."
He flashed a grin before taking aim at, among others, himself -- regarding his rumpled cream suit, he joked, "Summer must be here: I look like a symphony in oatmeal." And he could not help noting the pain the group felt from the stock market. "As someone said," Mr. Hoar remarked, "I don't know whether to kill myself or go bowling."
Once the laughter died down and the salad course was cleared, the real business began in earnest. First up was Cardiac Focus, a medical device company developing a disposable vest that will help doctors screen and map cardiac arrythmias without surgery.
Craig McMullen, 57, recently recruited as the company's chief executive, is even balder than most of the angels, and delivered his PowerPoint presentation in a quietly urgent monotone. The company was on the prowl for $2 million to complete the development team, perform clinical trials, and file for Food and Drug Administration approval. Given the angels' own aging hearts and the company's sponsors before the group -- among them Wally Buch, a heart surgeon, and Tom Fogarty, also a surgeon and the inventor of the first balloon catheter -- it was no surprise that they paid close attention to the spiel.
Several hands went up for questions, particularly about regulatory issues, which were handled confidently by Terry Ransbury, 39, the company's co-founder and its chief technology officer.
Mr. Furphy, 35, of Notiva went next. He started off badly, with an audience participation trick -- "Who's had a career in accounts payable?" -- that elicited weary sighs. One angel took a look at Mr. Furphy's nearly shaved head and whispered, "Who'd trust someone with a haircut like that?" But as Mr. Furphy described the big retailers that are already using Notiva's software to automatically reconcile purchase orders, invoices, and shipping and receiving discrepancies, heads started nodding. The company's management team, with years of experience at Wegmans, also got the thumbs-up.
Then the 20-minute timer on the table turned yellow. With three minutes left, Mr. Furphy sped through his PowerPoint presentation like the pitchmen in the latest Toyota commercials, abandoning sentences halfway through. "We've thought about getting a hook for moments like these," Mr. Hoar confided.
The brief Q.& A. consisted mostly of questions about Notiva's venture capital financing. Notiva's team was hoping to raise $500,000 from the angels to tide them over until they secure $3 million to $5 million in venture capital.
The audience was tiring in spite of the regular coffee making the rounds. And the final start-up, a developer of software platforms to allow wireless carriers to customize their mobile phone offerings, did not perk them back up. One investor even fell asleep over his apple tart.
Afterward, as people milled around, Mr. Furphy insisted that his timer malfunctioned. "I was robbed of a good seven minutes!" he laughed. He was not too troubled; apparently several angels indicated that they would show up for Notiva's follow-up lunch.
Before the chill in investing hit, two of the three companies that presented themselves to the Band could probably expect to get checks. Now, it's more likely to be one. But which?
As it turned out, no one but Notiva's sponsors and the two managing directors showed up for its lunch. The band's members were cautious, waiting to see if the company was indeed about to get a "term sheet," a venture capital contract. Others were less concerned. The morning of the follow-up, said Mark Brandt, the company's chief development officer, a single angel investor from outside the group committed to the entire sum.
The clear favorite of the evening was Cardiac Focus. In the week following the dinner, 10 members wrote checks, while another four rounded out the company's $2 million goal at its lunch.
"The mechanisms of the funding are pretty much the same, independent of product," Mr. Ransbury of Cardiac Focus, wrote in an e-mail the day after the dinner. "If you get critical mass with the investors who the followers admire, then the deal happens. If not, it really doesn't matter, even if you have the cure for cancer."
But Cardiac Focus still faces many hurdles, including proving its device works well enough to get F.D.A. approval and eligibility for Medicare reimbursement.
At least now it has a greater chance of finding out. "The lust for entrepreneurship has not changed," said Mr. Severiens. "And now there are great bargains to be had."

HEADLINE: Funds Stopped for Legal Programs Helping Illegal Immigrants 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, July 5 

 BODY:
A governor-appointed board has stopped financing four programs at law schools that offer free legal assistance primarily to poor illegal immigrants, drawing complaints from immigration rights advocates who fear that hundreds of people will be left in the lurch.
 The board, the Interest on Lawyer Accounts, known as IOLA, voted 5-to-4 last month to discontinue financing the programs, whose budget had been cut to $35,000 this year from $105,000 last year. 
 Each program had received money for "social justice fellows," created by the state board in 1996 in response to federal legislation that prohibited federally financed groups from representing prisoners or illegal immigrants.
Representatives of the law school programs said today that the fellows, all practicing lawyers assisted by professors and student interns, have served hundreds of clients since then, handling such things as asylum applications, small claims court cases, landlord-tenant disputes and a few class-action challenges to immigration rules. The vast majority of the clients have been undocumented immigrants. 
The four programs are the Hudson Valley Poverty Law Center at Pace University here; the Touro Social Justice Project at Touro Law Center on Long Island; Brooklyn Law School, and Syracuse University College of Law. 
The state financing ended on June 30, but the programs are carrying on with leftover funds that soon will be depleted. To keep the programs running, advocates have begun asking politicians and others with influence to help find other money or overturn the decision.
"We're kind of reeling from the decision," said Jennifer B. Brown of the Hudson Valley Poverty Law Center, which has 40 to 50 cases a year.
Craig Siegel, associate counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University, said that immigrants outside New York City might be hit the hardest because there are few if any alternatives for free legal assistance in suburban or rural areas. "There is going to be virtually nobody available to help them," he said.
The board, created in 1983, disburses about $12 million annually from the interest derived from small, temporary escrow accounts private lawyers set up for clients as part of their cases. The amount of money has decreased from a high of $24 million in 1992 because of the decline in interest rates.
Supporters of the social justice fellows said they were puzzled by the decision. The board put a total of six programs, including the four legal assistance programs, on notice last December that they would receive financing for only six months this year pending a review of their programs.Those evaluations came back favorable. But, out of the six programs, only one was financed.
Supporters said they also found the decision of the board, made up of appointees of Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, curious because Mr. Pataki has generally taken a pro-immigration stance.
The 15 board trustees are appointed by the governor; seven through his own discretion and the remainder on the recommendation of the leaders of the Assembly and Senate and the chief judge of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. All five who voted against the programs were Republicans and the four supporters were Democrats.
William R. Nojay, a Pataki appointee and the chairman of the board for the past two years, said in an interview that the board decided it could maximize its effectiveness by financing other programs. The money that would have gone to the five programs will be distributed among the other 85 programs that were funded, he said.
Mr. Nojay, a Rochester lawyer, said board members made their decisions independently, without political considerations, but he declined to discuss the merits of any particular program.
"The question was, in our judgment were these the most qualified to deliver these services in these geographic areas?" he said, adding: "It's a Hobson's choice. There are no bad programs. We wish we could meet all the needs but we simply do not have all the funds to do that."
The board may receive an additional $1 million in funding this year because of a change in bank rules, but Mr. Nojay would not say whether any of the money would be used for the discontinued programs.
Joseph Conway, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki said: "We're confident that the board is committed to using its resources as effectively as possible and targeting those resources toward groups that have demonstrated the clear ability to help as many low income New Yorkers as possible."

 BODY:

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW; 
'Superimposition'

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
Caren Golden Fine Art
526 West 26th Street, Chelsea
Through July 27
 "Superflat," a much-noticed exhibition of contemporary Japanese work recently seen in Los Angeles, was about art skimmed from the slick surface of pop culture. "Superimposition," a group show of young American artists organized by the critic David Hunt, also takes pop culture as a reference, but points to a different art, one derived from stacking, layering, recession, depth. 
 An incremental dynamic is most obvious in sculpture. Richard Dupont creates a towering female nude by slicing up a life-size cast, then doubling all the pieces. Gedi Sibony pieces together a pair of legs from small stones and cement. Jeffrey Reed turns plywood, fluorescent lights and beer cans into a kind of heavy-metal altar, while Matthew Bakkom fashions a funereal-looking urn from meticulously stacked reels of "The Insider," a film starring Al Pacino that is based on a "60 Minutes" expose of the tobacco industry.
There are references to the illusory depths of video games in attractive paintings by Jon Widman and Luke Dowd, and in a spectacular one by Jay Davis, which transplants modernist architecture to the moon. The deep space of science fiction gets some play in Yorgo Alexopoulos's "Thrill of It All," a Minimalist wall piece that doubles as a star ship control panel, or the other way around. (Mr. Alexopoulos's work can also be seen in a solo show at Bronwyn Keenan in SoHo this month.)
Layering is subtle and abstract in a milky, luminous new painting by Jacqueline Humphries. It takes digital form in computer-generated prints by Marsha Cottrell and terrific multimedia animation by Jonathan Calm, titled "A Place to Live." Mr. Calm's piece, for all its high-tech polish, has a personal, stream-of-consciousness feel. The same is true in Jessica Rankin's "Constant Return," with its chartlike play of words -- read, overheard, spoken, obsessively thought about -- hand-embroidered in overlapping layers on sheets of opaque fabric.
"Superimposition" does not try to tell us anything definitive about new art. But it certainly gives a sense of its range, depth and quietly concentrated ambition. One comes away reminded afresh of how much of interest there is to choose from these days, and thinking how smart so many of Mr. Hunt's choices are.
 HOLLAND COTTER
