HEADLINE: Franks Will Head Pharmaceutical Trade Group 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 5 

 BODY:
Former Representative Bob Franks, fresh from his second straight defeat in a statewide race, is about to embark on a campaign of a different sort, as the chief lobbyist for the pharmaceutical industry in New Jersey.
 Mr. Franks, who lost the Republican primary for governor to Bret D. Schundler on June 26, has been named president of the HealthCare Institute of New Jersey, a trade group representing 19 worldwide pharmaceutical and medical technology companies, officials confirmed today. 
 The group, formed in 1997, wants to make the pharmaceutical and biotech industries synonymous with New Jersey, the way the oil industry is associated with Texas or auto manufacturing with Michigan.
It bills itself not as a lobbying agency but as the voice of the industry, commissioning studies from time to time about the importance of the many biotechnology companies and makers of drugs and medical devices to the New Jersey economy. Those companies employed more than 60,000 people as of 1999.
But the group's three top employees are all lobbyists registered with the state, and group officials said today that Mr. Franks could find himself advocating stronger patent protection for makers of brand-name drugs that compete with generic-drug producers.
That would not be an entirely new position for Mr. Franks to take. In the recent primary campaign, he was derided as "the congressman from Claritin" by Mr. Schundler, who criticized him for sponsoring a patent-extension bill that would have helped Schering-Plough preserve its monopoly on the popular allergy medicine, Claritin.
Mr. Schundler also insinuated that Mr. Franks's loyalty to New Jersey pharmaceutical companies had been bought with campaign contributions. Drug makers gave him more than $250,000 in his race last year against Senator Jon S. Corzine, and Schering-Plough has given him more than $40,000 since 1994, according to the Schundler campaign.
Not long ago, Mr. Franks took umbrage at the suggestion that he had worked as a lobbyist. In a June 14 debate, Mr. Schundler noted that Mr. Franks had worked for Wayne Valis Associates, a Republican lobbying firm in Washington. "I was never a lobbyist, never chose to register, never would," Mr. Franks retorted.
Mr. Franks, who signed on as a co-chairman of Mr. Schundler's general-election campaign on June 27, will replace William H. Tremayne, who announced in December that he would be stepping down as president. A spokeswoman for the group, Rebecca D. Perkins, refused to confirm the selection of Mr. Franks today when questioned about it by a reporter, but then issued a news release, dated July 9, announcing his selection.
The group's chairman, Raymond V. Gilmartin, also the chairman and chief executive of Merck & Company, did not return telephone calls today. But in the release, he said, "With his significant political experience, Bob is an expert at elevating public understanding of complex issues."
Mr. Franks did not return calls to his office today. In the release, he said he looked forward "to advancing an industry that is dedicated to improving and saving lives."
People familiar with the search for Mr. Tremayne's successor said Mr. Franks first discussed taking the job several months ago, when he was looking for a lucrative job before running for the Senate against Robert G. Torricelli in 2002. Instead, he accepted a job at Wayne Valis Associates, but left two weeks later to the campaign trail when Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco withdrew from the Republican primary for governor. The job he has now is a lucrative one, after all; one person familiar with the position said it pays about $400,000 a year.

HEADLINE: Business Survey Adds to Evidence of a Rebound 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5 

 BODY:
Business other than manufacturing expanded in June for the first time in three months, an industry survey showed today, adding to evidence that the economy may have begun to pull out of a slowdown.
 The nonmanufacturing business index of the National Association of Purchasing Management rose to 52.1 last month, from 46.6 in May. The June reading was the highest this year and the first since March to reach above 50, which signals expansion. 
 The signs of strength at retailers, restaurants and other service industries come after reports this week that suggested manufacturing was starting to rebound. Today's survey "adds further weight to our view that the economy is turning up and should see decent growth" in the months ahead, said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
Still, the ability to recover may be limited by a rise in unemployment, which may undermine consumers' propensity to spend.
Initial jobless claims rose by 7,000, to 399,000, in the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department said today. The number of people collecting benefits rose to 3.027 million in the week ended June 23, the most since November 1992.
Businesses announced plans last month to eliminate 124,852 jobs, a 56 percent increase from May, according to the employment firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. The number of job cuts planned in the first six months of the year was three and a half times as much as the level in the period a year earlier, as companies cut work forces to help bolster profits.
"The biggest threat to the economy" is still dismissals by companies "and the effect that has on consumer income and consumer psychology," said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at PNC Financial Services Group in Pittsburgh.
The government's monthly employment report, to be issued on Friday, is expected to show that the jobless rate increased to 4.6 percent in June, from 4.4 percent in May, and that the economy lost jobs for a third consecutive month. The last time the economy lost jobs for three consecutive months was in 1991, a recession year.
The survey of nonfactory businesses is a companion report to the purchasing management association's manufacturing index, which has shown contraction for 11 consecutive months. The association gathers statistics from more than 370 purchasing executives in more than 62 industries.
Separately, an index compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago based on May data showed that the risk of recession for the economy increased to its highest point this year.
The Chicago Fed said its monthly National Activity Index recovered slightly, to -1.06 in May from a revised -1.23 in April. But the three-month moving average came in at -1.04, from -0.96 in April; the Chicago Fed said that reading suggested a greater risk of recession, which is loosely defined as at least two consecutive quarters of economic contraction.

HEADLINE: Canada Vote May Bring First Union to Japan Carmaker 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Ontario, July 5 

 BODY:
Only last month, J. D. Power & Associates named the Toyota plant here the best car factory in North America -- for the fourth time. The Harbour Report, by another industry consultant, ranked it the continent's most efficient producer of subcompact cars. 
 On Friday, the factory takes a step toward earning one more distinction, when its workers vote on whether to join the Canadian Auto Workers union. If the union wins, it will mark the first time that a Japanese-owned auto plant in North America has been unionized, not counting factories that began as joint ventures with American-based companies. 
 The vote is a challenge to the participatory management practices that Toyota Motor Manufacturing has pioneered, analysts say. The company tries to select team-minded employees, but the union argues that Toyota does not listen to its workers.
Further, a victory by the Canadian Auto Workers would give the union an advantage over the United Auto Workers union, with which it was once affiliated and maintains ties. 
Despite efforts over almost two decades, the U.A.W. has failed to organize any of the so-called transplant factories in the United States -- including plants owned by Toyota, Honda Motor, Nissan Motor, BMW and Mercedes-Benz -- since winning the right to represent workers at a Volkswagen factory in New Stanton, Pa. That plant opened in 1978 and closed a decade later. 
Currently, the U.A.W. is working to organize a Toyota plant in Georgetown, Ky. And though Daimler-Benz, in buyingChyrsler and forming DaimlerChrysler, agreed to remain neutral if the American union sought to organize workers at the Mercedes-Benz plant in Vance, Ala., the U.A.W. has not yet been able to win enough support to hold a vote there.
Toyota officials said they were confident that workers would reject the Canadian Auto Workers in Friday's vote. Plant officials, including Raymond Tanguay, the executive vice president, have lobbied against the union in meetings on the factory floor and in a video that was sent by courier to each worker's home.
In a letter distributed to workers at a shift change this afternoon, Takanori Sakaue, president and chief executive of Toyota Motor Manufacturing Canada, wrote: "The vote is by secret ballot. You are under no obligation to vote 'yes' simply because you signed a union card."
But union leaders say that workers have become increasingly frustrated with Toyota managers, who they say do not listen to workers' concerns even though the company is noted for a production system that is based on employee participation and encourages suggestions.
"We want to put them on notice that their system has some flaws," said Tom Rooke, the union official in charge of the two-year effort to organize the plant here, about an hour west of Toronto. "They either are going to start to listen, or they're going to be punished."
The union drive is not focused on wages and benefits; assembly line workers here get the same pay as union members at the other plants in Canada. "What good are wages and benefits if your body cannot keep up to the pace," read a leaflet distributed by the union today. "What is not competitive at Toyota are the rights of the workers on the shop floor."
Gary N. Chaison, a professor of labor relations at Clark University in Worcester, Mass., said that the vote is proof that Toyota's practice of carefully selecting employees for their fit into its corporate philosophy may not be fail-safe.
"Toyota's degree of participatory management may have been working all right for a while, but workers are wondering: are we better off with a union than without one?" he said.
The union has struggled in retaining its traditional strength at plants owned by the major automakers. It conducted a bitter strike against General Motors in 1996, in part over the company's plans to sell or close parts plants, and it faces the probable shutdown of G.M.'s assembly plant in Ste. Therese, Quebec, sometime in the next few years. This winter, Chrysler canceled plans to build a new plant in Windsor, Ontario, and is cutting 2,800 jobs in Canada as part of a turnaround effort.
The vote on Friday was ordered by the Ontario Labor Relations Board after the union declared that it had collected the signatures of 40 percent of the workers it hopes to represent. The outcome will not be known until July 31 at the earliest -- and perhaps never because of Canadian labor laws, which differ significantly from those in the United States.
In the United States, a union must collect signatures from 30 percent of the workers it seeks to represent, though in practice unions typically try to collect signatures from 50 percent or more to guarantee a substantial margin of victory. Then, the National Labor Relations Board hears challenges from both labor and management before deciding whether to hold an election. The vote is conducted within 50 days of an order from the board.
In Ontario, elections are held more quickly, with challenges left until after the vote. 
The main fight between Toyota and the union will be over the size of the bargaining unit. The Canadian Auto Workers say they want to represent 1,950 workers; the 800 signatures submitted by the union barely met the 40 percent threshold for a work force of that size.
Toyota says that the plant has 2,440 workers and that the union has fallen "significantly short" of the needed support, according to Greig Mordue, manager of corporate affairs at the plant. Those not counted by the union include team leaders who supervise small groups of workers on the factory floor, students on hand for the summer and contract workers on staff for a limited period. 
The Ontario labor board agreed to a request by Toyota that the ballots be sealed immediately after the vote. A series of hearings has already been scheduled later this month. If Toyota prevails in its challenge, the ballots may be discarded, according to Ron Lebi, the labor board solicitor overseeing the election. In that case, the union would have to wait a year before seeking another vote.
But if the votes are counted, the union needs only a majority of those voting in order to win.
Mr. Rooke said that union leaders had decided it was time to seek an outcome in the organizing campaign at Toyota. "We worried if we waited any longer, we would lose momentum," Mr. Rooke said.
Mr. Mordue, the Toyota official, said that the company was confident the vote would not hurt its relationship with its workers. "No one inside the plant asked the C.A.W. to come in here," he said. "The C.A.W. came to this plant."
Freddie Lopes, 35, who has worked at the plant 12 years, said Toyota management was unsympathetic to workers' complaints that they were overburdened. Echoing other workers', he said that employees did not seek treatment for injuries for fear they would be reprimanded. "We build a good car," Mr. Lopes said. "We've put in all the ideas over the years to make the car better."

HEADLINE: EMC Says Quarterly Earnings Will Fall Short 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: HOPKINTON, Mass., July 5 

 BODY:
The EMC Corporation, which makes data storage equipment for big corporate computer systems, warned today that its revenues and earnings for the second quarter would fall well short of Wall Street estimates because of the global slowdown in technology spending.
 EMC said it expected second-quarter revenues to be about $2 billion, and earnings per share to be 4 to 6 cents. 
That compared with the Wall Street consensus for earnings of 17 cents a share and revenues of $2.43 billion. 
 Joseph M. Tucci, the company's chief executive, said EMC's business was being hurt "with each unanticipated downward step in the global economy."
"The earnings results for EMC's major customers -- the bulk of the S.& P. 500, for example -- have been like a ball rolling down a hill for each of the past three quarters," Mr. Tucci said. "When our customers earn less money, most of them have less to spend on I.T." 
EMC, once seen as a safe haven for investors because of booming growth in corporate computer use, has succumbed to the same technology slowdown that has hit other sectors. 
The company said that the slowdown in the United States had spread globally and that its impact had been aggravated by a strong dollar.
"As a result, sales cycles have continued to elongate," said William J. Teuber Jr., EMC's chief financial officer. "We expect gross margins for the second quarter will be in the mid-40 percent range, reflecting several factors: lower sales volume than anticipated, customer incentive programs, and our competitive pricing actions."
EMC plans to announce complete second-quarter results on July 18.
Shares of EMC fell 10 percent, to $27, in after-hours trading. In the regular session, shares fell 5 percent, or $1.59, closing at $30.03.

HEADLINE: City Requests $160 Million To Fix Up Homes in Scandal 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
City officials have urged the federal government to spend $160 million -- twice as much as it had planned -- to rehabilitate hundreds of brownstones and other properties caught up in a home mortgage scandal that has hobbled revitalization efforts in Harlem, Brooklyn and elsewhere.
 Under the plan, outlined in a June 13 letter from the city housing commissioner, Jerilyn Perine, to officials at the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, the city would assume responsibility for renovating the buildings, using its existing programs and federal money. 
 Nearly 600 properties in the city were bought through schemes to defraud a federally insured mortgage program known as 203(k) that was intended to foster homeownership in poor neighborhoods. Of these, about half are vacant and half are occupied. Almost all of them are in foreclosure or are owned by HUD. Since January 1998, the city has found about 19,000 housing code violations at these properties and has spent more than $1 million on emergency repairs on the occupied properties. 
Under the schemes, which began in 1998, real estate speculators bought properties and then quickly resold them at vastly inflated prices, a practice known as flipping. The speculators sold the properties to nonprofit groups that did not have experience in providing housing and ultimately defaulted on the loans. Nineteen people have been arrested in the case so far, and nine have pleaded guilty. Sentencing will take place in the fall, prosecutors said. 
Before leaving office in January, Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo of HUD introduced a plan to rehabilitate the properties for an unspecified amount of money and then turn them over to community development groups with a long track record in providing housing for low-income families. That plan was scrapped by the new administration, which said it was willing to spend $80 million -- a sum that city officials say is unrealistically low -- to make the properties habitable, and then sell them on the open market.
HUD's rejection of the Cuomo plan fueled speculation that the Bush administration was reluctant to bail out Mr. Cuomo from an embarrassing situation that occurred during his tenure. Mr. Cuomo is running in next year's governor's race in New York.
A HUD spokesman said yesterday that the department was reviewing Ms. Perine's proposal but had made no decision. Ms. Perine said yesterday that HUD officials were taking the proposal seriously but were concerned about the cost. "They've come back with technical questions," she said. "It's not like they're not focusing on this. They are."
Ms. Perine said that the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development had an interest in ensuring that the 203(k) properties were rehabilitated, because abandoned buildings attract vagrants and vandalism, and many are on blocks where the agency invested in fixing up city-owned buildings. Since 1994, she said, the city has renovated more than 54,000 housing units. "We have an interest in getting these buildings into the right hands," she said, referring to the 203(k) properties.
Ms. Perine's proposal has the support of the groups that had been involved in the Cuomo plan. "There is mutual agreement among parties who usually don't agree," said Michael Gecan, a senior organizer for the Industrial Areas Foundation, which is working with one of the would-be participants in the Cuomo deal, the East Brooklyn Congregations, a consortium of 40 groups.
Karen A. Phillips, the chief executive of the Abyssinian Development Corporation in Harlem, said the city's proposal would prevent the 203(k) houses from destabilizing neighborhoods and falling prey to new speculators. "We know that the city already has the infrastructure in place to ensure that these houses get done without reinventing the wheel," she said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Troubled Yonkers Co-op Finances a Fresh Start

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
An 89-apartment co-op in Yonkers has emerged from bankruptcy after years of financial struggle that included damages it was assessed in a racial discrimination lawsuit.
 Under a reorganization plan approved last week by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, the Michelangelo Apartments co-op refinanced its underlying mortgage, adding $1 million in debt but stabilizing its finances. The co-op, a 10-story structure at 687 Bronx River Road, had been troubled since it converted from a rental building in 1989. The loss of the legal challenge in 2000 pushed the co-op to file for bankruptcy protection that year. 
 The lender is the Community Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit consortium of New York banks and insurance companies that finance moderately priced housing. The new mortgage replaces a loan from the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
The added money in the $4.1 million mortgage is to be used for improvements to the 25-year-old building, like repairing terraces and balconies. The new mortgage will also be used to pay the legal judgment, as well as to set up a reserve fund that will be increased by $12,000 a year.
To pay the new debt and generate a positive cash flow, monthly maintenance fees, which were already high compared with those at other co-ops in the area, were raised 10 percent. The fees are $375 to $1,075 a month for the studio-to-two-bedroom units.
Jeffrey Treisman, president of the co-op board and a 14-year resident, said not all shareholders were pleased by the increase. But he added, "Many realized the bankruptcy was necessary to preserve their equity and are optimistic of the co-op's ongoing financial viability." He said the previous financial problems resulted largely from ineffective management.
"The alternative, foreclosure, was unpalatable," said Steven A. Kirschenbaum, the lawyer for the apartment corporation and a partner at the Manhattan law firm of Hartman & Craven.
Mr. Kirschenbaum said co-op shareholders, who make payments for their part of the building's underlying mortgage as part of the monthly charges allocated to their apartments, can lose their investment if the mortgage is foreclosed, while remaining liable for the individual loans they have taken to buy their apartments. Given the issues affecting the Yonkers building, he said, it took time to find a lender willing to work out a deal.
Sadie McKeown, a senior vice president of the Community Preservation Corporation and director of its Hawthorne, N.Y., office, said her company got involved because the building has a number of positive points. Among them, she said, is that rents being paid for apartments that are being rented out by their owners are greater than the monthly maintenance fees, indicating that the building, if necessary, would work economically as a rental. 
A year or two after Michelangelo Apartments was converted to a co-op, 54 units were sold to resident owners and investors for $35,700 to $110,000. The remaining 35 units are owned by the original sponsor, who, like other investors, leases those apartments at monthly rents of $750 to $1,500. 
With the recession of the early 90's the co-op's problems worsened. Improvements were delayed, and some owners moved away and rented out their units because they could not sell them at the prices they paid. Other owners defaulted on their apartment loans and their units were taken over by the co-op, which resold them at reduced prices. And for four of the last five years, the owners paid a special assessment equal to one month's maintenance just to meet the co-op's expenses. 
The final straw was the lawsuit, filed against the co-op corporation and a former board president by an investor owner and his tenants, an interracial couple. In 1999, the co-op was found liable for racial discrimination and found in violation of the federal Fair Housing Act of 1968 and the state Human Rights Law. The judgment was upheld in 2000. Unable to pay the $435,000 in damages and legal fees or to refinance its existing loan, the co-op filed for bankruptcy protection.
Since then the co-op has put in place a new board of directors, superintendent and managing agent. And under the reorganization plan, the 30-year mortgage from Community Preservation Corporation will enable the co-op to pay the judgment, which was negotiated to $340,000, set aside $350,000 for repairs, pay $95,000 in bankruptcy administrative expenses and establish the reserve.
There are struggles ahead. While the high maintenance fees are expected to depress sale prices, Mr. Treisman, the co-op board's president, said, "Over time prices will rebound somewhat, which will afford owners a better opportunity to sell their apartments."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 89-apartment co-op at 687 Bronx River Road in Yonkers. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Red Tide Rising

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; Thomas L. Friedman is on vacation.

 BODY:
During the debate over George W. Bush's tax cut, administration officials told wavering supporters not to worry. The Congressional Budget Office, they insisted, was underestimating future surpluses; in fact there would be plenty of money, even after the tax cut, for other priorities. 
 Whoops. No sooner had Mr. Bush signed that tax cut into law than those same officials began admitting that the budget outlook wasn't that rosy after all. In fact, revenue is dropping like a stone. A suspicious man might wonder about the timing: isn't it strange that the bad news on revenue came to light only after the tax cut had passed? 
 In any case, get ready for more bad news. When the Budget Office updates its projections next month, it is certain to mark them down, not up -- and that will be just the beginning of a dismal trend. Forget about those budget surpluses as far as the eye can see; from now on the prospect is for chronic budget shortfalls.
By "shortfalls" I don't exactly mean deficits. The federal government as a whole will probably take in more money than it puts out for a decade or so, until the baby boomers reach retirement age. But more than all of this surplus will come from Medicare and Social Security. And those programs are supposed to run surpluses, to build up reserves for the demographic deluge. The rest of the budget will be in deficit; in effect, the tax cut will come at the expense of the retirement trust funds.
Of course, administration officials play down the sudden budget deterioration, saying that the surplus will return once the economy recovers. But it won't. Yes, corporate profits taxes -- the big item in this year's revenue slump -- will bounce at least partway back. But income tax receipts will steadily decline, as those huge tax cuts for the rich phase in. And the spending assumptions used to justify those tax cuts already look ludicrously low. In particular, the Bush administration has already asked for far more defense spending than it admitted it wanted before the tax cut passed, and Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld hasn't even started on his real shopping list. 
None of this should come as a surprise. Anyone who was paying attention knew that to sell the tax cut Mr. Bush's people deliberately underestimated the cut's impact on revenues; deliberately underestimated the cost of delivering on the administration's promises on defense, education and prescription drugs; and deliberately swept under the rug other budget issues, like the need to fix the alternative minimum tax, that will inevitably subtract hundreds of billions from the surplus. In short, the claim that the tax cut was easily affordable given other priorities was what is technically known as a "lie." 
The only real question was how long they would get away with it. Without the economic slump, they might have maintained plausible deniability until 2003 or 2004; because of the slump, the moment of truth is already here.
Now comes the spinning.
At first the Bush team's line will be that the economic slump is the sole cause of the shortfall. Once that line has been exhausted, they will move the goal posts -- saying that while the Social Security surplus is in a "lockbox," the Medicare surplus is fair game. This position makes no sense; both programs serve retirees, so both should be accumulating reserves to deal with the baby boomers. But this argument might succeed in confusing some people. 
Finally, when it becomes apparent that the tax cut will cut into the Social Security trust fund too -- quite possibly as soon as next year -- we'll be told that this doesn't matter, that the trust fund is a mere accounting fiction. (In fact, Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill has already started saying this.) And in a way that's true. But it's an accounting fiction with a purpose -- namely, to prevent irresponsible politicians from undermining the government's long-term ability to honor its promises. Alas, it failed. 
If the Senate had known six weeks ago what it knows now, it wouldn't have approved that huge, irresponsible tax cut. But now it's too late; proposals to scale the cut back don't have much of a chance as long as this administration is in office.
The truth is that moderates who voted for that tax cut were snookered. And the nation will spend years paying for the consequences of their gullibility.

HEADLINE: What Is The Next Big Idea? The Buzz Is Growing 

BYLINE:  By EMILY EAKIN 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C. 

 BODY:
It comes along only once every decade or so, typically arriving without much fanfare. But soon it is everywhere: dominating conferences, echoing in lecture halls, flooding scholarly journals. Every graduate student dreams of being the one to think it up: the Next Big Idea.
 In the 1960's it was Claude Levi-Strauss and structuralism. In the 1970's and 1980's it was Jacques Derrida and deconstruction, Michel Foucault and poststructuralism and Jacques Lacan and psychoanalysis, followed by various theorists of postcolonialism and New Historicism. 
 And now scholars are wondering if the latest contender for academia's next master theorist is Michael Hardt, a self-effacing, 41-year-old associate professor of literature at Duke University and the co-author of "Empire," a heady treatise on globalization that is sending frissons of excitement through campuses from Sao Paulo to Tokyo. 
Since Harvard University Press published the book in March last year, translation rights have been sold in 10 countries, including Japan and Croatia; the leading Brazilian newspaper has put it on the cover of its Sunday magazine; and Dutch television has broadcast a documentary about it. Fredric Jameson, America's leading Marxist literary critic, has called it "the first great new theoretical synthesis of the new millennium," while the equally eminent Slovenian political philosopher Slavoj Zizek has declared it "nothing less than a rewriting of the 'The Communist Manifesto' for our time."
During the same period, Mr. Hardt has given 21 academic talks and received tenure from Duke (a year early). And the compliments keep coming.
"He's definitely hot," said Xudong Zhang, a professor of comparative literature and East Asian Studies at New York University, who taught a graduate seminar on "Empire" for the second time this spring. Masao Miyoshi, a professor of literature at the University of California at San Diego, said, "He's one of the very few younger people who will have an impact."
There is no question that Mr. Hardt is unusually talented. But talent alone does not provoke scholarly commotion. Other factors must also be at work. For one thing, the topic must be in vogue; and globalization happens to be the trendy subject right now.
Then there is the allure of Mr. Hardt's flamboyant co-author, Antonio Negri, a 68-year-old Italian philosopher and suspected terrorist mastermind who is serving a 13-year prison sentence in Rome for inciting violence during the turbulent 1970's.
In large part, however, the fuss over Mr. Hardt and "Empire" is about something else: the need in fields like English, history and philosophy for a major new theory. "Literary theory has been dead for 10 years," said Stanley Aronowitz, a sociologist at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. "The most important point about 'Empire' is that Michael is addressing the crisis in the humanities, which has reached the point where banality seems to pervade the sphere."
Indeed, by the end of the 1990's, the sweeping approaches of the previous decades had been exhausted. Yet no powerful new idea emerged to take their place. A deep pessimism crept over the humanities. Today, scholars complain, their fields are fragmented and rudderless.
So just what does a disquisition on globalization have to offer scholars in crisis?
First, there is the book's broad sweep and range of learning. Spanning nearly 500 pages of densely argued history, philosophy and political theory, it features sections on imperial Rome, Haitian slave revolts, the American Constitution and the Persian Gulf war, and references to dozens of thinkers like Machiavelli, Spinoza, Hegel, Hobbes, Kant, Marx and Foucault. In short, the book has the formal trappings of a master theory in the old European tradition.
Then there is the theory itself. Globalization isn't simply the latest phase in the history of imperialism and nation-states, the authors declare. It's something radically new. Where other scholars and the media depict countries vying for control of world markets, Mr. Hardt and Mr. Negri instead discern a new political system and a new form of power taking root. They call it Empire.
Unlike historical empires, however, this one has no emperor, no geographic capital and no single seat of power. In fact, given the authors' abstruse formulation, it's almost easier to say what Empire isn't than what it is: a fluid, infinitely expanding and highly organized system that encompasses the world's entire population. It's a system that no one person, corporation or country can control. (It's also apparently still under construction. One hallmark of Empire is "supranational organisms," few of which seem to exist yet. The authors regard the United Nations, for example, as a precursor of a "real supranational center.")
More surprising still, Empire is good news: it's potentially the most democratic political system to hit the face of the earth. As Mr. Hardt puts it, "The thing we call Empire is actually an enormous historical improvement over the international system and imperialism." The reason? Because power under Empire is widely dispersed, so presumably just about anyone could affect its course.
"Empire creates a greater potential for revolution than did the modern regimes of power," the authors write, "because it presents us, alongside the machine of command, with an alternative: the set of all the exploited and the subjugated, a multitude that is directly opposed to Empire, with no mediation between them."
The book is full of such bravura passages. Whether presenting new concepts -- like Empire and the multitude -- or urging revolution, it brims with confidence in its ideas. Does it have the staying power and broad appeal necessary to become the next master theory? It is too soon to say. But for the moment, "Empire" is filling a void in the humanities.
For literary scholars it is evidence that the work they do is politically important. They are not simply analyzing Milton's religious convictions or parsing "Finnegans Wake," they argue, but shedding light on the way the world really works. Consider deconstruction; it revolutionized scholars' understanding of language. Lacanian psychoanalysis did the same for the human psyche. In a similar way, "Empire" lays out a new way of thinking about global politics. When it comes to understanding current events, the book insists, even literary scholars have something important to contribute. And at a moment of disciplinary crisis, that's a message that's bound to appeal.
Michele Lamont, a sociologist at Princeton University, argued as much in a famous article titled "How to Become a Dominant French Philosopher: The Case of Jacques Derrida," which appeared in The American Journal of Sociology in 1987. She concluded that Mr. Derrida's popularity had less to do with the intrinsic value of his ideas than with his "sophisticated writing style," "distinctive theoretical framework" and lucky timing. Deconstruction, she wrote, "was an answer to a disciplinary crisis." His famously stylish clothes and his thick French accent didn't hurt either.
Of course, Mr. Hardt can't trade on credentials like those. Not that long ago he even had trouble finding a job. With a Ph.D. in comparative literature from the University of Washington at Seattle, he lacked both an Ivy League diploma and the kind of narrow specialization that many academic departments look for these days.
"I applied to French, Italian, English, political science and philosophy departments," he recalled recently over lunch at an Italian restaurant near the Duke campus. "But the reality of it is that almost no one would hire me."
With his soft voice, denim jacket and unruly dark hair, Mr. Hardt looks and sounds more like an idealistic graduate student than a rapidly rising star scholar. When he did land a job in the Italian department at the University of Southern California in 1993, he said, he found himself at odds with colleagues in his field.
"I went to a conference on Marx and deconstruction," he recalled. "I listened to a series of papers that were so convoluted and abstract. The speakers said they were talking about politics, but I couldn't understand a thing political about them. I was so frustrated after the weekend that on the Monday after, I called the state prison commission and found out how I could volunteer teaching at the local prison."
By this time he was already collaborating with Mr. Negri. Inspired by the Italian philosopher's writings and political activism, Mr. Hardt had asked a friend to introduce them during a visit to Paris, where Mr. Negri had fled to avoid serving his jail sentence. (In 1997, he returned to Rome -- and went directly to prison.) They began collaborating on "Empire" in 1994.
From a professional standpoint, it was a risky move. Though Mr. Hardt had published a book of his own (on the French philosopher Gilles Deleuze), he had no obvious area of specialization. Moreover, interest in contemporary Italian philosophy was small in the United States.
For Mr. Hardt, the risks obviously paid off. Of course, his book has skeptics. Some say nation-states are as strong as ever; that the book fails to back up its theory with facts; that it's hobbled by Marxist ideology.
"The argument that the world exhibits a completely different power structure is at least grossly hyperbolic and more probably merely false," said John Gray, a professor of European thought at the London School of Economics, who has published his own critique of globalization, "False Dawn" (New Press, 1999). " 'Empire' theorizes the current state of the world in a way which produces romantically alluring phrases that gloss over the actual conflicts, discontinuities, uncertainties and sheer unknowability of the world and its power relations today."
Such criticisms don't seem to bother Mr. Hardt. He says he is pleased that the book has found an audience outside what he calls "our small fanatical readership." He has few illusions that he is the next Derrida.
"I'm sure I'm not," he said. "Toni and I don't think of this as a very original book. We're putting together a variety of things that others have said. That's why it's been so well received. It's what people have been thinking but not really articulated."
And he readily concedes that "Empire" has flaws. Mr. Zizek complained that for a book that preaches revolution, it had an unforgivable omission: no how-to manual. Mr. Hardt agreed:
"I wrote him an e-mail and said, 'Yes, it's true we don't know what the revolution should be.' And he wrote back saying, 'Yeah, well, I don't know either.' "

PERSON: Leo Clair Beebe 

HEADLINE: Leo C. Beebe, 83, Led Industrial Equipment Maker 

BYLINE:  By MARCIN SKOMIAL

 BODY:
Leo Clair Beebe, the former chairman and chief executive of K-Tron International, which makes equipment used in processing for industries ranging from food to chemicals, died on June 30 at a hospital near his home in Jacksonville Beach, Fla. He was 83.
 The cause was pancreatic cancer, said Edward B. Cloues II, the chief executive of K-Tron. 
 After nine years on K-Tron's board, Mr. Beebe succeeded the company's founder as chairman and chief executive in 1985, overseeing K-Tron's global expansion.
Mr. Beebe first retired from K-Tron, which is based in Pitman, N.J., in 1992, the same year the company acquired a German concern. That purchase led to a financial crisis, and Mr. Beebe returned as chief executive in 1995 to restore the financial stability of the company. Mr. Beebe retired again in 1998 but continued to serve as a director.
Before his career at K-Tron, Mr. Beebe was a professor at Glassboro State College in Glassboro, N.J., which is now Rowan University. He was dean of Glassboro's business school from 1977 to 1985.
Before going to Glassboro, Mr. Beebe spent 28 years at Ford Motor. At Ford, he took leaves to handle public service assignments. In the late 1950's, as vice chairman of the Committee for Hungarian Refugees, he organized and directed the resettlement of 35,000 Hungarian refugees in the United States. 
In 1969, Mr. Beebe was lent from Ford to handle the operations of the National Alliance of Businessmen, where he was responsible for finding 100,000 jobs for the unemployed. Within six months the alliance had secured nearly 200,000 jobs.
Mr. Bebee was born on July 20, 1917, in Williamsburg, Mich. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan and a master's degree in communications from Glassboro State.
Mr. Bebee is survived by his wife, Jan Wyss Beebe of Houston; a daughter, Anne Beebe of Lansing, Mich.; a son, Peter Thompson Beebe of Seattle; a stepdaughter, Catherine Jacobs van Merlen of Houston; a stepson, Marc Gisar of Philadelphia; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: New York City Schools Chancellor Warns Superintendents of Layoffs and Other Cuts 

BYLINE:  By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy warned the Board of Education's district superintendents yesterday to prepare for layoffs and other cuts if City Hall fails to provide adequate funding for schools.
 While his words were directed at administrators inside the school system, Mr. Levy was clearly seeking to send a message to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council and state leaders in Albany. 
 He wants City Hall to help ward off a $120 million shortfall with an increase in spending, and the Legislature to end its stalemate over education spending.
In a memorandum, Mr. Levy told the 40 superintendents -- the chief administrators of the 32 community school districts, high school superintendents and others -- to make cuts in district administrative staff before making any reductions in instructional or support services to students. 
He also asked them to look at nonclassroom initiatives like professional development to ensure that "only the ones proven effective are funded."
Mr. Levy stopped short of spelling out the scope of the cuts he anticipated, saying that would come later.
In Albany, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature are still far apart on a budget agreement. A tentative budget for the Board of Education includes an increase of $200 million, including $50 million in city funds, for a total spending plan of $11.5 billion. 
But board officials said they needed an additional $120 million from the city to keep pace with inflation and other cost increases, and that is why Mr. Levy is ordering the contingency cuts.
City officials said they had offered to address the shortfall. In June, the mayor and the City Council said that they would allot additional money in the fall to the board for school-based programs if the board demonstrated that it was cutting the size of the bureaucracy. 
The size of the central board has been the source of constant disputes between the mayor and the board. In February, Mr. Levy announced a program to reduce the operating expenses of the central board by about $20 million. Later, he hired McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm, to study the central board's structure and recommend changes. In June, he ordered a hiring freeze on administrators at the central offices.
About 3,000 people work in administrative positions for the central board, which could be significantly reduced after the reorganization. 
Aides to Mr. Levy said yesterday that the McKinsey study would be made public soon.
Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles said the mayor was waiting to see the administrative cuts.
"What the board should be doing is thinning and pruning its bureaucracy so that the billions of dollars it receives goes into the classrooms, not into administrative costs," Mr. Coles said. "The real problem at the Board of Education is not so much the amount of money it receives but how it spends the money."
Mr. Levy, in his memorandum, described other factors that would almost certainly cause trouble for the schools, including the absence of a contract for teachers. 
The school system would be required to pay the first $180 million of any raises negotiated under a new contract, said Steven Sanders, the Democratic chairman of the State Assembly's education committee.

HEADLINE: Brazil Hits Record Low On Currency 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Brazil's currency touched a record low yesterday, and some analysts said they did not expect the fall would stop until the country's central bank pushed interest rates even higher than they already are.
 Currencies in other emerging market countries, including Mexico, also dropped as some investors worried about contagion, the problems of one emerging market country spilling over into others. 
 "It is turning out to be a difficult year from Mexico to Argentina," said Arturo C. Porzecanski, chief economist for emerging markets at ABN Amro. "Little by little each engine in the world economy is shutting down," he added. "And these countries are being choked off because they can't export and can't attract capital." 
The problem for Brazil is partly its own making, partly a result of the economic slowdown worldwide and partly fallout from the severe financial problems being experienced by its neighbor, Argentina. All of these have combined to make foreigners less willing to invest there.
In addition, this year's plunge in the value of the real, which is down 20 percent against the dollar, has prompted many Brazilian businesses to hedge against further declines. This has added downward pressure on the currency because hedging requires selling the real now before it falls further.
In trading yesterday, the value of the real fell as much as 3 percent, to 2.545, its lowest since Brazil allowed its currency to trade freely in January 1999. But it rallied in late afternoon trading in New York to 2.4315, up 1.5 percent from Thursday. But traders said there was no change in attitude about the financial outlook. The Mexican peso dropped 0.9 percent, to 9.141 pesos. Argentina's currency is pegged to the dollar so it rose along with the American currency.
The real fell yesterday morning despite the announcement on Thursday that the Brazilian central bank would spend $6 billion in the second half of the year to support the country's currency. The possibility that some of that buying was done yesterday afternoon probably helped the real rebound.
Latin American stock markets also fell yesterday, with Brazil's down 1 percent, Mexico's off 1.5 percent and Argentina's down 0.8 percent.
"The central bank of Brazil will have to increase interest rates more to stabilize the currency," said Jose Luis Daza, head of emerging markets strategy at Deutsche Bank Securities. The country's benchmark interest rate was already increased 1.5 percentage points last month, to 18.25 percent.
But with the economic problems in Argentina becoming worse, Jose M. Barrionuevo, director of emerging markets strategy and economics at BNP Paribas, said that Brazil will have a tough time stabilizing its currency "until you get Argentina out of the way."
He said that Argentina was running out of options and that he now expected the country would face an involuntary restructuring of foreign debt. A voluntary restructuring, which delayed billions of dollars of payments for several years, was done last month.
"Argentina as a country cannot afford the kind of spending the government wants," he said. But there is not much chance of major spending cuts with an economy that has been in a recession for nearly three years and elections coming up in October. The economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, is expected to announce more spending cuts over the weekend.
Both the weakening currency and higher interest rates spell trouble for Brazil. As the real falls in value, it makes Brazil's debt payments abroad increase. But as interest rates are pushed higher, economic growth slows and the cost of Brazil's domestic debt increases.
Mr. Daza of Deutsche Bank Securities said that Brazil's current account deficit is expected to rise to $27.5 billion this year, from $24.5 billion in 2000. But direct foreign investment, which totaled about $30 billion in 1999 and 2000, is projected to fall to about half that this year. This shortfall worries investors because it makes meeting debt payments riskier.
Merrill Lynch advised investors yesterday that they were reducing their exposure to Argentine debt to underweight and to Brazilian debt to neutral.
"After our trip to Buenos Aires," the report said, "our main impression is that the risks of a spiraling of the crisis in Argentina have increased."

HEADLINE: News of New Military Work Is Welcomed in South Jersey 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: PEMBERTON, N.J., July 6 

 BODY:
Like other mayors, Thalia C. Kay worries about zoning and recycling and sprawl. But today she was also busy calculating the construction schedule for the C-17 Globemaster, the Air Force's newest transport.
 Pemberton and its neighbors, places like Wrightstown and New Hanover, are military towns where the local base dominates the economy and consciousness. And the news this week that the Air Force plans to spend $40 million at McGuire Air Force Base on new hangars for C-17's a year or two earlier than expected was not just of interest to local contractors who might get a piece of the project. It spoke to the health of the giant base that keeps towns around here alive. 
 "Without McGuire we would have tumbleweed rolling down Main Street," Mayor Kay said. "We would just wither on the vine and die."
The new construction at McGuire was announced on Thursday by Representative Jim Saxton. Additional word came from his office today that $12 million had been put in next year's defense budget to improve officers' barracks at Fort Dix, the Army base adjacent to McGuire. 
The back-to-back announcements reminded people around here that New Jersey is a center for military installations, and that South Jersey is particularly tuned in to the rhythm of base-funding politics in Washington. The announcements came at a time when the secretary of defense, Donald H. Rumsfeld, has declared that the military has more bases than it needs, and that he will send a new round of base-closing proposals to Congress by the end of the year.
McGuire fought one such round of cuts in 1993, when its air transport facilities were scheduled to be moved to Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York. 
"I had heard it was all done; they had even printed the new letterheads for Plattsburgh," Ms. Kay said. "It would have had a horrific impact on us." Instead, Plattsburgh was closed, and McGuire became busier than ever.
Much of the new money will be spent on local contractors, adding to the $558 million a year that Air Force accountants believe is already being pumped into the local economy each year by McGuire alone.
"The military traditions here make South Jersey almost a different world from the north," said Jeff Sagnip Hollendonner, a spokesman for Mr. Saxton. "New Jersey has the biggest military facilities in the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast region."
About 15,000 people work at McGuire, said Lt. Olivia Duer, spokeswoman for the base. With about 3,000 people at Fort Dix and another 3,000 at the Lakehurst Naval Air Engineering Station, Mr. Hollendonner said, the military is by far the largest employer in South Jersey after Atlantic City, which has 55,000 casino and hotel workers.
The C-17 Globemasters will replace the Air Force's veteran C-141 Starlifters as the workhorses for McGuire's mission to provide a jumping-off place for materiel and personnel headed overseas. The base was a hive of activity during the Persian Gulf war, and it has become the springboard for rescue flights to earthquake victims in South America and flood victims in Haiti.
"When the world dials 911, McGuire answers," Mayor Kay said.
In all, 13 Globemasters are to be assigned to McGuire, with the last scheduled to arrive in 2004. A 14th will be sent to Oklahoma to be used in training, and will arrive at McGuire sometime later, Mr. Hollendonner said.

HEADLINE: BROAD JOB LOSSES LAST MONTH SHOW SLUMP IS LINGERING 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The nation's employers cut 114,000 jobs in June, mostly in manufacturing but in other sectors as well, the Labor Department said yesterday, throwing cold water on recent reports suggesting that the economy was beginning to recover.
 Beyond manufacturing, the weak economy finally took its toll on the dynamic service sector, the great source of new jobs in the 1990's. Employment in the sector fell in June and for the second quarter as a whole -- the first quarterly decline since 1958. The unemployment rate ticked up to 4.5 percent in June from 4.4 percent in May, but would have been even higher if so many people had not left the labor force in the spring, declining even to look for work. 
 "You cannot spin this report to make it sound positive; there is nothing positive about it," said William Dudley, director of domestic economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "You have to look at other information to be optimistic. This report is very weak." 
Stock prices plunged in response to the employment numbers and to new reports of weak corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 2.17 percent and Nasdaq by 3.65 percent. Page B1. 
Still, for all the gloom in the June employment report, which is the first broad assessment of the national economy last month, some forecasters insisted on optimism. They focused their attention not on the job numbers, but on hints that the yearlong slowdown may finally be ending. Auto sales, consumer spending in general, home construction, a slight pickup in factory orders, falling energy prices -- all suggest to them that the economy is beginning to rebound, and by late summer or early fall job loss will turn to job creation.
"The darkest hour is just before the dawn," said Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis, "and we are hoping that we are at the darkest hour. There are reasons to expect a rebound."
Like many economists, Mr. Varvares is counting on stimulus from the Federal Reserve's six interest rate cuts this year and from the Bush administration's tax cuts, which authorize the mailing of millions of rebate checks this summer and fall. Sounding a hopeful note, Labor Secretary Elaine Chao declared in a statement that "the stable economy is poised to take off" once the checks begin to go out and, presumably, are spent.
Whatever happens next, the present is bleak for the nation's workers.
But there were a few gains in June. Retailers, for example, added 18,000 jobs. Construction jobs have been rising at a fairly healthy average of more than 15,000 a month this year -- despite a slight drop in June -- reflecting the strength in home building. While the federal government cut 6,000 jobs in June, once again shrinking its employment, local and state governments once again added jobs -- a total of 30,000, mainly in education.
For the private sector alone, excluding government, the job loss in the second quarter was greater than in any single quarter since the last recession, in 1990-91.
Manufacturers, deep in recession, eliminated 113,000 jobs last month. Over the last year, more than 4 percent of the nation's manufacturing jobs have disappeared, reducing the total to 17.8 million. The June losses came mostly among makers of computers, semiconductors and machinery. But they were not alone. "In manufacturing, there were losses all over the place," said Thomas Nardone, chief of the division that compiles the monthly employment numbers at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The manufacturing hardship spread last month to wholesalers, who store and resell manufactured goods, and to the transportation sector, which includes the truck drivers who distribute merchandise. The two sectors lost 27,000 jobs. "These had been growing industries," Mr. Nardone said, "and now you not only have the losses, but you are not getting the growth they had contributed to the economy."
The vast service sector is also making this shift. These are the 41.05 million people, out of a work force of 132.38 million in June, who work at hotels, are employed by temporary help agencies, barber shops, beauty salons and cleaning establishments, who repair and service cars, work at hospitals and doctors' offices, day care centers and old age homes, and provide all sorts of other business services.
Their numbers had grown quarter after quarter and year after year since the second quarter of 1958, and then in the second quarter of this year, there was the first slight drop -- 21,000 jobs, including 6,000 in June -- after so many years of growth. These service workers accounted for most of the work force expansion through the boom years of the late 1990's. While the loss came mostly among temporary workers, whose numbers have been shrinking for months, there was no longer enough growth elsewhere to offset this loss.
The cutback in temporary workers has occurred mostly among those sent to factory jobs, said Jeffrey Joerres, chief executive of Manpower Inc., "but the proportion losing jobs in call centers, banks and brokerage firms is rising." 
The shrinking job numbers, all seasonally adjusted, show up clearly in the monthly averages. In the first nine months of last year, employment in the private sector grew at an average of 167,000 jobs a month and then at a rate of 80,000 a month for the next six months, through March. Job growth then turned to job loss. Over the last three months, jobs disappeared at a rate of 117,000 a month on average.
Such rapid declines should be pushing the unemployment rate to nearly 5 percent, some economists say -- and there were sharp increases in black and Hispanic unemployment. What prevents the overall number from rising more is the steady exodus from the labor force, which has declined to 141.4 million people working or seeking work in June from 142 million in January. Those leaving are mostly men and women who either left or lost jobs and decided against hunting for new work. Only those who actively seek work are counted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics as unemployed. 
"This odd contraction of the labor force has kept the unemployment rate flat at around 4.5 percent for the last three months," said James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "It understates true unemployment."
Average hourly earnings for production workers, totaling more than 75 million people, rose a mild 4 cents in June, to $14.29. The average had risen by the same amount in May and also in April, suggesting that employers are under no pressure from rising wages to raise prices. While employment fell in the second quarter, so did an index of hours worked for those with jobs, after two months of remaining flat.
The combination of a shrinking labor force in the second quarter and fewer hours suggested to some economists that economic growth may be close to zero in the just-ended quarter. 
"What is happening is this," Mr. Dudley of Goldman said. "The profit squeeze is intense and business is reacting by trying to shed workers to control cost. And now the question is what is the consequences for consumer confidence and spending. So far they are holding up well, but we are not out of the woods."

HEADLINE: Among Nuptial Agreements, Post- Has Now Joined Pre- 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Not so long ago, prenuptial agreements raised eyebrows. What hope was there for a marriage, the thinking went, if even before the wedding the couple were specifying who gets what in case of divorce? 
 But these days what raises eyebrows, and a host of new practical and legal uncertainties, is the postnuptial agreement. 
 Increasingly, couples already married are asking their lawyers to draft agreements dividing their property, and setting forth their obligations to each other in case of divorce. 
Most commonly, the desire for a postnuptial agreement arises when one spouse comes into an inheritance or starts a business, or when there are children from a previous marriage to provide for. 
"It can be hard to tell whether postnups are a step toward divorce or not," said Carol Sanger, who teaches family law at Columbia Law School. "In some cases, it may be 'We'll get a postnup and live happily ever after.' But I think it's often 'Let's get a postnup, wink, wink, so I can get everything locked down.'
"Legally it's a little like a prenup, but the stakes are higher, since the parties are already married. And it's a little like a divorce settlement agreement, but that's more clearly adversarial. It's really an uncharted area, and all the states are trying to figure it out now." 
For centuries, husbands and wives could not enter into contracts with each other, because they were seen as one legal unit. Indeed, in many common-law nations, like Britain, Canada and Australia, intramarital contracts are still not allowed, said Thomas Oldham of the University of Houston Law School. But in the United States, with its high divorce rate, that doctrine fell by the wayside long ago.
It is impossible to know how many couples are signing postnuptial agreements, since they are drafted by private lawyers and usually not reviewed by the courts unless they are challenged. But lawyers who specialize in family and matrimonial law say the demand has been growing. And in most states, the general trend is toward recognizing and enforcing postnuptial agreements, as long as they are fair and were made voluntarily and after full disclosure of all assets. 
But ensuring fairness can be difficult. While it is possible that a postnup will equalize a marriage, that is not usually how it works out, Mr. Oldham said. 
"If you look at the agreements, they're almost always to increase the rights of the wealthier partner and decrease the rights of the less wealthy one," he said. "The equalization idea is largely a feminist fantasy. Often these agreements have some element of duress. If the marriage is in trouble, if one partner is threatening divorce, is that a fair agreement? Or if a couple is reconciling after some problems, and one partner is crazy and generous and says, 'To show how much I love you, I'll give you everything if we divorce,' should that be binding?" 
A case decided by a New Jersey appeals court in 1999 demonstrates that what may seem fair at the time an agreement is drafted may no longer seem so years later, when the agreement is to be enforced.
Antonio Pacelli married in 1975, when he was a 44-year-old builder. His bride, Francesca, was 20 and had come to the United States from Italy when she was 14. In 1985, the opinion said, Mr. Pacelli told his wife that he would divorce her unless she signed a postnuptial agreement giving her $500,000 and half their vacation home in the event of a future divorce. At the same time, he moved out of the house they shared with their two sons and into an apartment above their garage. 
Mrs. Pacelli was determined to preserve the marriage and, against her lawyer's advice, signed the document. But in 1994, by which time Mr. Pacelli's net worth had grown to more than $11 million, he filed for divorce. Mrs. Pacelli then contested the agreement. 
The trial court said the agreement was enforceable, but on appeal the Appellate Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey disagreed. To be valid, the court said, postnuptial agreements must be fair not only when they are signed but also when they are put into effect, and under this agreement Mrs. Pacelli would have gotten a far smaller share of the family assets than a divorce court judgment would have provided. 
"The close scrutiny and careful evaluation of midmarriage agreements also requires consideration of the agreement's impact when enforced," the decision said. "It may be inequitable to preclude her participation in postagreement wealth."
Some legal experts say the increasing popularity of postnuptial agreements springs from the growing likelihood that both spouses will have financial lives.
"It's part of the whole change of women being on a more equal economic plane than we used to be within marriage," said Battle Robinson, a former family court judge in Delaware. "Many husbands and wives are running their own businesses and managing their finances." 
And while many people find it distasteful even to consider drafting a formal contract with a spouse, others believe that postnuptial agreements can help to clarify issues in a marriage. At least that is the case made by equalityinmarriage.com, a nonprofit organization that offers advice on marriage-related issues. 
"If you didn't prepare a marriage contract before you wed, you can do it after you are married, perhaps in connection with a reaffirmation of vows ceremony," the organization's Web site says. "As with a prenuptial contract, one written now will help the two of you clarify how you feel about equality in marriage and enrich your communication." 
Lawyers also say a postnup -- sometimes known as a midnuptial or a midmarriage agreement -- can simply be a matter of sensible financial planning, not a signal of marital problems. 
"I had a call about getting a postnup recently, from a lawyer who has been sued for malpractice and knows that in Texas his wife's business can be subject to a judgment against him," said Mr. Oldham, the family-law specialist at the University of Houston. "He's interested in a postnup to protect his wife's assets, not because the marriage is in trouble. A lot of the time, the idea of a postnup comes up when someone comes into some money and thinks, 'I guess I'm rich, so what am I going to do in these circumstances?' "
There is ample opportunity for other uses. At least in theory, postnuptial agreements can provide a mechanism for couples to formalize not only their financial arrangements but also their division of household-chore responsibilities like cooking or paying the bills. Barbara Ellen Handschu, a family lawyer in Buffalo, described a couple who put together an agreement setting forth how much vacation they would take each year. 
When prenups were introduced in the 1970's, they were initially met with skepticism, followed by gradual acceptance. Postnups seem to be following a similar course, and a few states have already said explicitly that they should be evaluated for fairness under the same standards as prenups. But in most states, there is still little law on midmarriage agreements. 
Most family lawyers say postnups are a useful tool to keep up with the complications of tracking marital property in an era of high divorce rates. 
"In the last one I wrote, it was a remarriage for both, each owned a house, and they wanted to be clear about how money would be allocated to their first families," Ms. Handschu said. "When you take property like a house from a first marriage, where there's been appreciation, and the money from it might flow through a joint bank account and be legally commingled, it can be complicated to figure out who owns what. I think it's important, and useful, for people to sit down and talk about the realities of death and dissolution and their earlier obligations, and write down how they want to handle their property." 
Still, she said, not all postnuptial agreements are fair. 
"Right now," she said, "I'm representing a man who was hoping his wife would forgive him for his transgressions, and she said she would only work on the marriage if he'd sign this onerous financial agreement. He signed it, without a lawyer.
"But eight months later he realized she never wanted to work on the marriage, and he can't afford to live under the agreement. So I'm challenging it for him."

HEADLINE: New York Ranks City's Private Foster Home Programs 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
City child welfare officials said yesterday that they had completed an unsparing performance evaluation of all private foster home programs and vowed to send fewer children to the worst performing ones.
 The officials said their pledge to shrink the number of children placed with the most problematic of the 40 agencies could effectively force some out of the business of providing foster homes. 
 The evaluations, which included measuring how quickly children were adopted or reunited with their families, examined the work of agencies from small church-based programs to the oldest and most well-endowed in the city.
"This may be one of the most important things that we've done, to develop this system to hold the agencies accountable," said Nicholas Scoppetta, commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services. 
Some of the results surprised him. For instance, the Children's Aid Society, one of the founding institutions of foster care in the country and the place where Mr. Scoppetta served for years as president and a board member, was among the 10 lowest-rated. He also said there was no discernible correlation between size, financing and performance.
The lowest-scoring of the group, Miracle Makers, has had one of the largest and most rapidly growing programs since it was established in 1986 by a state grant aimed at creating minority-run agencies in neighborhoods with the greatest need. 
Mr. Scoppetta stopped short of ending the city's contracts with any of the agencies, which provide foster homes for more 23,000 children in the city's care. Instead, the poorest-performing have until December to show marked improvement, he said.
The city has not completed the evaluation of its own foster home program, he said, but he acknowledged that it does not perform well. A separate evaluation of group care by the agencies is under way. 
The evaluation methodology, years in the making, is a crucial ingredient in Mr. Scoppetta's ambitious plan to reconfigure all foster care services along neighborhood lines, and to extend his overhaul of the child welfare bureaucracy to the system's children and families. It involved the random sampling of case records, interviews with foster parents and computerized comparisons of outcomes like a child's re-entry into foster care.
In recent years, the city has had little control over how many children went to each agency, and its evaluations have largely been limited to a few elements. The last comparable effort to measure foster care agency performance peaked in 1984, when the city's foster care population declined to 16,230. But accountability measures were watered down, then abandoned, under the pressures of city politics, economic downturns, and the ballooning of the foster care population, to a peak of 49,100 in 1991.
Now, with the foster care population down to about 31,000 and still shrinking, Mr. Scoppetta said, agencies have accepted the idea that the worst performers will lose slots for children. 
"This system is measuring the performance of each of these agencies against systemwide performance -- against the performance of their colleagues," he said, "so for the most part they are all laboring under the same conditions, instead of against some hypothetical absolute."
Still, the details that make up each overall score reveal wide variations. Children's Village, a large agency based in Westchester County and known mainly for its institutional care, received the top grade of 88 for its small, recent foster home program for 100 children in the Bronx, but was not evaluated on adoptions or re-entry into foster care, the categories that were the undoing of several low ranked agencies.
The Council of Family and Child Caring Agencies, the umbrella group for most of the foster care agencies, said that it welcomed the evaluations, but that many of the agency shortcomings reflected inadequate state financing that had led to a 40 percent staff turnover rate. Mr. Scoppetta is lobbying the state for higher foster care rates, which can range from $16 a day per child for one agency to $30 a day for another under a complicated rate calculation.
But money does not account for performance, according to the evaluations. For example, Angel Guardian, a large Brooklyn agency with one of the lower daily rates -- $20.31 -- was one of the top performers, earning more than 87 out of a possible 100 points, compared with under 67 for Children's Aid, which receives a rate of $25.48. 
"We think our score should be higher than it is," said Jane Golden, director of programs for Children's Aid, which has a wide range of other highly regarded services for children not examined by the city. "But it's good that the city is doing this, and we're taking it very seriously."
Willie Wren, executive director of Miracle Makers, which also offers day care, housing and mental health programs, said he had confidence that Mr. Scoppetta would help the agency improve enough to keep providing foster care. Mr. Wren attributed the agency's problems to the 200 cases it inherited two years ago from an agency the city shut down, including foster homes not visited in five years and caseworkers who had sabotaged records in a labor dispute.
The lowest rated agencies face reductions of 10 percent to 30 percent of their current populations, cuts which Mr. Scoppetta said could come through attrition, as the city stops sending them new children, but which may require transferring some children, along with their foster parents, to the better agencies.
Mr. Scoppetta said he was urging many of the lower ranked agencies to develop or expand the other services that are necessary to keep children in their own homes safely, from literacy programs to homemaking services and "all of the things that help families stay together."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Stocks Fall on Warnings by Key Technology Companies

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday as profit warnings from technology companies, accompanied by a weak employment report, undermined investors' confidence that the economy would be recovering by the end of the year. 
 "The bell went off for people today to realize that here we are; we're in the third quarter, and any good news from this part of the economy is not going to be forthcoming," said Jonathan K. Simon, a managing director of J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management, referring to the technology sector. 
 The Nasdaq composite index declined 75.95 points, or 3.7 percent, to 2,004.16, as technology stocks lost what little ground they had gained last week, when the second quarter ended. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index closed the week with a loss of more than 7 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 227.18 points, or 2.2 percent, to close at 10,252.68, bringing its loss for the week to 2.4 percent. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 28.65 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,190.59, for a weekly loss of 2.8 percent. 
EMC and Advanced Micro Devices helped set the stage for yesterday's selling, with each company warning of weaker-than-expected earnings. "The surprise was that it came rather late in the earnings warning season," said Peter I. Cardillo, chief strategist for Westfalia Investments, though other analysts cited the magnitude of the earnings shortfalls.
Shares of EMC, which makes data storage equipment for corporate computer systems, fell $8.43, to $21.60, after it said late on Thursday that it expected earnings of 4 to 6 cents a share instead of the 17 cents a share that analysts had projected.
Many of EMC's rivals took steep losses, including Brocade Communications, which declined $8.88, to $31.89, and Emulex, which dropped $6.76, to $29.06. I.B.M., which also makes storage systems, plunged $5.60, to $106.50, weighing heavily on the Dow.
Advanced Micro Devices, meanwhile, decreased $7.84, to $20.80, after the semiconductor maker projected a 17 percent drop in sales and warned profits would miss Wall Street forecasts.
Its competitors fell, too. Applied Micro Circuits dropped $1.26, to $14.55, while Cypress Semiconductor decreased $1.50, to $21.78. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index dropped 53.19 points, or 8.6 percent, to 566.51. The losses spread across the technology sector, cutting Microsoft by $2.45, to $66.06, and Oracle by 72 cents, to $18.21.
If investors needed a reason to punish the old economy stocks as well, Alcoa provided it, taking charges for idling plants in the Northwest because of high power costs and reporting that earnings fell 16 percent. Without the charges, Alcoa's profits beat Wall Street's estimates, but the stock fell 98 cents, to $39.80.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the unemployment rate rose to 4.5 percent in June from 4.4 percent in May.
"The crux of that is what it does to consumer expectations and consumer spending," said Clifford W. Henry, a partner in Worthington Growth L.P., a hedge fund manager. While sales of new homes and automobiles have been strong, people have been reluctant to buy luxury goods like new clothing, he said, and "the key to this market is going to be what happens in the back-to-school. The burden of proof is on the bulls right now."
Despite the six cuts the Federal Reserve has made to short-term interest rates this year, yields on longer-term Treasury securities remain relatively high. 
Treasury prices moved higher yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note rose 13/32, to a price of 97 10/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.36 percent from 5.42 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed 11/32, to 94 31/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.73 percent from 5.76 percent on Thursday.
In the six months that have passed since the Federal Reserve began cutting short-term interest rates, the long-term interest rates that most consumers encounter in their mortgages and vehicle loans have not fallen much. And the Labor Department's report increased the chances of more short-term interest rate cuts, which in turn would raise the chances of higher inflation.
Bond investors, then, are left with conflicting worries. Inflation could erode their long-term yields, but if some part of the economy does not improve soon, a drop in the government's future tax receipts could cause the issuance of more bonds, diluting the market.
