HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Unemployment Up to 4.5% As 114,000 Jobs Are Cut
Employment fell in June and for the second quarter as a whole -- the first quarterly decline since 1958. The jobless rate ticked up to 4.5 percent from 4.4 percent in May, the Labor Department said, but would be even higher if so many people had not left the labor force in the spring, declining even to look for work.
 Employers cut 114,000 jobs in June, mostly in manufacturing, throwing cold water on recent reports suggesting that the economy was beginning to recover. Page A1. 

Mellon in Talks to Sell Retail Assets
Mellon Financial is in negotiations to sell its $14 billion in consumer banking deposits to the Citizens Financial Group, a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland, according to an executive close to the talks. Mellon could receive close to $3 billion from the sale. C2.

Coke May Still Face Bias Lawsuits
Despite reaching the largest settlement ever in a racial bias case, Coca-Cola will continue to face lawsuits from current and former black employees, a Florida law firm representing some of the workers said. C3.

Reliant Profits in California Surge
Reliant Energy, one of the electricity generators California officials have accused of overcharging, said its profits from the state rose more than fourfold last year but that it made less money per megawatt hour than some past periods. The disclosure, made in a filing with securities regulators, comes as Reliant and other generators attempt to fend off efforts by California to collect what officials say are $8.9 billion in overcharges. C2.

Swiss Group Expands to Europe
Martin Ebner, the financier whose stakes in Swiss companies have often led to corporate shake-ups, said that his company, BZ Group Holding, was reaching outside Switzerland to buy shares in European banks, including HypoVereinsbank of Germany. C2.

Calpine and PG&E Unit Reach Pact
Calpine said it reached an agreement with the Pacific Gas and Electric unit of PG&E to preserve power-supply contracts between the companies and resolve past-due bills. Under the agreement filed in bankruptcy court in San Francisco, Pacific Gas will pay the more than $267 million that it owes Calpine, the energy supplier based in San Jose, Calif. C3.

Marconi Chief Resigns Abruptly
Marconi, the biggest telephone equipment maker in Britain, ended a bruising week by announcing that John Mayo, who was scheduled to take over as chief executive next month, had resigned immediately. In a statement, Mr. Mayo gave no reason for his departure. He was to have succeeded George Simpson in a succession plan announced last year. Mr. Simpson and Marconi's chairman, Sir Roger Hurn, will remain in their posts. C2.

W.T.O. Rejects Europe's Challenge
The World Trade Organization in Geneva has rejected the European Union's challenge to an American law barring registration of confiscated trademarks. At issue was the 1998 American law intended to protect Bacardi's rights to the Havana Club rum label, which Bacardi had acquired from the owners who fled Cuba after the 1959 revolution. The law was challenged by Pernod-Ricard of France, which had started manufacturing Havana Club rum. C2.

Hitachi to Halt Production at Plant
Hitachi of Japan announced that it was halting production at a new plant that produces chips for cellular phones, the latest sign of the global squeeze in the semiconductor industry. C2.

Sony to Take Charge for Recall
Sony plans to take a charge of 12 billion yen, or $95 million, in its first quarter to pay for the recall of 1.1 million cellular phones. C2.

Senate May Be Final Stop For Nuclear Test Ban Pact
President Bush, who has long opposed the still-unratified Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, has resolved to let it languish permanently in the Senate, administration officials said. Supporters of the treaty concede they do not have the votes to revive it. A1

The new cease-fire between the Macedonian government and ethnic Albanian rebels may do little to overcome the chasm of anger and distrust between the two major ethnic groups in Macedonia: the majority Slavic Macedonians and the ethnic Albanians who make up one third of the population. A3

Supranational Sensation
At a time when fields like English, history and philosophy need a major new theory, scholars are wondering if the latest contender for academia's next master theorist is Michael Hardt, a self-effacing, 41-year-old associate professor of literature at Duke University and the co-author of "Empire," a heady treatise on globalization and the creation of "supranational organisms" that is sending frissons of excitement through campuses from Sao Paolo to Tokyo. Former F.B.I. Agent Pleads Guilty to Spying
Robert P. Hanssen admitted he had spied for Moscow since 1985 and had handed over many of the nation's most sensitive secrets. As part of the plea agreement, Mr. Hanssen, 57, will be sentenced to life without parole. The plea resolves a bizarre espionage case that shook the bureau and increased tensions between the United States and Russia. A1

Postnups Always Ring Twice
More and more married couples are asking their lawyers to draft postnuptial agreements that divide their property and set forth their obligations to each other in case of divorce. "Legally it's a little like a prenup, but the stakes are higher, since the parties are already married," a family law expert said of the postnups. "It's really an uncharted area, and all the states are trying to figure it out now." A1

Feather Collection Scrutinized
The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is investigating whether the private collection of Amazonian artifacts owned by Lawrence M. Small, the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, contains feathers and other items taken from endangered species, a service official said. A6

Robbers' Drug of Choice
There have been 14 robberies of pharmacies in Boston and its suburbs in the last six weeks in which the robbers have ignored cash registers and other drugs and taken only OxyContin, which gives a heroinlike high without the needles or the stigma. They are part of a surge in OxyContin robberies and thefts at drugstores across the nation. A6

Lyme Disease Study
A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine says that most people who believe they have chronic Lyme disease actually do not have the disease. And the antibiotics they are taking, the study says, are no more helpful than a placebo and carry substantial health risks. B1

BUSINESS DAY C1-14

Cold Shower for Economy
The nation's employers cut 114,000 jobs in June, mostly in manufacturing, the Labor Department said, throwing cold water on reports suggesting the economy was starting to recover. The unemployment rate was 4.5 percent. A1

Stocks fell sharply as profit warnings from technology companies, accompanied by the weak employment report, undermined investors' confidence that the economy would be recovering by the end of the year. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index closed the week with a loss of more than 7 percent. C1

PERSON: Stephen Ailes 

HEADLINE: Stephen Ailes Is Dead at 89; Former Secretary of Army 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Stephen Ailes, a retired antitrust lawyer and government official who served as civilian head of the Army during the early buildup of American forces in South Vietnam, died on June 30 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 89.
 Mr. Ailes (pronounced ales) retired in 1985 from the large Washington law firm of Steptoe & Johnson, where he worked primarily as a litigator in the antitrust field. He joined the firm in 1946 but took occasional leaves of absence for government service. 
 He did so first in 1947 for a brief stint as counsel to the American Economic Mission to Greece. The next leave, as a member of the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, lasted nearly five years.
In 1961, President John F. Kennedy named him the under secretary of the Army. President Lyndon B. Johnson promoted him to secretary in 1964 when the administration began to commit combat troops to Southeast Asia. 
Mr. Ailes resigned the next year to return to practicing law. His son Richard said that it was not a protest on his father's part but that a few years later "he had real concerns about the Vietnam conflict."
Mr. Ailes took another leave in 1972 to serve as president of the Association of American Railroads; he served until 1977. He was also a member of the Panama Canal Company's board from 1961 to 1971.
In the Ford administration, Mr. Ailes joined the president's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board and the Intelligence Oversight Board. He was an author of the charter for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and, in the 1970's, served as a trustee of the Washington educational outlets WETA-TV and WETA-FM.
He was a past chairman of the George C. Marshall Foundation and vice chairman of the Athletic Council of the United States. He was a trustee emeritus of Princeton University.
For many years, he sat on the board of the Accokeek Foundation, which was formed in 1957 to preserve the land across the Potomac River from George Washington's home, Mount Vernon. The foundation operates the National Colonial Farm in Accokeek, Md. Mr. Ailes played a pivotal role in establishing the site as an "ecosystem farm," land cultivated without chemicals, as it was in colonial times. He helped in the foundation's strategic planning and financial affairs.
Stephen Ailes was born in Romney, W.Va., and graduated from Princeton in 1933 and from the West Virginia University College of Law in 1936. He taught at the college, but at the outset of World War II he moved to Washington and worked on the legal staff of the Office of Price Administration.
In addition to his son Richard, of Bethesda, Mr. Ailes is survived by a daughter, Hester A. Abbuhl of McCormick, S.C.; two other sons, Stephen, of Martinsburg, W.Va., and Walter, of Bethesda; a sister, Edna J. Sprague of Albuquerque; five grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 10, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Saturday about Stephen Ailes, a retired antitrust lawyer and former secretary of the Army, misstated the name of an organization of which he was vice chairman. It is the Atlantic Council of the United States, not Athletic Council.

PERSON: Alex Padilla 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Quick Climb Up the Los Angeles Political Ladder

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
ALEX PADILLA grew up poor in Pacoima, which was pretty much the norm in that distressed section of the San Fernando Valley.
 But the young man, who can still vividly recount late-night excursions with his father to scavenge for recyclables, broke early on with what might be considered normal in that community. He went to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, returned home to work as an engineer for Hughes Aircraft, got interested in politics, ran a few successful campaigns for Democratic friends and then stepped into the political arena himself. 
 Two years ago, he was elected to the Los Angeles City Council and on Tuesday, at the age of 28, he defeated the veteran Council member Ruth Galanter to become the youngest president of the City Council and the first Hispanic in more than 100 years to hold the post. 
Mr. Padilla takes over as a whirlwind of change sweeps City Hall. In June, James K. Hahn, the city attorney, was elected mayor to replace Richard J. Riordan, who reached his two-term limit. There is a new city charter, several new city officials and the 1993 limit of two terms for elected officials that is just beginning to be felt.
"My vision is to couple all the positive energy we feel with the change," Mr. Padilla said, sitting in his office on the fourth floor of City Hall.
The son of a short-order cook and a house cleaner who immigrated from Mexico 33 years ago, Mr. Padilla played Little League baseball to stay out of trouble as a boy and got an early acquaintance with volunteer work thanks to his mother.
"Saturday mornings when most kids were asleep or watching cartoons, I'd wake up to a voice saying, 'Sure, come pick him up,' " he said.
He was recruited to M.I.T., where he received a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering. But he never really left Pacoima behind. After finishing college, Mr. Padilla, who is single, returned, living with his family until buying a house two blocks away from his parents six months ago.
His older sister lives within two miles; his younger brother has a year left at California State University at Hayward, south of Oakland.
After returning to Pacoima, one of the most distressed sections of Los Angeles, Mr. Padilla went to work as a software programmer at Hughes. His entree into politics came when he was 22 and ran a successful State Assembly campaign for Tony Cardenas. Mr. Padilla then managed the State Senate campaign of Richard Alarcon, who won by a mere 29 votes. But as he was managing those campaigns, he was also laying the groundwork to become a politician himself, attending three leadership programs, one of which led to a job in the Los Angeles field office of Senator Dianne Feinstein.
Mr. Padilla, supported by Mayor Riordan, won his first election in June 1999, running in the special election to fill the vacancy created when Mr. Alarcon moved to the State Senate. He was re-elected to a full term this year and, despite his Hispanic roots, he supported Mr. Hahn rather than the mayoral hopeful Antonio Villaraigosa, a popular Latino candidate.
Mr. Padilla said he decided to run for the City Council position, which was created by the death of John Ferraro, who was Council president for 18 years, because he believed he could serve as a bridge between old and new Council members and bring a fresh vision to the job. "I had been able to work with members of the Council that have been here 20 or 30 years," Mr. Padilla said. "To be the one point of continuity and provide stability through this transition is something I see as an enormous responsibility and possibility."
Ms. Galanter, who has served 14 years on the Council and was the acting president after Mr. Ferraro's death, promoted her candidacy based on her experience and knowledge of City Hall.
Mr. Padilla said he would work to make the Council less fractious and contentious. Rather than having "15 fiefdoms where each Council member only takes care of their district," he said he would encourage members to work for the interests of the entire city.
In winning the seat, he received the support of five of the six new Council members and four veterans.
"He's got a maturity that defies his age," said Councilwoman Cindy Miscikowski, who considered a run at the Council presidency but supported Mr. Padilla when she was unable to secure the eight votes necessary to win. "There's sort of a grace, dignity and elegance about him that is something you'd expect from someone who has diplomatic experience."
BUT Ms. Miscikowski said she was most impressed by what he had been able to accomplish for his district since taking office.
In two years, he has made strides ranging from cosmetic to economic. Some of the improvements involve simply filling potholes and planting trees, but others include helping make his district home to a new children's museum, a $10 million sports academy for low-income children, a new library and new industrial development.
"I've been in my house 49 years," said Isaac Arias, 77, of Pacoima. "Until now nothing ever changed. He's the only person who knows the problems we have right here."

HEADLINE: Lord of the Fliers 

BYLINE:  By Christopher Buckley; Christopher Buckley is the editor of Forbes FYI and the author of eight books. His new novel, "Trial of the Millennium," will be published next year.

 BODY:
 UP IN THE AIR
By Walter Kirn.
303 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $23.95.
 IF Walter Kirn is anything like the protagonist of his new novel, he may be the first author thrilled to be embarking on a 30-city book tour. Not for the attention -- for the miles. Quest novels usually have as their object a chalice once used at a famous supper, a sleeping fairy princess, a rusty key to a chest, a New World, a ring, the perfect martini, whatever. "Up in the Air" is the first -- and will surely remain the best -- novel about one man's quest to accumulate one million frequent flier miles. If this sounds like the dullest quest in Christendom, set your worries at ease, sit back in your seat, rip open the little bag of pretzels and relax. You are about to embark on a truly wild ride.
Your seatmate, as you crisscross Western America, will be Ryan Bingham, 35, a career transition counselor at a Denver-based management consulting company. That is to say, he flies around the country firing people. Find a niche and empty it, you might say. He's a tragicomic fusion out of Martin Amis, Nicholson Baker and Jay McInerney on a good day. But that's no way to put it. Walter Kirn, not those others, came up with Ryan Bingham and he can take a deep bow. For all his problems, and does he ever have those, Ryan is as original and cool a character to come along in American fiction in a while. Into the bargain, Kirn is such a sharp writer he gives your brain paper cuts. Never have I so happily bled to death.
The plot: Ryan is trying desperately to get to one million before he leaves or is fired from his employer -- Integrated Strategic Management, or ISM. He is divorced, which seems to be the norm these days for your basic alienated protagonist. His younger, psychologically disturbed sister is about to embark on yet another disastrous relationship. Ryan is angling to be hired by MythTech, a shadowy company in Omaha that turns out -- no, I cannot give it away. (Kirn does provide a corker ending.) Ryan takes a lot of pills and connects with women and has boogie nights with them in Las Vegas -- very boogie nights. Meanwhile, sitting in the back row of the airport chapel in Reno, he is convinced that someone is having him paged. Worse, someone may be furtively cashing in his precious miles. This prospect chills Ryan more than liquid nitrogen. It is tantamount to stealing his soul.
Ryan is one of those business guys you see at O'Hare or LAX, speaking into detached cell phone mikes as they pass by you on the moving sidewalk like figures on wheels to their connection at Gate 84. The world they (and we) inhabit is an American geography reconfigured into a series of -- fittingly enough, as the great vast West was colonized by rolling wagons on spoked wheels -- airline hubs. Finally, someone has come up with a name for it. "I call it Airworld; the scene, the place, the style," Ryan says. "My hometown papers are USA Today and The Wall Street Journal. The big-screen Panasonics in the club rooms broadcast all the news I need, with an emphasis on the markets and the weather. My literature -- yours, too, I see -- is the best seller or the near-best seller, heavy on themes of espionage, high finance and the goodness of common people in small towns. In Airworld, I've found, the passions and enthusiasms of the outlying society are concentrated and whisked to a stiff froth. When a new celebrity is minted in the movie theaters or ballparks, this is where the story breaks -- on the vast magazine racks that form a sort of trading floor for public reputations and pretty faces. I find it possible here, as nowhere else, to think of myself as part of the collective that prices the long bond and governs necktie widths. Airworld is a nation within a nation, with its own language, architecture, mood and even its own currency -- the token economy of airline bonus miles that I've come to value more than dollars. Inflation doesn't degrade them. They're not taxed. They're private property in its purest form." 
It's a place we're familiar with, even if we didn't know what it was called until now, where e-mail and voice mail are the communication norm, of Palm Pilots and rental cars, salted almonds and nameless suite hotels -- you've got mail, J. Alfred Prufrock! -- white noise machines, Kevlar luggage, and where you spend so much time that you know the flight attendants by name.
No, it's all right. It's fine. "Planes and airports are where I feel at home. Everything fellows like you" -- remember that Ryan is sitting next to you -- dislike about them -- the dry recycled air alive with viruses; the salty food that seems drizzled with warm mineral oil; the aura-sapping artificial lighting -- has grown familiar to me over the years, familiar, sweet." 
That "you" is key, and I haven't heard the second-person singular used with such effective intimacy since "Bright Lights, Big City." Ryan's voice is also, one gradually begins to gather, the voice of a man who is, well, not well. That's not giving anything away. You would have figured it out soon enough. Suffice it to say this just provides another serrated edge to the story.
Among Ryan's endearing qualities is his philosophizing about everyday devices, marveling at contrivances that we take for granted and investing them with souls of their own. He rhapsodizes about the white-noise-making device he takes with him from hotel to hotel. "Lately, I can't sleep without these gadgets. The one I own now is tuned to 'summer cloudburst' and I can't wait to turn it on tonight." A cup of coffee and he's off and running: "The espresso machine whirrs and burbles at my touch, filling a cup exactly to the brim. The gizmo deserves to be thanked, it works so beautifully. People aren't grateful enough to such devices. Mute valets supply our every need, but instead of pausing in acknowledgment, we jump to the next thing, issue another order. I wonder if some imbalance is building up here, a karmic gap between humans and their tools. Machines will be able to think not long from now, and as the descendants of slaves, they won't be happy." 
He does wonder at some modern amenities: "The side-by-side urinals are filled with ice cubes, a touch I've never had properly explained to me." It's a tribute to Ryan's companionability that you find yourself wanting to explain it to him, if only you knew. To whom did it first occur that men like urinating into ice?
Kirn, who is the author of two previous novels ("She Needed Me," "Thumbsucker") and a collection of stories ("My Hard Bargain"), can get you into a Moment faster than a Zen master. Spotting a famous businessman a few rows away, Ryan muses: "Celebrities always seem slightly lost on planes. Five years ago, I found myself surrounded by a rock band I'd worshiped as a kid. Two of them sat alone in their own rows and two had girls with them. Their trademark hairstyles -- tortured, spiky crests of dull black thatch -- looked overdone in such a neutral setting. The drummer, an alleged hotel room smasher who'd supposedly had his blood replaced at an expensive clinic in Geneva, thumbed a hand-held video game. The singer, the star, sat still and stared ahead as though he'd lost power and was waiting for repairs. His fame seemed to call for a class beyond first, and I couldn't help but think less of him, somehow, for sharing a cabin with the likes of me."
That's an epiphany at 35,000 feet. Here's a vignette from ground level: "I was given a small beige office in the rear of the company's crumbling brick waterfront headquarters and tasked with the care of seven executives who were let go in sequence, one per day, and sent to me before their tears could dry. All were middle-aged men with families, and all but two of them asked me what they'd done wrong, to which I answered, 'Nothing. Blame interest rates. Blame low commodity prices. This problem's global.' One heavyset fellow, a face like a potpie, his suit full of strange custom seams to hide his girth, mistook me for a priest and made me kneel with him while he prayed from a card he carried inside his wallet. Another asked me if I would call his wife and repeat my interest rates remark." 
A novel about a man who lives in a parallel world making his living counseling the downsized could hardly arrive -- land -- at a more apt time, in this season of dot-coma and summer-air-travel hell. But this is a book that will endure beyond its era. Ryan Bingham is our Man in the Casual Friday Suit, and he is sitting next to us. In fact, he may be us.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: (Andy Rash)

HEADLINE: Who Is the Real Adam Smith? 

BYLINE:  By Paul Mattick; Paul Mattick, professor of philosophy at Adelphi University, is the author of "Social Knowledge" and editor of the International Journal of Political Economy.

 BODY:
 ECONOMIC SENTIMENTS
Adam Smith, Condorcet, and the Enlightenment.
By Emma Rothschild.
353 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $45.
 It's hardly an accident that a contemporary investment guru took Adam Smith as his nom de tube. More than just the father of economics, Smith is the totemic ancestor of the free market idea itself, the system that since the fall of Communism in the East and the triumph of fiscal conservatism in the West supposedly rules the world under the name of neoliberalism. And indeed, according to Emma Rothschild, the start of the 21st century shares with the late 18th, Smith's period, "the rhetoric of freedom of commerce" and "the sense of living in a society of universal commerce and universal uncertainty." But where today's economics exalts "cold and rational calculation," Smith -- as Rothschild argues in an attempt to recover his insights for the present day -- saw economics as "intertwined with the life of sentiment and imagination." Director of the Center for History and Economics at King's College, Cambridge, Rothschild wants to bring Smith back as an apostle not of heartless market forces but of capitalism with a human face, as it might have appeared at the dawn of modernity and as, she hints, it might appear again today.
In her readable as well as scholarly book, "Economic Sentiments," she links Smith with the French philosopher the Marquis de Condorcet, another thinker seen today as an emblem of "cold, hard and rational enlightenment" but in reality interested, like Smith, "in economic life as a process of discussion, and as a process of emancipation," in which "one's freedom to buy or sell or lend or travel or work is difficult to distinguish from the rest of one's freedom." This larger picture, Rothschild thinks, is what was lost as economics developed along with the society it analyzed, and what she hopes to restore.
The French Revolution, during which Condorcet died in prison despite -- or because of -- his devotion to democracy, marked a watershed in politico-economic thought: the political restoration of the monarchy in the early 1800's was accompanied by a recasting of laissez-faire economics as the coalition partner of political conservatism. The present moment, Rothschild suggests, is another watershed: the worldwide triumph of the perpetually destabilizing market principle has brought with it the end of conservative certainty, and the opportunity for a fresh look at the lessons of the Enlightenment.
Smith, as Rothschild reads him, did not see state and market as competing principles, as later free-market ideologues were to do, just as Condorcet was not actually the prophet of the authoritarian state he is often taken to have been. For these thinkers, "the 'state' and the 'market' were not . . . two imposing and competing dominions of society" but were "interdependent." Indeed, "The Wealth of Nations" calls for legal reforms, such as the repeal of statutes restricting workers' movement into trades and between localities (and keeping some wages above their so-called natural levels). Rothschild is misleading, however, in describing this as governmental activism. What Smith wants from the state, for the most part, is to get out of the way of the "natural system of liberty" in which each man looks after his interests on his own. Rothschild would like to combat the conventional view of Smith as a critic of state regulation of the economy. However, she obscures the radical significance of his writing for his own time as well as for later generations.
The extent to which Rothschild goes beyond correcting a one-sided image of Smith to distorting his views herself is most striking in the chapter she devotes to his idea of the "Invisible Hand." Smith, she claims, "did not especially esteem the invisible hand," taken as a promise "that society will in fact turn out to be prosperous, or orderly, in the absence of government direction." In her view, he invoked the phrase ironically, mocking theorists who believe in systems of unintended order. Rothschild's somewhat postmodern Smith thinks of market transactions as a mode of conversation in which individuals work out the moral and social significance of their actions with the self-awareness that, as a man of the Enlightenment, he saw as the birthright of everyone, not just philosophers.
But the enlightened thinker, after all, offers a different service for sale than the enlightened farmer or laborer, within the division of labor that Smith (and Condorcet) took as fundamental to modern society. Smith's basic idea is that "every individual can judge much better than any statesman or lawgiver can do for him" how best to employ his capital and energy; and further, "that the study of his own advantage naturally, or rather necessarily, leads him to prefer that employment which is most advantageous for the society." With respect to economic questions, the individual need only think about his immediate interests, preferably in as enlightened a manner as possible; while the theorist may understand how individual advantage serves the social interest, it's not his understanding but the market that works the magic. This is why Smith calls not for regulation of trade following his prescriptions but for the system of "natural liberty" allowing every one to act, as far as is practically possible, as he wishes. Despite the fact, often noted, that the phrase occurs only three times in Smith's writings, the idea of the invisible hand is as central to his argument as it is generally held to be.
Rothschild doesn't want to admit that the invocation of Smith as a theoretical mascot of laissez-faire registers an important historical truth: for all their insistence on natural equality and the virtues of individualism, neither Smith nor Condorcet could think beyond the limitations set to these principles by the social system that invented them. Just as a truly free market has never existed, so individual freedom has taken only those forms permitted by the laws of capitalist society. As Rothschild points out, "the system of economic freedom is founded on the equality of all individuals, and it is at the same time subversive of equality." But this means more than that; as she has it, we must be able "to live without certainty" in a society that continually creates new opportunities while casting old decisions into doubt. It means that understanding forms of equality and freedom tied to inequality, and to subjection to the forces of state and market, calls for deeper modes of thought than those we have inherited from the 18th century.

HEADLINE: Where the West Begins 

BYLINE:  By Steven Merritt Miner; Steven Merritt Miner is a professor of history and chairman of the history department at Ohio University. His latest book, "Stalin's Holy War" will be published later this year.

 BODY:
 RUSSIA AND
THE RUSSIANS
A History.
By Geoffrey Hosking.
Illustrated. 718 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The Belknap Press/
Harvard University Press. $35.

EMPIRE
The Russian Empire and Its Rivals.
By Dominic Lieven.
Illustrated. 486 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $35.
 With the end of the cold war and the implosion of the Soviet empire, many Americans have taken to wallowing in complacency: history has rendered its timeless verdict on the virility of American society and its institutions. Free market democracy has vanquished totalitarianism and Communism; multiethnic federalism and decentralization have proven more adaptable than centralized empire. Contending visions lie in the dust; history is at an end.
As with most received wisdom, there is a great deal of truth in this view, but it is one of the many strengths of these two fine books about Russia that in providing a long and deep historical perspective, they serve to undermine any sense of complacency. As both books' authors show, in the mid-1800's Russia's rulers could look back on a century and a half of triumph in numerous wars, unparalleled geographic expansion, relative economic prosperity and, as contrasted with the French Revolution and the upheavals that stunned Europe in 1848, comparative political stability as well. Russians of that time could have been forgiven for believing Tocqueville's prediction that Russia and America would ultimately supplant the decrepit West European states. Who could have foreseen the century and a half of unimaginable violence and tumult that lay ahead? History holds many surprises. 
Geoffrey Hosking, a professor of Russian history at the University of London, gives us "Russia and the Russians: A History," an account of the full sweep of Russian history, which devotes roughly equal attention to four periods: the disputed origins of the Russian state in Kievan Rus and the subsequent era of Mongol domination (10th-15th centuries); the Muscovite era (15th through 17th centuries); the time of the czars (18th century to 1917); and the Soviet and post-Soviet period. This is a useful supplement to Hosking's more analytical "Russia: People and Empire," which appeared in 1997, and the new book is the most up-to-date, comprehensive one-volume history of Russia in print, drawing as it does on a wealth of scholarship to provide readers with a superb, well-organized chronological narrative. The footnotes alone give the reader an excellent guide to recent scholarship. 
More interpretive and thematic than Hosking's book, Dominic Lieven's "Empire: The Russian Empire and Its Rivals" is an ambitious study comparing the Russian empire with those of Britain, the Hapsburgs and the Ottomans. This is a much-needed volume, and it is a genuine pleasure to read. 
Too often, historians are inclined to view Russia as sui generis, appended to Europe but almost entirely different in its society and institutions. Russians themselves notoriously and endlessly debate whether Russia is truly a part of Europe, or whether it has its own unique spirit and mission. East-West confrontation during the cold war only heightened the sense of Russia as the alien "other." The view of Russia as the eternal outsider to Europe simultaneously overstates Russian difference and exaggerates European homogeneity. The Russian Empire was unique, to be sure, but then so were its rivals; at the same time, certain features often treated by historians as specifically Russian in fact had parallels in other imperial systems. 
As Lieven, a professor of Russian government at the London School of Economics, shows, the Russian Empire shared with the British both a self-proclaimed "civilizing mission" and a double standard of behavior in its imperial domains. In non-European regions, Russian rule, like British, was generally at its most brutal. Mass deportations and slaughters verging on genocide -- even though not routine, as they would become under Stalin -- punctuated Russian rule in Siberia, Central Asia and the Caucasus region. Alexander I's viceroy in the Caucasus, for instance, declared that "gentleness, in the eyes of Asiatics, is a sign of weakness, and out of pure humanity I am inexorably severe. One execution saves hundreds of Russians from destruction and thousands of Muslims from treason." Yet the same czar, when he looked west, chose to govern through constitutions in Russian Finland and Poland, constitutions that were immeasurably more liberal than anything the Russians themselves would enjoy for two centuries. 
Like the Hapsburgs' Austro-Hungarian Empire, czarist Russia was a contiguous, multinational land empire. It was precisely this contiguity that caused many outside observers to underestimate the imperial nature of Russia and to conflate the Russian nation with its empire. Both the Hapsburgs and the Russians acquired their first significant imperial domains in the mid-16th century. At that time, Muscovy defeated its Tatar neighbors to the east, the final, sclerotic remnants of the once great Mongol empire that had dominated Russia for 250 years. These victories enabled Muscovites to pour into Siberia and colonize it, feeding off its rich fur trade. For Russia, a second burst of imperial expansion followed the reign of the westernizing Czar Peter I, who ruled from 1682 to 1725 and was known as Peter the Great. In the succeeding years, Russia gained the Baltic provinces, Ukraine, Crimea, Finland and what is now Moldova. Most significantly, along with Prussia and Austria, Russia dismembered Poland. All together, these gains projected Russian power deep into Europe, giving the czarist state both the wherewithal and the geographic position to become a great power for the first time.
As Lieven and Hosking both deftly show, however, what had once conferred great strength would eventually become a liability for Austria and Russia. Whereas in the 18th century the acquisition of territory and non-Russian subjects simply meant more resources for the czars to exploit, a century later the rise of the nation-state, and with it notions of popular sovereignty, undermined the claims of monarchical legitimacy. Russia's borderlands, far from being an impenetrable defensive glacis, became instead a chink in the czars' armor -- a lesson Stalin would have done well to learn after the Soviet triumph in World War II. 
Following their victory over Napoleon in 1815, Russia and Austria had entered the 19th century as the dominant land powers; by century's end each had been weakened by the very forces that once made it great. Lieven is both honest and sympathetic in rendering his verdicts: neither the Russian nor the Austrian leaders found an answer to their nationalities question. Most probably, there was none to be found, short of dissolution. And, as events would show, disintegration of these empires only raised new, and even bloodier, problems. 
Lieven's comparison of the Russian and Ottoman empires is especially rich. Russia's western periphery -- namely Poland, the Baltic lands and Finland -- were wealthier and culturally more sophisticated than the imperial center. This certainly sets Russia's empire apart from the French and British variants, which are more familiar to Americans. Yet, like Russia's, many of the Ottoman dominions were more prosperous than the area that lay at the heart of the empire, the relatively impoverished Anatolian peninsula that would become modern Turkey. Faced with rivals whose economic might enabled them to field smaller, but more effective, armies and navies, both Russia and Ottoman Turkey were forced to devote far larger proportions of their revenue to defense than did the Western imperial powers, with disastrous consequences. Economic and even national development were throttled as a result, Lieven says, a verdict with which Hosking emphatically agrees. The establishment of secure property rights and the limitation of central government that characterized much of Europe, and that together helped to unleash the latent power that enabled the continent to dominate much of the world, were stunted both in Russia and in Turkey. In the famous phrase of the Russian historian Vassily Klyuchevsky, "the state swelled up, the people grew lean." 
The cost of empire could be ruinous indeed. In the 16th and 17th centuries, Russia's czars forced the peasantry into serfdom in order to pay the costs of empire and to compete with Western Europe's advancing military technology. The dark legacy of serfdom is reflected even today in the anemic state of Russian agriculture. As late as 1907, as an educated work force was becoming the key to economic and political power, the Russian government spent only 6.9 million rubles on higher education. (By comparison, a single battleship cost 30 million.) 
Stalin's collectivization of agriculture in the early 1930's (called the "second enserfment" by the peasants) imparted a characteristically savage imprint on this tradition. He explicitly sold his crash five-year plans as a quick fix for the Soviet Union's security problems; the cost came in ruined lives, deformed economic development, pervasive authoritarianism and ecological disaster. As Hosking writes, "The Communists had aimed to build an egalitarian system based on plenty; instead they created a hierarchical one based on scarcity." 
Tracing Russia's relative economic underdevelopment and its authoritarian social and political institutions to the cost of maintaining a huge military establishment is scarcely new. By comparing the Russian situation with those of other empires, however, Lieven is able to show with much greater force and nuance how certain social conditions often portrayed as peculiarly Russian in fact derived from the imperial drive to defend a sprawling, multinational empire against better-financed and more secure enemies. 
At the same time, the comparative approach facilitates judgments about where Russia truly was on its own. Its relationship with Western Europe was complex, and of course it would remain so through the Soviet period to the present day. Although with very few exceptions Russian elites have traditionally identified with European culture, Russia's attitude to Western Europe, and by extension to the United States, has been and remains ambivalent. Wanting to sit at the table of the great powers, Russia's leaders have always been at least partly uncertain of their right to be there, owing to the relative backwardness of their social system. Even the proudest and most assertive Russian and Soviet statesmen have shown, sometimes by the very assertiveness of their pride, that they long to be taken seriously by more established members of the club. 
For all the useful comparisons that can be made with other empires, the Russian system had its own characteristics. Unlike the British, Russian emigrants did not leave an island home to enter far-flung colonies. The demographic flood of Russians into the periphery, which reached its peak at the turn of the last century, has resulted in an unstable post-Soviet residue, where the line between the Russian heartland and the empire cannot be convincingly drawn. Twenty-five million Russians were suddenly stranded in the "near abroad" when the Soviet Union collapsed. Nothing on this scale happened at the close of the Ottoman or Hapsburg eras, much less as Britain withdrew from its empire. What will become of these people in the future will depend greatly on whether Russian leaders choose to exploit the issue. As Lieven shows, for all his failings as a leader, we should be thankful that Boris Yeltsin did not embark on that bloody road.+ 
Although the Russian and the Ottoman Empires shared many strategic problems, ultimately the Russians proved more adaptable. Under the Soviets, Russian power was reborn, even as the Ottoman empire was going the way of the Romans. Surely Lieven is right in arguing that this was because Russians could embrace the cause of modernity since, unlike the Muslim Ottomans, they did not have to shed their primary identity to do so. 
The legacy of great military power in current times is, however, far more dangerous than anything the Ottomans left behind. A largely disintegrated, yet still immense, empire in possession of modern nuclear weaponry has no parallel in history. Even now, under Vladimir Putin, Russia is clearly trying to reassert a great-power status to which Russians feel entitled by geography and history. Despite the post-Soviet squalor, it would be wrong to count Russia out. Both these excellent histories show how Russia has recovered from far worse to rise again. We may believe that the era of empires is over once and for all. But this may be only because we cannot envision the circumstances that would resurrect this ancient, endlessly adaptable human institution.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Alaska Gets Tougher On Cruise Ship Pollution

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE 

 BODY:
ON a typical summer day in Alaska, the number of people aboard cruise ships along the Inside Passage, from Ketchikan in the south up to Juneau, reaches nearly 50,000 -- enough to constitute the third largest community in Alaska, behind only Anchorage and Fairbanks. 
 This burgeoning waterborne population, nearing one million a year, has in many ways been an economic boon for Alaska. But it's hardly an unalloyed blessing: many Alaskans say the giant ships have marred the scenery and, even worse, fouled the pristine waters of the Inside Passage. 
 Last month the State Legislature passed a bill that would expand the state's authority to inspect vessels and to fine companies that violate state pollution laws. Sponsors of the bill say it represents one of the most comprehensive testing and monitoring measures anywhere in the world of the $14-billion-a-year cruise industry. 
 "We have elevated our protection of the oceans to a new, higher level," Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, said just after passage of the bill. "The message is loud and clear that Alaskans care deeply about their oceans, marine life and habitat." 
 After a voluntary testing program last year found that almost none of the waste-water samples from the ships met federal standards for fecal coliform bacteria and other pollutants, Mr. Knowles called the discharges a disgrace, and he and several lawmakers pressed for higher standards. 
 The cruise industry, having first taken no position on the legislation but perhaps sensing a potential public-relations disaster, ultimately worked with lawmakers on the new rules, which are more stringent than existing federal statutes governing discharges. 
 The industry did manage to dodge a contentious proposal when the legislature balked at levying a head tax on cruise passengers, which sponsors wanted to peg at as much as $50 a person, to cover some of the impact of the ships' visits to Alaskan ports. Similar proposals are likely to re-emerge next year; efforts to impose such taxes in individual ports have largely stalled because cruise companies could simply bypass those places; a statewide fee would apply to any passenger whose ship sails in Alaskan waters. 
 Randy Phillips, a Republican state senator who hopes to see the head-tax proposal reappear next year, said: "I don't want our communities to be stuck paying the bill for services that a million-plus people are enjoying in our state. This is a small price to pay for the services they get." 
 Under pressure from the San Francisco-based Bluewater Network and other environmental groups, the cruise industry says it is committed to higher environmental standards. Just recently, an industry trade association, the International Council of Cruise Lines, based in Arlington, Va., announced that its members must meet or exceed the recycling and waste-discharge guidelines established by the group or risk losing their membership. Royal Caribbean Cruises and Holland America, which both run Alaska cruises, have said they will comply with the new guidelines, as have the group's 14 other members. 
 "This industry is very interested in minimizing its environmental impact," the council's president, Michael Crye, said in a telephone interview. "What this pledge says is that we will embrace the best environmental practices that we can." New technology being installed on many ships, he added, uses filters and ultraviolet radiation to make the treated water "completely benign."
 The group, whose new standards took effect July 1, represent more than 90 percent of cruise ships visiting North American ports. Other members include Princess, Carnival, Celebrity, Disney, Norwegian, Princess, Radisson, Regal, Royal Olympic and Windstar. 
 But whatever promise the new technology holds, there have been several highly publicized illegal discharges of polluted water in Alaska in recent years. And of 80 water samples taken in the state from ship discharge tanks last year, just one met the federal standards for suspended solids and fecal coliform, which is a bacterium found in human waste. Some of the samples found bacteria levels thousands of times above the federal limits for treated sewage. The testing also found evidence of the silver used in shipboard photo processing, dry-cleaning chemicals, and oil and bilge residues. The chemicals can be toxic, and elevated fecal-coliform levels are a threat to human health and to marine life. 
 Moreover, just days after the State Legislature passed its new bill, Coast Guard inspectors said that Royal Caribbean's 915-foot Rhapsody of the Seas had illegally dumped waste water into Juneau's harbor, marking the third time a cruise ship had been cited for violations this season. (The others were Holland America's Westerdam and Norwegian Cruise Lines' Norwegian Sky.) 
 A spokesman for Royal Caribbean said that the discharge was accidental and was stopped as soon as crew members noticed the problem. "It violates the new discharge law, and nobody regrets that more than us," the cruise line said. "We have already taken steps that we feel are appropriate to prevent it from happening again." 
 An international marine-pollution convention 25 years ago set limits on dumping of garbage and oil, but, until the Alaska legislation, there have been few restrictions on the dumping of so-called gray water -- which contains discharge from galleys, laundries and showers -- in offshore areas. 
 Federal legislation passed last year and sponsored by Senator Frank Murkowski, a Republican of Alaska, set new limits on waste-water discharges in Alaska. The new state legislation, sponsors say, steps up both monitoring and enforcement of those standards.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Siemens Plans $120 Million Redevelopment in Iselin

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: ISELIN, N.J. 

 BODY:
OVER the next five years, the Siemens Corporation, the American arm of Siemens A.G., the German conglomerate, plans to replace its 30-year-old 350,000-square-foot complex here with a newer and bigger version.
 The redevelopment, at a projected cost of more than $120 million, will be done in phases and result in more than 700,000 square feet in a trio of office buildings, each with 237,000 square feet of space on eight stories, garage parking for 1,725 cars and outdoor plazas. 
 They will take the place of two squat, time-worn office buildings and a warehouse that now sit on the 23-acre site on Wood Avenue South, near Exit 131 of the Garden State Parkway in Iselin, an unincorporated section of Woodbridge, a Middlesex County township. 
The site will be cleared of existing buildings in stages as the new structures are completed. Construction of the first building began last month and will take 18 months to finish, according to Gale & Wentworth of Florham Park, the developer and construction manager for the project. A 575-car parking deck will also be built as part of the initial phase. 
The reshaping of the Siemens Wood Avenue South complex is the first project in the metropolitan area to reflect the 154-year-old company's business plan to "Americanize" by increasing its operating efficiency, profits and name recognition in the United States.
Among the tenets of the plan, begun in March, is to consolidate its diverse businesses into "central hubs" so they can share services and expenses and lower costs, including for real estate.
"The redevelopment is a prototype for us, a test bed," said Robert Mawhirt, president and chief executive of Siemens Real Estate. "It will give us the opportunity to create a campus environment to help with the building of Siemens as an American company and to show value." 
Siemens, based in Munich, is in businesses ranging from mobile phones to medical equipment to light bulbs; its brands include Westinghouse and Osram Sylvania. But it is not as well known here as its main competitor, General Electric, and consumers tend to confuse it with Seaman's, the furniture company. 
What is also spurring Siemens to change is that in March it was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. To draw American investors, the company realized it needed to pay more attention to profits, not just sales and employment, which has been its tradition. Last year Siemens lost $100 million in the United States although it had profits worldwide of several billion dollars.
MR. MAWHIRT said it was intended that the Iselin complex would eventually house the 6 subsidiaries now at the site and 8 to 10 other units within a 35-mile radius. The current businesses include Shared Medical Systems, Shared Business Services, Real Estate and some functions of the Siemens Corporation. The company declined to say how many total business units are in New Jersey, but did say they occupy 250,000 square feet in the state, most of it leased. 
The redevelopment of the Wood Avenue South site, which Siemens Real Estate owns, is designed to enable it and other operating companies to share the costs of carrying out common functions like payroll and buying common items like insurance. 
And in terms of real estate, "we must offer a better-than-market solution," Mr. Mawhirt said, noting that rents should be better than the companies now pay. He added that the new buildings would feature Siemens products, helping to lower costs. 
If all the space at the new complex is not taken by Siemens companies, the vacant space will be leased to outside concerns, he said.
The Iselin complex was selected as the maiden central hub site for several reasons, including that the company had been there a long time and the six businesses it houses have a total of 950 workers, out of an overall work force of 3,900 in the state. 
"We are looking to where there is a concentration of workers and businesses," Mr. Mawhirt said, noting that besides the New Jersey complex other consolidated sites are being considered in Orlando, Fla., and Atlanta.
Siemens, he added, also "is in the early stages of consolidating all its United States real estate into Siemens Real Estate." 
Another factor favoring this site is its location in the Metropark office submarket, which straddles parts of Edison and Woodbridge and is adjacent to the Metropark train station, which offers service on New Jersey Transit and Amtrak. It is also accessible to the Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike and Interstate 287 and to a deep pool of skilled labor, said Robert Dinner, a principal at the Iselin office of Newmark JGT, a commercial brokerage.
The Metropark area, he said, is "a potpourri" made up of corporate owned and multitenanted buildings as well as regional headquarters, and it is attractive to diverse users.
AS of the first quarter, the 5.8-million-square-foot submarket had a vacancy rate of 9.6 percent for Class A space, which predominates, up from 1.5 percent at the end of last year. The rise was attributed primarily to a 110,000-square-foot block from the Prudential Insurance Company in Iselin put on the market for sublease, which is now half leased, said Stephen P. Jenco, research services manager based at the Fairfield office of Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage. 
Mr. Jenco said the sluggish economy, which is slowing the pace of leasing, is affecting Metropark and the overall 11-county northern and central New Jersey market. 
But, surprisingly, he said, rents are still increasing, though the rate of the rise is slowing. His firm put the asking rents for Class A space in Metropark in the first quarter of this year at $30.43 a square foot a year.
The bulge in the inventory doesn't worry Joseph J. Sarno, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, a national real estate services firm, who works in the firm's Iselin office. "Historically," he said, "anytime space becomes available in Metropark, it leases, and because of its ground-zero location it will be among the last markets to fall." 
Siemens is not alone in making the most of its site. Developers are advancing plans for three office buildings in Metropark, together totaling about 800,000 square feet, as well as parking decks on sites near Siemens. 
Eighteen months ago Siemens selected Gale & Wentworth, which manages the Iselin site, to help devise a redevelopment plan for it that would balance several goals, said Kris Bauman, vice president of development at Gale & Wentworth. Among them is "to create a quality environment for Siemens, maximize the site and provide a new set of buildings with minimum impact on existing tenants," he said, adding that the new buildings are also to be flexible enough to meet the space needs of companies outside the Siemens umbrella. 
Woodbridge's mayor, James E. McGreevey, called the project a "significant capital investment" that will enhance the community's tax base for the next decade. That is, he added, "provided the necessary infrastructure improvements are done on a timely basis to ensure the long-term success of Metropark." Mr. Bauman said Siemens had agreed to such improvements as installing a traffic light at the entrance to the site and widening Wood Avenue South for about one-quarter of a mile to its intersection with Thornall Street. 
Meanwhile, Mr. McGreevey said a new exit on the Garden State Parkway is planned as are $31 million in upgrades in the next decade to the train station.
Aware of the cooling economy, Mr. Bauman said the fact that Siemens is the lead occupant ensures the success of the project. Designed by the Hillier Group of Princeton, the new buildings will feature precast concrete panels with glass panels on the upper six stories, while the first two floors will be mainly glass. 
As now planned, Siemens units currently on the scene will fill two-thirds to three-fourths of the first new building, which will rise on the northern portion of the property, now occupied by parking lots. Barring an economic tailspin, the rest of project will proceed in phases, with completion scheduled for 2006. 
Asked why Siemens did not try to save any of the existing complex, Mr. Mawhirt said, "It would have been like trying to make an old sneaker into a work shoe."

HEADLINE: Greenport Gentrifies: A Waterfront Facelift 

BYLINE:  By LORRAINE KREAHLING 

DATELINE: GREENPORT 

 BODY:
WITH a ribbon-cutting ceremony attended by Governor Pataki, Mitchell Park opened in the heart of downtown Greenport on June 29, capping a six-year effort spearheaded by Mayor David E. Kapell.
 The transformation, including an open-air performance space, a promenade and an antique carousel, has been a long time coming for Greenporters, who have had a vacant and weed-covered blemish on their picturesque waterfront since a fire destroyed the famous hotel and restaurant known as Mitchell's in 1978. 
 For 15 years, a series of private owners failed to push their plans for a commercial development of the property past the local planning board and elected officials. Even after the last owner, Mohring Enterprises, defaulted on its mortgage and the village acquired the land in 1996, conflicts arose over who should choose the final design and where a carousel house, which the mayor had envisioned as a magnet for children of the village, should be located. 
No small part of the achievement is Mr. Kapell's success in securing government assistance. So far, the state has committed $3.1 million to the project, which with a future marina and ice rink will have a final price tag of $10 million.
"I don't think it could have happened without him," a former mayor, Joseph L. Townsend, said of Mr. Kapell. "He has exactly the right blend of creativity, aggressiveness and charm to get things done."
The first phase of the construction of the new 3.4-acre park includes an amphitheater formed by semicircles of flagstone walls facing Peconic Bay. The new harbor walk stretches across the park to the partly completed dock that will become a municipal marina during phase two of the project. The carousel, given to Greenport by Northrop-Grumman when it closed its employee amusement park in 1995, now has a permanent home in a sleek modern structure of glass, steel and wood.
While shop owners expect the new park to help business, Mr. Kapell said Mitchell Park is first and foremost for the people of the village. In the winter, long after summer visitors have fled, the skating rink will operate alongside the carousel house, which will be heated.
"Our focus is on improving the quality of life in Greenport without really changing our village," Mayor Kapell said.
But the consensus among Greenporters seems to be that the park is an emblem of major change for the 200-year-old village. Greenport's increasing attractiveness as a vacation spot for residents up-Island and from New York City and as a second-home alternative to the Hamptons has brought rising numbers of cars and people along with rapidly inflating real estate values.
Paul Henry, a real estate tax consultant, said property prices had increased between 60 and 80 percent over the last two to three years. Waterfront property has gone up by as much 100 percent, he said.
"Greenport is changing big time," said Fernando Silie, who has worked for seven years at Clinton Hommel, a plumbing supply store on Main Street, and who said he moved from New York City so he could raise his daughters in a quiet place. Only it's not so quiet anymore.
"Now there are so many cars and motor bikes flying by my house on the way to the boat yard," Mr. Silie said. "They don't even see the stop sign."
Additional money is earmarked by the state to widen the traffic lanes of Front Street, where the park is located, and add off-site parking fields.
Of course, streets pulsing with more cars and people are good news for store owners, who often must struggle through the winter months.
"We are supposed to be in a recession, but Memorial Day was like the Fourth of July here," said Harvey Katz, owner of Harvey Claudio's Wines & Liquors. "The weather was bad, but town was jammed."
Mr. Katz, who recently expanded the shop he has owned for 11 years, is not alone among small business owners who are making significant new investment in the village. Around the corner, the owners of the Harbor Front Deli plan to move into a larger space under construction a few doors down. A downtown budget motel, The Greenporter, is being converted by new owners into a luxury spa. Porgie's, a former family restaurant just east of where Main Street meets the north road, is undergoing an estimated $500,000 reconstruction. The building is being transformed into The Shady Lady, a restaurant and hotel where, it is rumored, overnight lodging will top out at $300.
"We are seeing projects where the expenditure does not seem to be warranted by the current economy of the village," Mr. Townsend said. "The park is the beginning of permanent change for the village."
He added that the contemporary design of the housing for the antique carousel was an appropriate metaphor for Greenport.
"This village has always been a conglomeration of tastes, sophistication and honky-tonk," he said. "We've had bootleggers and brothels and families. Now we have added vineyards and spas and organic farms."

(Photographs by Deirdre Brennan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Is This Why Gregory Peck Was So Cool? 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT residents should be warned that if they see a sporty little Italian motor scooter zip by them along the state's back roads this summer -- and they will see one -- please, don't call it a moped. Otherwise, they will not only offend its very particular owner (there just may be a movie star under that helmet), they will also unwittingly label themselves as tragically un-hip.
 After a 15-year absence, the Vespa motor scooter -- made famous by Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn in "Roman Holiday" and by Matt Damon and Gwyneth Paltrow in "The Talented Mr. Ripley" -- is once again available in the United States. And with the perfect timing of high gasoline prices, climbing national scooter sales, and chi-chi marketing (Mitchells, the clothing store in Westport, has one on its sales floor), the Vespa is becoming this year's Must Have, joining the motorized stand-up scooter as another economical and trendy mode of transportation for the short jaunt. 
 "I see it as a stylish novelty," said Mary Rappa, a 41-year-old Greenwich mother of two young boys, who recently was at the state's only dealership at Branchville Motors in Ridgefield recently to pick up her new, $3,950 Dragon Red Vespa. "I like the fact that the Vespa looks retro. We live in an area where there are many Europeans and when people see it they do recognize it."
Charles Roy, 40, a Greenwich tax lawyer, said he doesn't even need a car to get to work now that he owns a Vespa. Mr. Roy said he was "quite intent" on buying a Vespa for a long time "because they are fun, and because of vanity," but they weren't available until recently. He finally purchased a black model in March. Each work day, he puts on a suit, straddles the Vespa and scoots to his office, which is one mile from his home.
"I buy $2 worth of gas, which gets me about 50 miles and lasts about three weeks," he said. "It is so practical for me."
The Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles considers the Vespa to be a motorcycle and requires new owners to pass a written and driving test and to register and insure them.
Mike Mount of the Motorcycle Industry Council of Irvine, Calif., which monitors industry sales, said in an e-mail message that national, overall scooter sales, which include such brands as Honda and Yamaha, have been increasing steadily since 1999 when 25,000 were sold. About 33,000 were sold in 2000, he said, and figures from January through April of this year are 38 percent higher than the same period last year.
Vespa re-entered the United States market last fall. The scooters were first manufactured with manual transmissions in Italy in 1946 and were sold in the United States until 1985 when the company left the market rather than deal with stringent federal anti-pollution standards. New technology has made the scooters, now with automatic transmissions, compliant with the United States standards, said Peter J. Laitmon, president of Vespa East Coast. Right now, the $3,000 and $4,000 model are available only at Branchville Motors, which sold only motorcycles and accessories prior to adding the Vespa line. But that will soon change, Mr. Laitmon said, as he has 68 requests from other business owners in Connecticut to sell the scooter.
At Branchville, Vespa designer clothing and other fashion merchandise is interspersed among the brightly colored scooters (Dragon Red is the most popular).
"We're selling about one a day," said Alex Gifford, owner of Branchville Motors, adding that it has sold more than 100 since sales began in March. "Many of our customers are very well educated and well traveled. They've seen them in Europe and would love to have one. I think they are the bike of choice for short trips." Mr. Gifford said when he drives his to a local dairy bar on Sunday mornings, "people flock around to see what it is."
Ms. Rappa and Mr. Roy reported similar experiences. Piaggio Europei of Italy, which makes the Vespa, is counting on the Vespa's chic, unencumbered style, nostalgia and Hollywood cachet to attract buyers. The scooters have appeared not only in movies like "American Graffiti," "Quadrophenia," "Austin Powers," and "American Pie," but also have been used in advertisements by American Express, Coca Cola, IBM and most recently by Abercrombie & Fitch in its spring catalog.
"We have always felt we were in the fashion and entertainment business, not the transportation business," Mr. Laitmon said. "Our concept is not coming back and selling Vespas in motorcycle shops, but as a lifestyle."
Mr. Laitmon said that the director Steven Spielberg and the comedian Jerry Seinfeld own Vespas. "Vespas have appeared in so many movies, that's how people came to know them," he said. "It would be wrong not to capitalize on the celebrity."
But all the talk of upscale owners and pop culture rankles Vespa purists like Michael J. Charles of New Canaan and Geoff Bolek of Stratford, who belong to a subset of Vespa owners that shuns the new versions for the vintage models. Mr. Laitmon estimated that there were 30,000 Vespas from the 50's, 60's and 70's in the United States and that vintage owners enjoy "an espirit de corps that represents the hardcore people who are the keepers of the flame."
Indeed, Mr. Charles, 31, who owns four vintage Vespas, takes on the zeal of an evangelist when he talks about his scooters.
"There's nothing else like sitting on a Vespa," he said. "I have such a kinship with the old ones. I was 15 when I sat on my first one and I felt like I was in Europe and I was back in the 60s. It's a true addiction."
Mr. Charles said he first became aware of the Vespa when he saw the 1979 movie "Quadrophenia." In the movie, the musician Sting zipped around on a Vespa, epitomizing the edgy "mod" scene of London. "That, to me, was it," Mr. Charles said. "That fact that you can get on a bike and it takes you back there, it's the closest thing to owning a time machine." 
Mr. Bolek, 31, said he thought that buying a new Vespa for $4,000 "just isn't practical." He said he bought his first Vespa, a 1973 model for $100, in 1992 "when you could still find them in the classified ads."
He bought his second one in 1977 for $600. "There's no way I'd part with it," he said. "I rebuilt it with a lot of trial and tribulation. That's the beauty of the thing -- there isn't a lot of moving parts." Mr. Bolek said he gets almost 50 miles to the gallon. But, that's not all he gets.
"It's fun to ride," he said. "On the scooter, you're going slow. You get from point A to point B and you do it in style. I'm trying to have as much style as Gregory Peck, I guess."

HEADLINE: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; 
Red Scare Over Newark

BYLINE:  By HELEN LIPPMAN; Helen Lippman writes about health and employee benefits. Submit your account of struggling or succeeding as a worker, consumer, investor or entrepreneur to My Money, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to mymoney @nytimes.com. All submissions become the property of The Times. They may be edited and may be republished in any medium.

 BODY:
I WAS a red-diaper baby. Born in 1947, the year the House Un-American Activities Committee unleashed its vengeance on the film industry, I learned secrecy at my mother's knee. 
 My parents, first-generation Russian-American Jews, remained members of the Communist Party throughout my childhood. They often talked to my sister and me about their idealistic belief in a society in which everyone happily shared wealth and power. Yet their insistence that we keep that vision to ourselves conveyed the message that people could not be trusted. 
 I dared to defy them only once, when I was 7, passing on my rudimentary understanding of their views to a friend. "Everybody has it backwards," I told her. Then I rattled off names of nations, carefully explaining that the ones people thought were bad were really good, and vice versa. I swore her to secrecy, but my lapse so terrified me that I kept our secret for another 20 years.
While I have long since rejected my parents' beliefs and overcome my fear, my upbringing has left its mark, reflected in the choices I make and the way I spend my money.
Newark, my father's birthplace, was my home for 21 years. We remained there until after the 1967 riots, repeatedly readjusting to a city in flux. Every four or five years, we moved to a different neighborhood, always after my parents' dedication to living in an integrated area was shattered by the realization that we were practically the only white family left.
Politics and party membership had a direct effect on family finances. Dad, an accountant, never even tried to become a C.P.A. He was concerned that sitting for the exam would have required him to sign a loyalty oath. Convinced that the F.B.I. was watching us -- citing men lurking, strangers knocking and telephones he thought were tapped -- he refused to take the risk.
Clearly, neither he nor my mother made much money. Yet my parents' spending habits, I suspect, had at least as much to do with a Depression-era mentality and an anticonsumerism attitude as with the size of their bank account. In the middle of a booming postwar economy, they acted as if it were sinful to desire frivolous things.
Consider the automobile. Our first car was a hand-me-down from my father's boss, an enormous clunker that Dad called Chief Hungry Horse, for its gas-guzzling habits and the Indian head on its hood. Our second, deemed a necessity, was bought only after the demise of Hungry Horse -- a new but stripped-down model in basic black without even a radio.
Clothing, too, was utilitarian. On shopping excursions, Mom taught me to inspect seams, reject rayon and forget about lacy frills that could easily fray. Despite an occasional temper tantrum, I generally accepted her no-nonsense approach.
Until I discovered mohair sweaters. Luxuriously soft and fluffy but leaning toward the impractical, these long cardigans were a fashion highlight of my high school days. The girls I envied had six or seven in an array of pastels, often with shoes to match. I had one, in baby pink, bought with my own money. 
Intellect was paramount to my parents, so they bought me books, a chemistry set and a miniature telescope. They also permitted me to attend Girl Scout camp, where a God we didn't believe in was part of the daily program. A fellow camper, also the daughter of Communists, shocked me by announcing her family's atheism to our bunkmates.
Now I belong to a Unitarian Fellowship, a spiritual community whose members share a desire to question life's mysteries and find our own answers. And I'm still a one-sweater woman; I believe that my two grown daughters are, too.
They were, after all, practically the only girls in their grammar school who never owned a Cabbage Patch Kid. When I see them squirreling away money for long-awaited purchases much the way my mother did, I realize that my family's disdain for conspicuous consumption has been passed on to another generation. 
Although my children grew up in a quiet suburb, I prefer a faster-paced, more integrated community, much like the Newark of my youth. In downtown Montclair, N.J., my home for several years, virtually everything is within walking distance, and the town itself is deliberately diverse. 
MY choice of career, however, is one that my father rejected. A clever user of words and the editor of his high school yearbook, he repeatedly said he would have pursued journalism if he had been free to write what he believed, not what others wanted. I did enter the field and have achieved success as a magazine editor and, more recently, as a freelancer. Pleasing editors and writing the truth as I see it, I generally find, are not mutually exclusive. 
I'm more apt to treat myself these days, secure that I earn enough to cover the cost of an occasional whim. But I'm still my parents' daughter: the 2001 Corolla I bought last summer is a no-nonsense car without so much as an automatic door lock. 
Some things can change over time, though. In his late 70's, Dad took to playing the market like a true capitalist. By the time he died, he had accumulated a tangled mass of stocks, mutual funds, bonds and annuities. But he left next to no records.
I originally attributed this to the waning mental acuity of a man in his late 80's. Now I suspect otherwise. Dad's failure to work with a financial adviser and to leave a solid paper trail just might be a final expression of his furtiveness and distrust, nurtured by years of being an American Communist in the midst of red-baiters.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (David G. Klein)
