HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
A Hulking Factory Is Given New Life in Norwalk

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FOR half a century a hulking 140,000-square-foot brick building loomed half-vacant and deteriorating over the corner of Marshall and North Water Streets in South Norwalk. In recent years it became a pariah amid its historic neighbors: the Maritime Aquarium across the street, the shops and restaurants around the corner on Washington Street, and the spreading development of the waterfront under urban renewal.
 Built in 1856 as the Norwalk Lock Company and vacated in the 1950's, the building became a warren of warehouse operations, carpentry and plumbing services, small businesses and artists' studios. 
 Last month it reopened as Maritime Place after a $12.3 million rehabilitation that has delighted tenants and visitors with its imaginative use of the 130,000 square feet left after partial demolition. Bruce Beinfield, a principal in the Norwalk firm of Beinfield Wagner Architects, and Eric Rains, project manager for Wesley Stout Associates, a New Canaan landscaping company, have converted a daunting old war horse of a building into a sophisticated interpretation of its hard-bitten industrial past. 
It is already 65 percent leased to a variety of office tenants. Annual rents that once accommodated impecunious artists and marginal businesses at $3 and $4 a square foot are now in the mid-$20's a square foot, still well below the mid-$30's and higher that prevails in Fairfield County's Gold Coast towns. Spaces range from 2,500 to 25,000 square feet, but hover predominantly around 3,000 to 5,000 square feet, with ground-floor space suitable for a restaurant or retail operation.
The project was developed in cooperation with the city and the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, which has oversight of a 70-acre area from the Norwalk River to West Avenue between Interstate 95 and Washington Street. The redevelopment partnership consists of the Spinnaker Companies of Stamford; Summit Development L.L.C., the leasing agent; and Greenfield Partners, both formerly of Westport but now headquartered at Maritime Place with 10-year leases for 2,000 and 9,000 square feet respectively. Spinnaker has leased an 820-square-foot office as manager of the building, but its headquarters remains in Stamford. 
The Lock Building, as it is known locally, is one of two Norwalk projects undertaken by the partnership. The second is the redevelopment of an 80-acre site at Norden Place off Strawberry Hill Road. Norden, a developer of radar equipment, has four years to go on a five-year lease with options for the 481,000 square feet it occupies. The property, developed by United Technologies, Norden's former parent, was sold to the Greenfield-Summit-Spinnaker partnership last year. 
The space vacated by a downsized Norden in the sprawling 633,000-square-foot two-story building is a sea of rubble while workers gut the interior before reconfiguring it as a flex office and research and development complex. Three tennis courts encircled by a running track will be retained on the property, along with a softball field and woods and wetlands where deer gambol. Driving a narrow forested road through the site could pass as a short spin in the country except for I-95 running alongside, out of sight behind dense summer foliage. 
A concrete helipad will be demolished and vast expanses of surface parking for 2,200 cars, minimal landscaping and an unpreposessing entrance to the property will be redesigned into a parklike setting by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum P.C. of New York, serving as landscape architects. The building is being redesigned by Perkins Eastman, Stamford architects, with Mr. Beinfield as architectural consultant. 
Charles Hoffman, a broker with Cushman & Wakefield in Stamford, has been talking to prospective tenants looking for 15,000 to 100,000 square feet. "We think it's a great location just off Exit 16 of I-95 and great value for brand-new, efficient office space without going to the eastern end of the county to get it," he said. "We're shooting for January 2002 occupancy."
KIM MORQUE, Spinnaker's director of development, found the disparities between the two buildings, built 100 years apart, a challenge. "Norden was built in the 60's and had a full set of original plans, with large floor plates, lots of steel and concrete, no mystery," he said.
But the Lock Building was a trip into the unknown because of its age and various uses, all brick and timber construction and lack of documentation, he said, and "community interest in these historic buildings made the project highly visible."
To begin with, 17 feet of the building facing the aquarium across North Water Street had to be cut off to create a 12-foot sidewalk where there had been none. New footings and a new brick wall were constructed, and the old bricks were used in various parts of the reworked building. Interior courtyards were revealed when old wooden buildings set into them were removed.
Original interior brick walls were cleaned and retained, supported by massive original wooden beams and perpendicular timbers. A new three-story main entrance on Marshall Street was glass-fronted with two tiers of steel and steel-mesh balconies inside. 
Walls made of wallboard were painted with a formula devised by Eve Novotny, a faux finisher in Stamford. Combining real rust with paint and other materials, she achieved a richly textured rusty look that the architect wanted. Concrete floors have been polished to a marble sheen, and tin-clad, heavy wood-core doors, fabricated in Lowell, Mass., are dead ringers for clanging old factory doors. The original black and white Norwalk Lock Factory sign on an exterior wall was exposed under layers of paint and touched up enough to be legible. 
One of two enormous original boilers was left standing in the board room of the Greenfield Partners' space. Two stories high, the room has a Beinfield-designed pyramidal fireplace painted in rust and edged in steel. Mr. Beinfield also designed the 4 1/2 by 14 1/2 foot conference table of half-inch steel plate weighing 2,500 pounds, painted black and treated with polyurethane. Lighting, designed by Mr. Beinfield and fabricated by the development's in-house electricians, is composed of 10- and 12-inch tall clear tubular bulbs with orange filaments. Some are strung vertically in a line from a steel plate high above the table; others rise from 7-foot-high copper poles attached to the floor and wall.
"We wanted the place to have a mythological industrial look of the bygone era," Mr. Beinfield said, "mixing new and old in ways that people would not be able to distinguish."
In one of three landscaped courtyards, Wesley Stout Associates installed a striking fountain consisting of a huge vertical iron pipe with a curved piece at the top, broken at the end where water spills out continuously onto a stone floor under which lies the reservoir that stores and supplies the water. The pipe looks like castoff industrial equipment, but it is brand new. 
Even the art, on loan from the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan, is attuned to the industrial theme. Two outdoor sculptures by Carole Eisner were created from industrial iron parts into striking works that are for sale for $44,000 and $36,000. A pair of indoor sculptures by Kevin Thomas in gold-glazed ceramic are $4,500 each. 
Silvermine hopes to exhibit in some of the building's ground floor windows, giving some credence to Maritime Place's subtitle: the Lock Art and Technology Center. The name is all that remains of the artists who lived and worked there until about a year and a half ago and were unable to negotiate the inclusion of an art center in the city's concept for the building.
The Navios Corporation moved last month into the largest space occupied so far. A former wholly owned subsidiary of U.S. Steel, it is now a privately owned shipping company that operates large bulk carriers of iron ore, coal, grain and bauxite worldwide, with a terminal business in South America. Its 13,000-square-foot headquarters supplants former locations in Stamford, Greenwich and Wall Street dating from 1978. "You can see we've been moving gradually north and east," said the company's president, Anthony Whitworth.
"Most of our employees live in Norwalk, or east or northeast of Norwalk, so the commute is improved dramatically. Lower cost is another factor, and a feature I found attractive is the ability to expand within the building."
Occupying 3,000 square feet since May 18, the Nat Nast Company is a maker of men's luxury sportswear. Patty Nast Canton, a daughter of the founder, runs the company with her sister, Barbara Nast Saletan. "We outgrew our space in Wilton," Ms. Canton said, "and we had our eye on this building from the time we heard it was going to happen. We have a showroom in New York, our design studio here and manufacturing in China, Peru and Italy." 
"They've done a remarkable job with conceptualizing the space," she said. "We hope to be able to expand here. Our only complaint is we still don't have window shades."

HEADLINE: When New Homes Drive Out Old Jobs 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
ON the northwest edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant -- bordering the bodegas and housing projects of DeKalb Avenue, but only three blocks from the Italianate brownstones and Victorian mansions of Clinton Hill -- six former factories built on a street called Taaffe Place at the turn of the last century have been reincarnated as beautifully renovated residential lofts with rents of up to $3,300 a month.
 The transformation of those century-old buildings seems at first like an answer to a community prayer -- trading up from industrial bleakness to residential sophistication. But to those within the manufacturing community that until recently thrived in the old buildings, and to many who live in the low-lying houses and apartment buildings surrounding it, the conversion bodes the end of something vital. To them, the changes driven by forces outside their community are less than welcome. 
 "Sometimes, when neighborhoods improve, the word 'gentrification' is overused," said Vivian Becker, director of the Pratt Area Community Council, a housing advocacy group in the neighborhood. 
It certainly seems premature, given the still gritty character of the community, to say that the border between Clinton Hill and Bed-Stuy has gone upscale. Yet there are pressure points in the city, like this one, where market forces and social shifts buffet a portion of the population and a sector of the economy like a sudden storm -- despite the fact that the change was made, to use zoning parlance, entirely "as of right."
In this case -- because of the conversion of manufacturing space in the six buildings on Taaffe Place and well beyond -- businesses have been displaced or shuttered, jobs have been lost and rents have jumped, leaving less-than-affluent local residents scared.
"What we're seeing in Clinton Hill, Fort Greene and western Bedford-Stuyvesant," Ms. Becker said, "is skyrocketing rents, tremendous turnover in home- and business ownership and rising home prices."
"What we would hope," she continued, "is to strike a balance between neighborhood improvement and business retention, as well as lower- and moderate-income resident retention."
There is a confluence of forces coming to bear on the neighborhood, said Rex Curry, associate director of the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development (not connected to Ms. Becker's group). The stately buildings of the Pratt Institute campus are nestled between the manufacturing district to the east and the more upscale Clinton Hill environs to the west.
In a long-roiling residential market, where rents and prices have barely abated in the city, even during the national economic slowdown, those wide open spaces in multistory warehouses and factories -- some vacant, some still hosting active businesses -- have become tantalizingly ripe for conversion.
"This is a giant pincer movement of two real estate activities," Professor Curry said. "One is the gentrification of Clinton Hill. These are refugees from Manhattan looking for $1,500 for a one-bedroom instead of $2,500, or two-, three-bedrooms for what they would pay for a one-bedroom in Manhattan. And the other is the expansion of the Hasidic community from Williamsburg, which is creating an enormous housing demand."
As Ms. Becker pointed out: "What ends up happening is that the interests of different groups get pitted against each other. Most of the employees who lose their jobs are local residents, primarily Latino."
TWO weeks ago, in a report commissioned by the Municipal Art Society, a nonprofit planning and preservation organization, the Pratt development center analyzed the continuing squeeze experienced by the manufacturing sector, what it calls the "silent partner" in the city's economy.
"An increasing number of properties in manufacturing and mixed-use zoning districts are being converted to nonmanufacturing uses such as commercial and residential space through variances granted by the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals," the report says. The conversion phenomenon is particularly apparent in and around the mixed-used zones, which permit existing industrial space to be retained, while also allowing as-of-right transfer of property to residential use.
Pointing out that manufacturing still provides nearly a quarter of a million jobs in the city, the report -- called "Making it in New York" -- says that "the manufacturing sector is no longer characterized by the smokestack industries of the past, but by a mix of small and midsized production businesses and 'niche' firms that are integrally related to the city's economic drivers, such as the finance, creative, cultural and health-care industries."
Gone are most of the chemical and pharmaceutical factories, the breweries, the electroplating and steel fabricating companies. What remains are the apparel, food-processing, furniture, precision instrument and printing companies, which, according to the report, average 34 employees each.
Sarah Crean, senior project manager for the New York Industrial Retention Network, a nonprofit group sponsored by the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation, said that in 1980 there were 18,914 manufacturing companies in the city with 492,407 employees. As of December 2000, Ms. Crean said, there were 9,486 manufacturing firms employing 234,531 people. "So the number has been cut in half, at least, over the last 20 years," she said.
"Most manufacturers are renters," Ms. Crean continued, "and even if they are located in a zone with a manufacturing designation, other types of businesses can come in on an as-of-right basis. This means that manufacturers are competing with a variety of businesses that can pay higher rents -- all types of information-based, service-based enterprises, art galleries, retail, storage." 
At the same time, as the Pratt report says, "Mixed-use zones have encouraged private owners to land-bank their properties in anticipation of the opportunity to dramatically increase their financial returns."
"City policy makers need to understand," the report continues, "that diversification of our economy is key to the creation of a sustained and healthy economy, particularly one that meets the employment needs of a diverse and rapidly changing population."
Roberto Santana, owner of the Christopher Food Center, a bodega on DeKalb Avenue across from the Lafayette Gardens housing project and around the corner from the Taaffe Place loft buildings, is worried about the 33 percent jump in his rent. "The area, it is changing," said Mr. Santana, so much so that for some months his landlord did not want to renew the lease. "He wanted to make his own business here, to put in his own liquor store," Mr. Santana said.
After extended negotiations, however, the lease was renewed last month. "Before, I paid $1,500; now it's up to $2,000," said Mr. Santana who, somewhat ironically, now hopes the Taaffe Place homes will soon be filled. "Maybe if the people come, I'll be able to make it," he said.
Melanie and Karl Carter -- she an associate art director for a magazine; he the owner of a marketing and promotions company -- came to Taaffe Place two months ago from Atlanta.
"We looked at Harlem and Washington Heights," Ms. Carter said. "I wanted to live in a brownstone area or an apartment building, and Karl wanted to live in a loft. Karl won. So I get to pick out all the furniture."
It wasn't as though Ms. Carter, 27, was disappointed with the 1,800-square-foot, sixth-floor space at 241 Taaffe Place. "I came in and said, 'Wow, this is it,' " she said. "It's a corner, two sides; 10 windows with views of the Manhattan Bridge, the Williamsburg Bridge, the Chrysler Building, the Empire State Building." The loft, with two full bathrooms, two clothes closets and two large utility closets, is renting for $3,000 a month.
Agreeing that the neighborhood is "not luxurious," Ms. Carter said: "It wasn't that we chose the apartment because of the neighborhood; we chose the apartment and took the neighborhood that was coming with it. But the nice thing is that there are wonderful restaurants up DeKalb Avenue" -- including French, Caribbean and Middle Eastern sidewalk cafes that have unfurled their awnings in recent years -- "and beautiful Pratt Institute and Fort Greene Park."
The six buildings on Taaffe Place were purchased in 1999 by Alma Realty, whose president, Efstathios Valiotis, said he paid $9 million, with renovation costs projected at about $20 million. Since 1978, Mr. Valiotis has purchased about 25 buildings containing approximately 3,500 units in the metropolitan area, including an 800-apartment co-op on Marine Boulevard in Jersey City that had been in bankruptcy and a 16-story, 284-unit co-op on Colden Street in Flushing, Queens.
"I decided to create lofts on Taaffe Place because of the shortage of apartments all over the city," Mr. Valiotis said. "The market was there for good investments." 
There will eventually be 335 apartments, ranging from 1,000 to 2,000 square feet. "Some have decks, terraces," Mr. Valiotis said. "Some are duplexes." All have 12- to 14-foot-high ceilings. "There's new plumbing, new heating, new windows, new electrical, new elevators, open kitchens with small islands," he said. "The floors we kept the way they were, just scraped them."
Rents range from $2,000 a month to $3,300. "Just bring your own furniture," he said.
THERE were about 25 businesses in the buildings, which were about 65 percent occupied, when he bought them, Mr. Valiotis said. Among them were cabinetmakers, a quilt manufacturer, a chair reupholsterer, a silk-screening company, three fabric wholesalers, a mattress refurbisher, manufacturers of jewelry, jewelry boxes, luggage. 
"They all had six-month cancellation clauses when I came," Mr. Valiotis said. "Some of them complied and moved out; some of them went to court and we had to evict them." The companies employed about 275 people.
Mr. Valiotis's daughter, Sophia, the on-site building coordinator for the project, said, "I can't tell you that we didn't displace workers, but we offset that by hiring workers." 
"We ended up subcontracting for the electricals, also the plumbing, and we hired a local security company," Ms. Valiotis said. "We've also hired 17 to 20 permanent workers; we've given out temporary construction work to local workers. And Brooklynites have been, and will be, moving into these apartments." Pratt Institute, she also pointed out, has taken two floors in one of the buildings to house students.
John Strohbeen and Jerry Schlemowitz aren't mollified.
Mr. Strohbeen, president of Ohm Acoustics, manufacturers of speakers for stereos and home theaters, had operated out of a Taaffe Place building for 28 years. "The old landlord told us things were going as normal, and then he sent a letter announcing that he had sold the building and that we should immediately vacate," Mr. Strohbeen said. That was in the summer of 1999. 
"We were doing very well," Mr. Strohbeen said. "Then we had to spend an unrecoverable amount of time looking for space elsewhere. I figure we lost one or two months of business from the disruption. Eventually, we located at 76 Degraw Street in Cobble Hill -- a smaller space at a higher price." 
Mr. Schlemowitz is president of Carpenter's Graphic, creators of ornate storefronts for landmark-designated buildings. After six years on Taaffe Place, he has yet to find a suitable new space and is temporarily sharing another company's space. "We looked actively," he said, "at least 30 different places: Williamsburg, the Bush Terminal area, lower Park Slope, Dumbo. If your rent was $4 per square foot per year -- we had 3,000 square feet -- and suddenly it's going to go to $18, you're in trouble. That's what the rate is today to go to, like, Dumbo."
Ms. Becker of the Pratt neighborhood group tracked 11 of the displaced companies. "Three went out of business," she said. "The rest relocated, some out of the country -- Santo Domingo, Haiti -- some out of state. They went to Long Island City, Sunset Park, the Bronx Terminal Market, New Jersey."
Mr. Schlemowitz said he had to auction off a lot of his equipment: "The saw, the computer router, sanding machines. We kept a few items -- what we call tooling for antique profiles and shapes to make all the classic moldings that go into fitting out an edifice or a door."
Currently, Mr. Schlemowitz is "bunking in with another cabinet shop to complete a project," he said. "From there, we don't know. His lease is up in a year also; a big rent increase. He's on the brink of where I was."
Last year, Professor Curry at Pratt surveyed about 90 properties between Flushing Avenue, Fulton Street, Clermont Avenue and Franklin Avenue that were "ripe for the kind of conversion" that occurred on Taaffe Place -- some vacant, some not. "Of the 90-some sites we found, almost every one is undergoing some kind of physical renewal," he said. "I can only think of three, maybe four that have yet to turn."
That sort of pressure "not only pushes jobs all over the place," the professor said, "it breaks up the 50-year formation of a cluster of businesses that have learned to depend on one another for an exchange of labor, resources, supplies, maintenance services."
Mr. Strohbeen of Ohm Acoustics said: "I had the only forklift, and virtually all the floors used it. One of the places used to cut our boards for us. There was sort of a flowing interchange of machinery and tools, if you ever needed something. In fact, we just recently returned a spare air compressor that we borrowed before we left. They moved to Queens. And they had some of our fans."
In Professor Curry's assessment: "There isn't any city policy for manufacturing retention, something that puts resources into areas of rapid change like this one where market forces suddenly just make things happen. There isn't a resource that looks at that problem, or can react in time."
The report prepared by the Pratt development center for the Municipal Art Society makes several recommendations for city action to support the manufacturing sector:
*Creation of manufacturing development zones where commercial development would be restricted and residential development would be restricted or entirely prohibited.
*Establishment of what the report calls nontransitional mixed-use zones where a predetermined balance of uses would be maintained.
*Promotion of manufacturing development through zoning regulations, financial incentives and infrastructure, such as construction of transportation and utility lines.
*Creation of a Trust for Industrial Space, an organization to acquire and develop properties for manufacturing.
"This is not an attempt to stop the clock," said Kent Barwick, executive director of the Municipal Art Society. "There are many areas in the city zoned for manufacturing where manufacturing doesn't exist, and these should now be thoughtfully rezoned for residential or commercial."
"And we're not pretending that it's 1935 and there are blue-collar workers all over the five boroughs," Mr. Barwick continued. "But we want to recognize that this is a central part of the economy, and we need to plan for it and assure that there is a place for it. That is the reason we need policies that are sort of more nuanced than the city has now."
The chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, Joseph B. Rose, took a more market-oriented approach to the problem. "While over the last three or four decades New York's industrial economy has declined significantly, it remains an important economic sector worthy of public attention," Mr. Rose said. "And the report offers some interesting suggestions to consider."
"But the city has to be careful not to substitute bureaucratic meddling for private, market-based initiatives," Mr. Rose continued. "Zoning and similar regulatory approaches have been consistently shown to be irrelevant to the health of the manufacturing sector. There's no reason at this point to believe that has changed."
FROM the vantage point of his grand, filigreed porch on Clinton Avenue in increasingly affluent Clinton Hill -- four blocks from Taaffe Place -- Tim Sullivan holds a long-term perspective on all of the change in his community. A retired interior designer, Mr. Sullivan lives in an 18-room home built in the 1850's, the style of which he alternately describes as Country Villa, Queen Anne or Victorian.
"When I was a student at Pratt, all the factories were very active," he said, "and the Brooklyn Navy Yard in the 40's was very busy. Then, for a long time, it was so fallow around here that a lot of the houses were turned into rooming houses, S.R.O.'s." 
"This has always been an integrated neighborhood," Mr. Sullivan continued, "Waspy folks, old-time Italians in row houses on Vanderbilt, now lots of blacks; and a lot of those people are very wealthy blacks."
Mr. Sullivan bought his home, with its interior Gothic arches and ornate, perforated-plaster moldings and cornices, in 1965. "Thirty-five years ago you could buy a house in the neighborhood for between $12,000 and $25,000," he said. "We paid $20,000. These would now go for $750,000."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: First of Three Middle-Income Buildings; 
A New Co-op Going Up in East Harlem

 BODY:
Ground was broken on Monday for the first of three middle-income co-op buildings on Madison Avenue in East Harlem. To be named Madison Park Apartments, the nine-story, 129-unit building that will span what is now a vacant lot between 119th and 120th Streets will be what Donald Capoccia, managing principal of the development company, called "a standard old-fashioned co-op." 
 But unlike most co-ops, the project brings together a variety of city, philanthropic and profit-making organizations. The land was bought from the city for $15 last month by the New York City Housing Partnership. It will be developed by Madison Park Development Associates, a joint venture of BFC Partners and L & M Equities. 
 The city's Housing Development Corporation is providing a $3.75 million construction loan at an interest rate of 1 percent. The remainder of the $18 million construction financing will come from J. P. Morgan Chase. 
When the building is complete, the Housing Development Corporation will issue a second loan of $3.75 million at 7.5 percent interest. Overall interest will average out at 4.25 percent. The Federal National Mortgage Association will also participate both in providing equity and mortgages. 
To qualify for the co-ops, buyers can earn no more than 250 percent of the $59,100 median income for a family of four in the area, or $147,750 a year. 
But most residents are expected to fall below that threshold. Mr. Capoccia has agreed to market 75 percent of the apartments to households with incomes at or below 175 percent of the median, or $103,425 for a family of four.
Prices are expected to average $92,000 for a one-bedroom, $147,000 for a two-bedroom and $166,000 for a three-bedroom. 
The two companion buildings will be on Madison Avenue between 117th and 119th Streets.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Easton, Conn.; 
A Town of Homes and Country Roads

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
MENTION Greenwich, Westport, New Canaan, Darien, Stamford to people looking for a house and they have a positive response. Those are Fairfield County towns they understand. But Easton? 
 Local historians say the British marched right through it during the Revolution on their way to Danbury -- or was it Fairfield? Anyway, another town they thought important enough to burn down. Easton, a farming community where buttons were manufactured for a while, wasn't incorporated until 1845, indicating caution in the face of change. 
 That is still true today, which is why when some potential home buyers are introduced to it, Easton's charm escapes them. For in spite of its beautiful homes priced a third lower than those on the Gold Coast, and its excellent schools, it has certain deficiencies that some people find disconcerting. 
There is no food market, for one thing, no retail stores, no railroad station, street lights or public transportation. Look in vain for a town center or quaint New England green, a dry cleaner, barber shop, commercial enterprise of any kind or offices. Even the real estate agents showing homes in Easton are based in Fairfield, Trumbull, Westport, Newtown and Monroe. 
And, oh yes, Easton is dry. 
But it has one of the best school systems in the state, and the term "residential community" must have been invented for it. Apart from a few farm stands, a garage, two country stores that are mostly for sitting down over a hamburger and schmoozing with neighbors, it is all houses -- winding, verdant, hilly, view-rich country road after country road of them.
Last summer, Susan and James Torres and their three children moved to Easton from Plano, Tex., when he was transferred to Stamford by GE Capital. "The school system was very important to us, and on top of that we found the center hall colonial we were looking for," Mrs. Torres said.
"I must admit the quiet has its drawbacks, and it's a little out of the way for shopping," she said. "I had to pull out my Hagstrom to find the most direct back roads -- I think they're all back roads, through the woods to a Stop & Shop in Newtown -- that's the closest, 15 minutes away. If my mind wanders for a second, I can miss the tree that marks my turnoff."
But, she said, "there are 16 children in the five houses on our street and there is great peace of mind not having to worry about traffic. We have a lot of woods, a pond and wonderful wildlife -- turkey, owls, coyote, Canada geese, mallard. My middle daughter is the neighborhood champion frog-catcher." 
David Buchanan, an Eastonite since 1986, is equally enthusiastic and has no regrets about leaving Scarsdale behind. "But if you forget that loaf of bread," he said, "it's a bummer."
Three acres, which the Torreses have, and one acre are the only standard lot sizes in Easton. Except for the southern 20 percent of the town, there is no town water. Elsewhere, every house has a well and septic system. There are no sewers.
"House prices," said Jack Johnston, a broker with Raveis Real Estate in Fairfield, "range from $385,000 to $1.8 million -- that's about a 20 percent rise from five years ago. We started getting million dollar homes here two or three years ago. There's less inventory now -- around 100 homes on the market. They tend to sell for 5 to 10 percent lower than asking." 
JUDGING by what John Hayes, the town land use planner, calls "a constant stream of subdivision applications," Easton has been discovered as an upscale market. Jean Lanvo, a broker with Prudential Real Estate in Fairfield, said: "There is practically nothing under $400,000, and homes of $700,000 to $1.5 million that were sitting since January are moving now. We are getting relocated buyers and people from Darien, Westport and Shelton."
A dozen homes are being built at Tatetuck Estates, "starting at $1 million, but you get more house for your money than in lower Fairfield County," said Eileen Dauginas, a broker at the Raveis office in Trumbull. Jeff Monroe of the ReMax office in Monroe is handling six new homes at Easton Heights and five new homes at Victoria Estates priced from $859,000 to more than $1 million. Vacant lots, when you can find one, go for $250,000 to $300,000. 
One reason Easton is so rural is that more than 40 percent of its land is watershed, owned by the Kelda Corporation, a British company that took over Aquarion, parent of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, which distributes water to several nearby towns. The state is preparing to buy 15,000 acres of Kelda's land, including 5,469 acres in Easton, the rest in Westport and Weston, to prevent Kelda from selling it for development.
Easton is passionate about open space, yet fearful that its residentially dependent property taxes are hurting its older residents and young families. "We are looking into a new master plan," said Mr. Johnston, a member of the Board of Selectmen, "which could designate limited areas for small corporate headquarters or research centers, or a community for people 55 and older." There is no housing for older people, no multifamily housing and none that qualifies as affordable by state standards.
William Kupinse Jr., the first selectman, seeking a balance between taxes and growth, said: "Office development is not an option under current zoning regulations, and the tax rates in other towns show that commercialism hasn't solved their tax problems but created more burdens in town services. Once new people move into town they seem to want more urbanization -- retail, a movie house -- one person wanted street lights. People in town would be aghast if I proposed that."
In spite of an influx of vocal young professionals, the old-fashioned rural pleasures prevail when it comes to relaxation: a ballgame or an afternoon at the pond and beach in 20-acre Toth Park, horseback riding at Lion Hill Farms, tennis at the middle school courts, lectures and musicales at the library. The Fireman's Carnival from July 24 to 28 draws a large crowd to its games, rides, dunk tank and tons of barbecued chicken and spareribs. And Easton Day on Sept. 8 and 9 turns Helen Keller Middle School into a giant town picnic ground with amusement rides and a craft show.
The Recreation Department runs a day camp at Toth Park for $89 to $115 a week, and adults can take four weekly tennis lessons at the middle school courts for $114. Riding lessons cost about $45 an hour, but people riding their own horses clop along the roads in substantial numbers. There are no zoning regulations about keeping horses at home.
Adults with children in tow make frequent visits to Silverman's Country Farm to see the buffalo, llamas, Texas longhorns, Indian antelope, deer, pigs, Polish hens, goats and inhabitants of the duck pond. Grown-ups usually go home with a load of fresh peaches, pears, apples or pumpkins from the farm's vast orchards. They can also pick up freshly baked fruit pies, cakes and scones, private-label salad dressings, vinegars, jams, mustards and local honey. The second generation owner, Irv Silverman, calls it his "agri-tourism business."
Eating out in Easton is simple. The Bluebird Inn (no rooms, just meals), the Village Store or the Country Store-cum-Bill's Bistro and United States Post Office. The food is plain and fresh, and the prices are down-home reasonable. Breakfast or lunch costs around $6, dinner around $15. Service starts at 6 a.m. The post office, a former stagecoach stop, measures 750 square feet, sells stamps and services box holders. Sorting and delivery are out of Monroe.
"The centerpiece of the community" is how Superintendent of Schools Kenneth Freeston describes the school system. The district's average scores exceed the statewide average by 10 to 20 percent in Connecticut Mastery Tests, and the system's designation for excellence by the Federal Department of Education has attracted so many new residents that a major building program is under way. 
THIS fall the fifth grade at Samuel Staples Elementary School will move to the Helen Keller Middle School, and six portables will be put to use at Staples until a new elementary school can be built. Helen Keller Middle School will open a 25,000-square-foot addition of new classrooms for every grade level, and a $28.5 million, 72,000-square-foot addition, renovation and expansion of the playing fields at Joel Barlow High School will begin this summer. Located in Redding, it serves Easton and Redding students.
Easton students are encouraged to broaden their outlook by getting involved in community service at Bridgeport nursing homes and shelters. "We are under serious mandate by the state to create diversity," Mr. Freeston said. "Our high school graduates undergo culture shock in college, when white students may be only 40 percent of the population. We must find opportunities to reduce racial and economic isolation. We have four Bridgeport students, but we are so overcrowded that we can't take more."
Last year Staples's fifth grade students wrote, composed and produced an original operetta based on the life of Benjamin Franklin, in conjunction with the social studies curriculum. "It brought tears to my eyes," said Donna Dennison, the principal. Staples is one of six Connecticut schools using specially trained teachers for Higher Order Thinking -- a program that incorporates dance, theater, visual arts, music and writing into the curriculum. "Research has shown that children retain information and take more interest when the arts and academics are interconnected," she said.
The arts are a strong component throughout the Easton system. At the Helen Keller Middle School the curriculum, geared to preparation for high school, focuses on basics, the arts, French and Spanish and physical education, said the principal, Annemies Sniderman. 
At lunchtime on Fridays at the high school, Dr. Allan Fossbender, the principal, takes cafeteria duty. "We have relieved the teaching staff of pedestrian administrative duties," he said. Instead of monitoring hallways, teachers are available in labs for students who want help with a particular subject or concept.
Juniors must assemble extensive portfolios of their best writing for assessment, and the curriculum includes yearlong studies of such issues as plagiarism or why males are not achieving the same honor roll status as females.
Forty-two extracurricular activities include Amnesty International, a cappella choir, theater, jazz, student council and an environmental club. One area of the 33-acre campus is an environmental lab for bird migration studies, frog calling, wildflower surveys and vernal pool ecology.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Susan Gerber, Anthony Lo Sasso

 BODY:
Dr. Susan Eve Gerber, the daughter of Dr. Marcia G. Gerber and Dr. Donald A. Gerber of Brooklyn, was married in Chicago last evening to Dr. 
Anthony Thomas Lo Sasso, a son of Patricia and Thomas A. Lo Sasso of Palatine, Ill. Rabbi Daniel Friedman officiated at the Chicago Historical Society.
 The bride and the bridegroom, both 32, work at Northwestern University in Chicago. The bride was a fellow at the university until last week. In August, she is to become an assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology in the division of maternal-fetal medicine at Northwestern University Medical School. The bridegroom is a research assistant professor at the Institute for Health Services Research and Policy Studies, where he studies economic issues related to employer-sponsored health insurance. 
 Dr. Gerber is keeping her name. She graduated from Yale and received both her medical degree and a master's degree in public health from Columbia. Her parents are on the faculty of the State University Health Science Center at Brooklyn, where her father, a rheumatologist, is a professor of clinical medicine and her mother, an internist, is the director of the student and employee health service and is a clinical associate professor of medicine.
Dr. Lo Sasso graduated from DePaul and received a Ph.D. in economics from Indiana University. His mother is the office coordinator for library and media services at Oakton Community College in Des Plaines, Ill. His father retired as the owner of an industrial engraving shop that was in Park Ridge, Ill. 
The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3473 words

HEADLINE: The Power Of Choice 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
AT sparsely attended committee hearings in the State House this spring, senators concerned about the blackouts rolling through California peppered state regulators with questions about electric power. 
 Their worries came down to a few simple points: Will there be shortages here? Will there be soaring prices? Will the lights stay on? 
 Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos, chairman of the state Republican Party, was persistent. 
"Kyrillos asked, 'Is there anything we should be worried about, is there anything on the radar screen?' " said William Potter, an environmental lawyer who attended the hearings.
The worries were understandable. In 1999, New Jersey followed California into the uncharted territory of electric power deregulation, and for several months the legislators had been reading about the shortages and soaring prices in the nation's most populous state. Visions of California-style blackouts and hefty electric bills clearly troubled committee members. 
Herbert H. Tate, the unflappable chairman of the Board of Public Utilities, reassured them that New Jersey's regulators had it all under control. There was plenty of power, and there would be no shortages, he said. New Jersey is not California.
But there was one problem. 
To protect utilities during the difficult transition to deregulation, the state had promised to allow the power companies to recoup certain losses they sustained. Senator Kyrillos and other committee members asked Mr. Tate to estimate what New Jersey consumers would have to pay when the transition ended in August 2003.
It was still impossible to say for sure, Mr. Tate said. But his best estimate was that the losses could run close to $1.8 billion.
"The senators sat around, trying to pick their jaws up off the floor," said Mr. Potter. "The utilities are already prepared to file for massive rate increases."
Fluctuating energy prices could certainly affect how much the losses actually total. Each utility company will pass along its deferred costs to its own customers rather than pooling them, according to the Board of Public Utilities, but questions like the time period for repayment of the losses have yet to be worked out. 
By all accounts, New Jersey has handled the deregulation of its electric power system more smoothly than most other states. There have been no rolling blackouts, rates have been stable, and people have even received price cuts. The state is part of a regional electric grid that experts consider to be the strongest in the country; unlike many other regions, the grid requires a hefty power reserve as a hedge against blackouts like those that have plagued California.
But the transition has not been problem-free. Energy experts and some state officials feel that while New Jersey has been able to handle its energy supply better than other states, it still faces many of the same difficulties: Increasing costs driven by rising natural gas prices, lack of choices for customers and uncertainty about future rates.
"New Jersey has created the same sort of problems that most states have," said Richard S. Rosen, executive vice president of the Tellus Group, a Boston-based energy consulting firm. "The economics just don't work out. Competitors cannot afford to get into the market for smaller consumers."
Dr. Rosen, whose firm has done consulting for states including Pennsylvania, New York and Massachusetts, said deregulating markets without introducing viable competition could lead to problems when government-imposed rate caps are removed.
"The problem is, what happens when the transition is over?" he said. "The prices are likely to shoot up much more than anyone anticipated."
Dr. Rosen's prediction is disputed by many people responsible for New Jersey's deregulation. Senator Kyrillos, a Republican from Middletown, said the state Board of Public Utilities would be able to arrange the repayment of losses sustained during deregulation so that consumers would not face soaring electric bills when rate caps come off in August 2003.
"I was comfortable with what I heard from President Tate with regard to that issue this spring," he said. "There would not be a rate shock." 
Mr. Tate, who left the Board of Public Utilities on March 30 to become a consultant and a professor at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, also said massive price increases were extremely unlikely. But Mr. Tate acknowledged that consumers probably would see some increase in their bills.
"The board has the tools to make sure that any rate increases after transition would be under double digits," Mr. Tate said. "We have the tools to prevent rate shock."
Of course, one person's reasonable increase is another's shock. And even the fact that people are talking publicly about skyrocketing prices is a departure from the optimistic projections that surrounded New Jersey's efforts to end electricity regulation in the late 1990's. At the time, proponents cited the successful deregulation of the telecommunications industry, with increasing services and decreasing prices, as an example of what would happen after utilities were released from government oversight. 
Most predicted similar results for the electric power system.
"There was a movement that deregulation would provide benefits to consumers -- better options, lower rates, technological advances," said Blossom A. Peretz, the state's ratepayer advocate.
Ms. Peretz, who is the state official responsible for protecting utility customers, said the deregulation of electric power seemed to be the next step in a free-market philosophy that had swept the airlines, communications and the natural gas industries.
"I call it an evolution, not a revolution," she said.
In New Jersey, the evolution began after business groups complaining about the state's high energy prices began to agitate for ways to lower rates. 
"The rates for electricity were a significant disincentive for any manufacturing located in New Jersey," said Richard H. Bagger, chairman of the state Assembly Appropriations Committee and an executive with the Pfizer Corporation. 
By the mid-1990's, New Jersey's electric rates were 50 percent higher than the national average and among the highest in the nation. This was not solely the fault of state regulation, or the utilities. New Jersey has significant disadvantages for cheap energy production: it has no large dams to provide hydroelectric power; there are no big coal deposits; the state has a dense population with a constant demand for electric power.
The State Legislature took a series of actions to try to correct the problem, at least for large industrial users.
The first step, so-called flex rates, allowed regulators at the Board of Public Utilities to reduce electric rates for large companies. In 1995, the Legislature passed flex-rate rules, which allowed the board to change rates case by case. In a separate step, legislators eliminated the 13 percent energy tax that had long been imposed on electric power and replaced it with the state's 6 percent sales tax.
The steps were well received by business, but many felt they did not go far enough. 
"We had the fourth highest rates in the nation, and we had no way to shop for a competitive supply," said Hal Bozarth, executive director of the New Jersey Chemical Council, whose group represents 100 companies in New Jersey. "We needed to open up the marketplace."
In fact, Federal regulators had already changed the national rules to allow for electricity deregulation in the early 1990's, and other states were already examining deregulation. But initially, New Jersey's politically powerful utility companies were dubious.
"All you had was thin-air rhetoric, without a lot of scholarship," said Alfred C. Koeppe, president and chief operating officer of Public Service Electric & Gas, the state's largest utility.
However, as Mr. Koeppe said in a recent interview, "you had that bow wave from the telecom deregulation moving through the state. Big business clearly saw deregulation and restructuring as a solution to business problems." 
After a year of committee meetings and negotiation, the Legislature passed the Electric Discount and Energy Competition Act in February 1999. 
The complex, 100-page law officially ended the regulation of electric markets in August 1999, but it capped rates for four years and gave customers automatic rate reductions of at least 10 percent during the four years. After that, legislators believed, free competition among providers would lead to better service and better prices.
Proponents hoped that the open market would attract new electric companies to New Jersey. It was a basic law of economics: more players would lead to lower prices and technological innovation.
At first, it seemed to work. 
Ray Notaro is the site manager of the Huntsman Polyurethanes plant in West Deptford. "In the first year of deregulation, we were able to save a good amount of money, around $30,000, through competitive pricing," he said. 
Some businesses, like Mr. Notaro's, contracted directly with electric suppliers. Others formed buyers' groups and purchased electricity in large blocks. Mr. Bozarth's chemical industry group gathered 60 companies to bid for 360 megawatts of energy, roughly the output of a midsize generating station. He said that over six months, they were able to save nearly $20 million in electricity costs.
Companies saved money by contracting with power generators whose plants are attached to the gigantic electric grid that runs from Washington, D.C., to the New York State border. This electric grid -- called the PJM system -- includes most of the independent power generators and the power utilities in the mid-Atlantic states. The PJM system, which is administered by an independent operator regulated by the federal government, allows the generators to trade electricity throughout the region.
Under the old, regulated system, utilities traded electric power in the PJM system and sold it to their customers. But deregulation created an open wholesale market for the PJM grid. Under the new system, groups of companies could also buy power on the wholesale market, either for to use themselves use or to resell to consumers. They could take advantage of the excess power generated in the PJM system, and buy it at a cheaper price. 
But about a year ago, the price of natural gas, one of the prime fuels for electric generators, shot up, helping drive up the wholesale price of electricity. 
Soon, independent buyers like Mr. Notaro found they could buy electricity cheaper at their old utilities -- many of which had long-term contracts to buy their electric power. In the last six months, competition for business customers has all but dried up.
"We are not saving money anymore," said Mr. Notaro. "We are back with P.S.E.&G., which was our original supplier."
Mr. Bozarth said competing electric generators could not match the price of utilities once the price of electricity shot up last year. He said the contracts arranged for the members of his group, which saved its $20 million during those six months lst year, evaporated with the rising market. Despite the initial drop in electric rates after the deregulation bill passed in 1999, the state is now back where it started in the competition for electric prices.
"New Jersey is still not competitive," Mr. Bozarth said. "Our rates are still 50 percent higher than the rest of the nation. And we are fourth highest in the nation, still, even after the reduction."
Competition for residential customers followed a similar path. After deregulation, several competing companies entered the New Jersey market looking for customers. But as the price of electricity rose, most could not compete.
"The monopoly utility has a big advantage over any competitor," said Ms. Peretz. "They are the brand name, they have the service territory."
What the established utilities also had was long-term contracts with power generators, ensuring a supply of electric power at low prices, particularly compared with the soaring wholesale market. This insulated the utilities from the market rise, and allowed them to undercut new competitors.
"The price of natural gas increased right at the time you expected to see competition," said Mr. Koeppe of PSE&G. Competitors were unable to buy wholesale electricity cheaper than the utility could supply it.
And if the utilities' cheaper contracts were not enough of a hurdle, there was the system state legislators established to deregulate New Jersey's electric power. John E. Kaufman, a Pennsylvania-based energy consultant, said New Jersey legislators capped the amount utilities could charge for power generation in an attempt to protect customers during deregulation.
The well-meaning gesture had unintended consequences when the price of wholesale electric power shot up last year.
"If the amount P.S.E.&G. can charge for electricity is capped at 4.5 cents an hour, and I can only buy power at 6 cents, I can't compete," Mr. Kaufman said. "As the wholesale rate for electric power goes above the capped rates, it basically freezes out competition."
And the automatic price cut, intended as an immediate benefit to those who did not have the time or sophistication to shop for power, also helped drive down prices and further discourage competitors from entering the market. 
John Holtz, spokesman for the Green Mountain Energy Company, which came into New Jersey in March 2000, said several independent power companies entered the the state after deregulation, but since the increase in wholesale power prices only his and one other remain. Green Mountain Energy, based in Austin, Tex., is less vulnerable to market increases because the company's strategy is to offer electric power from environmentally friendly sources, like wind farms, and its customers are typically willing to pay slightly more for electricity. 
But Mr. Holtz said New Jersey's deregulation rules had made it difficult for his company to make inroads in the state. According to the ratepayer advocate's office, fewer than 2 percent of New Jersey residents buy their electric power from a nonutility generator.
New Power, which entered New Jersey last year, has not left the state but is not seeking any new customers here for a variety of reasons related to the cost of obtaining wholesale electric power in the region, according to a company spokesman. Marc E. Manly, general counsel for New Power Holdings, said: "Whenever competition can take root, customers benefit through lower prices and efficiency. We would love to see it happen, but the regulators have got to get the rules right and let us compete."
Independent energy companies' first complaint was about the public education campaign that accompanied electric deregulation. Mr. Holtz said that after deregulation New Jersey started an advertising campaign telling customers they could "do nothing and save 15 percent." Other ads warned customers against signing up with unscrupulous companies seeking to defraud them on energy bills. As a result, he said, most customers did not think about shopping for electric power.
At the same time, in an attempt to protect customers from fly-by-night electricity producers, New Jersey set up rules requiring customers to notify companies in writing that they wanted to switch suppliers. Mr. Holtz said the rule made things much more difficult for legitimate companies.
"It takes six Green Mountain employees to sign up one New Jersey customer," he said. "Our cost for signing up a single customer is 84 percent higher on P.S.E.&G.'s side of the Delaware."
The proof is in the numbers, Mr. Holtz said. He said 708,000 residential customers in Pennsylvania have switched electric suppliers since that state deregulated. In New Jersey, 35,000 have switched.
Legislators acknowledge that competition has not been viable for the residential market, but they defend the structure of the law. Mr. Bagger and others involved in the deregulation bill say that the items that people criticize -- rate caps, allowing utilities to maintain long-term contracts with power suppliers -- are also those that protected New Jersey from California-style rate spikes and shortages.
"We are not California for some very important reasons," Mr. Bagger said.
Still, legislators have already begun to take steps to increase competition. For example, Senator Peter A. Inverso, a Republican from Hamilton, has proposed a change in the law to allow customers to switch electric suppliers over the telephone.
"The expectation was that by 2003 there would be sufficient competition to keep rates down," Mr. Bagger said. "If competition is not robust by 2003, the Legislature might need to step in and take a look at the threshold."
There is some debate over whether the current lack of competition is a cause for concern. Mr. Koeppe of P.S.E.&G. believes that increased competition will come as costs of electricity and natural gas stabilize during the next year or two. Until then, he said, consumers are already benefiting from lower prices.
Consumer advocates and some business groups are concerned about what will happen when rate caps come off in the summer of 2003.
"We have unregulated monopolies in far too many instances," said John Guinan, staff attorney with the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.
As Mr. Tate reminded Senate committee members last spring, the state promised to protect utilities against any losses they suffered during the deregulation transition from the summer of 1999 to the summer of 2003. Independent companies like Green Mountain do not have the same protection.
UTILITIES are expected to have widely differing losses. P.S.E.&G., for example, is not expected to have large costs because its parent company chose to keep its power-generating stations after the deregulation bill passed. As a result, P.S.E.&G. was able to buy power from its sister company relatively cheaply under long-term contracts. Mr. Koeppe estimated that his company's losses, known as deferred costs, would be in the neighborhood of $100 million.
But GPU, which owns Jersey Central Power and Light, is in a different situation. That company sold its generating plants after deregulation, and so it was forced to buy electric power on the wholesale market. The company could not pass its rising costs along to consumers because of the rate cap.
Jeff Dennard, a spokesman for GPU, said the company had sustained about $319 million in deferred costs by the end of May. He said the company could not estimate how much the amount would total by the time the rate caps ended in August 2003.
"We generally don't engage in projections because it involves speculation regarding energy prices," he said.
Whatever the final amount, Mr. Tate said the Board of Public Utilities had the power to structure the repayment to avoid a huge increase in customers' bills. It is hard to say how much any given person might be affected because that depends on which utility the customer does business with, how much the utility loses in the next two years, and over how long a period the debt will be repaid.
The bill will come due in two years. At the same time, electric generators are scheduled to be freed from the caps that have restrained prices since the deregulation began. What will happen then is anyone's guess, but consultants like Mr. Kaufman said there was a good chance that energy bills would increase in the short term.
"A lot of the large industrial customers are fearful of what is going to happen and are looking for ways to protect themselves," he said.
Energy experts say the deciding factor could be the amount of generation that is added to the electric grid in the next four to five years. Steven Gable, president of the energy consultants Gable Associates, said nearly 7,000 megawatts of additional electric generation was scheduled to come on line this year and next. That is a substantial addition to an electric grid with a 50,000 megawatt capacity.
Many experts, such as P.S.E.&G.'s Mr. Koeppe, believe that if enough power comes on line before the rate caps come off, that will inevitably lead to reduced prices and increased competition.
But others worry that without companies to sell the power to consumers, the effect will be minimal.
"If we have real new technology and new competition, there will be benefits to the consumer," Ms. Peretz said. "Right now there is no competition."
Ms. Peretz said the lack of competition was partly the result of market forces, but also an unforeseen result of the system established by the state legislators. She said legislators "have to revisit the act that deregulated the marketplace."
"The wholesale market went awry and this kind of threw a big roadblock into energy deregulation," she said. "There has to be a creative balance between the utilities and the competitors. It is a balance that has to be achieved through reasoned regulation."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Surplus Magic: It Works Both Ways

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
NO one ever quite figured out why the strong economy of the 1990's generated so much more tax revenue than anticipated, wiping out the federal budget deficit and creating substantial surpluses.
 So it should not be surprising that no one has a good handle on what the slumping economy today may do to the fiscal outlook. 
 The issue is front and center again because both Democrats and Republicans have already allocated much of the projected surplus to a variety of uses. Should it be smaller than expected, something would have to give among three main policy goals: cutting taxes; increasing spending on education, health care and the military; and paying off the national debt. It would also leave little money to strengthen Social Security over the long run. So far, there is little evidence that the nation is falling back into a fiscal abyss. Even if the surplus is smaller than anticipated, the two parties seem intent on living up to their pledge to use excess Social Security revenue to pay off the $3 trillion in government debt held by the public. 
But the economic slowdown this year has forced a re-examination of the presumption that the projected surpluses are as good as money in the bank. One of the most detailed -- and sobering -- studies of the interplay between economic trends and the fiscal outlook comes from Goldman, Sachs.
Two trends provided the foundation for a rosier budget outlook, said William C. Dudley, the chief domestic economist at the firm. One was a surge in tax revenue, greater than expected even at a time of strong economic growth. The other was an improvement in the nation's long-term economic potential. Both now seem to be going into reverse, he said.
One big source of additional tax revenue in recent years has been strong corporate profits, which are taxed at higher rates than individual incomes and have been making up a growing share of the total tax base. But in the last several months, corporate profits -- and revenue from taxation of them -- have plummeted. 
The pretax profit share of gross domestic product will fall to 8.4 percent this year from 9.5 percent last year, Mr. Dudley projected, implying a substantial drop in corporate income tax revenue.
Moreover, individual income tax receipts could also be under pressure because of the end of the bull market on Wall Street, he said.
Mr. Dudley pointed to the experience of California. It estimated recently that the exercise of stock options had contributed more than $80 billion to personal income in the state last year, up from $50 billion in 1999. Now the state is assuming that income from options will fall back at least to its 1999 level.
Extrapolating from that, Mr. Dudley calculated that the drop in options income nationwide could shave as much as $40 billion off federal income tax receipts next year.
Capital gains revenue is also likely to tail off, he said. The stock market is now down more than 20 percent from its peak last year, he said, yet the Congressional Budget Office is estimating a falloff in capital gains revenue of only 3 percent next year, to about $125 billion. A more realistic estimate, Mr. Dudley said, is $98 billion, the level of capital gains receipts in 1999, when the market was roughly where it is now.
Over all, Mr. Dudley estimated that tax receipts could fall short of projections next year by $50 billion to $75 billion -- enough to put a crimp in the plans of both parties for more spending, maybe even enough to wipe out the available surplus for next year.
SUCH a shortfall could set off a political storm -- Democrats are already building a case that the tax cut President Bush signed into law last month will lead to renewed budget deficits -- but the real question is what happens over the next decade or so.
Mr. Dudley said predictions that productivity gains would remain high -- and therefore that growth would return to historically robust levels once this cyclical downturn ended -- might be overly optimistic.
The analysis by Goldman suggests that the economy is capable of a long-term noninflationary growth rate of about 3 percent a year, three-tenths of a percentage point lower than the growth rate assumed by the budget office in developing its 10-year surplus projections. If Goldman's figures are correct, Mr. Dudley said, the surplus would come in $750 billion lower than the budget office's projection.
After accounting for Mr. Bush's tax cut and the bipartisan agreement to put the Social Security portion of the surplus off limits, there is no more than $1 trillion of the 10-year surplus projection of $5.6 trillion still available. If Mr. Dudley's calculations are right, then the surplus will have all but disappeared.
Easy come, easy go.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Betty Abebe, Geoffrey Chapin

 BODY:
Bethlehem Abebe, a daughter of Freweini Abebe and Dr. Loolseged Abebe of New York, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Stark Chapin, the son of Diane and Peter Chapin of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. James G. Amos performed a Lutheran ceremony that combined Ethiopian and Eritrean traditions at the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church in New York. 
The couple, both 27, graduated from Williams College, where they met.
 The bride, who is known as Betty, is a medical student at Temple University in Philadelphia. Her father is a hematopathologist and the director of blood bank and transfusion services at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in New York. Her mother manages the budget for the communications office of the United Nations Development Program. 
 The bridegroom is studying for a master's degree in public policy and an M.B.A. through a joint program of Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His father, who is retired, was the managing director of the Boston office of Deutsche Bank Securities.
The couple had met casually a couple of times at Williams but had their first real conversation in December 1995, when Mr. Chapin sat beside Ms. Abebe at a long table in the Purple Pub, one of two student bars on campus. 
"I was celebrating the end of exams," recalled Mr. Chapin, who was then finishing the first semester of his senior year. "I just happened to be looking around the room and a thought popped into my head that I would not meet my future bride at Williams. 
"Then I saw Betty," he continued. "There was an unoccupied seat next to her, so I thought I'd go talk to her."
The two ended up talking until closing time. After the winter break, Mr. Chapin said he "summoned up the courage" to call Ms. Abebe to ask her out to dinner. 
"I'd never asked anyone out to dinner before," Mr. Chapin said. "In college you don't usually ask people out to dinner. You just hang out." Ms. Abebe agreed to have dinner, but with a casualness, Mr. Chapin recalled, "that revealed to me that she had not shared my epiphany at the pub in December." 
But they continued to see one another, and their relationship grew. It came to a crossroads just before graduation, in June, when Mr. Chapin had a job offer in Boston.
"We asked ourselves, What are we doing now, Where are we going now?" Ms. Abebe said, adding that she had offers to teach chemistry in New York or do epidemiological research in Boston. 
She chose research. "I could have stayed in New York, where I had friends," said Ms. Abebe, who later decided to go to medical school. "But I went to Boston because I thought it was worth the risk."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/HISTORY; 
Bronx Loyalists, Manhattan Luminaries

 BODY:
NAMING NEW YORK:
Manhattan Places and How They Got Their Names
By Sanna Feirstein
New York University Press
($45, hardcover; $16.95, paperback)
Streets and public areas of Manhattan have acquired names for various reasons since shortly after the Dutch established a settlement on the southern tip of the island in the early 17th century. . . .

Little Italy
 Lieutenant Petrosino Square. Named in 1987 for Lieutenant Joseph Petrosino, a police officer who, when he joined the force in 1883, was the city's shortest officer at 5-foot-3. Disguised as a tunnel worker, a blind beggar and a gangster, he infiltrated and exposed the criminal gangs that preyed on Italian immigrants. 
 Promoted to detective, he was assigned to uncover anarchists, and warned President McKinley of the danger to his life. Petrosino's warnings were ignored and McKinley was assassinated in 1901. Working in Italy as part of an effort to stamp out the American-Italian mafia connection, Petrosino was shot to death in Palermo in 1909.

SoHo
Macdougal Street. For General Alexander MacDougal, 1733-1786, a founder of the Sons of Liberty, a group of working-class men active in resisting British policies in the colonies before the Revolution. MacDougal went on to become the first president of the Bank of New York and a state senator.

Gramercy, Union Square and Chelsea
Union Square. Before the implementation of the 1811 Commissioners' Plan to lay out Manhattan Island in a grid form, the Bowery and Broadway crossed here at an irregular angle. The new streets and avenues dictated by the grid plan produced an awkward intersection here. The solution was to leave a public plaza, today's Union Square, named for the union of these thoroughfares. The square has been a traditional rallying place for labor and political protests.

Upper East Side
Henderson Place. This gemlike grouping of rowhouses tucked just off East 86th Street and East End Avenue was developed between 1881 and 1882 by merchant John C. Henderson. Henderson used the houses as rental properties and gave the cul-de-sac his name.

BRONX ACCENT:
A Literary and Pictorial History of the Borough
By Lloyd Ultan and Barbara Unger
Rutgers University Press
($32, hardcover)
While the established landed gentry, like those portrayed by James Fenimore Cooper, presided over the colonial government, economy and society, most residents of the area to become the Bronx were hard-working farmers who barely eked out a living raising flax for the linen market, sheep for the woolens trade, wheat to be made into flour and apples to be pressed into cider.
Discontent with British rule was growing. The First Continental Congress imposed an embargo on the exporting and importing of specific items to and from Britain in reaction to the British Parliament's passage of the Intolerable Acts following the Boston Tea Party. The town of Westchester had been granted privileges in a royal charter and its residents were reluctant to sacrifice them. They also thought that the American retaliatory measures went too far and were highly destructive to the local farmers.
For these reasons, many Westchester residents tended to support the British. Samuel Seabury, the Anglican rector in the town of Westchester, wrote a pamphlet, effectively using biting ridicule to make points in support of the farmers against the actions of the Congress.
He disguised his identity, posing as a simple farmer residing in the town.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MURRAY HILL; 
Debating Whether Plants With a Long Past Have a Future

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Inspired by the Tate Modern in London and the Power Plant complex in the Inner Harbor of Baltimore, some urban planners are hoping that a pair of 100-year-old power plants near the United Nations will be renovated as part of a revitalized East Side waterfront. But a developer, which has recently contracted to buy the site, has other plans.
 Consolidated Edison owns the plants, which sit in a nine-acre industrial park along First Avenue between 35th and 41st Streets. FSM East River Associates, a development partnership of Fisher Brothers and Sheldon H. Solow, contracted to buy the site for $680 million last year. FSM wants to demolish the buildings and put up a mixed-use complex with as many as 6,000 new residences. 
 The Municipal Art Society, with the support of some preservationists and elected officials, is urging the developer to consider renovating one or both of the plants, rather than taking them down.
"Good planning does not necessarily start with a clean slate," said Frank E. Sanchis III, the society's executive director. "These spaces offer soaring interiors and a sense of place."
Built as coal-burning producers of electricity in 1901, the plants have been altered since then and today provide steam for heating and cooling offices. The structures, built of red and yellow brick, have kept their classical proportions, including a series of arched windows that rise nearly four stories.
The planners say their effort is inspired by London's Tate Modern museum, which opened in last year in an abandoned power station along the Thames River, and the Power Plant in Baltimore, an 1895 plant that is now a shopping mall.
"Anything that is not a high-density money maker is more palatable to the neighborhood," said Edan Unterman, president of the East Midtown Coalition for Sensible Development, an umbrella group formed to influence the site's design.
The developers recently commissioned architects to create a master plan for the site that does not include the power plants.
"No final decisions have been made," said Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for the developer, who added that the plants "may very well take up space that could be put to better use in this community."
Still, advocates of renovating the plants are keeping their fingers crossed.
"We're not trying to second-guess the developers," said Kent L. Barwick, the society's president. "But this could be a new Rockefeller Center." DENNY LEE
